The wise man answered him, "My friend, what you are seeking is madness,
It is a most impossible thing, I assure you.
If you look for them, you'll find more than enough liars,
Who, with their enchantments, will show you right away
Shadows or false spirits that will be illusions,
And anyone who puts faith in them comes out the worse for it.
So drop this matter(that would be best;
Dedicate yourself to something else that will bring you honor.
You seem like a worthy man as is evident from your valor;
With good reason you must live to accomplish great things.
Most people are false and treacherous;
Those who depend on them vex the Creator.
Go forth then on your way and make confession.
Repeat your sins to a true confessor
So that you confess completely your major sins."

lg.head: Laisse 61
lg.l: The count was well aware of all his bad deeds,
And that the wise man had counseled him in complete good faith;
So Count Huon did as he said right away.
As soon as he could he recalled his sins,
And then did penance as he was wont to do.
[The confessor] imposed no [penance] on him; indeed he was amazed by him,
That he was actually without sin and followed a very holy path.
The priest himself wept out of pity
And said, "Oh, noble man, you are of better faith
Than I myself am currently; you should take no special pride in this,
But if you continue thus, God will have mercy on you;
He will perform a miracle through you---this I do believe."
He made the sign of the cross over him and said, "I give you this blessing:
I declare you absolved, both by me and by God.
You have told me something remarkable; I cannot advise you to about it.
You are going to seek the Devil on behalf of your lord?
Trying to remain faithful has put you into this distressful situation.
The thing is impossible; may God not consider it harmful;
And I will pray to God for you, and very often,
That He keep you safe wherever you go,
And that He let you accomplish whatever you desire."
Huon arose and Samson bowed before him,
Saying, "Most holy confessor, listen to me.
I am a sinful man, I have caused so much harm
That it would take two or three days to recount.
I can't even remember it all and it grieves me very much;
But I'll tell you the most that I can,
And then you'll decide my penance.
I wish to accept it in the name of God the Father."
Then he recounted to him all that he could tell,
And when he could remember no more, he fell silent.
He humbled himself greatly and tears fell from his eyes.
[The wise man] gave the penance, not as much as he should have
In order that [Samson] do better; he then made the sign of the cross and blessed him.
He also told him that from now on he must take care to cause no trouble.
He has a good example before him every day:
"Already there is this good man to whom you have pledged your faith.
In the name of good companionship he is taking you with him.
Now attend well to him and you'll do as a proper man should."
And [Samson] replied, "So I shall; I'll serve him with all my heart."

lg.head: Laisse 62
lg.l: Once Huon and Samson had made confession
Along with many of the others who were nearby
And had received their blessing from the priest,
They took their leave of him full of good intentions.
Then, as they made their way back to their galley,
They took time to buy provisions--
Bread and game--for himself and for the horse,
And there was plenty for all the others,
Enough for a whole year, we believe.
Then they left the port because they had a good wind.
They set off for Acre en route to Jerusalem,
To the temple of God, where His defenders are.
And they all said, "Thanks be to God!"
Then they pressed ahead on their route, for they were prepared
To do their job as they were wont to do.
Once they had eaten to their satisfaction,
They started their journey without any racket or disputes.
We have nothing to tell of their travels(
The light was fine and clear, the wind was good;
Before a month had passed they arrived at the port [that served] Bethlehem.
They disembarked once they had rested;
They asked for news from a shepherd,
Who told them approximately this whole story:
How four Christian kings had been besieging Jerusalem
For a year and a half already, for people knew for certain
That they would not surrender for anything,
Because they would lose so much of their [people and possessions] to the Slavs.

lg.head: Laisse 63
lg.l: "Who are these kings?" asked Huon the warrior.
"Sire," said the shepherd, "I have no desire to lie to you.
Henry, the emperor from Constantinople,
Came here from his land with all his forces,
More than one hundred thousand mounted on battle horses,
Besides all the foot soldiers and the fine archers.
The emir of Persia, and those of Spain and Valcler
Have threatened the Christians and challenged them to battle
In order to shame them if they can come upon them;
I cannot yet tell who will be defeated.
Today is supposed to be the biggest battle;
I truly believe that the Christians will have the worst of the encounter;
That's my opinion and as much as I can tell you,
But I can't really verify this properly for you,
Except to say that the pagans outnumber the baptized."
"Oh, God," said Huon, "I am a miserable sinner
When I tarry so much; I have delayed too long."

lg.head: Laisse 64
lg.l: Huon, who was a man of valor, spoke:
"Forward!" he said. "Follow me, sinners!
You who are condemned to the shadows,
Here you can earn merit by your holy labor,
By working for the glory of Jesus, our Lord.
Come now with me, I will be your leader;
Today, if it please Jesus, you will have great honor.
And if you die from this bit of labor,
Your soul will be saved; I'll never be a deceiver.
Now come with me and have no fear."
And they all answered, "Onward, guide,
We'll follow you right away with a good will;
There where you die, we will die."
Huon thanked them, then he mounted on his battle horse.
He left fifteen of their men at the port
To guard the food on the galley that day.

lg.head: Laisse 65
lg.l: The good count of Auvergne left the port;
He took with him more than a hundred foot soldiers
With fine weapons and noble arms.
He advanced as quickly as he could
Until he reached the camp where the Frenchmen had gathered.
He hesitated a moment to resolve his doubt
About who had the upper hand in the battle;
He recognized it right away, for he had often seen it.
Among those who are of our faith
The news was that the four kings had already been taken;
He saw the pennant of the empire dragged down before them,
And many of their [men] actually down on the very gravel.
When Huon saw this, he cried out in a loud voice:
"Leave the banner to me from now on,
Because even in the face of death I wouldn't desert it.
Now follow me and have no fear
For I pledge to you right now in good faith
That I will most surely win this battle today!
He who'll die in the cause of his faith
Will have saved his soul; never will I doubt this."
They heard him and were thrilled,
Saying, "Good sir, use us as you see fit,
We will come with you for good or ill."
He raised the banner and they followed him right away
Straight into the battle, throwing themselves into it.
He struck and struck again to the right of his horse.
Now he lowered the banner, now the French saw it.
Anyone on the receiving end of his blows did not get up that month.
When his people saw him so bold and strong,
The heart of a king developed in the most cowardly.
He threw himself into the press where he saw it the thickest,
And with terrific force he broke through where it was most tightly packed;
He kept on striking and they all fell instantly.
Huon was reassured by this first assault;
Moderation is good and often so is fear;
These cowards were worth more than fifty-three of the others.

lg.head: Laisse 66
lg.l: After Huon seized the gonfalon
There was nothing for it but to fight well;
He plunged right back in to the fray where he saw it was the worst.
He struck and struck again like a great champion.
There was none he touched who didn't fall to the ground.
All his companions performed rather well;
The least courageous became a brave knight.
Whoever might have seen them in such a combat
Would never describe any of them a coward,
Rather one remembers their great prowess.
At this moment Huon spoke to Samson:
"Vassal," he said, "here is a good idea.
If you conduct yourself thus, you'll be a worthy man as a result;
Through this [deed], you could expiate the greatest sin in the world.
Act with good faith and good intention,
For these things save the soul, however stained it already is.
I urge you to look at that part of the battle---
Do you see those knights whom someone is leading to prison?
If you can free them now,
We will soon have the honor of victory
And both God and the people of this world will reward you for it.
One thing I will say about it, and I'm not saying this out of arrogance,
We'll vanquish all if we conduct ourselves well."

lg.head: Laisse 67
lg.l: They all heard his words and were much heartened:
"He who has a good leader cannot be dishonored.
Go forward now, sire, and we'll follow you.
Nor will we fail you as long as we are alive."
So [Huon] spurred his horse forward toward the enemies leading the prisoners away,
Crying out, "You whoresons, you shall not advance like that,
For you have finally come to judgment(
And not one of you will survive if he doesn't flee."
Then he entered among them like an enraged lion;
In this way he showed them clearly that he was no friend of theirs;
In short order he cleared out many [of the enemy].
The count exerted himself so much that he recovered the prisoners.
The boldest among them was slowed down;
They abandoned the prisoners and were put to flight.
Huon said, "Oh, kings, do not be alarmed!
You are delivered, thanks to God.
There is plenty of armor here and good war horses;
Take any that please you, for no one will stop you.
We will recover the banner, if it is God's will,
And if not, I'll die in your service."

lg.head: Laisse 68
lg.l: Huon rode forward into the fray
With those who followed him.
And the prisoners were amazed and quiet(
All the greatest were very powerful kings.
They said, "Holy Mary, what a wonder!
Who is this knight who is of such great prowess?
Because of him we are safe; he has the victory in the battle.
He doesn't know our language, but still he believes in God;
He has come to our aid in good faith.
We'll die with him; we follow his lead.
If anything bad should happen to him through the lack of troops,
The trouble and distress would fall upon us."
Having said this, everyone got ready;
Then they mounted their horses, calling together their men,
Most of whom were spreading in alarm across the field.
When they were called, they did not fail to come;
They spurred their horses forward into the thick of the fight.

lg.head: Laisse 69
lg.l: The four kings entered the fray
And their men followed; there were quite a lot of them.
Near the banner, which was a bowshot away from them,
They saw Huon, that valiant warrior,
Who was himself fighting with energy and vigor.
Soon they had fought so well that the pagan people
Could not endure their great blows.
All the pagans, great and small, fled before him.
He did not turn back, rather he kept advancing.
As for the standard, took hold of the oriflamme;
He attached it that day on the highest pole
So that everyone could see its brilliance throughout the battlefield.
The pagans fled from there as quickly as they could;
Our men gave chase over hills and through fields.
May God confound them! They have neither pity nor tenderness.
In that attack, which lasted all day long,
Fifteen kings were killed plus an emir,
As well as many other princes and counts.
Many were taken prisoner---not at all a bad catch,
More than a thousand seven hundred; there was a sultan among them;
From him, they would regain the land and honor
Of Jerusalem; thus they would have gotten it without struggle.

lg.head: Laisse 70
lg.l: The pagan host was defeated;
They were all dead or captured, [the Christians] had not held back.
There were very few who fled homeward.
A huge amount of booty was recovered there.
The poorest was as rich from it as he could desire;
They didn't wait at all to take their share of the loot.
People came quickly from three and four days' distance;
They'll have a sufficient portion, in my opinion.
Now we need to speak of the most valiant man among them,
Of the noble count of Auvergne, who, while recuperating,
Recovering from the ordeal, suffered in great torment.
Anyone who would have looked at him really closely,
Would have wept with great pity for him.
And at this time our noble people came;
They all gathered together by the standard.
Grifon was there, speaking up first:
"Vassal," he said, "you are brave and valiant.
Because of you the entire pagan host has been vanquished
And we have escaped death to return safe and sound,
We who were both defeated and captured.
The reward for this belongs entirely to you;
We couldn't possibly recompense you, your service was so very great.
May God, the Almighty Father, do it for us,
As we have all come in His service.
Accept our homage, if it's pleasing to you;
We'll all serve you with good intentions.
And if you wish further reward from us,
You shall be king and emperor of Jerusalem
And of all the land around pertaining to it.
Indeed, you should possess it, and without any restriction,
And even much richer gifts.
You have certainly earned it, the way I see it;
See here four kings all before you,
All descended from Christian people;
We are henceforth completely at your service.
However, fair sire, there is one thing we desire:
To know your family, if you wish to tell us,
And also your name; for the sake of God Almighty,
Please tell us and don't go hiding it."

lg.head: Laisse 71
lg.l: When Huon saw the barons before him
All offering themselves to him without restraint
To serve him well with good intention,
Tears streamed down the nobleman's face.
He knelt humbly, looked down at the ground,
And wanted to kiss the feet of each and every one of them.
They would not allow this and raised him up again:
"You must not do this, for God's sake, most noble man!
It's not fitting that you ever forget yourself this way.
Accept our homage and we shall serve you
Always in good faith just as we should."
"Most noble men," said Count Huon, "I don't seek such a valuable gift,
Nor to take from you even a piece of apur.
But in order to uphold God in Heaven
And protect all your people, if I can do it,
You see me here; I am at your disposition.
Since you wish to know where I come from
And my family background and what my name is,
I'll tell you, since I've been asked.
I am a liegeman of Charles Martel the blond,
The one who believes himself to be the most important lord in the world,
And I was born in Auvergne; Huon is my name.
I have told you the important things about myself;
Now I'd like to tell you about my comings and goings.
Know that it would make any honest man feel pity."
Then he fell silent, saying neither yes nor no,
Nor would he have said a word for all the gold in the world;
So he remained a long time without saying anything.
All the kings wept out of great pity.
They spoke and many times urged him:
They couldn't know his situation, yet they perceived clearly
That he didn't have all he desired and needed;
They realized that he was preoccupied with another matter.

lg.head: Laisse 72
lg.l: "Friend Huon," said the four kings,
You are from a highly-placed family and many men speak of you;
Your reputation travels to many lands.
There is no man who wishes to harm you;
With good reason everyone prizes you.
You are descended from the good Narbonnais,
From the greatest family that ever was in Christendom;
You should be called lord over two or three kingdoms.
We're all here before you now.
We'll serve you devoutly in good faith;
From now on command us as it pleases you."
Huon answered, "I'll never do that.
I'm not so important nor should I be;
I am a servant; you are lords and kings.
As for this, I have another task
That isn't less important than this matter, I believe;
I won't tell you more at this point;
Nevertheless, I urge you---if you see any other task,
If you have something to be done that is troubling you,
Tell me now while I'm with you;
I'll advise you and tell you in good faith.
If not, I intend to leave right away;
I have too much to do, God surely knows the rest.
I've been on a quest now for several months;
Nor will I accomplish my task before at least three years have passed
If God doesn't begin to guide me,
And may He do it since I go in good faith."

lg.head: Laisse 73
lg.l: When the four kings heard what Huon the count,
Who was very concerned, said,
And that he revealed nothing of his situation,
But rather hid it from them, yet sighed very often,
They didn't know what was wrong; they were filled with sorrow for him.
Then they thought to offer him comfort.
They announced water for handwashing, then they entreated him politely:
"Be seated, sire, let's eat together;
Then afterward we'll give you the wealth
That you have conquered from the pagans,
For you overwhelmed them,
And us as well, fair and square, most certainly."
Huon answered, "I'll do as you ask,
But I'll eat very little
Because of a vow that I intend to keep,
Taken when I left my domain
More than two years ago, I believe;
It allows me to eat not more than once a day;
My only nourishment is bread and water,
And similarly I sleep on the ground---
Indeed, I have no other bed or food."
When all of them heard what he said,
They felt great pity for him.
Everyone wept copiously with great emotion;
With soft words they comforted him.
He sat at the high table with the others.
The food came and was replenished frequently
And they all ate what pleased them most;
The count took from it what he wanted.
When everyone had eaten his fill,
The tables were taken away and discussion followed,
While those who were to mount guard did so.
The four kings explained the situation clearly
Regarding the men of Jerusalem who didn't fear an attack:
They wouldn't give themselves up if they weren't starved out.
Whoever had advice to give, now was the moment to present it.

lg.head: Laisse 74
lg.l: "[My] lords," said Huon, "listen to what I have to say;
Let no one be offended if I address the court.
You have captured some of these people as you desired
And chased them down with painful suffering.
Pagans are dead; you need fear those no more;
You holding some of them, and not the worst ones.
Tomorrow you'll make them come here;
Have a fire lighted before the gate;
Then let it be said to the one who is their leader:
Does he wish to accept and collect a recompense,
Giving up the city, or does he insist on holding it?
If we take him prisoner, we'll make him suffer
Like these others whom we'll burn.
Yet if they wish to, they can be saved.
Let them choose to take it or leave it.
[Their leader] knows it well, he cannot keep waiting;
From day to day his situation simply grows worse.
For that reason, I think he will take good advice,
If not, they will suffer further slaughter.
There is enough to do; there is nothing else I wish to say to you about it.
Anyone who has a better idea should not keep it quiet,
And then we'll make the best choice."

lg.head: Laisse 75
lg.l: "This is very good advice," they answered him.
"Let them be asked then if they are willing to do it."
So he sent two messengers who went all the way to the gate;
They were to relay the message that they were surrounded.
They came to the gate and called to the porter:
"Go now and announce that messengers are coming
To your lord in order to find out what he will answer
For his people; they have come from their side,
In fact, from the kings who are besieging the city.
If he loves [his people], now, at this point it will be evident;
If not, we will then turn back."
The porter took off quickly and promptly;
He recounted and explained the entire matter [to] his lord;
[The lord] ordered that they lower the bridge.
The two messengers entered through the gate,
They spoke and recounted the whole message to the king;
But [the king and his men] kept silent while the messengers spoke.
Everyone was quiet; no one heard a single word spoken.

lg.head: Laisse 76
lg.l: For a long time they were there;
Those who had been called to the council didn't utter a word.
Then they answered, "Sire, do now as you wish.
You have no great hope of holding the city.
Our lords have failed us
And this land has been starved out;
Those who don't have enough to eat fight poorly.
We are completely at a loss, unable to give advice.
If you have a good agreement, it will be accepted quickly.
Make a truce with the Christians; let it not be put off;
Let us swear it to each other.
Henceforth we will be at their mercy;
Let them do with us whatever suits them.
Tomorrow at dawn, we'll bring them the keys;
Let's surrender the city, the towers and the palace."
"Let it be exactly so," answered their lord.
Then the letter was written and sealed;
They gave it to the messenger and he turned back,
He then presented it to his lord.
In the presence of many it was read and examined,
Everyone was quite pleased with this result;
In fact there was great celebration of it among the people,
And they remained in peace until dawn.

lg.head: Laisse 77
lg.l: The next day as dawn appeared,
Those of the city didn't dally there.
A good thousand of them, all valiant men,
Approached the encampment where the largest tent was located.
They weren't armed and all were on foot;
Their lord was in the front of the group.
They handed over their keys and their land immediately,
Then let [the winners] do with them as they wished;
Let their life and death be at [the winners'] disposition.
The emperor of Constantinople the great
Received the gift for all of them together.
Then he ordered that some of his people
Enter with them into the prosperous city,
But that they take care that no one pillage anything,
For even without that booty, they would be completely satisfied.
Everyone agreed to follow his orders.
The group that he chose entered the city right away;
[The inhabitants] offered their biggest houses to the great barons,
Other lodging to the other people.
No one committed any wrong, rather everyone acted reasonably;
Each man behaved properly.
When the non-believers saw
That no one showed any inclination to do them harm,
They called out repeatedly to be baptized.
Our emperor was rather pleased
That due to the worth of some of their barons,
All those present were baptized
And each one had it done of his own free will.
No one strayed; on the contrary, they did it willingly.
Following that event, they held a meeting
To choose a king and [to do it] promptly
In order that henceforth he hold this domain.

lg.head: Laisse 78
lg.l: Many barons were at the meeting;
Each one of them stated his choice
To make the brave and wise Huon king,
"For by rights he should have it without any contention
Since it is owing to him that we conquered what we have."
Everyone begged him to take the offer,
But he answered, "It's no good to insist.
That cannot be; elect another now.
I've told you in large part my reasoning.
I've taken on a heavy responsibility and have no idea if I will accomplish it;
Never has anyone been sent in such a way
Who might be able to speak of it truthfully.
If you desire to know, I will explain it.
But Jesus truly understands my purpose,
Whether it's good or bad; may He thus forgive me for it."
Then he recounted to them his great dismay:
In what manner he had departed from Charles,
How he had to seek what no man finds.
"It cannot be otherwise; such is my fate,
To have only suffering in life.
But may everyone know perfectly well: never as long as I am alive
Will I ever fail my lord,
Or be forsworn for this reason."

lg.head: Laisse 79
lg.l: When the barons heard this speech,
No one there could keep the tears from falling from the eyes in his face
Out of great pity, when they called him to mind.
One person said to another, "This truly cannot be the whole story;
The king wants this man to be killed,
For which reason he has arranged such a task for him.
It would be something possible, I certainly believe,
If Hell were somewhere on this earth,
But it is a supernatural thing, you know well;
Charles Martel has gone out of his mind, I think,
Or truly he has put his faith in bad advice!
He should be keeping this [knight] with him,
Yet he's sending him to his death, you see clearly.
Let's keep him here;
Everyone will increase greatly in honor by it.
Since he doesn't want to be king, I say to you,
Let someone else be chosen as soon as possible,
So that he may reign in peace, and so I advise.
Of our people, all the Spanish who are recently converted
Will remain with him
As well as the foragers who have joined us.
Let everyone be well instructed how to fight with a bow;
We'll take a brief rest in our land,
Call up the army, then march on France;
Let everything be destroyed, if Huon doesn't call it off.
Then we shall leave the land and the country
To the baron Huon." And at that word he fell silent.

lg.head: Laisse 80
lg.l: Huon spoke when he heard and understood this,
[That they wanted] to choose a lord for this fief:
"I agree to it personally and praise you for it.
But regarding the other matter that you have brought up,
It would be bad for many good people
To destroy that kingdom for no good reason.
It is better that one man die
Than that many lands be put to destruction.
Leave it to God to wreak vengeance,
And I, poor wretch, am content to die.
I don't know where I'm going nor where my end will come;
God knows as well as I, if it is His will,
That as long as I live, I will not fail my king;
I'll never refuse anything to my lord.
I am fully cognizant that it's useless
To seek that which no man can truly find
Unless it happens for me by divine miracle."

lg.head: Laisse 81
lg.l: "Don't worry about me," said the count,
"I think I will leave you during the day tomorrow.
Pray to the sovereign Creator on my behalf,
That He take pity on this sinner
Who wanders like a sorrowful wretch.
I don't know how to recognize the best road
To fulfill my quest; each day looks worse to me.
Thus I would ask my people, out of love,
To stay here with you and that you honor them.
I don't want them to undertake such a task on my account;
Here they can remain in joy and pleasure,
Leaving me to seek great pain and great strife."
They answered him right away with much sweetness:
"Oh, sire, you are our rightful lord;
If we left you, we would be traitors;
We'll always stay with you, come life or death."
At that everyone began to weep piteously;
There was not one baron among them
Who did not weep with feeling for Huon and his men.
Then they said to him with loving affection
That if it could be, for him stay there with them,
They would then serve him night and day.
The good count answered them right away:
"That cannot be, I have delayed too much;
Moreover, I would then be false and a liar."

lg.head: Laisse 82
lg.l: "Many thanks," answered Count Huon;
"Have someone lead me to Solomon's temple.
May the Sepulcher of Our Lord, in whom we believe,
Be shown to me in its entirety.
I have sworn to stand there in prayer
And to beg Him with good intention
That He allow me to accomplish what I must do
So that I don't lose courage due to a weak will."
They answered him, "We'll all come too.
We have long wanted to do this."
They left the council and sought the worthy man
Who held the city and the keep freely;
They explained the situation to him and then they set off.
They traveled until they came to the Sepulcher
And went inside with great devotion.
Those who knew their prayers best then said them:
Franks were praying all around the Sepulcher;
There were many candles and tapers all around,
And everyone strove to pray.
Huon and the four kings were on their knees
Before the Sepulcher and said their prayers.
I cannot say exactly what Huon's offering was,
But I will speak further only of Huon.
He placed his candle on the block of stone,
Bowed his head, and prayed:
"O Lord God, Father, in Your holy name,
You made Heaven and earth and sea through division,
The beasts and flying birds, fresh water and fish,
And made Adam out of earth and mud
And gave him his earthly home to keep,
And to him, together with his wife whom You fashioned from his side,
You handed over all things to them except for one fruit,
And You commanded them not to touch it,
Because it was the fruit of mortal downfall.
And later You said to those from whom we are descended,
'Do not touch it, you will be doing wrong.'
Later You gave them worldly knowledge,
And You freely showed them right and wrong.
'Since you are made in My image, I give you the goodness
Of all earthly things, of all that is there.
According to how you act, I will give you its rewards;
Up to that point you will have My blessing,
And you will have what pleases you without constraint.'
He heard perfectly well what was said but he soon forgot it;
His wife deceived him through mortal treachery:
She convinced him to eat the fruit through mortal folly.
For this act You condemned him to great misery
Until pity took You for the sinners of the world
And You descended to earth for our salvation.
When Your mother willingly brought you to the temple
After forty days as we find in the Bible,
A blessed man held You in his arms;
He who wanted [to hold] You was Saint Simeon,
Who said, 'Nunc dimittis.' Lord, Your servant, in peace.
Just as when You made Saint Lazarus rise from the dead,
That one said 'Te Deum laudamus' as an offering.
Just as we truly believe this,
May it please You, Lord, to show us,
Whether we'll have victory over the race of Muhammad,
[Or] if other, worse distress awaits us
That might cause damage to the Christian faith;
And that we choose the lord
Who will be good and loyal to rule this realm.
And furthermore, for me, a miserable sinner, I pray to You for mercy:
By a divine miracle, may all know,
Whether I should stay here or now go forward.
I don't know where to go; Father, I am abandoned.
I don't know what else to tell, I say this to You faithfully."
With this he fell silent; behold, a white dove [appeared]
Carrying a letter written carefully
About the one who should be king and what would happen.
The letter said many things but it mostly concerned Huon,
That he must continue on, not give up;
If he continued what he had undertaken with good intentions,
God would be with him and he could expect a good reward.
And the one who should be made ruler of the kingdom---
His candle was lit and he was called forth by name,
Danfroy, and he was the son of the Greek emperor.
Once everyone was aware of the decision, there was no dissent;
For everyone it was agreeable, to both the cruel and the good;
They shouted loudly "Te Deum laudamus."
According to the sun, it was three in the afternoon,
And the archbishop Drugon celebrated mass;
The barons listened to it with great devotion.
Afterward, they made confession,
Then left the temple once they received the blessing.

lg.head: Laisse 83
lg.l: Huon spoke with tears and with weeping:
"[My] lord," he said, "I command you
To keep doing such good works for God the Creator
That you never lose the greater joy as a result of earthly delights.
You have understood through a miraculous light
What task you have completed; and your Lord seeks
[That] you serve him with a good heart and bring honor to him.
I cannot remain; it doesn't please God the Creator;
Rather I must carry out in pain and sorrow
That which I promised to the sovereign emperor.
I take my leave, I won't remain any longer."
He embraced each one in turn as he wept and cried,
Then he mounted his horse along with his entourage
And continued his journey. They went back to the galley
That he had supplied well for a year['s journey].
I will now say no more about those who remained there;
[The king] led a good life with the many people.
We'll speak rather of Count Huon of Auvergne,
Of the voyage he made, how he completed his task.

lg.head: Laisse 84
lg.l: Who wishes now to hear a fine song?
One won't find here lies or fables;
Listen with your ears and heart to this true tale.
It will be a decidedly delightful task:
It is worthy of attention and effort,
A proper parable of prowess and honor,
Of suffering great tribulation when one must do so.
And a wretched man who doesn't have a constant heart
Doesn't attain honor or pleasing goods.
Let he who wishes for a reward from our spiritual Lord
Learn from Huon, the noble count of Auvergne
The admirable knight, who led such a life!

lg.head: Laisse 85
lg.l: Huon left, going directly to the shore;
He embarked on his galley, he didn't delay for long.
As soon as he could he left, without long delay,
For they had good weather, clear and with a good wind;
He had no idea in which direction to pursue his journey,
Nor where he would take lodging
Should he arrive; all the lands were wild,
Where people did not believe in God nor pray to His image.
He crossed himself and blessed himself,
And said to the sailors, "Don't lose heart!
Let the ship go where it will, wherever the wind blows most.
Now we shall sail by the grace of God:
May He bring us to a good end;
And let us do things that satisfy the Crucified One,
I don't know anything else to say but may He follow our journey."

lg.head: Laisse 86
lg.l: The galley sailed rapidly across the sea;
No one guided it, only the wind that blew.
From day to day it sped it further along,
So that afterward in this manner they sailed a full month.
But at the beginning of the [next] month there arose a whirlwind
That swelled the whole sea with great force
Andrea lasted more than five full days.
In such disorder no one knew how to help himself;
Nor could anyone, however wise and brave, not think of drowning.
Huon did not cease to pray for [safe] passage,
And he called upon God that He not let them perish.
And if he were to escape from this, the noble baron
Would certainly remember [it] every day of his life.
Anyone who saw the whirlwind constantly growing
Would remember his great fear about it.
It seized the galley and turned it around;
A mill wheel when it turns as fast as it can
Doesn't spin around as much as this galley did in the sea;
Vision fails trying to watch this.
After five days passed, the weather began to improve.
A wind came up that made the weather change
And brought the galley up to a great rock;
It ran aground there onto the wide, sandy beach---
There was no longer need for anyone to moor it;
And those inside the galley became so terrified
That no one could move that whole day;
They lay there like the dead all night long.

lg.head: Laisse 87
lg.l: At dawn's appearance, when the sun shone forth,
Huon the count came out of his long faint.
When he saw he was on land, he rendered thanks to Jesus
And prayed most devoutly.
Those on the ship all wept, they cast themselves down fervently;
Huon prayed for himself and also for his people.
As soon he had finished his prayer, he crossed himself
And arose; his companions seemed
To be completely disoriented as if they were dead.
The baron went around shaking them, and soon comforting them
With the right words and fitting expressions.
Then they all threw themselves down, rendering thanks to God,
But they were barely grateful for the good fortune they enjoyed,
For they were more concerned by earthly matters.
They should have praised Jesus like Huon,
Who did not cease to lament, to pray to God Almighty
That He keep him from dire calamity,
And that he be able to accomplish soon the thing he sought to do,
And present the message that he got from his lord.
For the storm at sea from which they had escaped alive
He thanked Jesus with as much humility as he could.
Then he prayed for all his companions
That they be put on the right path and be grateful.
Then he beat his breast, he struck his chest hard,
And confessed his sins, saying with great devotion,
"Have mercy on me, You who were hanging on the Cross."
When he had finished the psalm, he stood up;
He looked before him, he saw his men already eating.
The count said, "O God, these [men] have little knowledge;
They should be praising You, [but] they have little heart or desire for it.
They rushed to start eating; clearly from that they are not afraid."
Then he said, "Alas! What have I said? I have greatly erred.
They have good, stout hearts and good intentions,
They are long accustomed to the great perils of the sea,
To good luck and bad, as fortune will have it.
And above all today: six days these men have been in great dismay.
If they now comfort themselves, they do so like bold and valiant men;
They have good reason and are right; he who would reproach them does wrong."

lg.head: Laisse 88
lg.l: Count Huon came over to them,
Blessed the food, then said to them, "[My] lords,
Eat at your leisure; in the name of the Creator,
Because of the stormy weather that was just battering us,
You will rest here for several days.
You have enough food, by all means eat the best of it;
As for my horse, I beg you to take care of him;
I want to climb this mountain and the highest cliffs
To look around and scout out what is here.
I'll tell you the entire truth upon my return,
But I don't believe I can get back before three days' time.
Since you are exhausted from the heavy wind and the fear,
I don't want to take anyone along to do more work now;
You'll remain here; farewell, I'll be the scout."
But if he had known the adventure before them,
He would not have left, even if someone had offered him a tower.

lg.head: Laisse 89
lg.l: The count left them in order to climb the mountain,
Taking no food with him on which he might live,
Only his good faith and the cross that he adored.
Thus it was that Huon ate nothing for six days;
The vassal held to the good and did holy works;
For this reason, God gave him strength and a stoic nature.
It was fitting that He made suffering and a difficult path for him;
This [life] is a purgatory for the soul that suffers
Such that man may bear it [only] through faith.
The Gospel, which demonstrates it well, says this,
"If a man wants to have joy from the Eternal Kingdom,
He must simply persevere through tribulation
[And] through weakness of heart, for nothing [else] is possible:
There is no one so excellent that he doesn't strive for faith."
The more he learns how to persist, the more God will reward him;
When he proclaims his repentance for what he has done,
Then it cannot be [that] God's grace not be present.
For that reason God said, "Such a scent arises on earth
That passes the heavens, so as to shatter my anger."
[God] said this about the sinner for when he commits folly
And is repentant, He warns him concerning evil.

lg.head: Laisse 90
lg.l: The count didn't worry about anything, he set off with confidence;
He left his men without any trouble or grief,
All alone he went away, he took no one with him.
But had he known the adventure he would have,
He would not have left them before a month had passed.
When he was a mile or maybe three miles' distance away
And could no longer catch sight of his men or their equipment
Because of the great forest and also the precipices,
He actually rushed to climb and mount the slopes,
Never imagining anything untoward---he continued in good faith.
Let us leave him here; now I'll speak of his men,
Who did not want to serve him, indeed they got rather upset.
Once they had eaten and rested,
They said to Samson and his two sons:
"What are you thinking? Are you going to follow this fool?
He's a desperate man who takes no reasonable care of himself!
You have already seen him in battle and in combat
As well as his way of living; he despises his own life.
He's going to seek the devil, and he'll find him, this I believe,
At his own great peril, before the month is out.
Let's not wait for him; rather let's turn back right away
To Jerusalem where there are people of our faith.
We'll say that fellow is dead and all because of his rashness.
He was reckless because he had no fear for himself,
Seeing that he wanted to battle the beasts of the woods
As if he were a lion, a leopard or even two or three [of them]!
He wants the help of no living man, I see that clearly.
They'll believe us quite easily; you'll have great honor;
They'll give us castles, and we'll remain without further ado,
And we'll live in honor and remain at rest."
But it won't be thus, as I declare for sure,
Never will they see Jerusalem in joy.
They will go to other strange lands, so I believe;
Many times will they suffer; their lord will lament;
It'll truly seem a thousand years before they see the honest man.
I can't recount the entire affair nor should I.
I'll tell it in song at the appropriate time and moment.
But let's return to our story; now I want to tell the tale,
For now it seemed Samson was overcome by scruples.

lg.head: Laisse 91
lg.l: Samson spoke to them and said, "[My] lords,
By God the Creator, don't even think of doing such a thing!
Serve your lord; maintain his honor!
Each one of you has just pledged faith and real love to him;
If you do this, you act like traitors.
He trusts you. The count has good intentions:
He's already explained it to you, that you will return,
[But] you must remain here quietly near the others,
Since you won't fail to have great treasure;
There [in Jerusalem] you all became rich with pagan booty.
In the desert where he is now, he doesn't have anyone's help
Except ours, which has little value.
You want to betray him out of laziness?
You're not acting rightly; indeed you're acting the worst.
You will know it, that day will yet come."
The others answered, "Now shut up, felon,
It's only because of your doing that we are all in this great difficulty.
If we're sinners, you're still worse;
If you utter another word, we're not lying about this,
You'll die in front of us in pain and torment.
Your sons will have to live in suffering with you,
For I believe it's your fault that we have become sinners."

lg.head: Laisse 92
lg.l: When Samson heard this violent threat,
That these villains opposed him so strongly,
And, as they said, that they absolutely were not going to wait,
He understood the full extent of their evil conduct.
Then he had no idea what else he could say;
He realized clearly that forcing them was useless;
He feared them greatly and was afraid for his life.
Thus he stopped speaking; he humbled himself to them:
"Do what you will, I won't oppose you.
I agree and will carry out your wish."
"Many thanks," they said, "you are frightened;
Fear is better at making you act than courtesy."
That said, they set sail in their galley on the sea,
They had lingered there very briefly.
They sailed off and navigated for they had an excellent wind.
They planned at that time to return to Jerusalem;
But their ship was turned in another direction,
They wouldn't know where they were going except that the wind guided them.
Before they made landfall, their many goods
And numerous possessions would be well taken care of.
Many times they would be closer to death than to life,
For they would find robbers much stronger than they.
I won't tell you the whole tale about how the thing went;
Later on a time came when they were at the mercy
Of their lord whom they had abandoned in the woods;
From this point on, we'll tell you about the path he followed.

lg.head: Laisse 93
lg.l: Huon hiked through the forest that climbed up the mountain;
He came upon great precipices that did not please him.
He endured great pain before he reached the top;
It was past noon by the time he reached a flat place.
At that point the baron was exhausted; hunger and thirst tormented him.
He sat on the ground, his face bathed with sweat.
He wished to rest a bit; in order to ease his suffering,
He took some wild herbs and ate from their roots,
As large a portion as he wanted.
Whether or not you wish to hear, he didn't care whether he was healthy;
He would willingly have drunk because he was suffering from thirst,
But that could not be because he was in a high place.
Then he began to think and called to God the Father,
That He lead him to a good country and remember him.
Then he began to walk again and crossed himself.
He climbed the highest peak that there was in that land
In order to see how the mountain was laid out behind and before him.
There were many precipices with tortuous passages;
An incredible forest with no dwellings.
"This is a horribly evil place," said the preeminent count.

lg.head: Laisse 94
lg.l: "Indeed," said the count, "this is an evil place to tarry;
I won't accomplish my goal by getting stuck here."
So he started descending and thought to return
When two bears and a fierce leopard attacked him.
When the count saw them, he only felt anger;
He then prepared to defend himself like a baron.
He placed his shield before him and drew out his sword of steel,
He caught the leopard's paw which brought it down;
He sliced it all up, then stopped to recover.
He gave it such a fearsome blow right on its head
That he struck it dead without noise or cries.
He advanced to one of the bears that wanted to rip his armor off him;
He gave it such a blow that he knocked it to the ground.
Nor could the other one get far away from him;
As soon as the count challenged it, he struck it on the head.
He knocked it down dead before it could cry out or bray.
[The count] journeyed on, leaving them there,
And searching the mountain for the best path down.
Before he reached the bottom, he had to do other things,
For he was about to meet a serpent on his way
That blocked the path by which he had to pass.
It kept its maw open and it breathed a fearsome breath;
A man could completely burn up from its breath in a very short time,
And it threw fire and flame from its nose and from its tail behind.

lg.head: Laisse 95
lg.l: When Huon saw the serpent, it gave him quite a fright;
And it's no wonder since it was huge and hideous.
Besides it was almost night and he was rather tired
And thirst tormented him; he yearned to drink.
He would have let it go if he easily could have,
Because never would any man alive have held it against him.
However, since it blocked the way before him,
He challenged it to a rude and fierce battle;
Then he went to strike, he didn't wait any longer.
On its head he landed a blow and such a heavy one
With his sword that still didn't hurt it one bit.
The sword bounced off, [the serpent] sprayed out fire
That greatly damaged [Huon's] armor.
After that it arched its tail in a great curve,
Trying to reach the count, but he guarded himself from it.
He leaped back and forth, landing many a blow,
But he couldn't do it a pennyworth of harm.
When the count saw [the situation] thus, he got angrier and angrier.
The beast stood there firm, defending itself with fire and tail
And with its teeth, if it could seize anything.
The count then thought of a feat of valor:
He positioned himself in front of it and placed his shield in front
To avoid the stink and the fire that it belched forth.
When it opened its maw that was spewing out fire,
[Huon] thrust his sword into its throat right up to the hilt;
He touched its heart and at once it fell prostrate.
When it felt death, it let out a tremendous roar
So that the whole mountain reverberated with it.
[The serpent] then became quiet and fell backwards.
Such a disturbance arose from that roar,
That more than a thousand seven hundred came forth because of that noise;
They issued from their lairs; they were seeking one another.
The whole mountain seemed to be burning.
"Holy Mary," said Huon, "please help me!
If this is what I await, it will go badly for me."
He quickly sheathed his sword;
The proverb says, "He is mad who awaits a madman";
The departure from the cruel place was truly good.

lg.head: Laisse 96
lg.l: Count Huon took stock of his situation;
He left there quickly without delay.
Darkness surprised him as the sun went down;
He didn't see where he was going.
The path was terrible, indeed there were many crags.
The air was disturbed and there were great flames.
The wind howled which tormented him;
Red-hot fire fell that burned the whole meadow.
Later the fire was put out when it rained;
Whether the count feared all that, I don't doubt.
He sat down on the ground near a large boulder,
That it might now be his shield: thus was he sheltered.
From the racket of the evil beasts and the other disorder
The whole mountain rang; one called to the other.
"Holy Mother Mary," said Huon, the courteous,
"This is a terrible place, I don't know what to do;
I would happily leave this place if I knew where I was going,
But I see no flat piece of land anywhere before me,
Only when lightning flashes and flame issues forth;
Here I must remain against my will.
Now may it be as it pleases God, I am in His keeping
Everywhere with a willing heart, whatever He wishes to do with me.
Whatever I might see, whatever might befall me,
I will never desert Him, for I love Him in good faith."
He crossed himself devoutly many times.
The count stayed there until the sun rose;
At that point he thanked God and blessed His mother;
Then he stood up and left that place.

lg.head: Laisse 97
lg.l: The weather was lovely and clear, the storm was over.
The count crossed himself, then got up on his feet.
He descended the mountain which he had climbed with such difficulty;
He found great steep slopes there, and great lamentation.
He most certainly found there many agitated beasts,
Both good and cruel ones were stirred up by the tempest;
They had so exhausted by the weather that they were somewhat slow.
At this time they showed no ill intention toward the count;
If they had been in their right minds, as far as I know,
It would have gone badly for the count. With that state of mind,
They looked at him frequently, and he them as well;
He passed on beyond them rather quickly,
But because of a difficult passage that the valiant man now found,
He couldn't now move quickly but rather went slowly.
He continued on the route until he came to the flat plain;
Once he had passed through the forest, he descended to the sea.
There he stood looking backward and forward,
For he thought indeed to find his galley and his men.
He was astounded when he found nothing
Except for the place where he had previously landed.
"Holy Mary," said Huon, "please help me now:
Alas! With all my faith and heart I give myself to you, Mother of God!
I know with absolute certainty and see clearly that I have been betrayed
By those who were supposed to serve me at [my] pleasure,
For they have gone away, [and] now I remain
In this wild location; this is an evil dwelling place;
I don't know what to do. O God Almighty,
Please don't leave me to perish in this torment."
Then he threw himself to the ground and piteously
Confessed all his sins, striking himself hard on the chest;
He declared himself a wretched and miserable sinner.
After that he offered the beginning
Of a psalm asking for grace, reciting with devotion:
"Out of the depths, I have cried out, O Lord, and I am happy
To endure illness and pain, my Lord, hear, hear
My prayer, if it is your pleasure."
He recited the psalm to its very end;
Sweating he confessed his sins and stretched out [on] the ground;
He crossed himself and then immediately arose.
He left that place and took up his journey.

lg.head: Laisse 98
lg.l: Huon arose and crossed himself;
He set off and left that place.
All day long he wandered through the uncultivated land;
He advanced at least twenty leagues that day.
Then, since night overtook him, he took shelter
Under a precipice that he perceived from a high point.
There was a spring that gushed out in abundance;
When the count saw it, he yearned for it greatly:
He had passed many days without drinking anything.
Then he gathered roots of plants and began to eat;
Once he had quenched his thirst, feeling satiated,
He lay down close to the cliff, in the name of blessed God,
And then he crossed himself many times.
Then he waited in case he heard anything
Make a move, draw near to him.
Everything was quiet, there was nothing that showed itself;
Remaining wary like that, sleep came over him:
The count was exhausted; the previous day had challenged him.
For this reason he slept until the day brightened,
Then he stood up and crossed himself.
He began his prayer and recited a psalm:
"Deliver me, O Lord, from the hands of my enemies."
He recited the entire psalm until he came to the end,
Then he set out again through the uninhabited land.

lg.head: Laisse 99
lg.l: The count walked along the seashore;
He never stopped praying and calling upon God the Father,
That He come to his aid so that one day he might still succeed
In accomplishing his quest, which he yearned to do
With all his being; I don't know how to explain it well.
He experienced much pain and affliction
From flying birds and malevolent beasts
And from vermin that blocked his way;
When he came near them, he knew what to do:
Some he killed, others he let go,
But nonetheless he constantly intended to advance.
When daylight failed, he had to take shelter;
He ate a little, then he tried to rest,
Though he couldn't find a place where he could be secure.
I cannot tell everything about his days,
Except that he traveled every day and never turned back.
More than three months this frightful journey lasted,
During which he couldn't take a single rest day.

lg.head: Laisse 100
lg.l: I shall recount what happened to the count:
After he said his prayers
And crossed himself with the cross that he had,
The weather changed while the baron was going
Through the fallow land, and the wind blew so fiercely
That it buffeted the count on the road he was following.
After that a whirlwind rose up;
It made the sea and the mountain resound;
Great bolts of lightning made the sky light up entirely.
The sea billowed and swelled and caused great alarm.
The count couldn't protect himself from the nasty weather or the storm.
The baron leaned against a huge rock and waited
While the bad weather lasted, then it became calm.
Next he saw a ship sailing at such a high speed
Because of the bad weather that pressed it
[That] it dashed against a rock. It made such a crash
That the whole mountain resounded with it.
At this point the ship broke up completely;
Everyone on board drowned in the sea
Except for two young ladies whom the waves tossed
Along with much baggage of little worth that they had.

lg.head: Laisse 101
lg.l: When the count saw the great storm,
The ship broken and the people drowned
---Only two women escaped alive
Whom the sea tossed onto the stony shore---
He cried out, "Holy Mary,
Great is the power of God Almighty!
These people have been lost in a single moment."
As quickly as he could, he went to help the ladies;
He followed the shore along toward the mountain,
He brought them up to [solid] ground, making the sign of the cross over them.
They themselves were not conscious at all;
All day long and that night as well they were like that,
For they didn't move or speak at all;
In fact, they appeared quite dead.
Huon watched over them, many times he made the sign of the cross over them;
All night long, he hardly thought
While he watched so that no living thing
Did them any harm or disturbed them.

lg.head: Laisse 102
lg.l: What can I say? When the next day dawned,
The young ladies recovered from their fear.
They recovered consciousness, their color returned.
It was obvious that they were afraid:
In honor of holy God, they bowed down to the earth,
Striking their chests and beating their breasts harder,
And after that they began to weep uncontrollably.
So much did they lament and weep that Huon was overcome with tender pity;
He watched for a long time how they demonstrated their grief.
Soon he comforted them and said out of [brotherly] love,
"Let it go, put away your sorrow;
Pay attention to other things that might be better tasks;
You will never gain anything from such sorrowing.
Put aside your grief, you would be doing the best thing,
And I will be your defender here."

lg.head: Laisse 103
lg.l: They looked at him quite calmly;
They didn't recognize him, so they became afraid,
Because they saw him holding weapons;
They were truly very frightened of him.
So the good count did all he could to reassure them:
"Have no fear of me; on the contrary, I am here to help you.
By the faith in which you believe, I ask you most earnestly,
Tell me your story, where you are both from."
The higher-ranked lady told him as she continued to weep:
"I am from Tarsia, a very extensive kingdom.
My father is its king and rules the domain,
And he is called King Corebelant.
He had given us to a king of Dalmatia before witnesses;
Of course I brought much wealth as dowry with me.
He was my husband but never touched me at all;
I am still a virgin, most assuredly.
I thought I would live honorably as any other lady expects.
But in my opinion it appears that everything is going otherwise:
I've lost my treasure and all my people,
For with me I see no friends or well-wishers.
They are drowned in the sea, indeed I know it truly;
I am a pagan woman, I haven't believed in the living God.
I don't know who you are, but you seem to be
A noble knight, if your face does not lie to me.
I beseech you, in the name of the thing you hold most dear,
Cause me no harm or anything distressful;
I must stay with you from this time forward."
Count Huon answered her: "This I want most truly.
If your luck is bad, mine is equally so."
He recounted to her a large part of his travails:
"All in all, friend, we will suffer [together]."
The count told them his situation, all the while preaching
And speaking of God, the true Almighty,
Of how He perfected the world and Adam together,
How [Adam] sinned, then how he was repentant.
Right then and there he told them the story willingly and deliberately,
Just as Holy Scripture contains it.
So much did the baron keep explaining and preaching
That he made her forget Muhammad and Tervagant
And believe in Jesus Christ. Then she asked for baptism.
The count repeated to her, "Do you believe this sincerely,
And do you want to leave your wicked life from now on and into the future?"
"Oh, yes, good sir, I do repent most sincerely."
So the count said to her, "You have good sense."
They went down to the sea, right up to the water;
Three times he poured it on her head without stopping
In the names of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit;
Three times he made the sign of the cross.
[Her servant] raised her, she was [re]named Drusiant,
And the same was done for the other as well.
And her lady held her, she who was her servant,
And they named her Valence the joyful.

lg.head: Laisse 104
lg.l: The two women were delighted once they were baptized,
They had already been wanting for two years and more
To receive baptism and holy Christianity.
Now they feared death not one little bit;
They loved the baron very much and he trusted them.
Also for many days he instructed them thoroughly:
He taught them prayers; they were well-tutored in the Scriptures,
And they prayed for him frequently
That God would have mercy on him and send him on the right road.
(What will you do now, [my] friend?" the count asked,
"Should we stay here or seek another shelter?
This is a very wild place and evilly inhabited
With beasts and flying birds [and] harmful creatures.
For the last three months I haven't rested,
Not a single day was I in peace or tranquillity.
Now my suffering doubles, I know it truly,
And I will be quite vexed about both you and me.
How do you feel? Have your spirits recovered now?
Can you walk? We'll go in short stages."
"Yes, of course, good sir, if we might have a little bit to eat;
It's been already four days since I've tasted anything."
So the count said to them, "There is nothing much worthwhile here
Except for some wild plants, but of those there are plenty.
Take some, my lady, in holy charity;
Eat some, I pray you, don't be afraid at all,
It will help you before this day is over."

lg.head: Laisse 105
lg.l: Huon said, "Eat, [my] lady, with confidence.
From this [food] I know you won't ever feel less strong
If you have true faith in God Almighty,
Since Abraham and Moses and our ancestors,
Whom we call holy fathers, did so likewise.
The Scriptures say and recount it quite often:
We must suffer living in this world by undergoing
Manifold tribulation and great pain
If we wish to attain the kingdom of the true God.
Never through having our fill of bread, wine and spiced dishes
Will we acquit ourselves to God above; the flesh keeps weakening,
Which after misfortune desires worldly delights too much.
And because of this many times comes great wickedness,
Such that the body and the soul are lost together.
For this reason, I implore you, don't fail to believe;
You'll find it to be so as I'm telling you."
The ladies answered, "We'll do as you wish."
Then they crossed themselves and set off to gather herbs.
They ate some plants and some roots as well;
Huon, the noble, handsome count, did likewise.
Once their hunger was satisfied, they rendered thanks to God the Father.
They came to the stream that descended down the ravine
And drank from it completely to their satisfaction.
Then they crossed themselves [and] left that place.

lg.head: Laisse 106
lg.l: The count quickly left that place,
And the two ladies departed with him.
On the sea where the ship had broken apart,
They found many pieces of their gear;
They made no pretense of carrying it with them,
For they had no idea where they would go.
They left everything behind; from the cases they took
A large bill and the guisarme that were there.
They thought they might need these
Because of the beasts that lived there.
They didn't fear at all the blows of a sword,
For this reason the count had these brought to him as well.
They made their way as best they could:
Every day he continued along the foot of the mountains,
Praying to God and all the saints of the world
That they protect him and the blond-haired lady.
I cannot say how many days they traveled like this,
Nor the trouble and pain they endured.
No one would believe it if he didn't see it with his own eyes,
But the story tells a part of it.

lg.head: Laisse 107
lg.l: Listen, [my] lords, to a fascinating and beautiful adventure
As it happened to the count near a little valley.
He looked in front of him and saw a marvel:
Two fierce beasts were fighting each other.
They bit with their teeth and scratched with their claws,
They screamed and brayed; the mountain shook.
Many other creatures surrounded them
But none of them joined the battlefield
Unless to watch the contest and howl with them.
"Jesus Christ, Lord, who was born from a maiden,"
Huon said, "Son of the holy Handmaiden,
Help me here, alongside these ladies,
So that I not be harmed together with them.
There are so many kinds of beasts in this meadow;
If we want to wait and watch the battle
Of beasts that I see tormenting and harassing [each other],
We'll soon be harmed; I can't see a solution.
I can't go any further in this stony place.
I see that the path is extremely narrow,
The sea on one side, on the other the mountain."
The ladies feared falling down the cliffs.

lg.head: Laisse 108
lg.l: "I won't turn back. As long as we can go forward, let's go."
He crossed himself, saying, "Ladies, wait a moment,
Climb on this large rock, have no fear;
If need presses you, at a call and a yell,
I'll surely come to your aid, if God allows me to.
I'm heading over to participate in that battle;
There is no great worry from some puny beasts.
If one attacks me, I'll soon give it such a wound,
I'll make such a play on them quickly [and] decisively,
That afterward there will be no [creature] that can get away."
Then he came between them and cried aloud:
"Yield this place to me, evil beast and serpent!"
They looked at him, while some beasts fled and others backed away,
And many asked for battle by means of gestures and manner.
Huon, who was a master at swordplay, had the upper hand
As he protected himself on all sides; he slashed many of them in passing.
Those whom he reached with a blow got what they deserved.
In short order he mistreated them so,
He killed more than two hundred before he stopped;
The others escaped to their dens or caves.
They slunk into their grottoes; woe to any who appeared!
Now we must tell about the two large [beasts] before him,
Neither of which retreated from the fight;
They call one beast a lion who is very worthy
Since he fights all other animals with more force.

lg.head: Laisse 109
lg.l: The lion is the lord of all other animals and powerful.
The other beast was a serpent; it was utterly hideous and enormous
And was spewing forth fire and flames through its nostrils and tail at the same time.
The lion held it down and choked it by the throat
And was dragging it backward and forward.
The serpent seized him with its tail and held him so tightly
That there was no way he could get away from it at all.
With his paws and his claws he continued to fight back against it.
Huon said, "Oh, my God, this is a tremendous battle,
They are both truly in danger of death.
But I want to help the handsomer beast
Because all other [animals] belong only to him."

lg.head: Laisse 110
lg.l: "Oh, God," said Huon, "Should I allow
This most noble beast, who is lord of the others, to die?
Since I am able to help him [and] serve him at this time,
[If I don't help] men should scorn me greatly from now on."
Then he turned to those ladies and had them approach him.
"Come forward in safety, have no fear,
So that you can see in this place a great marvel---
Two wild beasts when they are most warlike.
One of them has a great advantage over the other, but I want to say:
In a very short time I will help [the latter one]."
Then he picked up the sharp bill, seizing it with two hands,
And stabbed the serpent where he could reach it,
Taking care not to hurt the lion whose body was stretched out,
So very weak and exhausted was he from attacking the snake.
The count struck the flanks and sides [of the serpent] so heavily
That he destroyed bones and flesh; its long tail lay distended.
The count cried out to the lion, "Noble beast, do not despair!"
When the lion realized that he was receiving such help,
He willingly pulled away from the serpent.
He dragged himself over to the side to lie on the ground
And let the count strike the serpent.
With his huge bill the count went to hit it so hard
That he caused the serpent to fall dead to the earth.

lg.head: Laisse 111
lg.l: Now the serpent was dead and Huon examined it;
He estimated it to be about eighteen feet long,
And in the width of the body there were more than than three feet.
"Oh, God," said Count Huon, "what a marvel this is!
How did such a devil exist when it did nothing good
And only hurt and tormented those who passed by?
If this place is wild no one should be surprised---
Since I came here, and it has been a while now,
I couldn't measure it with my eyes, it was such a huge devil;
If one can find something worse than this, that would really take the cake!
I can never be safe anywhere I go;
I fear greatly for myself and for you, dear ladies, what will happen [next].
This particular monster has been vanquished; look at the lion over there.
He is terribly wounded from the resistance he put up;
See how he writhes this way and that?
His fur is badly burned and his flesh has been scorched.
I don't know if he is poisoned, but he is in great pain;
If he were attacked now, he would be dismembered.
He's not in his best condition; he fills me with pity.
If he could understand me, I personally would trust in him already;
He's still a wild animal, I can't really trust him.
One thing I must say: he won't leave here.
I'll wait to see what he'll do.
Whether he'll die like this or walk away.
If I leave him like this all alone, he'll have no defense.
Around here there are all kinds of vermin---see how he has been laid low!---
And many other animals who will harm him."
Just as he said that, a troop of [loathsome] creatures arose
And came toward him, issuing forth from their lairs.
As soon as Huon saw them there, he stopped then and there
And placed himself before the lion as a defender does.
The two ladies climbed up on a big boulder---
They were not without fear, their bodies were trembling.
Each one called upon Jesus Almighty,
They implored Him sweetly to come to their aid:
If they ever left this place [alive], they would always remember it.

lg.head: Laisse 112
lg.l: On the other side [of the clearing] stood Huon the count;
He acted like the good shepherd
Who always tries to save his animals
When he sees the wolves round about them:
He calls them and places himself before them.
He risks any fight both for himself and for them.
That is what Huon did on that day;
He did not want them to come at [the lion], so he attacked them.
He gripped his club and struck most of them;
Those he managed to hit quit their assault.
He killed more than one hundred quickly,
He made them abandon the place without delay.
They went back to [their] caves and didn't reappear that day,
And the other small beasts stayed hidden.
They left the count the completely empty field
He went back to the ladies who had gone pale.
He comforted them greatly and said to them sympathetically:
"Be reassured and don't be afraid.
God is with us and will be forever.
If you are truly without sinful deeds,
May the Generous Giver give you of His grace.
By ourselves we cannot live a single hour of a day;
Let us constantly give thanks to God and His grace."

lg.head: Laisse 113
lg.l: Now we must really talk about the lion.
Once he had recovered a bit from his great suffering,
He rose upright, he proceeded to get up on his feet,
Shook himself three times, then raised his face
And looked all around him and saw many types
Of serpents, all dead and lying on the ground.
He was fully aware that he had not done this nor was it his work;
Then he looked at the man whom he saw standing to the side
Ready to fight if he found any creature who might strike him.
But for no reason at all did he want to start [a fight].
The lion looked closely at him, sideways and surreptitiously;
He showed no sign of ill intent, on the contrary, he began to humble himself!
He lay down on the ground and began to whimper,
He scratched the ground with his paw [and] began to shake his tail.
He approached the nobleman Huon, dragging his body
As a sign of humility and of one seeking mercy.
When the count threatened him, he withdrew somewhat,
With his head low to the ground he began to humble himself,
Just like a living man who must now say:
"I beg mercy from you; do not abandon me now;
Because of you I am alive, [saved] from that devil."
And he went back and forth; he wanted to show the truth of the situation
As if to say, "This deed belongs to you,
It doesn't belong to me; I want to render thanks to you."

lg.head: Laisse 114
lg.l: Count Huon looked fiercely at the lion
Who didn't dare get up; on the contrary, he saw him in submission:
He shook out his tail, whimpering like a puppy.
And when Huon looked threatening, he came no closer;
He lowered his head to the ground; it was a sign of humility.
"Dear God!" said the count. "Here are great marvels!
He shows he recognizes the service that was done for him.
At present he is awkwardly showing me [his] nature,
And in this way he is asking me for mercy and forgiveness.
Should I trust him? I see him, a wild beast;
Many times have I heard it recounted by many men
That the lion is indeed the noblest beast in the world,
And the most grateful of them all.
Now he wants to prove it rightly to us."
Then he sheathed his sword and lay down his bill;
The beast was joyful when the baron did so;
Huon signaled with his hands to reassure him.
The lion came to him, always in submission,
His look making clear that he had no ill intent,
Only the humility exhibited by every puppy.
When he was close to him he went down on his knees,
Licking his clothes, yelping like a hunting dog.
The count leaned over and scratched him on his rump.
[The lion] lay down beside him, showing his wound to Huon,
As if he were saying to him, "Give me a cure."
Thereupon the count remembered
That he was supposed to have a container of excellent ointment
And also a good antidote, so the worthy man seized it.
He applied it there where the beast needed it most;
The venom flowed out and he washed the flesh immediately,
Then anointed him abundantly with the ointment
So that it alleviated the pain from him rapidly.
The lion slept a bit in front of the nobleman,
And the count scratched him all over.

lg.head: Laisse 115
lg.l: After the lion had slept a little,
He felt himself well-protected against any threat to him.
He bowed to the count, showing him much humility;
He seemed to have no intention of leaving him,
And the good count understood this well.
Afterward he remained with him for many days,
And subsequently he proved his worth to him in many adventures,
As you will hear told according to the record.
Huon stayed with him for so long
That the day had passed and the night darkened.
He was set up camp; he had never stopped to rest
When guarded in this way.
Because the lion didn't leave him.
Never could anything attack him unawares without [the lion's] hearing immediately;
If he heard anything approach, he leapt to his feet,
And, roaring, approached the beasts and yelled.
When the creatures heard that tremendous voice,
They would slink back into the forest.
He came to his lord, and lay down at his feet.
"God," said Huon, "this is an excellent companion.
If he continues like this, as I have seen,
I will keep him like a human brother for me,
And I will have as much hardship as I've been enduring,
[But] the greater part I will leave to this one."
Then he readied himself; he crossed himself many times.

lg.head: Laisse 116
lg.l: Once Huon felt certain of the lion's state,
He ate a few herbs that he found.
He and his companions then lay down;
With the lion [present] they were not afraid.
Soon they were asleep;
So they remained until daybreak.
When dawn broke, the sun rose.
Huon recited and completed his prayers,
Crossed himself and then turned away from there.
He wished to make progress on his road as was his custom;
The lion walked near him, sometimes ahead, sometimes at his side.
Whenever he perceived evil beasts he began to roar;
They fled before [him], nor did they stop,
[But] if they did stop, he quickly defeated them.
Not one found that it could withstand the lion.
When he wanted to eat, he used a different method:
The beasts understood his many roars and cries;
Every [creature] in the area gathered in a field.
He took the one he wanted, not one resisted;
He was able to eat his fill from that one,
He allowed the others to leave safely.
"My God," said the count, "You perform many miracles!"
"Ladies," he said, "marvel at this from now on;
That was true nobility that you just witnessed.
This creature was crowned by all the other beasts---
All the animals fear him, I have seen it for sure---
I have now gained a good companion."
He set off again on his way, he didn't stop anymore.

lg.head: Laisse 117
lg.l: Huon walked in front, the lion brought up the rear;
[The lion] bore the brunt whenever it came to a fight.
From that time forward he always helped Huon.
But I can't tell you any more about their journey:
For more than a month and a half with him at his side,
They met up with many a danger.
The count progressed so far on his journey
That he came to a new country
Between two mountains closed in by an ocean inlet.
They couldn't go forward any further
Toward the other side without a ship or galley.
The sea blocked them on one side and the mountains on the other:
The water ran swiftly in from another side.
When the count saw this, he stopped for a moment.
He considered the situation, then said to his group:
"I want to climb the mountain; you remain here
With the lion, you need not fear anything.
I feel him [to be] of such abundant and worthy goodness,
That he will surely guard you with his life.
I don't want to bring you with me, the way is too difficult;
There are too many steep drops, nor do I see a path.
When I return I will tell you the truth,
Where we can proceed; I won't turn back."
He crossed himself, and then he made a sign to the lion
That he must remain there, and [the lion], understanding him well,
Bowed his head to him and marked his acquiescence.
But the ladies were afraid, they trembled because of the lion;
They couldn't do anything about it so they rested,
For they were unable to climb the mountain.

lg.head: Laisse 118
lg.l: The count turned away to the other side where he climbed the hill;
Before he was at the top, he underwent great hardship in the climb.
The count rested many times [on his way up] the hill;
Once there, he looked all around him.
The mountain was quite high and there were many precipices;
The sea encircled them, there was no opening
Through which he might pass. Then he said, "Alas, what to do?
I see my life ends here; this is not a good cliff
Because here it causes me torment and suffering
And to exist always as the beasts do.
But I am worse off than they: each has its own den
Where it is at ease, protected from bad weather when it wishes,
Whereas here I have no dwelling."
He gazed at the other mountain and that he saw further on:
In the middle of the peak, he spotted a cave.
Once he saw it, he desired it
And said to himself, "If I can make it there,
There I will stay until I die."
Since he could not accomplish what he desired to do,
He preferred to stay there as long as God wished.
As best he could, he climbed down the mountain;
He was thoroughly battered and bruised by the time he found his people;
They had lost their color because they were in great fear of the huge lion,
[But] they were completely safe and sound together, and from tis he took much comfort
Although wretched and weak.
Huon comforted them, then he rested a little bit,
And recounted to them everything he had seen.

lg.head: Laisse 119
lg.l: Once the good count had rested a little,
He said, "Let's go on, we can't stay here.
Let's go find a better place
Beyond the sea and the coast." He set off right away,
[With] the lion up ahead who didn't delay.
They moved along until they came to the dark cave;
There he stopped, then he looked quickly around;
He saw the high mountain and the great cliff;
He reflected and said, "Even if I could climb up there,
I don't believe I could get around it from there forward;
I want to remain here resting for a day and a night."
Then he beat his breast and said, "Alas, poor sinner!
I will remain here as long as it pleases the Creator."
He thought a good bit about how he would spend the day.
The water was vast, he had no ship nor wooden boat;
So he thought about felling some of the bigger trees
In order to build a raft, so he could sail away,
He and the companions whom he had with him then.
Immediately he set to work:
He took hold of the saw firmly [and] started in among the trees.
He cut down enough of the biggest and best ones,
Then, taking vines, he lashed them together all around
And set it in the water. The lion, unafraid,
Jumped on board, constantly looking at them.
No man has ever seen a gentler beast,
Who watches out for his lord every day.

lg.head: Laisse 120
lg.l: Once the raft was completed, Huon boarded it;
He brought with him the company he had.
He guided the raft, directing it through the water;
Behold the lion with him who lay at his feet.
He guided the raft in such a way that he came to the other side,
And then he tied up the raft to the bank.
Once disembarked, he called to his companions:
"Look at the mountain, how steep it is!
Ladies, let's leave, there are many cliffs
And a long route [going] back and forth;
If we can just climb up to that cave,
We should be able not to move for a good while."
He led the way, then he declared himself a sinner;
He crossed himself and commended himself to God.
