Then he climbed the slope as best he could,
He made a ladder of dug-out footholds;
He dug up much earth with his bill,
So that his group could go along with him.
They climbed so far that they came up to the cave;
In front of the cave there was a level meadow.
There, spread out on the ground, was a serpent,
As huge and horrible as he had ever seen.
"Oh, God," said Huon, "I will have no rest;
Just when I think to rest, more evil befalls me."
Then he communicated by gesture to his people with him
That they hold back; they were not to approach;
Right away they stopped short.
The count leaped into the [cave] entrance to defend it;
He struck the serpent with his bill and cried out,
He gave it such a beating all up and down,
That he struck its bone and flesh all over.
The creature let out such terrible cries at its death
That the entire mountain resounded with its howls.
"God," said the lady, "what a devil there!
Our lord is being attacked; I believe he needs [help]!"
The lion, hearing her voice, advanced
Forward toward his lord, little did he delay.
When he realized that the serpent was dead,
He bowed to his lord, he showed great devotion;
The ladies came, they saw the marvel.
They thanked Jesus for what He had demonstrated,
And greatly praised their lord [Huon] for it.

lg.head: Laisse 121
lg.l: "By my faith," said the ladies, "this is an excellent knight!
Never have we seen him afraid in danger!
The more suffering he finds, the more fierce he becomes.
When he finds humility, he knows well how to value it,
As he did this wild and timid animal.
He himself never thought he could tame him,
Yet he's completely made friends with him;
[Huon] has trusted him as he would his own true brother."
The count said to the lady who had just spoken:
"Henceforth I want this place to be our shelter,
And we'll quickly put the body of this great creature
Into a pit in order to bury it,
For if we wanted to leave it just as it is,
In two days it would stink to high heaven,
We wouldn't be able to dwell in the cave.
Let it be broken up down below the big rocks."
After these words he went to cut a tree;
He went to carry back two great branches,
One he kept for himself, the other he gave to the ladies.
Then he showed them how they should do it,
By rolling they were going to cast [the monster's corpse over the edge].
And the lion saw them working hard,
So he went to pull on it from the back with his paw,
They pushed [the corpse] so far by rolling it
Down the mountain that they destroyed it.
And it made such a crash in rolling
That the mountain resounded from it.
"Go to the devil, creature issued from the devil!"
Then Huon praised God and crossed himself.

lg.head: Laisse 122
lg.l: Count Huon said, "Let's go into the cave,
See this place, how long and how wide it is,
Whether we'll be able to stay or will have other difficulties here."
So they went inside, crossing themselves;
They went forward as long as they could see light there.
They found the place abundantly spacious;
The cave seemed to go straight through the mountain.
The mountain was wide and there were many paths,
In that place a devil had been imprisoned for a long time.
Many a day had he been there, through many long seasons;
I'll tell you more about his behavior now:
By night and by day he had suffered great afflictions,
He had been condemned to a stone block.
From his voice, [he seemed to be] giving a sermon,
It sounded like he was reading and reciting prayers,
But no one could understand what he said.
When Huon heard him, he immediately stopped
And said to his company, "Let's not move forward another step.
This is a hermit, a man of good intentions.
He has freely remained thus for a long time,
And leads a holy life, so we believe;
He never stops reading and saying prayers.
Let's stay in this area, let's not disturb him.
If it pleases God, we will all be better thanks to his life."
But if he knew completely the true nature of the felon,
The good baron would have thought to do otherwise.

lg.head: Laisse 123
lg.l: Count Huon sheltered in this lair,
And he firmly admonished his companions
That they were not to bother the hermit there.
If they could learn anything from the words he said,
Then they would take it for it would do great good.
Then they ate what they found;
Night fell and they lay down to sleep,
And the lion, because the pit was there,
Left the lair [and] settled down just outside.
He made a sign to the count that they were badly lodged,
But [Huon] didn't understand him at all, he entered feeling safe;
He wanted to bring [the lion] with him, [but] he went the other way.
The count thought that [the lion] would guard the entrance;
With that he let the lion be and went to lie down;
May God take throught for them; [Huon] has found the devil
Who has no judgement or, indeed, abstinence.
He could quickly fall, he would consider himself wretched,
But God was with them, for Huon frequently called to Him
With all that he ever did or said.
At that moment he crossed himself and said many good prayers:
He began a psalm which David had pronounced,
"Set me, O Lord, a law," and then he finished it,
Then he began another, "Praise the Lord, you that are his servants,"
And "Let the whole earth praise, for all He does for us,"
As long as he knew how to say it well he never stopped
Until midnight when he fell asleep.
He slept a little bit there, he tossed and turned with worry;
He saw a great vision, he didn't know what it meant.
He remained that way until the morning,
Whereupon he said his prayers and crossed himself.
For a long time he heard the voice murmuring over there,
But he didn't understand it at all; he didn't know his language.
Indeed he truly believed that it was a good thing,
He very much feared disturbing him.
In this way nine days passed,
But on the tenth day the count reflected further about it,
Because of the lion who still wouldn't come in at all.

lg.head: Laisse 124
lg.l: And Huon said, "Holy Mother Mary,
This lion has signaled me many times;
But I have no idea what to make of it.
He won't come to me because he would [have to] come in here;
I believed that he stayed outside to stand guard.
Many times I have heard it said that beasts have such an ability:
If they sense something supernatural,
If it is something evil, they offer up a great prayer.
Here inside this cave I have been hearing this voice continuously for days,
But it never stops to speak or say anything,
Nor can one pick out a single word.
And many times I have gone over there to listen,
I have never seen him move or go [anywhere].
I'm afraid that he might be the devil,
That he is here to deceive us.
I'll say one thing: I intend to go test him.
Before I leave, I will beg
That he speak more clearly to me.
And if he doesn't want to do it,
I'll make him do it, if I can find a way.
Come to me, don't be afraid at all.
If it's dark, I'll make it light enough
So that from all sides you'll be able to see."
Then the count placed his hand in his bag,
And pulled out the cross the pope had given him
Out of great love when it was time to part.
When he unwrapped it, it cast such light
That he saw clearly in front [of him] as far as a bow shot.
When the devil saw this, he began to cry out:
"Oh, noble lord, pull back a bit;
I cannot look at what you have in your hand!
It makes me feel weak and burn terribly."
Huon answered, "So, are you the evil one,
Who cannot look upon a holy object?
I command you by the power of God the Father
Who spilled His blood for remission of our sins
—By means of this holy cross the Devil was conquered—
That here you cannot harm me in any way,
Nor my companions whom you see here in this place.
Now speak to me about what I have asked you;
You shall explain it to me without any deceit."
The devil said, "Tell me your bidding.
I'll answer you, for I cannot do otherwise."

lg.head: Laisse 125
lg.l: The count said, "Who are you and what is your name?"
And the other answered, "Since someone wants to know,
Indeed I am one of those who weep.
Once I was in glory, now I am damned,
They sentenced us for this to eternal pain:
From day to day our pains double.
I am called by name Quilides the demon;
A worthy man, who knew much of sorcery,
Enclosed me here within a large stone;
I suffer every day in this way from a great burning.
I know you well and what you intend to do,
What you are seeking, we know it very well:
You're seeking the house of Hell.
It is a thing of the spirit, only souls are there;
The one who sends you loves you not one jot.
He sends you to your death, like sheep to the butcher.
He wishes to shame your wife, we know it well;
Since you left your home,
He thinks only of evil things concerning your wife;
He has besieged your land on all sides.
Up until now they have defended it well;
But from here on out I don't know how they will fare."
Huon replied, "Say nothing about that, you scoundrel!
That cannot be, it's impossible to believe.
My lord is wise, he keeps very good counsel;
He wouldn't do what you accuse him of for anything in the world,
For we would have the whole world full of anger and spite.
Tell me something else that we might want to know,
For I wouldn't believe this scheme at all.
You have now deceived me like a villain."
"No, I have not." Still, [Huon] answered him,
"I won't believe you about this; now speak on."

lg.head: Laisse 126
lg.l: The count said this, "Now tell me, devil,
Will I be able by any means to find
That which I desire, request and seek?"
"Not, I believe, without divine help;
He is the only one who can assist you."
Then he said, "So why do you seek it so much?
Can't you see clearly that someone is tormenting [you]
When every day he causes you suffering and harm?
It is a sign that he cannot possibly love you;
Thus you have been lost for five whole months.
You have not had even a full hour of rest;
You seek devils, you can find them right here
From one day to the next without moving any further."
Huon replied, "Speak no more of this, devil;
Some of what you are saying is true and part is lies.
As to what you say that God can really accomplish,
You speak indeed truly, for He has judged you,
In Him there is nothing but perfection.
But as to your saying that [the king] has conceived a hatred for me,
And that often he causes me suffering and harm,
Certainly you are not wrong; but this was to test
Whether or not I am constant in carrying out these valiant deeds.
What I am undergoing no noble man should fear.
It is fitting that he who wants to attain the good realm of glory
Purge the world of its filth,
And he purify in himself all that he can purify.
I don't want to argue this here with you any further;
I adjure you in the name of God the Father
To show me the way and the path to
Where there is a decent lodging and where I might go
Without doing harm and without trouble.
Then go back to stay in that deep abyss."
The demon answered, "Behold the whole path there.
You have adjured me to such an extent, I can't stay here;
I leave to you the exit [and] the entrance of this cave
With the great stone that closed it off
So that it blocked the abyss through which we must pass."
[Then] the demon took off with a great bray and a cry,
And Huon started crossing himself several times,
And comforting his companions a great deal.

lg.head: Laisse 127
lg.l: As soon as the devil had quit that place,
The lion knew it, for he had been watching it closely.
Now he came, entering into the cave,
And came to his lord, lying down at his feet,
He showed him many signs of obeisance.
The count scratched him, then thought to himself:
"This beast was wise; for several days he has demonstrated it,
But I never recognized it; now he has instructed me
About the devil that has been dwelling in this place.
The place was dangerous; [fortunately] it went well with us.
Let's go now, we'll go to the other side,
Then we will quickly choose the best option."
At that word the lion came forward;
He placed himself in front of [Huon] and they got underway.
They passed the mountain through the wide cave;
They found the path well trodden and beaten down
Where people walked a lot every day.
When Huon saw it, he gave thanks to God;
He looked before him and scouted carefully:
Beside the mountain he saw a city,
Very beautiful and large, of great antiquity:
Nobie the Great, that was its name.
They turned that way, they set out on their path;
The lion went in front. Once they had advanced enough,
They were so far along that they found a very large crowd
Gathered at the entrance to the city.
They were there to carry out a sentence, for they had lit a fire.

lg.head: Laisse 128
lg.l: The count said, "Let's head over in that direction;
We'll see what this act of justice is, whether it's good or not.
If it's not being done with proper intent,
We'll defend this person before she dies,
For justice doesn't seek anything other than the truth;
And for this purpose reasoning is frequently necessary
Because weakness of the flesh corrupts all things."
Then he quickened his pace, about which we'll say no more;
He came to the square without delay.
When the people saw the lion come trotting quickly along,
No one lingered in front of them:
They took flight, they emptied the field.
No one was left there, neither old man nor young boy,
Only a young woman with blond hair,
Who was bound to a large stake.
Huon advanced and the count pulled her into his arms.
Then he said, "Maiden, what is the reason
That you are mistreated here and put in such a position?
Are you guilty of this charge?"
"Not at all," she said, "sire, by my god Muhammad.
But justice and reason have failed me,
As well as the courage of a worthy man, for no champion has been found,
Someone to defend me from the hands of a cruel man
Because I'm not willing to do other than what I should.
I am queen of this region,
My father died when I was a child,
And all the country around belonged to me.
I have a sister, not a very reasonable one,
She is a natural [sister], and not [a sister] through marriage.
A cruel castellan who is by rights my vassal
Wanted me very much for his wife completely against my will.
Because he behaved like a traitor and a felon,
I distanced myself from him as I should have;
He received my response badly.
He knew so well what to do that he thereupon took my sister.
I allowed him [to have] her, but then I repented it;
As soon as he had possession of her, he began a dispute with me.
He claimed that everything was hers and thus belonged to him;
It is because of this I am completely lost.
He had me thus brought here, to this burning stake;
The people of the city are very unhappy about it,
But do not rush to my defense,
For he has chased away from himself all the great men,
And put or thrown many in prison.
This is the whole truth that I have told you, sir."

lg.head: Laisse 129
lg.l: "O God," said Huon, "what great arrogance this is!
If it's as you say and you can show it to me,
I'm here before you, I swear to you in good faith,
To help you if you are truly right.
Watch out for being wrong; I want no lies."
And she replied, "By the religion I believe in,
It is exactly thus; I'm not lying about anything."
"Then come with me," said Huon the courtly man,
"And have no fear of the one beside me.
If right is on your side, I'll surely be able to prove it
Against the best prince that may be of your faith."
Then he untied her, next he took her by the hand;
She came before the other ladies along the gravel path.
The lion preceded them, all the people fled,
And Huon cried after them, "Don't be afraid, by my faith!
Come to the trial and discover the truth,
Whether your lady is justified or not!
Uphold right therefore, and you will act as courtly people,
Because it falls to me to defend her; I want to do it."
So much did he say resoundingly that the people felt reassured;
They followed behind him; he continually advanced.

lg.head: Laisse 130
lg.l: The count continued until he came to the palace,
Then he climbed the steps to the top.
There he found this people's lord who had a great household;
He broke through the throng, he went before the lord.
The lion guided the lady through and without any harm,
Since a great number of the people fled from him and stayed quiet.
The lord of the city was afraid and dismayed;
He feared the knight and the fierce lion.
Huon reassured [the people] so that they not fear [the lion] at all:
"But come to the trial, you should listen
So that you correctly uphold and maintain justice."
Then he said to their lord, "Now what will you do?
Look here at these ladies: now, you condemned this one;
You are her liegeman! What reason did you have for it?
You are supposed to defend her with a true heart;
And you want to kill her wrongly and miserably.
Let's test to see if you have the right, if you please,
In my presence you'll prove it to me.
I'll not take it wrong in any way if you are [proved] right;
I will do justice just as I must."

lg.head: Laisse 131
lg.l: Huon said, "Good lord, hear this;
If right is on your side, the victory will be yours,
And if you love justice, then justice will prevail,
Because it will never fail thus out of fear.
I am here for her. Now tell me what will be."
The lord listened to his words and then replied:
"If I didn't fear that beast that I see there now,
I would do something else that cannot be said now.
But know for sure, and don't ever fail to believe,
That I intend to uphold justice as it has been established;
It's a great marvel that you oppose me concerning this matter."
Huon heard his speech and the words he spoke,
Then he said to him, "It will be evident at once;
There will be no date set or hostages [exchanged],
The battle will take place right here straightaway
If I may have a horse. In this way it won't delay
My fighting you. It will be according to this agreement:
Whoever wins will demonstrate that the right is on his side,
Because the right never abandons anyone good.
With you and that lady who is waiting over there,
It is fitting that both you and I should pledge faith to each other
To fight for the right." The lord said, "I won't do it
For a wretched man! Now do you hear me there?
My dignity will never be debased in such a way.
I shall not swear; the battle will simply take place."

lg.head: Laisse 132
lg.l: "Now go arm yourself," said the baron Huon,
For right here we'll determine the truth,
Don't be afraid of anything but me.
But have them give me a good horse,
So that all is done fairly,
And so that you'll have praise and a good reputation."
And thus he had it done forthwith, without delay,
And [Huon] took up a lance with a long banner,
He didn't ask for any other equipment.
He mounted the horse, they held his stirrup;
Before jousting the Gascon horse ran about the field
Back and forth on free rein.
Then [Huon] had him gallop; he found him quite good.
Here came the lord of the land, fully armed,
And people called him Malancres the Felon.
He took to the field a bowshot away;
The two of them struck each other at exactly the same moment
On their shields that were of beaten gold.
They gave each other massive blows that rang out in the air;
Malancres's lance flew off in two pieces;
Huon's did not break at all.
He shattered [Malancres's] shield with his arms [painted] on it;
All the rest of his armor was now not worth a button.
[Huon] thrust the banner right through his side;
One could see a stump of the lance sticking out [of him].
[Malancres] fell to the ground, emptying his saddle;
He was nearly dead, he wouldn't recover,
And, close to death, he asked for pardon.
The baron granted it to him with a condition,
That he tell the truth concerning the whole dispute,
So that many people know [and] that he not be scorned.
[Malancres] revealed the situation so that many men heard it;
The lady was vindicated and the villain was dead:
So it goes with traitors who practice treachery.

lg.head: Laisse 133
lg.l: This deed was soon known everywhere,
How the lady was vindicated and [Malancres] defeated.
Everyone said, "God and Muhammad, help us!
This is a miracle for a lost cause."
They brought back their lady and reinstated her properly;
They all swore their loyalty to her
And said, "Lady, state your desire.
We are ready, our eagerness demonstrates it;
We know well that we hardly defended you
Against your brother-in-law who seized the city
Against reason like a wretched felon,
And wrongly confounded all your people,
Exiling some and imprisoning others.
He was a foolish trickster and a perjured traitor;
Everyone has seen it clearly today,
Since he is dead and thrown to the earth.
Tell us, lady, will you be the mistress of this knight?"
"No, indeed not, although he has served me well,
For whoever he might be, he has displayed great prowess;
By him I have been defended, as you see.
Whatever he wants, let it be provided through you.
And if this is not everywhere accomplished properly,
Then you'll be completely out of favor with me."

lg.head: Laisse 134
lg.l: Before the worthy count dismounted to the ground,
Many citizens came up to him
On behalf of their lady whom he had delivered from danger.
They eagerly offered him peace and great devotion;
"Ask us [what you wish], sire, and we'll do it immediately."
And he said to them, "Then without delay,
Have that evil woman who betrayed her sister
Burned there outside along with her husband;
Justice requires and demands it right away.
Thus, if you wish to take full advantage of my efforts,
This is the thing you should do that will be best
And I'll willingly help you throughout."
They heard what he said and obeyed him right away;
They did as he said, nor did they take a long time to do it;
The lady was dispatched along with her lord.
[Everyone] great and small gathered in the square,
They were very afraid of the savage beast, [the lion].
Huon reassured them, he greatly boosted their courage:
"Do what I tell you for your own good
And I'll tarry here as your defender.
In good faith I'll teach you and love you kindly."
They all replied with one loud voice,
"We are ready to serve you forever."
The lady replied, "Now take charge right away;
Thanks to you I am alive and restored to honor;
Truly I'll never stray from your commands."

lg.head: Laisse 135
lg.l: "Sire," said the lady, "command as it please you,
We're all ready to do your will,
And whoever is not willing to do so, he'll no longer be my friend.
Right away he'll be exiled from my land,
And I'll hold him as a mortal enemy."
And [Huon] replied, "For the sake of holy charity,
Take baptism in the name of the true God,
Let Muhammad and Tervagant be completely forgotten.
We have shown you the rightness of this;
The devil will not have dominion over you;
Your souls will be saved, if you do what you should."
At this speech, many looked at him;
The count said, "What do you think about this?
Are you ready to do it willingly?
If not, I am absolutely prepared
To do something else that will not be to your liking:
I and this beast will challenge you all.
You'd never be in such a well-fortified place
That you wouldn't be brought very quickly to my judgment."
And they all cried at the top of their lungs,
"We're all coming, sire, to your grace.
Show us the way; it will be honored by us."
And he replied, "Be baptized, all of you!"
"We are very willing to consent to it, completely willing."
[Huon] blessed some water that he had sanctified,
Then he said to them, "Undress yourselves without delay;
Immerse yourselves three times in the name of the Trinity:
That is the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit;
These are the three persons that make up the one God.
Believe in Him, in complete good faith,
And in His Mother, and also in His saints.
Support each other, and love each other,
Just like brothers; then you will be saved."
They replied that they would do so,
Then they immersed themselves in the water to the best of their ability.
Three times they immersed themselves in the name of the Holy Trinity,
Then they got dressed and all gathered together.
And [the count] preached to them very well;
He prayed a lot for them, and then he made the sign of the cross over them,
And he sent them home.
Only then did Huon get off his horse;
He turned to go back to his ladies.

lg.head: Laisse 136
lg.l: Once Huon had dismounted, he turned to go back
To the ladies and he led his beast.
Everyone feared [the lion] and watched him closely;
They all marveled at him and at his lord,
How much goodness there was in one man.
Huon found many people at the entrance to the palace,
And they were those who had fled his company,
And who had abandoned him on the island
Perfidiously when they deceived him.
They all watched what he did;
They said to themselves, "There is no one better than he.
Indeed we have failed, [but] he'll forgive us;
Let's give ourselves up to him; he'll have pity on us."
At this word, they explained everything to him,
That they had little of anything, for they had been robbed of everything.
Each of them knelt at his feet
And frequently cried out "have mercy"
For the great betrayal they had committed against him.
The count stopped and looked closely at them;
Then he said to Samson, "I never would have believed it,
Not for anything, that you would ever abandon me
In such peril." And [Samson] apologized profusely.
In front of the others, he recounted the story.
They confessed the whole thing;
They begged pardon for all that they had done.
Huon was quiet, and reflected for a while
Whether he would punish them,
It still could be [that] it would turn out for the worse.
They were Christians, and he could strike them down;
If they were sinners, they could yet improve,
And they would exalt Christianity through [their penance].
So he would designate a lord over them
Who would henceforth govern this people:
"And all the others will come with me.
I must travel to strange lands;
I cannot remain here because some would consider e a traitor.
In this way one becomes a good man.
My soul is thus safe, if it pleases Jesus,
When it will have done so much good in my life."

lg.head: Laisse 137
lg.l: After a moment Count Huon spoke;
He said, "First of all, now listen to me, Samson;
You clearly acted toward me without any great injury [to me].
Each of you would be quite worthy of death,
But out of love for your father, named Raimon---
He was a worthy knight, the best in Aragon,
I saw him often and we were companions---
For the sake of his goodness, I acquit you here and now,
You and the others who are here before me;
From here on out, you will be worthy men."
He made the sign of the cross over them and gave them his blessing,
Then everyone there went up to the great hall.
After that, they sat down to dine;
There was plenty of food and meat,
And much pleasure, as is proper.
They all enjoyed themselves in peace,
They all ate for they had good reason to do so.
The baron Huon had enough from very little [food and drink]:
The baron ate just a quarter measure of bread
And drank great quantities of pure water,
For he loved God with true intent.
[God] was with him and Jesus sustained him
Through whatever problem the worthy man might have;
He placed his heart entirely in God's hands;
He gave Him praise and blessing at all times.

lg.head: Laisse 138
lg.l: After eating, the tables were removed,
Then Huon the count addressed them;
He said many good things.
But the count did and said so much,
That the queen of that land promised him
To obey whatever he wanted her to do,
And never ever to doubt him.
Therefore he gave her [in marriage] to one of Samson's sons:
His name was Guy, and he dubbed him a knight,
And there on the spot Count Huon crowned him;
And he married the lady before the people,
So that no one might bring up any challenge at all.
After that, everyone swore loyalty to him:
From that time forth they held him as their lord.
Guy bowed to [Huon],
The lady and her people loved him dearly.
And [Guy] was wise; he got good advice;
He held the realm well, he increased Christianity.
No more will be said by me about their situation,
Except that I believe God helped them a lot,
For a sinful man rose to such great honor.
Huon stayed there a long enough time,
So that their people turned completely to goodness,
And he endowed them with many good customs.
He had churches built and ordained priests
Who would celebrate mass.

lg.head: Laisse 139
lg.l: After Huon had spent many days there,
He took his leave of them with tears and crying.
There was no one there with such a hard heart
That he didn't weep and feel pity at that moment.
Of all those people who were accompanying the count,
The warrior [Huon] left some with their lord,
And took others with him.
Samson and Anseïs still accompanied him;
[Samson] thanked him profusely for the great honor done them
By what he had done for Guy, his younger son.
And the count begged him gently, for love of him,
To remain faithful and to leave behind all error;
If he did thus, it would be better for him.
Just then he said in his ear,
"Do you see those ladies who are still accompanying me?
If anyone recounted their adventure,
It would soften the heart with great compassion.
One is the queen of Tarsie, she deserves honor,
The other is a countess of great property near there;
The two of them are very fond of each other.
If God grants that they return to their country,
Before I leave them, I believe I can manage
To have your son Anseïs take [the queen] as his wife.
He will have the lady and both land and honor;
Think of being a worthy man, you along with all of them."
[Samson] thanked him, his eyes brimming with tears.

lg.head: Laisse 140
lg.l: Thereupon Count Huon left Nobie;
He brought his people with him as well as the prancing lion.
He rode away on horseback and did not delay;
I won't tell you now about their journey,
Just that while they went along,
There was nothing that occurred to disturb them.
It happened one day, before prime sounded,
That he saw the buildings of this country,
The great palace and likewise the tower.
When the count saw it, he marveled;
And then he next said laughingly, "[My] lady,
"What land is this, do you know it at all?"
"Yes, indeed, this is my home;
Its lord is my father, the powerful king, Corberant.
You have done so many excellent deeds for me
That he will give you a reward if he can;
May Jesus Almighty give it to you for my sake.
But I'm telling you something with certainty:
Do as you wish with me and with my father;
The land and his property is now at your service."
He thanked her for it, then he rode ahead;
They entered the city through the earthern gate.
They went a good way until they came to the main square;
There they found a great dispute going on,
For people were gathered, both great and small.
They were all armed deliberately:
They had clearly divided up into two groups,
They intended to fight each other.
I will explain what the case was about:
The lord had died, and just recently;
The barons wanted to choose a lord according to their wishes,
But the people did not wish to consent to this at all;
On the contrary, they wanted the land to remain commonly held;
That was the dispute for which they were facing each other.
Huon heard the quarrel; once he knew the truth
From a local inhabitant, he did not delay any longer;
He went to the square, all his people with him.
Then he cried out, "Be quiet, all of you!
Listen to me, because I wish to tell you something pleasing.
And if anyone sayas one word out of line,
Everyone will be put to death immediately."

lg.head: Laisse 141
lg.l: At the voice of the count, everyone fell silent;
From that moment no one said a single word.
They looked at him---how he was accompanied---
And at the lion who was in front of him
Who was rolling his eyes! He displayed a terrifying look;
He very much wished to make an impression,
But he still looked at his master,
As does the servant who loves his lord.
Everyone who saw him was terrified;
They were afraid of death, don't be surprised about that.

lg.head: Laisse 142
lg.l: Huon spoke when he saw the people quiet down:
"[My] lords," he said, "now listen to me.
You have assembled here in order to elect an ruler;
One part of the group wants a ruler whom they like,
The other wants something else and isn't willing to agree to it.
But I would like to propose an alternative and to say:
'Put down your anger, each one [of you], show each other good will,
For this matter [of who rules] doesn't belong to either of you,
For it only to the heir of the king who is dead
Can rule. To that person must pass
The entire kingdom, without any doubt,
As you here present can clearly see;
And he who doesn't want to believe it at all,
Won't be my friend, I have to state it clearly;
I challenge him, I don't intend to deceive.
Then it will be clear who knows how to defend himself.
Honor your lady as you should serve her;
This I advise you to do without any bad intention.'"

lg.head: Laisse 143
lg.l: The people gazed at the lady and the knight,
As well as at the lion who seemed exceedingly fierce.
It seemed to all of them that he wanted to fight;
They were quite afraid the more they began to look at him;
The hearts in their chests started to quake.
Not one of them knew what to advise the other;
They started to flee, they didn't even know where to go.
[But] when they came to think for a moment,
They clearly recognized their lawful lady.
With one voice they started to exclaim:
"We're willing to concede everything to you!
Command us; we'll willingly do anything."
The count replied, "If you are prepared to love her,
You must leave behind Tervagant and Muhammad,
For your faith is not worth a single penny.
Believe in Jesus who allowed Himself to suffer;
He underwent death in order to save all of you.
If you wish to be as I'm making clear to you,
Your souls will be saved when you pass from this life by loving Him willingly.
Now get yourself baptized immediately,
Believe in our religion in order to do a good act."

lg.head: Laisse 144
lg.l: At that moment, their lady came forward
Among them so that they saw her clearly;
In a loud voice, she cried out:
"Lords," she said, "listen to me now.
I am your lady, don't ever fail to believe it;
All of this kingdom that exists belongs to me.
My father is dead, he has no other heir;
Do just as this vassal has said:
Receive baptism and the faith that he holds.
It can save you, for there is no other God.
Those who do so will be my friends;
Those who do not agree to this,
Know this for a fact, they will seriously vex me,
Never in my life will they be my friends.
See over there the lion who desires nothing else
But to come at you; he yearns to do it.
If his lord doesn't hold him back, he'll be upon you in a flash;
And he has [already] killed one." Thereupon, they all cried out:
"Lady, do with us as it pleases you;
No one will avoid your summons."
Thereupon Count Huon made the sign of the cross over some water,
And ordered all the people there to do
Everything that is said and explained in Scripture.
The people undressed and entered [the water]
In the name of the Trinity; and everyone took [baptism],
Each gave it to the other as the religion commanded.
And after that, Huon said many things,
He told them so much and taught them so well
That, with great joy, he put them all on the right road.
Then, right then and there, he gave the lady in marriage:
He united her with Anseïs, Samson's son,
And all the people swore him fealty.
He was from that time forward good and wise:
Toward all good men he showed humility;
Against the cruel, he demonstrated proper pride.
For this he was loved. [Anseïs] kept the country
For a long time in peace so that no one found there
What might harm them, for as long as he was alive.
He begat two children with his wife
Who were in time good men, who advanced [the cause of] Christianity
And recovered many lands near theirs:
One was named Raimon, the other Corobora.
I cannot tell you anything further about their lives,
For we'll return now to my story.

lg.head: Laisse 145
lg.l: Count Huon dwelled there long enough
So that all the people turned to virtue.
After that, he made the sign of the cross over them as was proper,
And commended them to God the Father.
"Lady, may Jesus be with you!
I don't know if my eyes will ever see you again,
For I don't know myself where I'm going;
I'm rightfully putting myself at risk.
Pray to Jesus that He grant me a good end,
[And] that I never lose heart for anything in this world
Concerning what I yet believe I'll find."
"May God grant that it be so," the lady replied.
Huon took his leave, great tenderness overcame him.
He didn't bring with him or lead any men-at-arms
Except Samson, whom he trusted greatly,
And the lion whom he didn't forget at all.
He had an excellent companion in him;
From the many difficult situations the baron found himself in
The lion defended him as best he could.
[The lion] came straight from God, [Huon] knew it for sure;
Day after day, just as at night,
He thanked God the Father; he was very grateful to Him.
He prayed for himself and for all people,
That God bring everyone to a good place.

lg.head: Laisse 146
lg.l: Now Huon had made a good start;
For this he didn't claim the glory for himself at all,
But rather gave very great praise to God.
"We have dominion over three kingdoms
Where the true faith in God now rules,
Which before were [held] by the pagan people.
One was the kingdom of Jerusalem
And all the land that belongs to it.
Another is Nobie, a very pleasant land,
Where there are many castles and many estates.
The other is the kingdom of Tarsie that is a very extensive land;
Their peoples now serve God.
Now let us ride on," the count said,
"If it please God, at some time before I die,
You, Lord Samson, don't doubt it at all,
I will make you ruler of the greatest dominion
In the whole world, so do I intend today:
That is the great kingdom of Cappadocia.
Its lands stretch out as far as the eye can see.
Indeed, the sea surrounds it on three sides;
From that place on there is no habitation,
Not a castle or city or other domain;
Will you take it if we can conquer it?"
"Yes, dear lord, if it pleases you."
Then he thanked him, he bowed his head to him.

lg.head: Laisse 147
lg.l: The count turned toward the road;
Day by day they rode briskly
Until they arrived at the capital of the kingdom of Cappadocia.
Hear what adventure happened to the good count!
He found a great mass of people
That had been besieging the city for a long time.
The sultan of Persia and the one from Babylonia,
With all the troops they could possibly bring there,
Thought to possess the land, but it had defended itself;
The people preferred to die [honorably] before being starved out.
But there were few people [to fight] those of the [attacking] army;
Here on the field the two sides were assembled,
The combat couldn't be avoided:
The battalions [were] formed, the combatants in advance position.
"God," said the count, "from this point on it will be shown
Who'll have the most valor and gain the greatest reward.
Both sides are made up of infidels
Who love neither God nor his saints.
Let them strike each other, then we'll begin;
Whichever side is losing will awaken my pity.
Then we'll help the losing side."

lg.head: Laisse 148
lg.l: "Now let's watch the battle," said Huon to Samson;
As they began to watch, [the opponents] joined battle.
The armies fought together; cries and noise arose;
The one rode hard upon the other without holding back.
They gave each other mighty blows;
Whoever could fight best would not do so at all in vain.
I cannot say who died or who escaped,
But the battle lasted a very long time.
On both sides already there was great loss of life;
Then the two sultans who were part of the [besieging] army
Vanquished those on the field, unhorsed them.
They already would have had the land in their power
When Huon pressed himself into the ranks.
He held back the pursuers by force;
He struck and struck again against these pagans,
Those who received a blow didn't need any more.
Samson and the lion followed him with great effect into the fray;
They charged into the thickest part of the press.
It was a marvel what they did killing people.
When [the pagans] saw this, the strongest among them were afraid;
Everyone fled the battlefield before him.

lg.head: Laisse 149
lg.l: Huon and Samson were both in the battle;
They had an excellent companion with them,
Who led the way---that was the good lion.
[Together] they broke up and routed the great press [of warriors] ;
He caused such a level of mortality among these people,
Not even a wise clerk could describe it.
I'm not going to tell the details of the whole event,
And anyone who remained can truly be held a fool
If he didn't flee, no matter how brave he was,
Rather than die without any reason.
Both sultans died by Huon's blows,
As did other people in great numbers.
There the count also took possession of such a marvelous horse
That he wouldn't have given him away for [all] the gold in Besançon:
For one could hardly have found another like him anywhere in the world.
One could compare him to Bucephalus,
That once belonged to that baron Alexander.
He had a black and white breast and hindquarters;
And a heart on his forehead;
One could not have seen a more beautiful beast.
The count mounted him, and gave his [horse] to Samson;
He rode forward helter-skelter through the battlefield,
Striking and killing all those he found.
Quite a few died, quite a few fled,
They left behind all their armor in abundance,
And the people from the city then came out
To help them if they needed it,
But he didn't need it; they had won the battle.

lg.head: Laisse 150
lg.l: Huon had won the battle;
He found no one to challenge him at the standard
For they had all abandoned the field,
And most of them [had been] killed and destroyed.
The people from the city came there;
They found the knight, and greeted him properly:
"Sire," they said, "this business will be made known,
That we have gained this victory because of you.
Our lord is dead, may Muhammad help him;
The land and the domain will be given to you.
Command now, it will be attended to;
You will not be deprived of anything you want."
The nobleman replied with wise words:
"I will accept this gift if you are truly determined;
Now accept baptism, believe in the name of Jesus,
And hold to the faith that Holy Church has upheld.
Leave Muhammad behind, he isn't worth a saddle-cloth,
Pray to God the Father and believe in Him.
If you do this, you won't be damned.
Your souls will not be lost at the end of days;
Thus you will do what the [true] faith has decreed."
They made obeisance when they heard this:
"Do with us, sire, as one does with his friends;
We are yours, there is no one who will deviate from this."

lg.head: Laisse 151
lg.l: Then Huon said, "Thanks be to God!
Put down your arms, dismount from [your] horses.
Enter this water in honor of Jesus and His name
Of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost which are all one,
A single substance in three persons,
And one sole God---thus must we believe;
Those who will serve Him in good faith,
Will then guard themselves from the filth of this world
Which causes sin through their vainglory.
They will be saved; Scripture says it's so.
Enter into this water, holding one another;
May you receive blessing from me and from God.
Immerse yourself three times, then come out quickly;
Let others do the same, those not here [now]."
From day to day as they were reborn,
The good vassal Huon made the sign of the cross over the water;
Each one bathed in the name of the Trinity,
Then issued forth [from the water] and dressed again.

lg.head: Laisse 152
lg.l: Once he saw them baptized, Huon gathered them all together;
He spoke many fine words, many fine sermons.
They all paid attention and learned many things there.
After doing this, he exhorted them about other things;
Before he left that place where he was,
He gave them a lord, the good nobleman Samson.
[The people] swore fealty to [Samson] and became his men,
And he married the lady whose kingdom it was.
Count Huon gave the city to Samson,
For he was worthy and wise and maintained it properly;
He loved justice and accepted wise counsel.
And then Huon gave him a good companion,
Out of fear of the other people, so that no one might harm him,
Nor on any occasion be able to overthrow him.
This was truly the temperament of the lion:
To the good he was peaceful, to the cruel he was violent.
Those who watched him the most feared him completely;
Because of him, good [Samson] was feared by all the people
In many foreign places, as the story is told.

lg.head: Laisse 153
lg.l: The noble count of Auvergne blessed the beast,
Then he signaled to him what he must do.
And [the lion] understood him well; he inclined his head,
As if he were saying, "I'll do as it pleases you;
You'll have the worst of it, who made yourself wretched.
You don't know where you're going, nor what might happen to you;
Your adventure is an incredible story, that's how people see it."
The count began to eat, for he understood [the lion's] signals;
[Huon] knew that [the lion] spoke the truth, but his heart grew tender;
He thus demonstrated a great love for Samson
When, for the good of others, he sacrificed himself.
For a man alone assailed [by troubles] might be worth very little
Yet he still entrusts his life to Jesus Christ.

lg.head: Laisse 154
lg.l: The count was well acquainted with the entire situation,
But this adventure had touched him greatly
Because of the fear of losing what he had gained
For minor reasons if he moved too impetuously;
A lot of bad things could certainly come out of it,
So that they wouldn't worship Jesus nor [before] the crucifix.
He would rather go on at the risk of being killed,
Than lose what he had gained up to now.
He believed it would be maintained by the lion,
Thus he spoke to him respectfully.
He made the sign of the cross in the name of God, the King of Heaven,
Over the animal who had so obeyed him.
"I believe I have made the better choice;
May God do with me everything as He sees fit.
I give myself up entirely to Him in His mercy."
With a happy expression he raised his head;
He said to Samson, "Now go in, fair friend;
Be sure to be a good man, in God's service and [your people's].
Love justice and loyalty too;
May there be in you compassion, reason and mercy.
Have these tents and this equipment gathered together;
Distribute them among these people as you see fit.
Don't care only for amassing possessions, I beg of you,
For soon you will be considered avaricious.
Joy in this world has no value at all.
If someone acts rightly toward you, reward his service.
I don't know what else to tell you; I'll stay with you a little while,
I'll remain with you for a month and a half.
Then I will recommence my quest; I have been thinking about it for a long time;
You'll remain [here] in honor; I'll depart in misery.
You must pray for me to the King of Heaven
That He allow me to accomplish what I have sworn and pledged to do
For the great king, that is, Charles of Paris."
[Samson] bowed to him, and [the count] blessed him;
He did everything just as the good count told him.
They gathered together all the [captured] equipment, then it was brought into the city,
With great joy they received it.

lg.head: Laisse 155
lg.l: Great was the joy in that land
As the people celebrated their victory,
Their new lord and the great wealth
That they had conquered from those who were not willing to believe in God.
If there was joy, that's not to say
Other suffering was forgotten through this happiness.
Everyone was willing to act rightly,
[And] Huon often preached as a priest [would have].
He often beseeched them, indeed very often said
That they must love one another as brothers---so he reminded them.
"Our faith says it, it is written in our history,
For it is good and not to be disbelieved;
Brothers must dwell together in unity.
There is another thing I wish you to understand:
Don't do to another what you don't want [done to yourself].
There is a proverb told by the wise teacher,
That which one does not want done nor [wants] to receive
He will not do to others. Then will the God of glory love you,
Your soul will be saved at the end of [your] labors,
When you depart from this vainglorious life."
They thanked him for this [sermon], saying, "We truly hope for all this,
Our hearts and our will understand this well."
The count made the sign of the cross over them all, blessing them,
Saying to them all, "May God grant you strength."

lg.head: Laisse 156
lg.l: Thus the people reconfirmed at this time
To do everything well; they gave and pledged their hearts to it.
Huon remained with them, so I believe,
More than a month, and then he departed.
He then took his leave, his eyes streaming with tears;
He took nothing with him except his horse,
Which he would not have given up for all the riches of Araby.
He felt safer when he was on him
Than if he were in a castle on a hill.
The count left by way of the gravel path;
He didn't know the road or the route
Or anyone to advise him as to the direction to follow
That might be worth anything at all to him.
One [can] find quite a few [places] for staying at ease and repose,
But he considered all that as vanity;
Painful effort and torment might fall upon him,
[But] he would be a traitor if he broke the word he had given,
So he had to do the best he could.

lg.head: Laisse 157
lg.l: Count Huon left Cappadocia;
Weeping, he kissed the worthy Samson
And others who were worthy men.
He left them without delay;
He didn't bring any companion or peer with him;
As for which direction to take, he left that up to Jesus.
He took the road that went to the right;
He began to ride, since he had a good horse,
That soon distanced him from that land and household.
The baron rode continuously uphill and down,
Never forgetting to pray,
But rather repeating the liturgy, hour by hour.
He recited a psalm that he had learned as a boy:
"Remember me, O Lord," until its end.
Then he would recite another that he remembered:
"Troubled, [I come] to you, Lord Jesus,
I cried out to you, O Lord, and I render thanks to You
For all the care I have received from you."
He rode until he came to the top of a hill
By a shore where there was very deep water;
He came across a young man coming out of a ship [with many sailors].
He needed some rest, for it had been many days
Since he had had any repose because he was deeply upset
About the great killing that happened in Cappadocia.
He didn't know what was going on, how things were at present,
Who had won or who had lost.
Upon arrival [the merchants from the boat] had gone straight into the city
With their merchandise, as they always did,
[But] when they had to deal with armed conflict,
They left the place stealthily.
From that point on, they weren't without any worry;
They just now thought themselves safe and were about to rest
When they caught sight of this knight riding at full speed.
They thought they might be captured and wanted to flee;
The count was before them and began to speak:
"Have no fear at all, let me reassure you completely.
What manner of men are you, and from what country?
Please be so kind as to tell me
In the name of whatever in the world you hold dear."
The others were reassured when they heard the worthy man,
And so they said, "We'll tell you then."

lg.head: Laisse 158
lg.l: "As you can see, we are merchants,
Who go to foreign countries to buy and sell.
For what I don't have, I go seeking other things;
At one moment we lose [money], at another moment we manage,
According to the destiny God the Father allows me."
When the count heard this wise speech,
That they named God, the Father Almighty,
The count asked, "Are you all baptized?
Do you believe in the New Testament and the Old?"
"Yes, of course, we are all believers,
And we know very well indeed that He reveals it to us."
Huon crossed himself when he heard and understood
Since he hadn't thought to find Christian people here.
"Now speak to me," he said, "and don't be afraid."
And they answered him, "We'll do as you wish."

lg.head: Laisse 159
lg.l: "[My] lords," said Huon, "in what land were you born?
Who is lord over all, what is his name?
I never thought to find Christians in such a place,
Except for a new kingdom where [the people] have just now been baptized.
I'm speaking of Cappadocia, which is close to here.
I don't know yet if the faith that God the Father commanded
Will be observed as their law.
But I know for sure that they are all Christians,
They have a good lord; they swore themselves and their faith to him;
May God the Father, from whom all goodness comes, preserve them."
When the merchants had listened to these words, [they said]:
"What are you saying about this good kingdom?
Who accomplished this? We saw ten kings at the siege,
Besides the two sultans who were arrayed in bright colors,
Who have never loved God nor believed in the Trinity.
Whoever did this has been more victorious
Than any man ever born of woman,
More even than my lord, who has great power:
That is Prester John, so he is calle,d
He calls his kingdom The Land of Truth.
But I think that all you have said,
Saving your honor, might be proven a lie
That someone did it, that someone defeated so many.
The two sides, who don't believe in God, the Lord of Majesty,
Had challenged each other."
"So it is," said the count, "and so it occurred."
"Then who did it? Tell us about it."
"Two men only suffered great distress
And with them a wild beast.
One of them remained behind as lord, the other left;
I won't tell you more now about this matter.
But all praise belongs to the Trinity;
Without it no man would be able to do anything."

lg.head: Laisse 160
lg.l: "Now listen to me," said Count Huon,
"Since you are Christians just as I am,
I ask you out of charity, for God's sake and in His name,
That you take me with you now on your ship.
I wish to go to your land, not for any evil purpose;
I've never been there [and] have a great desire to go.
I've heard it mentioned in many places
Because truly real justice is upheld there.
I've not heard it mentioned that an evil man or a felon
Can endure there, for he would very soon be noticed.
Justice is thoroughly carried out in the name of the Cross;
Goodness truly exalted and evil completely confounded.
If this is truly so, as they say in many places,
Then it's filled with all the saintly people in the world.
They must truly be in divine grace,
Since they all know good and evil,
But seem never to sin for any reason."

lg.head: Laisse 161
lg.l: After he spoke, the merchant answered him,
"You're a good Christian and hold to their faith;
You know very well that man is a fragile thing.
If you're going to live on this earth [and] dwell with other people,
You simply must commit sins repeatedly.
Such is [Christians's] faith that they are driven to repent,
And to protect themselves by loving God Almighty,
And to make amends, if they can, for their excesses.
But he who perseveres in evil for days
Isn't willing to be aware of it; thus he goes around mocking others,
And if he can, goes seeking [evil] frequently;
He won't last long in our land,
For he will be recognized [for what he is] in short order.
If he doesn't leave furtively right away,
He and his relatives are shamed.
You know well something of the state of our land;
We won't tell you more about it in advance.
If you want to come, without paying a lot,
We'll be happy to take you, as far as I am concerned.
Our country is broad with extensive estates;
The way is narrow for the one who doesn't seize it right away."
And [Huon] answered, "I do want to come right away
To the place where your lord, Prester John, lives;
I want to speak to him a little about my misdeeds;
Indeed he can advise me concerning what I seek."

lg.head: Laisse 162
lg.l: The merchant said, "And I'm quite willing [to take you];
He'll give you good advice, for he is wise.
If he doesn't do it, don't hope for it from anyone else,
For there is no other man born on earth
Who is more capable than he concerning temporal matters.
And through God the Father are frequently revealed
Things I'm not willing to discuss, and furthermore I don't know
What may well turn out to be false.
Let's get on the ship, for we have remained here too long,
Since we have a good wind and fair sailing weather."
And that is just what [Huon] did, he didn't hesitate;
He brought his horse onto the ship and he himself boarded with him.
He found plenty of food there, both oats and grains,
And the baron fed [his horse] his fill.
They left the port as soon as they had crossed themselves.
The ship departed at full sail:
It cut through the sea faster than a swallow flies;
It went quickly, day by day, from daybreak,
From village to town, from castle to city,
Because of their rich cargo, of which they had so much,
As if nothing else mattered other than this important commerce,
Until [the ship] was pushed into port.
Others came and made their purchases as was their custom;
In this matter, [their wealth] didn't lessen; on the contrary, every day it doubled.
When he saw this, the count swore on his faith,
[In comparison] every other land was useless [in business].

lg.head: Laisse 163
lg.l: The count delighted in seeing these people;
He listened to and heard a lot about their business:
That they stated the cost according to the merchant's code,
They thought that they could gain with little harm;
The payment for it was immediately made to them.
Afterwarad they were soon free of [any] discord;
But if someone felt they had been wronged there, [the merchants] revealed all,
They told the truth about it according to their understanding:
[The buyer] didn't fail to purchase the goods and pay the price.
[This commerce] didn't happen in one [land] alone however,
But throughout all the lands that Prester John held.
Even without the other properties that he held securely far away,
No one could truly calculate [his holdings] in a day.

lg.head: Laisse 164
lg.l: "Good God," said Huon, "such wealth is here!
All who live in this kingdom must be rich:
There is no less wealth here, for those who want to compare,
Than there is in Rome, we must truly believe;
[But] if they do it out of vainglory, that's a terrible sin."
"They don't," said the pilot, "have no doubt about it;
They are all merchants who travel hither and yon,
For little profit they'll sell [goods] rather quickly.
All the cities here have an excellent market for them;
They don't cause price increases and that's no lie.
Let's go, for now there's a good wind blowing;
You'll see greater lands than there are around here.
They're in the realm of my lord, whom we'll point out to you."
Huon crossed himself and then they were off;
They sailed quickly day by day
Until they arrived in Libya, that large country.
Then [Huon] disembarked from the ship and mounted his horse.
He rode on until he came to the main square,
He marveled greatly at the wealth he saw;
He couldn't believe that so much of it existed in all the world.
Then he dismounted [and] tied up his horse;
He asked for Prester John; someone said, "You'll find him;
He intends to sing mass in that church over there.
With him are many barons as well as several kings;
There are at least a hundred counts, seventy-two marquis.
You'll find more than two hundred bishops and archbishops;
There are crowds of knights and other people."
When Huon heard this, he hurried up;
He left his shield and his helmet near his horse,
Then he went immediately into the church.

lg.head: Laisse 165
lg.l: Huon entered the church, then looked all around;
He saw the church full of princes and counts,
Kings and dukes, [and] other great vassals;
He saw but a single commoner [who] looked little like them
Before the altar on the highest step,
[And there] stood the priests who were talking among themselves
About saying the first office of the day.
When he saw this, the noble ambassador [Huon]
Knelt down at his feet without delay
And said in a very loud voice,
"Following the Divine Office of the Lord our God,
[You], master of all others who intercede for them,
Have mercy on this sinner.
I wish to make confession of my greatest sin,
And receive the body of my Lord."
And he answered him, "Most willingly, right now."

lg.head: Laisse 166
lg.l: The office began as well as confession;
The priest listened to them all as it must be done.
But Huon the count stayed on his knees;
He listened to the office with great devotion.
He struck his breast, calling himself at the same time a sinner;
Great numbers of tears fell from his eyes
That completely bathed the fur cloak over his armor;
No one witnessed him without feeling compassion for him.
Many men said stealthily in private,
"See that great nobleman over there!
His heart urges him now to great piety;
Should he have within himself the greatest sin in the world,
The weeping and the contrition he manifests
Show him to have salvation,
And may God grant it in His most holy name."
The office was sung and they all listened intently,
Right up to the end when they received the benediction.
The priest took off and put away God's vestments,
Then he looked and saw the count kneeling.
He was wet with the tears that fell freely from his eyes
All the way down to his heels.
For this reason, the good priest felt great compassion;
He said to the others who were in the church,
"Go outside; this man wants to make confession."
They did as he asked without delay.
The priest said, "Now listen, noble man;
If you want to confess with proper intention,
Recount your sins and we'll listen to them.
Then I'll advise you, just as we're supposed to do."
Huon told them with tears and weeping,
As many as he could remember from start to finish.
Afterward he struck his breast saying, "I am a miserable sinner."
Then, after he said this, he bowed his head;
He kissed [the priest's] feet and begged for forgiveness.

lg.head: Laisse 167
lg.l: "Oh, my lord," said Huon, "listen to me,
Concerning my sins which I have committed day by day,
There has been no greater sinner than I am, I believe;
If only I could receive the body of God!"
"Friend," said the priest, "you are in good faith;
I'm not speaking, however, so that you take pride [in this]:
I have found in you only such sin
As [found] in recently baptized children.
I absolve you, both on my part and that of God."
[Prester John] took the body of God and afterward made the sign of the cross over him;
After that, he asked [Huon] about other matters:
"How are you traveling, how have you come [here] and how have you come to me?
What land are you from? Tell me your name."
So he recounted to him the king's request,
And how he had gotten there, day by day,
Everything that he had done, keeping nothing secret.

lg.head: Laisse 168
lg.l: When Prester John heard the whole story
He was amazed by what he heard;
To his knowledge, he had never heard the like.
As a result of what he heard, he made the sign of the cross in front of him,
And then said, "Oh, fair Saint Mary,
It's a marvel, I know of none greater that it.
How can you find this [place], if God doesn't help you with it?
All virtues are in Him who lights up the heart of man;
You have less sin than a young child.
You do great penitence, I've never seen the like;
Go in peace," he said, "your situation is a marvel.
From this time forth may God the Father counsel you;
You've taken on such a burden that no woman's son has ever seen before.
Your lord, who torments you, acts wrongly,
His sins cause your torment.
If you bear [this burden] in peace, his soul will be damned;
It will be sad and miserable in infernal hellfire.
And you will escape if it pleases God."

lg.head: Laisse 169
lg.l: Prester John took Count Huon by the hand:
31 Vb) "Vassal, come to me, thus we'll be companions.
I see such things in you that I have never seen in any earthly man;
If you wish to remain in my household,
I don't want anyone at all more valiant than you.
I acquit you of your quest most certainly,
In the name of God, our sovereign Lord;
I say this because your deeds are pleasing.
Let go of what is a futile plan;
I release you from it from now on.
This [quest] is completely impossible for any earthly man."
"I know that well," answered the captain [Huon].
Then he bowed and said to him, "Exalted one,
I render you thanks for what you say [to me].
[But] it cannot be; I would be breaking a vow.
I'll stay here with you for a little while,
In order to see the nature [of this place], how everyone behaves.
The great wealth that I observe in this kingdom,
I've seen part of it, I've truly never seen greater."
"All this pleases me," replied Prester John.
Then he crossed himself and next they left right away;
Outside the church was a large square.
He saw the barons having a good time,
But several of them were guarding his steed
And the other equipment that was nearby.
When they saw him, they valued him highly.

lg.head: Laisse 170
lg.l: Prester John said, "[My] lords, listen here:
Do you see this man here with me?
Honor him as you already do me;
He's a man of faith and has all the virtues
That belong to good people and he observes chastity."
They listened to him, each one knelt down
Before Huon and he honored them greatly.
They said, "Fair sir, it is fortunate that you came here;
Ask of us all that will please you."
Huon bowed down to them, humbled himself to them,
Saying, "Don't [bow] to me, it's not fitting."
Nevertheless, they didn't stop because of [his request];
Rather they carried him so that he didn't touch the ground,
They carried him to the main hall;
They placed him on the seat of honor.
They sang aloud Te Deum laudamus;
The count marveled at the honor they showed him,
But they did what they had to [because] their lord requested them to.
After this ceremony, they sat down to eat;
When the water was announced, they all washed their hands,
Everyone sat at the place assigned to him.
The servants served according to their custom;
The court there was filled with every good thing.
Nothing at all was missing in that place,
But no beseeching ever prevailed
To get Huon to partake of the food there
Other than a measure of bread, with that he was satisfied.
Then he drank some water; he refused everything else.
Above all Huon requested of them
That they have his horse well stabled there
Because soon he wanted to leave and depart.

lg.head: Laisse 171
lg.l: Prester John answered the count most graciously:
"Have no fear, for he'll have good lodging."
After the meal, they washed their hands and drank,
Then he recounted Huon's undertaking to his assembled barons:
"Concerning what the valiant Huon has done,
Because of his valor, we now have four kingdoms
That have been entirely turned to Christianity.
He has done something else, [my] lords; he is traveling through the world
To keep faith with his lord Charles.
He intends to go to Hell, where it is deepest,
To speak to the Devil, down there where he is powerful,
To seek tribute from him, as we understand from him.
This thing is impossible, truly we know it well,
There's not one of you who would advise it then.
No indeed, in truth, we understand well this situation,
If he wishes to remain, we indeed absolve him of it.
The lord who sent him to do this therefore did wrong;
He cannot accomplish it, nor does reason encourage it(
On him is the sin; this one will have salvation."
When [the people] heard him they wept copious tears.

lg.head: Laisse 172
lg.l: When the baron heard this said, he replied:
"That cannot be, my vow would thereby be broken,
I wouldn't do that for all the gold in the world."
And he, meanwhile, ceased speaking at that point;
The others remonstrated with him out of their desire
That he remain; they expounded many different things,
Such that they had to embellish a lot.
But he who had undertaken to serve God
Was not a bit concerned with vainglory.
That was not his nature as the story shows;
He gave his heart completely to serving God.

lg.head: Laisse 173
lg.l: The barons did indeed realize concerning the count
That he didn't accept one little bit of what they explained to him.
They spoke to him out of affection and requested
That he remain; it would be the best thing.
[Prester John] was lord of seven kingdoms;
There was a fair number of princes, dukes and counts --
Seven kings rendered him service, both by night and by day;
For up to a month, if he wanted;
He had seven hundred thousand [men] as far as Syria.
Everyone was doing his duty while he was in this court:
Prelates and bishops, priests too;
Of all the other knights who were still in the world,
To [my] knowledge, the flower truly remained in this place.
They had no hate for one another, rather they loved each other sincerely;
They served each other every day like brother and sister.
"Stay here, you'll be a great lord,
You'll be the companion of the great emperor."
He thanked them with weeping and tears;
The baron humbled himself greatly to them.
"This cannot be," said the good count,
"For up to this point I have never been a deceiver;
I will not, if I can help it, ever be false to my word."

lg.head: Laisse 174
lg.l: Because of what the count said, they felt great pity for him;
They wouldn't be able to retain him in any way.
They promised him quite a lot, but in this nothing worked;
He just spoke about leaving.
Eight days they kept him beyond his intended [departure];
When Prester John saw that it would make no difference,
He granted him his wish while lamenting exceedingly [over it].
He gave him his blessing, handed him over to his nephew, Tadeus:
"Here, good nephew, I commend this [man] to you;
Carry out for him his will and his orders.
I'm very distressed by his departure;
I can do no more; I hand him over to God and to you."
Because [Prester John] saw him going off wandering,
Then he promised him a thousand masses
Sung every day for the next seven years
So that God might allow him to carry out his intent,
And that he might return alive, safe and sound, to his land.
At that point Tadeus brought him to his lodging;
In that place and at that time they discussed his adventures,
How he might steer his course to the end;
The more they thought about it, the more they wondered;
Indeed they knew of no way to get any good advice.
He was getting a ship prepared in the best way possible:
They loaded it with hardtack as well as grain.
They said that for sure
He would need nothing else for a year.
And other things that he might want,
They would deliver it all if it were his pleasure;
[Tadeus] allowed [Huon] quite a lot, but he took nothing,
Rather, he wished to go alone in secret
To the end of this mission. He waited until the next day
When he had a mass sung before him.
He listened to it, and most devoutly
He prayed fervently to God the Father Almighty
That He keep him from evil encounters
And that He allow him to accomplish what he wanted [to do];
And at the end, the priest gave him his blessing.
Thus will we leave Huon for a little while
And sing of Charles the powerful,
Who committed such treason toward the count
As soon as he was far away from his home.

lg.head: Laisse 175
lg.l: As soon as Charles had heard from his spy
That Count Huon was out of the way,
He took counsel with his closest advisors
As to how he would accomplish his desire.
He was advised to send for
The lady Ynide without delay
So that she come to court without tarrying any longer,
"Since her husband had left her in your keeping,
For the queen would render her honor
Until the count, that respected vassal, might return.
Once you have enclosed her very self
In your own dwelling, you will then satisfy
The great desire that you have had for her.
That is the advice we offer.
If she refuses to do what we have mentioned,
You won't have any problems besieging her."

lg.head: Laisse 176
lg.l: "Send word to her now, Sire, without delay,
[That] if she doesn't come freely right away,
You will have good reason to wage war on her:
She'll hardly be able to mount a defense.
Send her a lot of rich gifts;
Send word to her that she'll be with the fair-faced queen
In her chamber and household.
But before making this known,
You must present this matter to many of your barons
So that you don't get blamed for any reason.
A proverb says, 'A man does ill to start a fight
If he cannot complete what he began.'
A lord must never lack justification."

lg.head: Laisse 177
lg.l: Thereupon the king left the council;
With his plan ready, he wasn't going to delay anymore.
He prepared five very appropriate messengers,
They were powerful men and great landholders,
Among all the others Roger, count of Nantes,
And the minstrel Saudin the traitor,
The archbishop of Mainz, who knew the arrangement,
And Morant of Hautefeuille, who was their kin,
And Guy of Barcelona, and the count Galleran,
Duke Tholomeus, courteous and handsome,
Ogier of Savine, and Gautier of Clervant,
Henry of Aubespine, a traitorous scoundrel,
The marquis, Belencer, and Teris the powerful.
"[My] lords," said the king, "listen to my intention;
I have sent for you, now I'll explain [my] orders."

lg.head: Laisse 178
lg.l: "[My] lords," said the king, "I have sent for you,
And I'll explain why; now hear me out.
There are two things in this world that I should mention:
Honor and dishonor, for one can [do] no more;
I'll tell you the reason for this, and then I'll conclude.
Count Huon d'Auvergne, when he left us,
Begged me to care for his lady.
I don't wish to be blamed concerning this by any living man;
By sending for the lady as soon as it pleases you,
I believe that honor toward the count and myself will be served.
One never knows what can befall a lady;
Very often those who believed her lose faith in her.
Often a lady is changeable, according to what I have read,
As a tree leaf turns when the wind strikes it.
But if I could do anything, I would prevent
Her from doing anything that would reflect badly on the count or myself.
You'll go to her as soon as it pleases you,
And bring her a hundred greetings from the queen."

lg.head: Laisse 179
lg.l: "[My] lords," said the king, "I have told you the best [thing to be done],
Let Ynide thus come [to stay] with my wife.
She would be more honored, and we will have honor [from this deed];
If you agree to this, let there not be any more delay,
Nothing remains but to go [get] the lady, with joy and jubilation."
The archbishop of Mainz then pretended to weep,
Saying, "O God of glory, true Creator,
I don't believe that there has ever been in this world a more noble-hearted lord,
Wiser or more courtly or more full of sweetness
When he thus bows down to an earthly servant,
To every creature provided they show him love.
Have you heard our emperor,
How he is mindful of our senator[, Count Huon]?
In order to honor his lady, he makes us ambassadors.
Everyone great and small must serve [such a] Ptolemy well.
Now let us go get the lady, in the name of the Creator;
Let everyone be ready at matins close to dawn."
And they replied, "As you wish."
They all bowed to the king, and then they departed.

lg.head: Laisse 180
lg.l: Each one took [his] leave from the king with a bow,
Except for Roger and Saudin and the lord of Mainz,
And Morant d'Hautefeuille---may God grant them grief!---
And Aumeri the traitor, those in whom [Charles] had confidence.
"[My] lords," said the king, "you know my intention;
Love troubles me; it puts me in peril;
If I don't have help through you, there's nothing else to expect
Except a horrible death, without any expiation.
Oh, Ynide, lady more beautiful than a rose!
My love for you constrains me to such a terrible distress,
That without you, beloved, I'll never have solace;
The wretched king of France would die of grief."
Then he collapsed in a faint, so strongly had love overcome him.
His barons raised him back up; such was the pity
That the king inspired (when his [mind] was turned)
In the presence of his barons. A common lamentation,
Like a girl against [her] father in her first youth,
[Asking] that he have mercy on her for her great ignorance,
This is how one acts because of love; such is its custom,
That something black often appears red and white.

lg.head: Laisse 181
lg.l: The barons then sighed when they saw the king's grief,
Saying, "Oh, gentle sire, don't be afraid,
For after the pain joy will come to you next."
Then the king gave them the ring and the purse,
And the great diadem with which he was crowned.
"[My] lords," said the king, "I can certainly tell you,
That it is this heart of mine being sent as tribute,
There is nothing in the world that could please her
That I wouldn't do, I'm dying of this.
I don't know what else to say at this point, I'll leave it to you)
Just accomplish your mission and come back.
Give everyone generous amounts of gold, silver and coins,
Horses and palfreys and expensive silk fabrics.
If you can convince her who wages war on me,
Never will I ask for any other paradise from God."

lg.head: Laisse 182
lg.l: Saudin said, "My lord, have no doubt about it,
For we have brought about many other [such] matters.
It would be impossible [...]
A lady couldn't [...]. "
"Noble sire," said Roger, "this is true."
They took leave of the king. When he embraced them,
At [their] departure, many tears were shed.
Many leave in joy who return in sorrow,
As you'll be able to hear before this story ends.
Close to nightfall, each one got ready,
And the horses and baggage were loaded with riches.
They left Paris just as matins were rung,
They set off as a group by the direct road to Blaye.
They crossed many hills and many valleys,
On the second day they lodged in the city,
For the lord of the town honored them greatly.
On the third day toward matins they took their leave,
And crossed the Gironde river, entering into Gascony.
They found the king at Galleris Castle,
Him and his barons, who were enjoying themselves there.

lg.head: Laisse 183
lg.l: They crossed the drawbridge of Galleris Castle;
The king rejoiced when he recognized them.
He asked about the emperor, how he was doing, and where they were going,
And they replied, "[We're going] for Count Huon's lady."
The king sighed deeply when he understood them:
"[My] lords," said the king, "our ruler is wise,
But whoever gives him advice doesn't please me in this matter,
I don't believe they do well troubling someone else's wife."
"Sire," said the archbishop, "he does it for this,
For the great love that he has for Count Huon."
The king stopped speaking and didn't reply to this,
Just like those who understand the situation, how it's going;
Out of fear, he hid his own feelings.
He spoke of other matters, and they let [the subject] drop.
The king honored [his visitors] as much as he could.
Then at dawn around matins, they took their leave,
They would lodge that night in Charions Castle.

lg.head: Laisse 184
lg.l: Our company was lodged in Charions Castle;
A little before matins, their equipment was loaded,
And their host came out then, and spoke to them thus:
"Where are you going, [my] lords? Tell me your intention,
For you certainly appear to be people keen to do well.
From this point forward there is nothing worth a penny
Either to eat or to drink, if you haven't brought it [with you]
Until you get to Le Mans or Nevers, that strong, established city."
Roger and the archbishop asked him why:
"What is the reason for this?" And he explained it to them,
"[My] lords," said the host, "about a league from here
You'll find a [body of] water that is very calm and wide;
On the other side of this water it is called Auvergne.
The lord who held it went away a long time ago,
[He was] the best knight ever born on earth.
But the one who sent him away is much blamed for it,
Because he thinks to have the lady, and for this reason has sent for her.
But she is so courteous and valiant and wise,
That our emperor's intentions will be in vain."

lg.head: Laisse 185
lg.l: "Barons," said the worthy man, "you have heard me well;
Ever since the count of Auvergne left,
The lady, who is wise, constructed a plan such that
Throughout her lands, three and a half months ago,
There would be gathered into Auvergne
