Bread and wine and foodstuffs and grain and hay,
So that the city and the castle might be provisioned.
And it was all done like that, no one opposed her.
Out of fear of the king everyone has fled.
The country all around has been burned up to the hills;
Not a creature is lodged there, I swear to you this is the truth.
All those who pass get provisions here;
And if you are not friends of the lady,
Be careful which way you go, [my] lords, this I beg of you;
You could well have something [happen to you] not at all to your liking."
The lord of Normandy answered [him] first,
And said to the host: "Listen, fair friend,
We are the ambassadors of the king in Paris;
You appear in good faith, and I have faith in you."
"[My] lords," said Richard, "what is your pleasure--
Go forward or go back?"
Both Roger and Saudin cried out their answers:
"We have no fear of any man alive on earth."

lg.head: Laisse 186
lg.l: Both Roger et Saudin yelled this time
Quite angrily at the lord of Normandy;
"Lord Richard, we know well your arrogance,
And about you, and about others, who don't love the king,
Nor have you ever valued his honor at all.
Whoever wants to go, let him go, since it won't matter,
For what we are supposed to do will be accomplished."
Afterward spoke the lord of Vermandois,
And Guy of Barcelona, who was wise and valiant,
And Duke Tholomeus, who was exceedingly courtly:
"Let's drop this quarrel now, for that would be better,
Because we know how things stand between you.
Everyone knows what's black or indeed violet or blue,
He who would accuse others would surely be very wrong.
He who accuses others gains no praise;
When we are armed to take up and enter combat,
Then we will distinguish light from dark.
For now you should leave the matter for that day."

lg.head: Laisse 187
lg.l: The quarrel was getting quite serious among our barons,
When count Gautier bowed before Roger;
"Lord Roger," he said, "I won't fail to tell you
That venom and antivenin don't go well together.
Loving and hating contradict one another.
There are here seven counts of ancient ancestry,
Each one holds his lands by noble right,
Nor has there ever been among them any lying or trickery,
And there won't be [any] among us if it pleases the Son of Mary.
Let it be according to your pleasure concerning going or staying,
And if you wish otherwise, it doesn't matter to us."
Then Henry, who was full of wickedness, spoke up;
He didn't say at all what he really wanted [to say]:
"Lord Roger," he said, "when a man chastises you,
You must love him for it, that would be courteous,
And he who does otherwise would commit villainy.
We are here in pleasant company;
These [companions] are right and I shouldn't fail to tell you
When you take the whole decision upon yourself."

lg.head: Laisse 188
lg.l: "Roger," said Morant, "he is completely right
When he leaves up to you the yea and the nay."
"Indeed," said the archbishop, "and we recognize it."
"Indeed," said Saudin, "[if we leave], we'll all leave together."
The host called them: "Come now, gentlemen.
Load up, my friends, with what's needed."
And they did it right away, without any delay;
Bread and wine and foodstuffs, cooked meat and fish.
"[My] lords," said the host, "I and my son
And everything I have here is at your disposal,
[For] I and my town belong to King Charles."
"Galleran," said Gautier, "and we are grateful."
They left the castle early, before dawn.
The host accompanied them all the way to Le Mans, to the river;
He escorted them to the other side and then they took their leave;
[The host] turned back and our group continued
The whole day long, until evening fell,
For they found no habitation or house,
Nor man or woman anywhere around there
Except for a chapel [...].

lg.head: Laisse 189
lg.l: Our group lodged inside the chapel;
They sheltered themselves as best they could that night.
As soon as day dawned, each one took to the road,
Looking this way and that all day long,
For they saw no house or habitation anywhere there,
Saying to one another, "This is a great misfortune.""
In such a situation, in such a quandary, they camped on the banks of the Flores,
Such was the name of that river.
There they drank and ate from what they had brought with them,
They talked about this and that;
They traveled by day, once dawn brightened,
All along in the direction they found.
As the sun descended, they arrived at the bridge.
Saudin spoke first since he recognized the porter:
"Galudin, sweet friend, come over here a bit.
We are messengers from France, whom the king sent here.
Once the countess knows this, I do believe she will be pleased;
Go find out. These men will wait for you.
The other answered him: "[My] friend, I won't fail
To take care of your wishes and of you if necessary."

lg.head: Laisse 190
lg.l: Galudin thus took off down the main street,
Until he came to the palace where court was held.
In the main hall built and decorated with gold,
He found the countess sorrowful and upset,
And the assembly of barons was silent and mute.
I'll explain to you why if you'll listen to me,
For that [very] evening a pilgrim had come,
Who told her news that had not pleased her:
That he had seen the count in Jerusalem,
And through his might alone the city had been conquered,
And the people baptized, and our faith adopted.
Then the people great and small wanted to proclaim him king,
That he take possession of earthly glory,
For out of love for him all of Syria would subject itself to him,
And Greece and Turkey and Salonica and Valdrue,
Vermidonois, Valisars, and Tarsia,
Even the Olidans the Mighty of Tartary,
Everyone would trample the faithless king.
"Either he will absolve you of the promise,
Or he will be destroyed and confounded,
And the crown of France will be rendered to you."
The count had an angry reaction to that;
[But] he refused very calmly.

lg.head: Laisse 191
lg.l: "[My] lady," he said, "just as I have told you,
The count refused the position and its benefits;
Two weeks later he took his leave.
Everyone was sorrowful and upset,
Most of them believe that he was lost at sea,
Because no further news was ever heard concerning him.
May God counsel him and those who are left behind."
"Alas," said the countess, "I no longer have any desire to live,
When I have lost my hope and my lord."
She wrung her hands and pulled out her hair;
"Oh, knighthood, what has happened to
Great generosity and perfect honor,
The arm of justice and the tree of virtue,
The counselor of all counselors for the bereft betrayed,
Oh, Christianity, how [...]
Oh, wretched king, if only you had never been born!
Don't you remember, you wretched, wicked man,
Outside of Rome on the battlefield where you were struck down,
And your barons killed and thrown into disorder;
And the Auvergnat who engendered [Huon was] killed,
And the banners [were] struck down and your barons put to flight
Across the mountains and valleys and those craggy hills?
Not a single one of them would have remained
If it were not for Count Huon [strengthened] by the power of Jesus,
You would never have had any more honor on earth;
You have held on to your crown only because of God and my lord."

lg.head: Laisse 192
lg.l: Anyone who might have heard the lady express her sorrow at that time,
Couldn't have had a heart so hard as not to be moved,
[As she continued] saying, "Oh, alas, I have lost my lord,
For only because of me, a miserable sinner,
He who will return [too] late has gone away
And I will die languishing for him."
Then she fainted dead away in a sweat;
Her barons, with tears and weeping, helped her up again.
Throughout the hall there was such a great tumult
That everyone throughout the city, great and small, wept.
At that moment here was Galudin, crying out fearfully
Breaking through the crowd without stopping.
When he saw Ynide, who had gone pale.
He greeted her properly [and] nobly for the love
Of the God of glory, the true Creator:
"[My] lady," he said, "there are ambassadors
Whom the great emperor has sent to you.
What do you command? State your will,
To let them in or not, I'll return [to do it]."

lg.head: Laisse 193
lg.l: "[My] lady," said Galudin, "what is your command?"
"Oh, alas," said Ynide, "just let me be!
I'd rather die than endure any longer."
"[My] lady," said [...]
"Indeed," said Baudoin, "[my] lady, it must be done."
Both Teris and Gautier said exactly the same thing,
And Thomas and the others agreed.
In order to go meet them, properly honoring them,
Many men went out and mounted their horses.
They rode up to the gate without stopping,
Had it opened and had the drawbridge lowered.
The ambassadors entered within;
Saudin the traitor spoke up first:
"Barons," he said, "may God keep you from all harm,
Both you and those who love the emperor,
And may He totally confound villains and scoundrels!"
"Indeed," said Thomas, "and the evil advisors
Who inflict pain and suffering on others."
As these words were said, they went to dismount
In the square; the knights went together
Up to the high hall.
Now you'll hear told and recounted
How one side argued with the other.
The very first one to speak was Roger,
Since he was the king's principal administrator.

lg.head: Laisse 194
lg.l: The ambassadors stopped in the great hall
In front of Ynide, whose head was covered.
Dressed in black, pious and virtuous,
There were hot tears [coursing] down her robe and gown;
The pilgrim had not yet left.
Now you'll hear the deliberation of a lamentable affair;
Roger, who had very great authority, began:
"That Lord of glory, from whom all good appears,
May He grant complete joy to everyone, young and old,
And most of all to the great king [here] on earth;
And to you, noble lady, and to all your family.
The emperor, who possesses this tormented world,
Has sent us here and the reason is this:
[It is] out of love for your lord, whom he loves more heartily
Than Calisor [did] or the king of Guineste,
Or [than] Achilles [loved] Patroclus of Floreste.
It is indeed thus the evident truth,
Seeing that he has given you full authority over him
Solely to honor you, in the name of God the Heavenly King.
You will be together with his wife and his daughter,
I don't know how you could be with more exalted company
Than you will have, if it delights and pleases you,
Until the count comes back from this quest."
"I won't come," said the lady, "by [God's] highest majesty."

lg.head: Laisse 195
lg.l: After Roger, Teris spoke:
"Lady," he said, "the emperor of Paris
Has dispatched and sent us out of great love,
Only to honor both you and the marquis.
By rights he is obliged to do it, for he is his friend."
"True," replied Ynide, "but not all of [what you are saying].
One [thing] is white, and indeed the other gray."
To this comment replied Henry,
The one from Aubespine, a cursed scoundrel,
And Teris uttered nothing else about it.
"Lady," said the scoundrel, "your lord's honor
And that of mine as well cannot be violated.
From this, one might think that you hated him."
"Wretch," said the lady, "you're lying through your teeth,
For I love my lord more than the eyes in my head.
Whoever believed you would be foolish!
Go away, evil, vile man,
For no good ever comes from a base heart,
And if [something good] does come out, it immediately regrets [it].
We know you well [and] what your wishes are."
He retreated, distressed and embarrassed.
The next to speak was Belencer the marquis,
He was wise and courtly, humble and well-bred;
He spoke in good faith, without any bad intention.

lg.head: Laisse 196
lg.l: "Lady," said Belencer, "listen to what I'll say:
The emperor who has sent us in this way,
Sends [us] all the way here for you, [my] lady,
If you please. Indeed, I'll escort you back to France
Just until I deliver you to the king by the hand,
Afterward, if there is anything else, I don't know;
I truly believe that my lord will do you honor;
You'll be staying with his lady and his fair daughter,
You could never find a nobler companion
Than the queen who holds the world in her arms.
There you'll stay until [your lord] comes back,
For which reason [your] status and joy will double.
The king and all his friends will come to you;
I believe I speak rightly and don't know if you will take it wrong."
"Belencer," said the lady, "I'll say one thing to you,
That the words are separated from the music."

lg.head: Laisse 197
lg.l: Belencer fell silent and the lady as well.
Next Morant d'Hautefeuille spoke:
"Fair one," he said, "the king has the intention
To serve you as long as he lives.
He doesn't wish to make a distinction between you and the queen,
[But] to honor you as much as her, together,
Because at departure your lord
Was begging this of [the king] above all things,
And my lord made a vow to him
To take care of you always as long as he lived.
Once you are in his household,
Together with the queen and her lovely daughter,
People will know to kneel and bow down
Who wouldn't pay attention to you on your own;
You'll be more honored than any other person.
Lady, think about whether I speak the truth or lie."
Then he fell silent, looking very pious.
"Morant," said the countess, "and I'll say something.
Your lord speaks kindly, for which I send him thanks.
[But] I would be severely blamed by everyone,
When my lord is undergoing such hardship,
If I went entertaining myself with pleasures.
I would be very loath that you or anyone else
Might in any way scorn me for this.
You have heard me clearly; I won't come at all."
Guy, who possessed Barcelona, replied to this.

lg.head: Laisse 198
lg.l: The lord of Barcelona was very wise;
"Lady," he said, "it is asserted everywhere in the world
That one must show reverence to the crown,
And every creature, horrible, bad and good
Must support the emperor, with [his] wealth or [his] person;
And anyone who does otherwise I don't believe is making a proper effort.
I say this for your sake, fair-faced lady,
That the emperor, whose [name] resounds throughout the world,
Has sent for you; and it seems an excuse to me
That you refuse [to come]. Where does this provocation come from?
The king is not some mercenary or lout;
This is unbelievable, by the body of Saint Anthony,
In good faith, may God be my witness!"
"Friend," said the duchess, "I do believe that only with great difficulty
Could one find in you anything not good,
For one can clearly differentiate the wheat from the chaff."
"Indeed," said Galleran, "and terce from nones."

lg.head: Laisse 199
lg.l: Galleran, the eminent count of Artois, spoke up:
"Lady," he said, "the Roman emperor,
By the advice of those you see here,
In the name of his honor and that of the marquis [your lord],
Requests that you come to France, to [his] glorious kingdom,
You and any [such] company that pleases and delights you.
You must stay with the queen and her daughter with the blond hair
For however many weeks and months [might pass]
Until the count returns from the king's mission.
He does it only to honor you, so I believe,
And out of love for the one whom good men praise.
Now come to him, my lady, for I believe you would be acting properly."
"Friend," said the countess, "you are in good faith,
But old tradition recounts a proverb:
'If someone is overexcited a quick slap will calm them down.'
I say it for this reason: you should leave off now;
You'll go away, [my] lords, and I'll remain here."
"Lady," said Tholomeus, "indeed it is praiseworthy of you
To raise such a ruckus about the order of the king!
Think, my lady, what could happen."
"Friend," said the countess, "I have been thinking about it for a long time,
And for that reason I have replied immediately without delay."

lg.head: Laisse 200
lg.l: Tholomeus fell silent and bowed his head.
Next spoke Ogier of Savine;
He addressed Ynide and said, "Oh, lady of the palace,
You know well that the king holds power over the world,
And can raise or lower [people] in earthly glory.
It is too astonishing, by the Virgin Queen [of Heaven],
That you aren't willing to carry out his wish and his intention.
What is the reason? Do you hate him?"
The rosy-cheeked lady answered,
"Ogier," she said, "you give a truly awful gift
When you ask me the secret of my hatred.
Do you take me, friend, for a simple-minded girl,
Such that my eyes can't distinguish between the rose and the thorn?
I wasn't raised in the woods or in the forest,
But truly in Lille, in Brois or in Menine.
Indeed, my mother was neither a fallen woman nor a servant,
But [rather] was born of Broces, daughter of the duke of Saline.
Her father was the lord of Flanders, up to the sea,
He was esteemed from here to Salumine.
And I am the wife of the count who rules Unverise,
And who is lord of Brabant, of Auvergne and of Cassine,
And Roman senator by the grace of God.
He who reminds me of the pain of my distress does evil!
Now may death and I be very close cousins!"
Tears from her eyes spilled down her breast,
For desire and sorrow ended mixed up together;
She could scarcely keep from falling down to the stone [floor] of the hall.

lg.head: Laisse 201
lg.l: Ynide was in great sorrow, so Ogier fell silent.
The noble count Gautier of Clervant spoke up:
"Lady," he said, "you musn't upset yourself,
Rather you must be completely comforted,
For through tumult and through weighty matters,
And through pain and through trouble
One knows virtue by the end.
You are wise, there's no need for this;
I will say something concerning the emperor's desire
With which we were charged.
He has sent these noble knights to you
Out of love for your lord, whom he loves and holds dear.
Therefore come stay in Paris,
To live with the queen and her daughter
And the other ladies who will love you very much;
You and her daughter will share a bed.
News will arrive there from overseas,
You'll know the truth about the count by messenger
Who comes and goes through foreign lands.
You are wise, I don't want to discuss this with you any longer;
May God grant you the best counsel
So that no creature born of a mother
May ever blame you or the count for this."
Ynide replied, "May God keep you from woe!
It is certainly true, for it can never be hidden,
That the fruit resembles the tree."
"Indeed," said the archbishop, "for the one who must taste it."

lg.head: Laisse 202
lg.l: The archbishop was very noble and had great learning;
He began his discourse very softly.
He raised his eyes toward God as proof
That his very soul must be participating [in his prayer],
And he said, "O true Lord, from Whom all good comes,
Glory in the highest is your habitation,
Send peace on earth, love and consolation,
And grant us perfect knowledge
To carry out such deeds before our death,
So that we may attain the heavenly state,
So that the false angel may have no dominion over us.
You must know, [my] lords, that because of [his] disobedience
It was necessary to expel Adam from Paradise,
[And] suffering and arrogance came upon us.
But I have so much hope in the true Lord
That He will keep us well away from such ignorance.
You are wise, each one of you messengers, such is my understanding,
Obedience is the flower of all virtues.
That is why I say this, I want to remind you,
Because these are the ambassadors of the emperor of France.
With your barons you should consider carefully
That it can actually happen afterward
That sometimes one might later repent.
Having too much arrogance dishonors a lady
And those who believe them make a terrible mistake.
The lady who put the world at risk was a devil."
"[My] lord," replied Ynide, "your sermon is a good one.
If the heart within agreed to it,
It would want to repent without delay."

lg.head: Laisse 203
lg.l: At this point Saudin spoke up,
Humble and somber just like a pilgrim:
"Lady," he said, "if our divine Lord
Had to put together a group of ambassadors for an earthly man,
He could not have assembled men of more noble lineage
Than those sent to you by the heir of Pepin.
There is nothing in this world
Such that, should my lord have such power,
It wouldn't be accomplished for you morning or evening.
So, worthy lady with a noble heart,
Henceforth, without further delay, fulfill
The wish of this great Constantine:
Open the gate of the merciful garden
And apply antivenom where there is poison.
You see here Thomas and Baudoin,
Berart the valiant and Teris and Ullien,
Gautier of Estampes, Corberan and Sanguin.
These are your brothers and uncles and cousins,
Who should accompany you to Paris and Orleans
In order to show that you have submitted to the king
And that you wish to obey his will and his intention."
"Friend," said the lady, "I understand this speech very well.
I would rather be burnt at a pine tree
Than ever come to him. And that will be my final [answer]."

lg.head: Laisse 204
lg.l: "Lady," said Saudin, "tonight you'll think about it;
Tomorrow soon after eating you'll answer us,
For it is time to sleep and to have rest.
Thanks to God and to you, we are well-lodged."
They took their leave and went to their lodging;
The flower of the noblemen accompanied them.
They were well-served and most marvelously honored
With as much food [and] drink as pleased them.
When the meal was over and they had washed their hands,
They spoke together about this and that.
Saudin was clever and sidled up to Thomas;
He lay out and explained many arguments to him.
"Thomas," he said, "I have always loved you,
And you me in your kindness.
You must believe, as honest truth,
That I would want to advise you in good faith:
The king of France, who has sent us here,
Is truly desirous that you be honored;
And where can greater honor be found
Than by obeying the king and doing his will?
And your sister is therefore absolutely wrong,
Seeing that she wants to disobey the emperor,
And anyone who believes her is definitely committing a great folly.
Owing to women, great suffering has been encountered,
And many lands both burned and devastated."
"Sire," said Thomas, "I won't fail
To do everything that will please my lord."

lg.head: Laisse 205
lg.l: Saudin was clever and full of guile.
"Thomas," he said, "I know for certain
That you love the king quite loyally.
Yet entreat your sister most affectionately
To do what the king commands.
Otherwise, know truly for certain
That you could be running into trouble
And experiencing great sorrow and great suffering;
The king is lord, and can do more or less [to you]."
Thomas replied, "By the body of holy Abraham,
He won't fail to carry out his will because of me."
"[My] lord," said Saudin, "you speak wisely."
Roger and Baudoin also spoke together,
As did the archbishop and Berart the captain,
And Morant and Henry bowed to each other.
"[My] lord," said Berart, "I'll tell you my opinion:
Let's leave it until tomorrow, I think,
And then we'll bring an end to this discussion."
All the barons replied, "As you wish."
Half of them left, the other half stayed;
The ambassadors, who had brought great trouble,
Went to bed in the main hall.
Ynide's princes and captains returned to her.

lg.head: Laisse 206
lg.l: "[My] lords," said Ynide, "have those barons been well served?"
"Yes, indeed, [my] lady, to their satisfaction.
How shall we act, [my] lady, toward the felonious king?"
"Very well," she said, "have no doubt about that at all.
Go to bed; we'll talk [about it] tomorrow."
And so they did as soon as they heard the answer.
Ynide of the lovely face
Entered her chamber decorated in the fashion of Solomon's;
Except for a young girl who was still a virgin
Whose name was Tobie, there was no one with her.
She got down on her knees before a crucifix;
She stretched out her hands toward God with great humility,
Tears from her heart rose up to her eyes
And spilled out abundantly on to her breast.
She spoke: "Oh, alas, woe that I was ever born!
Just because of me, sinner that I am,
I see Christianity in great confusion!
O Lord God, please grant me this:
Receive my soul, which is in this wretched vessel,
Let there me no trouble because of me, wretched one.
I would rather be burnt in fire and in coal
Or miserably hanged as one does to thieves,
Than that my lord believe I betrayed him."
Then she picked up a stone and beat herself all over.

lg.head: Laisse 207
lg.l: The noble lady picked up a stone,
Gripping it tightly in her hand, she beat her breast.
She recited a psalm, as you will hear:
"God, have mercy on me and Hail, [Holy] Queen, help!"
Before she reached the Gloria at the end of the psalm,
Ynide had hit and beat herself so much,
That whether she intended it or not, she fell down in a faint.
Tobie saw her and was very worried;
She came to her lady, she wiped her eyes and her mouth,
And when the lady had come to again,
Anyone could have seen her great sorrow
Through [her] weeping, lamenting and tears shed;
There is no heart so cruel that would not have felt pity for her.
"Oh, Tobie," said Ynide, "why have I lived so long?
Oh, horrible Death, what do you want, what have you been waiting for?
Come to me, for I have sought you for a long time!
Oh, king of France, where have you placed [your] love?
If you had known me just as I do myself,
You never would have set off on such a quest.
I would let my heart be cloven
And my soul utterly lost before
I would ever do anything that might please you
From which it might appear that my lord accrues blame."
And then Tobie questioned her.

lg.head: Laisse 208
lg.l: Tobie adopted a very humble expression;
"Oh, my lady," she said, "and what is the king asking for,
That it has upset you so terribly?"
"Tobie," she said, "my body, may God destroy it!
Ah! He won't get what he's asking for in his lifetime."
The maiden fell silent and said nothing else.
Ynide wept repeatedly and frequently,
And said, "O God of glory, truly omnipotent,
Keep the count of Auvergne from sorrow and torment,
And lead [my] lord back healthy and alive,
And grant this king repentance,
And [grant] to me, wretched unhappy one, strength and moderation,
And to my people bravery and boldness,
So that there never be discord among them."
The lady wept and kept lamenting
Until she fell asleep in front of the crucifix.
A little bit after dawn there appeared to her
An elderly man, completely gray-headed.
He had a long beard spilling down his chest,
Bushy eyebrows and a fearsome expression.
Dressed in a hauberk, he had his sword strapped on,
Silk hose and spurs of shining gold,
A golden cap [and] a glove in his hands;
He called to Ynide, gently and sweetly.

lg.head: Laisse 209
lg.l: In a soft voice the knight
Said to Ynide, "My sweet lady,
Always resist the king's desire,
And guard yourself carefully, for the sake of the Virgin Maiden,
From doing anything dishonest or wicked,
For, by that Lord upon whom sinners call,
You could never manage to hide yourself in a chamber or tower
Without being destroyed at the edge of a sharp blade."
The fair Ynide replied with great sorrow:
"Who are you, friend, that you address me in such a manner?
I don't know you, but it seems to my ear--
Since I, poor wretch, was raised as a child in that country
Whose speech it appears to me [you speak]--
I believe you are Flemish, from Bruges."
"Indeed I am, lady, I was lord all the way to Bordeaux;
For eighty-four years I carried its scepter,
You were raised there in my territory.
You never wanted to suck from any creature
Other than your mother, you were so difficult.
One May, that season when flowers bloom,
I gave you to the one who has left for that business;
You were just eleven years old when he gave you the wedding ring."
When she heard this, Ynide's heart leapt.

lg.head: Laisse 210
lg.l: When the lady heard this, her eyes filled with tears;
"Oh, Father," she said, "how much you loved me!
I beg you for mercy, in the name of God the Creator,
May you have pity on this sinner!
Take me away, Father, from pain and suffering;
Carry me away with you now, Father.
I no longer want to exist in this treacherous world,
For I have lost my rightful lord."
"Daughter," said her father, "this cannot yet be.
Have no fear at all of this emperor;
Remain noble and defend your honor,
For you have good people, all dressed in [your] colors.
Now I commend you to the great Redeemer."
Then the noble lady wrung her hands;
She tried to embrace him, but it was completely useless,
For she was awake, dripping with sweat.
Raising herself up, she looked all around;
"Oh, Father," she said, "you have now doubled my sorrow,
If only I were with you now, noble warrior count!"
Tobie awoke, so she recounted to her with gentleness
The entire vision just as the author has written.
Already the ambassadors had come up to the hall.

lg.head: Laisse 211
lg.l: The day was clear and the air was calm,
And the sunlight spilled across the plain.
Baudoin, Thomas, Berart and Ullien
Came to the chamber above the main hall.
Ynide's brothers and cousins addressed her:
"What shall we do concerning the great King Charles?"
"Well, well," said the lady, "in honor of Mary Magdalene,
I wish to hear mass first before I finish discussion."
She came to a chapel dedicated to Saint Helen.
The mass was chanted by an abbot from Grosaine;
The entire church was filled with barons.
In front of the altar on an African silk
Ynide knelt down in pious prostration.
She said: "O true Lord, Whose goodness rules all,
As truly as I believe, and You know it for certain,
That You were God and man in order to conquer fearsome death,
Only to save us, God Almighty,
[From] what our wretched and unfortunate ancestor did.
Oh, how compassionate was Your sovereign Godhead
When, out of pity for us, You sent us Your seed,
Your precious Son to take on human flesh,
And Your supreme virtue gave Him to us
To heal us of that infernal torment
Where everyone is lodged because of the first sin,
As I believe, and you can do more and less.
Have mercy on the one from whom my heart [is] not distant;
And as for that wretched king, grant him a healthy mind,
So that he knows to distinguish the white from the indigo."
The tears in her heart spilled from her eyes like a fountain.

lg.head: Laisse 212
lg.l: The lady wept and sighed deeply,
And when the priest, the great lord, saw it:
"Remember me, gentle and holiest Spirit,
According to our great misery, [grant us] consolation.
I don't know what else to say, but [let it be] according to your will."
After these words they finished the mass.
Ynide and her barons left the church,
Not stopping until they came to the main hall.
The lady had both the good men and the bad seated;
She remained standing in order to reveal her wishes.
Respectfully and honorably, she began to thank
The king of France and those who obey him
When he deigned to send her such a lofty embassy:
"Dido and Candace of Syria would be greatly honored,
But I wish to speak and tell you something, [my] lords,
For this world is false and full of vain desire,
And those who have the most have nothing when they leave it
Except for sorrow and pain and travail and torment.
Honor and dishonor come together at the end
With good or evil, therefore I say without believing that I lie:
You shall leave, [my] lords, we must remain here."
Then Saudin went to Thomas to grab him by the arm;
The archbishop, pretending to laugh, [moved toward] Baudoin,
And Henry--may God curse him--
Who was, to tell the truth, more treacherous
Than even Mohammed to Lachebire) [moved] toward Berart.

lg.head: Laisse 213
lg.l: Roger et Ullien pulled at each other,
And Morant and Robert seized hold of each other;
The archbishop of Mainz spoke up first:
"[My] lords," he said, "I beg you to leave the hall."
And so they did, such that no one remained there
Except for the ones I spoke about before you;
They stopped in front of Ynide.
Then the archbishop began, as you will now be able to hear:
"Lady," he said, "you listen to us.
I am an archbishop, ordained and consecrated;
Do not think, [my] lady, that I desire to damn my soul
For any creature born, be certain of this;
And what I'll say to you is lawful and true,
Just as is the Sanctus that the priest sang.
I have advised you in the good and right path
That you obey the king in all his bidding.
And if you act thus, you'll be honored,
And your family will be exalted by it, [my] lady.
But if you do otherwise, you will be dead and cut to pieces;
No castle or stronghold would be able to protect you.
My lord would be right and you would be proven wrong,
When you refuse to do what he has ordered you [to do].
So help me God, it will be blamed all the more
Since our lord loves you and you hate him."
"[My] lord," said Ynide, "you are very wrong
When you blame me contrary to truth,
For I love my honor more than any creature alive;
For some time, [my] lord, I have refused your proposal,
However you'll never find me otherwise."
"Lady," said Saudin, "this comes from folly."

lg.head: Laisse 214
lg.l: "[My] lords," said Saudin, "if you please,
I will shortly bring these discussions to an end."
And each one replied, "Let it be so without any more delay."
"Henceforth withdraw, [my] lords, and let me tell her
Something she doesn't know but must be revealed to her.
I don't want this heard by anyone except for the lady, Thomas and myself."
So then the others left, withdrawing [to stand] by a column;
Now Saudin began to embellish his speech:
"[My] lady," he said, "I can no longer keep this quiet;
Because of you the king is suffering pain and torment.
Often, [my] lady, you make him dry out and overheat;
Often you make him strip when he should be getting dressed;
Often you make him stay awake when he should be sleeping;
Often you make him call for death to make his soul depart.
And when he should be joyful, you make him languish,
As for eating, you make him feel ill.
When he has been confident, you make him feel lost;
You make him feel the fire of love.
There is no shield that can guard him against you,
Such that your arrow won't shatter it,
Nor can any creature except you,
Who are the doctor, ever heal this wound.
Oh, noble lady, I must beg you for mercy,
In the name of the Holy Spirit,
Which went to swallow death for our sake,
You must henceforth accept his love,
And you must welcome him in your arms,
So that your beauty doesn't kill him."

lg.head: Laisse 215
lg.l: (Laisse 215) Saudin wept, tears falling from his eyes;
He said: "Oh, [my] lady," with a pitiful voice,
"Oh, Ynide, oh, fair one, so what will become of the king?
Must he die in such complete distress?
Oh, think, [my] lady, if it is [to be] renown and praise for you
Or indeed blame and talk and isolation?"
The lady replied, "I have already told you many times,
Lord Saudin, if you remember,
That Charles is in the wrong when he would request of me
Something that leads to my lord's shame."
"[My] lady," said Saudin, "What are you talking about?
Don't you know that no man has any power over love?
I'll tell you something, don't consider it a joke:
I'm not going to stop [speaking] at all on account of Thomas, who is loyal and true,
To whom I give earthly honor. On you lies the burden [of responsibility]
For the peace and repose of Christendom.
And you could thus ruin it all, [my] lady, if it so pleased you."
"How is that possible?" said Ynide, "You'll have to explain that to me."
"[My] lady," said Saudin, "you have the Roman emperor
So trapped and enclosed in your snare
That he wouldn't dare do anything but what pleased you."
"Saudin," said Thomas, "how could this be?
If you can't show me something more certain,
I won't be able to believe it, by the eyes in my head."
"Indeed," said Ynide, "this is all hot air."
"[My] lady," said Saudin, "I'll show you the truth right away."
He went straight back to his companions.

lg.head: Laisse 216
lg.l: Saudin returned to his companions,
He gathered them around him [and] recounted the entire situation:
"[My] lords," he said, "this affair will soon be settled,
So I believe, don't you doubt it."
They listened to him; they thanked him profusely for it.
"Saudin," they said, "you are valiant and sensible;
Dear friend, do as you see fit,
Whatever you do, we'll be completely content."
Saudin and Roger soon retired,
Together they rushed to their lodging.
I could never recount to you in truth
The great treasure that was carried to the palace,
Brought into the hall before Ynide.
This great wealth was laid out there,
To be promised and given to each one.
If He who made the sky and the dew doesn't take care [of them],
It's likely that they will pay too much for those riches;
For you all know well, and it is the truth,
That wealth has already contaminated many people.
Now may God place strength and moderation
Among them, as well as peace and humility!
For man is tempted by two things:
One is wealth, which everyone desires;
The other is love, which has tormented the world.
On these two [things], which have been thoroughly sought,
Evil is entirely based and created.
Now I will speak about Saudin, who desired more than anything
To accomplish the wish of his lord,
And to betray and trick the countess.
May God in His worthy goodness confound him!

lg.head: Laisse 217
lg.l: Before food or drink were served,
Saudin went to the great hall.
He had the great treasure brought with him;
You'll soon hear about this wicked traitor!
He had all the barons come with him;
With Ynide watching, he spoke thus:
"[My] lords," he said, "a noble heart
Cannot fail to feel mercy.
And when [the beloved's heart] fails him, he often ponders
In what way one who has suffered
Pain and torment may earn it.
And if he can't earn it all by himself,
He often considers how someone else might obtain [it],
Either a relative or friend on whom she might rely.
And and the other hand, he must certainly recognize
That in them reign power, courtesy and virtue.
You'll understand why I tell you this:
I've been acting on behalf of the emperor,
For I'm explaining that he might have caused offense without fault."
And he went on recounting exactly how the matter stood:
Whether in error or not, nevertheless it happened.
"But yet our lord has so much good in him,
He wishes to reward you all however he can.
He has sent you all this wealth,
For it to be given and shared out among you;
And once you have distributed and spent it,
You'll have more, however much you please,
For he has given up and separated from Avarice;
He doesn't like her and she doesn't like him;
He has always held Courtesy and Generosity close,
And he kisses them without corrupting them."

lg.head: Laisse 218
lg.l: Saudin stopped speaking with a pious [look on his] face,
For he had explained the emperor's case well.
There was no man of high estate there in that hall
Who didn't say quietly and furtively to his neighbor:
"Saudin spoke well, and who would contradict him?
He must be very wise, by the body of Saint Hilaire!"
At this point Saudin lit up with joy,
Just like one who believes that he's accomplishing his task.
But the ancient scholars have a proverb that says:
"He who doesn't find anyone to contradict him rules all."
Ynide saw their people all standing there completely silent;
No one there came forth to seize the treasure.
"Oh," said the lady, "may the true and supreme Father
Protect me from this powerful Caesar!
This son of the Devil thinks to trick me;
Oh, Mother of God, do not allow him to do so!"
Then, speaking aloud, weeping bitter tears:
"Barons," she said, "what are you contemplating?
Are you asleep? Why are you slumbering?"
Berart replied, hardly delaying an instant:
"Saudin," he said, "have you anything else to show us,
Any other offers to put forth or give?
O truly, Lord, may you also have mercy."

lg.head: Laisse 219
lg.l: "Yes, indeed," said Saudin, who was very wicked.
He came up to Ynide, holding tightly beneath his mantle
The crown, the purse and the ring.
With just Thomas and the lady and himself forming a little group,
He said "[My] lady, the king, Charles Martel,
Offers you himself and his seal.
Never in our time has there been a richer or more beautiful treasure."
He raised [his] mantle and appealed to Thomas:
"Look, [my] lord, I'm certainly not some stooge,"
[He said] only so that [Thomas] wouldn't know why he spoke so quickly.
"Now take [this], [my] lady, don't resist him any longer.
There has never been such a gift since the time of Israel,
The jewels, rubies and carbuncle are worth more
Than the castle Illium of Troy."
A feeble colt would have gone more than half a league
Before anyone young or old spoke up;
Everyone hid under his hat.
Saudin looked around and then redoubled his rant:
"My lady, take this gift for it is not surprising,
For you possess the premier flower on the bush,
Which is the [king's] heart hidden away under such cloth.
He can no more resist you than the lamb can the wolf."
"Saudin," said the lady, "you are a mercenary!"

lg.head: Laisse 220
lg.l: Aloud the lady said "Saudins, you don't know why;
How is it that the king gives me such presents?
I'm not a queen to be crowned."
Saudins replied: "[My] lady, when it pleases you,
You will be proclaimed queen of the entire world."
"Friend," she said, "how could that be?
Explain it to me, so that my brother will hear it."
"[My] lady," said Saudin, "I'll explain it to you thoroughly.
I'll tell you now, [my] lady, how the situation will be:
The emperor of Rome rightly loves you so much,
[Is so] full of desire and burning with love,
That, for your sake, the present queen would be killed,
And then he would marry you in Rome,
And place [you] in the high seat on the wheel."
The lady replied, "All this could be?
And as for my lord, tell me, what would happen to him?"
"Indeed," he said, "well, he will never return.
And if he did return, he would be completely cut down."
The lady stared at him, she rolled her eyes,
And she said, "Evil perjured traitor,
Rascal of a man, wretched and perjured,
Son of a whore, vile stinking bastard !"
After this, the lady cried out so loudly
That the entire hall and palace reverberated,
She said, "Oh, languishing sorrowful one, in an evil hour was I born!
Draw near, barons, and listen
To these traitors full of every kind of cruelty!"

lg.head: Laisse 221
lg.l: Ynide wept and was overtaken by great sorrow,
All her noblemen gathered around there.
Then she recounted to them Saudin's plot.
"[My] lords," she said, "this malevolent traitor
Believes he can trick us in such a manner,
Saying that the king has sent for me,
Because he had sworn and promised it to my lord,
And all these riches and these woven silks,
And these horses and these palfreys from Frisia
He sent you because of his great nobility—
So that they be distributed among you and spent
And the pain and the sorrow done away with.
And with this treasure alone he thinks to separate
You from the one who is prized by good people.
But one thing I'll tell you, don't treat this lightly:
All of this is in order to violate my body,
And for this [reason] they have sent my lord far from me.
Now look at the proof [to see] whether this is the truth!"
She took hold of the crown and the ring and the purse,
[And] as everyone was watching, she hurled [them] down and destroyed [them],
Saying, "Oh, [my] noble people, don't be so covetous
That you would consent to the disgrace of the count or myself!"
She cried out aloud and said, "Oh, sweet Progenitrix,
Mother of God, have mercy on this sinful woman!"

lg.head: Laisse 222
lg.l: When the barons approached to hear their lady,
And how loudly she lamented her sorrows,
And saw the jewels spread out on the floor
As well as the ambassadors turning pale as ash,
They ran toward them just in order to tear [them] to pieces,
Whereupon the lady rushed over to protect them.
And Tholomeus cried out: "We give ourselves up entirely!
We haven't come here to fight with you,
But only to honor [you], according to my understanding.
I beg mercy from you, in the name of the One who allowed himself to be hung from the Cross,
For he who has done no wrong shouldn't have to go to court.
We are seven barons, the least among us is a count;
If we have done anything that could be perceived as evil,
God help the lady and you if you have us hanged."
The archbishop, who didn't wish to hold back any longer, spoke:
"There are those who appear to buy when they want to sell,
And those who think to ascend when they must descend."
"Indeed," said Henry, "and break all their limbs."
"And [those who] bend," said Roger, "when they think to stretch [up]."
"Indeed," said Morant, "and Crassus
Served King Sulla when he intended to attack him,
And king Porus, the great Alexander."
Saudin replied, "And Pelias in the port of Endre
Did the same to Jason when he intended to destroy him.
But I'll tell you something that bears the same stamp:
Some amass money that they have no opportunity to spend."

lg.head: Laisse 223
lg.l: (Laisse 223) "Oh, traitor," said Ynide, "wretched scoundrel!
Once before I told you exactly what I thought
When you brought me greetings from the king,
That if you were ever again seen in Auvergne,
You and your companions would be hanged!"
"[My] lady," said Saudin, "you were wrong."
"Pig!" said Berart. "Be quiet, don't speak again,
For in a short while you'll be hanged.
You're doing just what the son of Daedalus did,
Who believed something that then failed him:
He wanted to be a bird whereas he was born of woman.
But God certainly granted him mercy for it, according to what I've read,
Since he fell from the sky, thinking to soar.
Everyone great and small still mocks them
As they will [mock] all of you before you leave."
"Indeed," said Baudoin, "let [him] be taken,
For I consider it a dishonor that we have endured [this] for so long."
As soon as he said that, [Saudin] was seized and held-
What he said then couldn't be believed-
Before [anyone] had eaten or drunk.
Ynide and her barons gathered in a chamber;
They held a discussion there that would not please others;
It couldn't be otherwise, according to what Isaiah the grammarian,
Who discerned the truth, demonstrated,
For one cannot serve two lords.
This Zeno has told you, who included this saying.

lg.head: Laisse 224
lg.l: After Ynide all her barons entered,
One spoke to the other, settiing out many ideas;
One said to hang [them], another said that they shouldn't;
One said it would be a good thing, another said it wouldn't.
They couldn't agree on how to judge them
For fear of the emperor whom each one dreaded.
But Berart and Baudoin were of one mind,
That they neither deserved nor merited death,
But [did] indeed [merit] some punishment by which they would be chastised,
So that such an embassy would never be carried out [again];
In any case, it would be as Ynide pleased.
Then the countess spoke; listen now to what she said;
She began and laid out wise reasoning:
"[My] lords," she said, "He who saved the world
Forgave [Longinus] for the wound
That he gave Him in His body with a lance,
And even more, He enlightened him;
And with His mouth He said to us and commanded [us to say]
'Forgive us' whom He will then forgive.
Those who have mercy on others, God likewise will have [mercy] on them.
But, if I can, this will be partially observed between us.

lg.head: Laisse 225
lg.l: The lady said, "[My] lords, listen, please:
One acts wrongly ever to take pity on traitors;
On the contrary one should hang [them] right away without delay.
But people who read used to say a proverb
'It is shameful for a wise man when [his own] guilt blames him,'
Nor should a prominent man be a troublemaker.
So think hard [about it], for we are all sinners,
[And] rather, out of reverence for our Redeemer,
Let us commute [their] death sentence in His honor;
But I will shame them, [causing them] humiliation and sorrow."
She asked for four of her servants,
And they rushed willingly to her service.
"What is your pleasure, my lady?" and she said to them:
"Have these ambassadors completely stripped,
And then led right away to the main square,
Barefoot and in their shifts, without finery."
And they replied: "My lady, in the name of the Creator[, right away]."
They returned to the hall. No need to ask, [my] lords,
Whether Charles's men were terribly afraid,
Full of sighs, anguish and sweat!
But the four servants came with a great furor,
Calling out in loud voices: "Oh, debauched scoundrels,
You are dead men today,
Your emperor cannot save you!"
The cries [and] tumult and clamor were so loud,
That everyone great and small came to the palace.
The noise of the hue and cry was great;
The news spread throughout the city.
Absolutely everyone great and small ran to the main square,
Men and women crying out with all their might:
"Absolute death to these traitorous scoundrels!"
At this point, the lady came out of her chamber,
Princes, counts and dukes accompanying her.
The ambassadors had already been completely stripped;
They were barefoot and in their shifts just as I said before.
Berart and Baudoin came in the lead;
The ambassadors saw them [and] said weeping,
"Oh, noble barons, have pity on us!
You are young and valiant knights.
Each one of us has important land holdings
And powerful relatives of our lineage,
Oh, think therefore what could happen
Should we be condemned and killed.
Your desire wouldn't be achieved through this;
Rather there would be war and increased anger."
"Indeed," said the archbishop, "it could not fail
That vengeance would be taken on [you] all.
I am consecrated, blessed and ordained,
And [these are] counts, marquis and knights chosen [by the emperor]."

lg.head: Laisse 227
lg.l: (Laisse 227) The archbishop wept, and his companions lamented,
Just like those who believed they would suffer an extraordinary death,
Saying to one another: "O true Sovereign King,
Exalted, gracious Virgin, have mercy on us!"
But Galeran of Brittany called out loudly:
"Have mercy, my lady, on this captive company!"
Ynide summoned Alisant of Aquitaine:
"Have [them] all shaved for me, such that not a hair remain;
Then have them brought out to the open country,
Beating them with strips of leather as long as they still have blood.
And those you see over there, who are cut from the same cloth,
Make the blood run down to their heels;
And [put] the archbishop in front, make him the leader.
As for Saudin and Roger, take no pity whatsoever on them,
But as for those seven counts, don't spend much time [on them].
Rather, throughout the city, whatever good or ill it leads to,
Have them stop at every crossroads,
And [have] heralds in front who don't fail to proclaim it.
And once you have done this, let them not suffer anymore,
Rather cast them out into the open countryside,
Never let them out of your sight
Until the mountain blocks the sun."

lg.head: Laisse 228
lg.l: "Alisant," said the lady, "you have heard my orders.
Before you return, make sure they have gone so far
That they have crossed over the river; then you'll free them,
And then give them this letter and tell them politely
That they should present it to the king from me."
And they replied, "Just as you wish."
Alisant and Grailet, Melians and Gralant,
And many others of their household, with a demeanor of fierce pride,
Conducted the ambassadors away from the square.
Don't ask, [my] lords, if the crowd was large
With men, women, old men and children;
Great racket and noise and tumult,
With cries and shrieks, horses colliding,
Soil and earth torn apart, like at the end of the world.
The ambassadors trembled, seeing this,
Everyone running in a furor, full of outrage,
Crying out, "Death, death to these foul deceivers,
Who tried to trick our lady through treachery,
And our barons with gold and silver!
May it not please God that they live a long time!
All of them should be dismembered and thrown into a burning fire,
And the ashes tossed into the wind to be blown away,
So that there never be anything left of them anymore."

lg.head: Laisse 229
lg.l: The din was deafening, and the cries
Of youths, old men and young squires redoubled.
The ambassadors might have already been killed and hacked to pieces,
For the armed men were useless in this situation,
For everyone was shrieking: "Death to the king of Saint Denis
And those who love him and those who would follow him!"
There was no more respite for them after these words.
Once the countess had heard the news [of what was happening],
As fast as she could, she ran through the palace,
Went to a window, then peeked out.
She took great handfuls of money
And tossed them down to both rich men and beggars.
And once she had stopped the people with the money,
They let go and abandoned the ambassadors;
They ran to the loot in [groups of] ten and twenty and thirty.
Berart and Baudoin armed themselves well,
[As did] Thomas and Ullien, Robert and Anseïs,
A good thousand [men] wearing armor mounted horses.
They surrounded the ambassadors,
[Who were] sorrowful and overcome by fear,
Exhausted and anxious, cold and pallid,
Just like those who are dead and gone.
They kept their heads down as if dead.

lg.head: Laisse 230
lg.l: The twelve barons were completely terrified,
Destroyed and overcome with great anguish.
At that moment, here came Berart and Baudoin the marquis,
And Thomas and Ullien and Robert and Anseïs.
Duke Guy spoke to them in a low voice:
"What's going to happen to us, noble knights of renown?
For we haven't merited death at all;
It's proper for us to carry out the pleasure and the commands of the king."
And they replied: "[My] lords, don't be dismayed."
Then the heralds, who had raised the hue and cry
In Ynide's name, [cried out] that everyone was to quiet down,
And they did so; there was no further delay.
Then Ynide spoke, once she could be heard;
She said: "Oh, worthy folk, noble people, subjects!
I truly know well that you love me faithfully!
Let justice be carried out; I beg you to have mercy on them."
Everyone cried out: "Lady, as you please!"
Then the noise and tumult and cries quieted down.
For this reason the sage tells a wise parable:
The anger of the people is cursed by God,
For together they act like sheep;
When a hundred of them or twenty or ten are together,
They think to graze in the lushest pasture,
But [just] a boy with a little stick
Makes them run and change their direction.
If one falls, the next one falls over him;
So people do out of fear of authority.
Let's drop this [subject], for Jesus Christ knows it well.

lg.head: Laisse 231
lg.l: Now let's leave that [subject] to the One who knows everything,
So that each one be blessed according to [their] acts;
Now I need to return to my moral tale.
Twelve sergeants prepared themselves,
Holding leather strips. When the trumpets sounded,
They then began whipping the ambassadors,
They stopped at each crossroad,
And the heralds told the whole story.
They led them throughout the city in this way
Up to the city gate, because they didn't stop.
Whoever looked at Roger and Saudin, how they were,
[As well as] the archbishop and Henry and Morant who couldn't bear it,
[Saw] blood flowing down from all over them.
But the other barons had hardly been touched.
At that point Berart and Baudoin ordered:
"Don't hit them anymore for that's enough."
And the others did so, and then expelled them,
Too bloody to eat or drink;
Alisant led them to the river,
And then he gave the letter to the archbishop:
"Give this to the king from my lady.
Henceforth go to whatever place pleases you.
Forgive me for whatever might have been done to you."
"Sire," said the archbishop, "we will always have affection for you.
Are we now released?" And the other replied, "Yes."

lg.head: Laisse 232
lg.l: I don't believe that even Adam felt more complete joy
On the very first morning,
When he felt the sweet gracious hand
That first formed him into this life,
When it was said "Behold [My] hand"-for I've indeed heard it,
That He formed us most holy and sweet and pious-
Nor did the prophets have [greater joy] with their company
When they were led into the holy way,
Than the joy that the archbishop and that group of barons
Had when they heard those words.
[Ynide's men] commended them to the Son of Holy Mary,
Then they returned for they didn't delay at all;
Thus they finished the mission for their lady.
Ynide divided up the great treasure [the ambassadors had brought]
Between the poor people and her barons.
The diadem, the ring, the jeweled purse
She sent to a rich abbey
Belonging to the order of Saint Margery.
There was an abbess there who was elderly and white-haired;
She was the count's aunt; she was full of wisdom.
There hasn't been anyone wiser since the time of Jeremiah;
She had already lived and completed a hundred and four years.
She pried off and buried the jewels,
Never were they taken by anyone
Before the count returned from his mission.
May He who holds the world in His power guide him!

lg.head: Laisse 233
lg.l: Concerning both the nun and Ynide
I need to leave off, and instead I'll tell you
How the ambassadors were pressing on.
No one who has ever been beaten or whipped
Can manage more than a trot.
They often turned back toward the old castle
To see if other people were following them.
For this reason the sage says--which is a wise proverb--
"One who has felt fire should truly be afraid
For good is recognized through evil."
All day long they walked together, preoccupied,
While no one spoke. Then it was past midnight,
When several of them were so exhausted and slowed down,
That, since their souls were leaving their bodies,
They collapsed on the spot whether they wanted to or not.
Tears falling from their eyes, they offered thanks to God
That He delivered them from the hands of Ynide.
Then they spoke to one another, saying:
"What shall we do? For we're in a very bad way.
May God, the Lord of Paradise, advise us!"
They had nothing to eat, but they drank some water.
They stayed there until day dawned;
Don't ask, [my] lords, in the name of God who doesn't lie,
Whether the pain of their wounds increased as it grew cold.

lg.head: Laisse 234
lg.l: (Laisse 234) The pain of their wounds caused them much agony;
The moon set and the sun rose.
But Saudin and Roger and the false archbishop,
As well as Morant and Henry spoke among themselves:
"If the Heavenly Lord doesn't perform a miracle for us,
We'll never see the great emperor again."
And then they started off, lamenting their suffering;
They walked all day long, never finding lodging,
Thus they ate nothing; they came across no vassal,
Not a man or a woman, young nor old,
Nor any creature other than beasts and birds.
That night they took their lodging alongside an uncultivated field;
Each one of them collapsed because of his great hunger.
They had no bedclothes of silk or scarlet or sendal,
Nothing other than the earth and the open ground.
That night they slept on the thick grass,
There was no other bed, nor carpet spread out.
Their suffering increased still more:
At about midnight the open space was disturbed,
For the sky darkened and the air appeared [to be] colored
With gold and azure, it seemed it had been split by fire!
Lightening descended and fine hailstones,
It rained and stormed, just as we have read,
Without ceasing until dawn appeared.
Don't ask, barons, since there's no need,
If they felt sorrow and pain from these things.
It's a marvel that each one was not separated from his soul;
But it couldn't happen for it didn't please God.
The storm passed on and the weather changed;
The sun rose, it gave off its brightness,
Spreading out over the countryside all around.
When the barons felt the warmth,
Together they got on their knees;
They stretched their hands out to God,
Most gratefully did they greet and thank Him:
"Remember us, O Lord, for we needed [it],
According to your great mercy."
And once they had recited the Gloria after the psalm
[And] beaten their breasts, they set off on the road,
Grieving and weeping over what had happened to them.

lg.head: Laisse 236
lg.l: The next day once mass had been heard,
The count of Auvergne didn't want to tarry at all.
He called on the lord of the ancient city,
With him [were] all the noble barons:
"[My] lord," he said, "it is now incumbent upon me
To leave your company, which saddens my heart.
If people wouldn't reproach me with cowardice,
And I wouldn't be deceiving my lord,
I wouldn't leave here for any riches whatsoever.
I have been very pleased by your holy life
In which you practice no deception among yourselves.
Please direct your prayers for me
To that God who has all of us in His keeping,
So that He send me what I desire,
However much I might find it foolish
To go seeking the Devil's kingdom.
Even if I live as long as Jeremiah,
I will never return to my lands
-If that's [even] possible-until I carry out
My mission in the great place of darkness,
Or I will die, so that no one speaks ill of me.
I thank you for the great courtesy
Of having provisioned this ship
With hardtack and grain for the horse;
For a whole year and more I'm now well-supplied;
May God grant you a good reward for my sake."

lg.head: Laisse 237
lg.l: All around the count there was great lamentation
From knights, ladies, the young and the white-bearded.
Tadeus, who was bailiff of the town,
Weeping, took hold of him by his chain-mail hauberk:
"Loyal man, brother, you have truly upset me,
When I hear of your going to a cruel country
Where no man who has ever been alive has gone.
It is quite impossible, so is it written;
May God grant [it] to you, since you have good faith.
I don't know what else to say; may He have mercy on you;
One thing I will say, don't think it foolish:
Once you have passed between these high mountains,
You'll find no more humans of living flesh.
Indeed you won't find gardens or blooming woods;
Only leopards, lions and ferocious bears,
Serpents, vermin, huge flying birds.
Indeed, believe me, I don't think that will be the worst;
So you should leave this prize war horse here,
Who is so good and of great worth:
The dangerous beasts will kill him.
I'll pray to God and the Holy Mother
That They both keep you from being killed.
By the faith I owe the Holy Spirit,
You have aroused much pity in my heart,
Such that I am grieving seeing that you ever came here.
Huon, dear brother, my good close friend,
May the One who was crucified grant you grace,
That I may see you once again healthy and hearty,
May you yet find all that you have been seeking.
My heart says to me, thus I feel certain and sure of it,
That for such a one as you are
The Lord of Paradise will do great wonders.
If I didn't believe that you would be wronging God,
I would come with you, so willing am I."
"I wish to go alone in order not to be reproached,"
Huon replied. "May God reward you."
[Prester] John's nephew put his arms around [Huon's] neck;
Huon kissed him and said, "Noble Tadeus,
This foreign man is leaving you,
Whom he loves more than a brother or cousin.
Pray to our Lord Jesus Christ for me,
May He allow me to accomplish everything I have undertaken."
With these words he took hold of the prize war horse,
Put the ship's rope over the [horse's] chest,
And the marquis led him by the bit
Along the bank of the river Tigris;
Everyone big and small wept for him.

lg.head: Laisse 238
lg.l: The good people grieved exceedingly
For the nobleman who was enduring such an arduous journey.
The count set off according to the will of God
Led forward by his hope in Him.
He traveled on foot like a wayfarer,
Leading the charger by the bit;
Never before had a ship had such a steersman;
Thus the good war horse pulled [the ship] at a trot.
The count traveled until the sun set;
He made camp once night was near.
He provided for himself and for the charger as well;
[Huon] gave him as much grain as he wanted.
He satisfied himself with bread [and] water,
He required no other food at all.
As day dawned, he set out traveling;
He continued his journey, going by foot every day.
I'm not going to recount to you their journey,
Except that he always endured great hardship.
He rested little and yet he was satisfied;
There has never been a man of such good sense!
He could have had an easy life, yet he went off seeking hardship.
He traveled a long time along the flowing river
Until he passed beyond the great mountain,
Where, Tadeus said, from there [going] forward
He wouldn't find any living creature
Except for dangerous beasts, serpents and flying birds.
The count, as he walked, remembering this,
Called upon God the Father frequently and repeatedly.
And then in that place he made camp,
Giving the horse as much oats as he wanted.
On his knees he bowed5 toward the east;
He stretched his hands toward Almighty God,
Rendered thanks both to Him and to His Mother;
He prayed devoutly to Them, if it please Them,
That he be able to accomplish what he wanted.
In spite of pain or anguish, he wouldn't give up
"Without doing my utmost in what I'm strivng for,
So long as I'm alive, God willing."

lg.head: Laisse 239
lg.l: The count arose once he had finished his prayers;
Went to the ship and then boarded it.
He ate some bread, for he had no other food,
And drank some water; with that he was satisfied.
He led the worthy horse on to the ship,
He lay down close to him, he rested a little.
At night he fell asleep, for nothing disturbed him.
But henceforth he will never be confident at all;
Frequently he will come across great tribulation.
If he survives it, truly it will be a story to tell;
Never from such [an undertaking] has any vassal survived.
Night passed and day returned;
The baron Huon got himself ready,
Crossed himself, commended himself to God;
He got off the ship, leaving his war horse there.
He wanted to spare him as best he could;
He tied the rope tightly around himself,
He placed it around his chest and bent over.
The count was tall and strong, he pulled it well
For at least ten leagues during which the count didn't tire.
Never has any knight--you mustn't ever disbelieve this--
Endured so much hardship for his lord.
He labored so hard until nones
That he advanced a full ten leagues on his path.
When hunger troubled him, the baron stopped;
He fixed a post [into the ground] and tied the ship to it.

lg.head: Laisse 240
lg.l: The loyal-hearted count of Auvergne
Led his horse along the river;
Never had there been such a horse since Bucephalus.
Odinel recounts that he was just like
Alexander's [horse] in his head and chest;
[Huon] won him in Cappadocia the day
That he killed Roisel, the emir's son,
And then he had the land and the kingdom
In his power; finally he designated its ruler.
He taught him goodness, he got him to stop doing evil.
Let's turn back now to [our] subject.
The kind-hearted baron fed [the horse],
Then he seated himself in a wild spot.
Once he had prayed to the Heavenly King
That He not look unkindly on what he was seeking [to do],
He ate his bread, for he wished for nothing else;
Other than the day he had left his land,
He had tasted of no other food
Except some roots from plants in the woods.
I tell you, without fail, no mortal man
Ever lived in penance in a holier way
Than this one, by God in Heaven,
In order to find the infernal Devil
Whom he then found inside the eternal ice--
Not even Galahad who conquered the Grail!

lg.head: Laisse 241
lg.l: By the time the count had eaten and drunk,
The sun had already set.
"Horse," said Huon, "it has been destined for you
To live with hardship; in fact I am prepared for it
To have it thus all the days of my life
I know for sure that what I seek is folly,
But never in my life will I be forsworn.
I prefer death to breaking my word.
But if it please the King of majesty,
He will deliver me from this great difficulty.
He won't count my great sins against me;
As for my quest, if it can be completed
And I return to the kingdom where I was born,
You will be well compensated for your tribulation.
I feel very great pity for you;
You cannot understand and for that reason great sin lies upon me."
Having said that, he tarried there no longer;
He tied the rope around the golden saddle-bow,
He struck the horse on his dappled rump,
And then he cried out to him, saying "Come on, let's go."
So [the horse] set out along the riverbank;
Thus they continued, both of them in motion
All day long until it was evening.

lg.head: Laisse 242
lg.l: When night fell, in the gloomy air
Next to the Tigris, before a high hill,
The noble warrior made camp.
During that night he felt a great apprehension,
For the air was shaken and great darkness came.
It thundered, lightninged, and thunderbolts cast great light;
The weather turned cold, the count became afraid.
The earth cracked, [as did] the rocks and the trees,
Within a short space of time the air was so frozen
That the count shivered, both he and the war horse.
They had no time or respite to sleep,
And [Huon] behaved like a stalwart warrior
Who bore this hardship with patience;
He didn't run off in any direction.
Rather, as a sinner, he called upon God,
And prayed to him in tears and in lamentation:
"O, take pity on me, Jesus my Lord!
In the name of Mary Magdalene, who was sister to the one
Who rose from death on the fourth day,
Remember me in this [my] weakness!"
Once he had said this, he felt a heat;
Like a reeking cloud, a stink issued forth,
Strong and horrible and with an awful smell,
So that even the swift war horse
Trembled and continually rolled his head around.
He wanted to break away from the burden of the bridle;
He wanted to flee, but the noble warrior
Held him back gently out of affection.
He was drenched in sweat from this exertion;
If God, the Divine Sweetness, does not think [to help],
This struggle will soon get much worse.

lg.head: Laisse 243
lg.l: When the torment of the stinking cloud
Had passed, the clear dawn appeared,
And the riverbank was covered with birds.
The count recited, "Hail, Queen, Mother [of God]."
His prayer over, [now] he made his entreaty:
"O true God, since I am a sinner,
I plead with you, be my protector,
So that I not be shamed and in some evil way!
Hear my prayer for help, Father!"
Then he said, "Glory to the Father," and finished his prayer.
Next he arose with a gentle expression;
He took his equipment and climbed up a rock
Just in order to see; the noble count [...]
Entirely on foot to where it was most difficult;
He looked all around, in front and behind,
He saw no habitation of wood or stone,
Nothing but the woods and the thick forest.
Then he really wished he had believed his friend [Tadeus]:
"Oh, God," he said, "what a fix I'm in!
The situation of Duke Naimon of Baveria was nothing
When he went to [see] the demon Agolant.
O God, true Judge of glory,
Come to my rescue and in such a way
As you did for him when he was a messenger!
Thus my promise will remain truthful,
That is, I will never turn back,
Thus I'll carry out the emperor's desire."
He made the sign of the cross in front of his visor.

lg.head: Laisse 244
lg.l: The count descended from the high hill;
He took the rope and tied it to the saddle-bow.
"Let's go on, in the name of Jesus Christ,
May He grant me what I've asked for."
The good horse set himself on the rough road,
With much great effort they passed the heath.
One might hardly believe how much distress they endured.
Once they were beyond the wide moors,
They found a river which pleased them greatly;
The horse neighed from great joy.
It would have been rather better had he not done that;
For he had hardly moved when two leopards came out
Of the great woods, for which reason the count stopped short.
The good war horse shuddered from fright,
If he had been allowed, he would have quickly run away.
Huon cried out, then he placed himself in front.

lg.head: Laisse 245
lg.l: (Laisse 245) The leopards moved with great energy;
With great temerity they dashed out of the wasteland.
The war horse trembled as they came toward him;
Even Huon was greatly worried by this,
But he never showed the least bit of cowardice:
On the contrary, he placed himself in front of his grey horse,
His naked sword in hand, serving as his standard.
He didn't act at all like a foolish simpleton;
One of the two he struck right away, the boldest one.
Immediately he sliced off a foot on one side,
Then he attacked it and stepped back from the other.
This one fell down dead, but Huon stayed on guard against the other.

lg.head: Laisse 246
lg.l: When the second [leopard] saw the other fall,
He yelped, then began to flee
It made the earth shake with such force,
It made the country all around echo.
Then you saw multiple beasts coming out
Of the woods; but they didn't dare approach
When they saw the other [beast] lying dead.
Behold a lioness, who caused much fear,
Roaring as it went seeking food for its cubs.
It saw the horse, and began to drool;
The count saw it and had no intention of treating this lightly.
He placed himself in front of the horse in order to defend [him]
And drew [his] sword and rushed to fight [the lioness],
Then he struck the beast; he he cut through it with his blade.
Just as it thought to seize the good horse,
Huon, a master of swordplay, smote it.
Such a blow he gave it in their battle
That it should have well pleased anyone:
He cut off its right leg from the trunk.
The blade advanced, he couldn't hold it back;
He cut off part of its head.
He struck it dead, then he began to bless
The name of Jesus, who had consented to [help] him.

lg.head: Laisse 247
lg.l: Listen, [my] lords, people
Should continually recognize their danger,
And leave an evil place right away
When one sees harm suddenly approaching.
Similarly the animal that's in that situation
Flees when it sees mortal danger,
It doesn't dare remain or tarry there.
In any case the count didn't wait any longer;
He shouted to [his horse] and very quickly
Went to his ship and took hold of the rope
And put it on his horse.
He set himself back on his way along the riverbank,
Guiding the ship with great strength
And leading the good, swift horse by his bit.
A huge bird came, stretched out toward the horse;
It thought to seize him, but Huon defended him.
With his sword he gave it such a blow
That he sliced off its wing and foot together.
[The bird] fell to the earth, for it was worthless.
[According to] one who would tell it accurately,
It was larger than an ox, to [my] knowledge.
But when the count saw it there clearly dead,
He thanked God the Father, indeed he blessed Him continually,
Chanting a prayer most devoutly:
"Lord, you open my lips," [he said] with much weeping,
"And my mouth very often,
Will proclaim the glory of your coming."
As for himself, great emotion overcame him,
Such that his tears wet his garments.
Then the baron prostrated himself in prayer,
But he feared greatly for himself and his horse.
These words spoken, the valiant man arose;
He recommenced his journey, going along swiftly.
He looked around often both ahead and behind;
He thought he might be taken by surprise but he was very much on careful guard.

lg.head: Laisse 248
lg.l: Thus he went, hurrying down the path,
He and his ship that went swiftly down the river.
He personally suffered great distress,
He and his horse walked both day and night;
When it was time, Huon gave [his horse] grain.
They rode hard until the hour of nones
Without having seen any person or creature
Except for leopards and bird and lions
That he counted as nothing.
Those that attack [Huon] indeed get from him a bad reward;
When he strikes with his good sword,
He puts them to death, with such a judgment he sentences them.
One Wednesday, about the hour of nones,
As Odinel recounts, he came across something
On account of which he had great wonder and great difficulty:
While he was recovering, he saw up ahead
On the shore of the Tigris what seemed to be three maidens
Singing in his language because love was calling them.
When the count, on that horrible road, thus saw
The maidens singing, gathering togehter before him,
He forgot his great sorrow as he heard their words.

lg.head: Laisse 249
lg.l: Each one of them possessed great beauty;
Their eyes were gray-blue and their cheeks were fresh,
Red and white like roses on the branch;
Their braids hung down over their shoulders
In front of their breasts springing up on their chests.
Each one of them sang and they played their vielles
So sweetly that all through these little valleys
These swift animals ran to them.
The count cried out, "Queen of maidens,
I have seen marvel upon marvel."
And then he asked, "Who are you, damsels?"

lg.head: Laisse 250
lg.l: The count led his ship toward the three;
When he was close to them, his horse stopped.
He saw them dressed in the French fashion;
They had gray-blue eyes, and their complexions were clear and fresh,
[And] vermillion in color, and their tresses completely blond;
At this marvel he made the sign of the cross.
This made them laugh while making eyes at him;
The count called out, "What are you doing in these woods?"
They said, with amorous looks:
"Welcome, stranger knight,
What are you seeking? You seem to be suffering a lot!
It seems you have had no rest for a long while;
Don't lose your soul, don't kill yourself;
Stay with us; you'll be acting as a brave man,
And you'll be served just as you would like."

lg.head: Laisse 251
lg.l: The count quickly greeted them;
They responded to him with a look of ardor:
"Welcome, stranger knight.
Do you wish indeed to speak a little about love?
What are you doing here among us on this journey?
We have never had a greater marvel,
For never since ancient times
Has any sinful man arrived in these parts."
And he answered without any delay:
"I have come here along the river in service
To a lord; although it may be foolish,
I have to spend my life [in this way] day after day.
It has been seven years, if I'm not mistaken,
That I haven't seen my lord or my wife.
I don't know where I'm going; I'm truly in great distress.
Seeing you makes me homesick,
Remembering my country right now."

lg.head: Laisse 252
lg.l: Once the valiant knight had said this,
He wept a few tears;
He began to remember his home,
How he used to live in great honor,
[But] now he went begging like a wretched pilgrim;
He almost gave up the idea of taking another step.
[But then] he began to remember his oath,
Right away he wrested himself away from these bad thoughts.
He beat his breast, then he looked up
And saw the ladies laughing and jesting.
The second one said, "Vassal, don't be dismayed;
Instead tell us more about your quest;
You were born in France, according to your language.
How did you cross the Red Sea?"
The baron said, "So listen to me recount
Who I am, what I am asking for and what I seek.
Whatever you're accustomed to reacting to
With pity, I will make you weep:
I have a lord who is called Charles;
He has the entire world under his rule.
There is no man, king, duke or prince
Who does not serve him out of love or for money.
A vain desire came to him,
So that he had me swear on the saints in front of him
That I would go find Hell.
I must ask the great Devil
If he is willing to bow before my lord,
And [I must say] that he must send [Charles] tribute,
And if not, he will come to fight him.
[Charles] will pursue him until he finds him,
He will want to demonstrate his great wrath to him.
It is a grievous thing to anger [Charles];
This is the charge that I must now fulfill;
I must never return to him
If I have not first descended into Hell,
So that I can describe both the entrance and the exit,
What kind of army [the Devil] will be able to assemble.
I've suffered for more than six whole years;
I don't know how to find it, nor who might be able to show it [to me].
No more sorrowful man was ever born of woman!
You who have me recount my mission,
Explain to me this great marvel.
How do you know how to speak correct French thus
And come to inhabit such a place
Completely full of vermin and beasts?
They have caused me quite a lot of pain and harm,
Because of them I can scarcely rest.
Do you have another home? You mustn't hide it from me."

lg.head: Laisse 253
lg.l: The count said, "Tell me, fair companions,
How is it that you are in this wilderness?
Who brought you to this strange land?
It appears to me that you come
From the good country of King Charles the Great."
One of them said to him, "Since you want someone to tell you
About our situation which will make your heart grieve,
You must know that our leader
Is a lady near that mountain.
