Neither Medea nor Helen was as beautiful,
There is no one like her from here all the way to Brittany.
She is the truly the queen of necromancy:
She knows more about it, I tell you without deception,
Than many instructors from Toledo in Spain might know.
She'll tell you truthfully, without lying
About the marvels that your heart might scorn."

lg.head: Laisse 254
lg.l: "Furthermore, vassal, I'll tell you whatever you wish to know:
Our ancestors, who had us settle and remain here
In such an abode,
Were from France, from that glorious dwelling-place.
At that time when Alexander set his troops in motion
In order to possess the entire world,
And he came here to see these trees
So that they tell the truth concerning his fate,
The peers of France, perforce by necessity,
Sent him tribute and great riches.
Three hundred envoys, each one with great authority,
Came of their own free will, accompanied by their ladies,
To see and meet Alexander.
They brought maidens and officers and riches;
Once they had passed where King Porus reigns,
They followed close behind Alexander's army.
But one evening they lost the path;
When they looked, they couldn't find it.
Among these woods, indeed, over in this direction,
There is a city that belonged to Duke Saloire;
All others beside that splendid kingdom
Don't amount to the value of a single pear.
There one finds the best food and drink;
All spices bloom there, [including] mandrake.
If you go there (there is no disbelieving this),
You could never get enough;
We have no suffering, only true joy.

lg.head: Laisse 255
lg.l: Furthermore, vassal, I tell you, if you go there
To see this lady of great power,
You wouldn't be able to leave in the morning.
The beautiful city, the forests and the garden
So delighted our ancestral lineage,
That they have remained here until this day.
When they lost track of Alexander,
They stayed there, until their end.
From them were born girls and boys,
With whom this, our territory, was populated.
From this land you can take away the trick [to finding Hell]
With which you can accomplish your entire quest.
The noble lady to whom we are devoted
Is very knowledgeable in magic.
If you can get close to her,
You will have the land and the control of the land.
And then you will know exactly how to do it,
How you might enter [the land of] the fallen angels."

lg.head: Laisse 256
lg.l: "May it not please God," answered Count Huon,
"Nor my wife, when I have so much reason
To love her without any betrayal
That I ever deal wrongfully in magic.
There will be no occasion owing to my error
To act any way but well toward me,
For I have no wish to speak like the Devil.
But I will certainly come to your dwelling,
In order to see your lady [and] speak to your barons;
None of her chants or readings
Can make me change my intention.
This thing that I'm seeking,
I know [it's] impossible, and I know it well,
If it doesn't please the Lord of Heaven.
Scripture speaks of it, we know that well.
[Her enchantments] can surely reveal in shadow forms what doesn't exist,
However I clearly must be there in person
And relate my message to [the Devil] for Charles.
I know well this cannot be; you speak in vain.
But I am quite troubled about something:
I fear that in these parts where I now am,
There are no living creatures other than spirits.
In parting from me, Tadeus in Libya
Swore to me in the presence of many worthy men,
That in this region here where I have come,
I would find no one of normal birth.
Almost two months while I have been wandering in misery,
I have found nothing except for evil beasts
And vermin, of which there has been an abundance.
I have suffered greatly much hardship;
How can this be, that you live
In a savage place from which no one takes anything good?"
They said, "Vassal, we have told you
What people we are and what [kind of] life we lead.
We have both body and soul together,
And if you have any doubt about that,
Touch us on the hips and chin;
Then you'll feel whether we are flesh or not."
The count swore by Saint Peter of Rome:
"I'll come with you, be it well or ill."

lg.head: Laisse 257
lg.l: The noble count, without bad intent,
Came to a tree, cut off a branch of it.
He shaped it into a stake with his sharp sword;
Once he had stuck it [in the ground], which he did without delay,
He attached his ship [to it], then said without any fear
To the maidens, "Whenever it pleases you,
My ladies, I am at your disposal,
[Riding] this valiant war horse,,
To go see your home."
Then the messenger from France mounted up;
If he can't now maintain the habit
Of chastity because of his great abstinence,
Never will such misfortune have befallen a sinner,
For the devils will work their power
To lead him to a bad outcome.
Now may God grant him strength and temperance!
He'll need it, know this without mistake.

lg.head: Laisse 258
lg.l: Near the damsels, who seemed from noble lineage,
Rode Huon, without any bad intention;
The three in front, in order to shorten their journey,
Sang a song in their language
The better to attract the messenger to them.
The little birds who are in the forest
On the trees when the [spring] season arrives
Don't know the way to sing [any better]
Than [the damsels] did for love of the messenger.
As they came out of that uninhabited place,
They found fields, woods and the riverbank,
And foliage and meadows of spice plants;
From them wafted a pungent fragrance to their noses!
Before him [Huon] saw a large, wide castle;
He had never seen such a beautiful one in his life;
It pleased the count in his heart more
Than the city of Carthage pleased Dido.

lg.head: Laisse 259
lg.l: The castle appeared to be very beautiful;
Seeing it, [Huon] marvelled greatly at it.
The towers were high, there were more than a hundred towers;
Even freezing snow isn't as bright
As the pillars of fine shining gold.
Around the walls flowed a great river
Much clearer than German crystal.
One could see huge fish all the way down
On the bottom as they swam along.
The count continued looking along the wall;
He saw maidens and youths singing.
They walked two by two holding hands;
When they saw him, both him and his charger,
They left off singing and dancing a carole right away,
And descended quickly from the wall.
Just as the count entered the estate,
The maidens placed themselves in front;
On their faces there was nothing but laughter.
The count said to them, "May God keep you, fair people!"
No one responded to what he said at all,
But laughing, they bowed to him many times
And made it obvious how much they marveled
At the arrival of this knight errant.

lg.head: Laisse 260
lg.l: Whenever two great armies have fought in the field,
The messenger departs from those who had fought and won
---Solely in order to be granted booty by their lord---
And then returns to the place from which they had come,
After having earned such good fortune.
When he is seen by the people,
Entering rejoicing, grasping a leafy branch,
Everyone great and small runs up to him
And asks, "What news do you have?"
When [the knight] answers, everyone grows completely silent
In order to hear what they most desire.
In that very manner, when the count came,
Everyone looked at the handsome knight;
Great and small ran around him.
The count looked at them, to many he returned their greeting,
And they in reaction were silent and mute.
He was amazed when he noticed
That there was not a single white-haired man among them;
There were few of them who even had a beard.
"I don't know where I am or where I have come;
May merciful Jesus remember me,
For I don't know what I have gotten myself into."

lg.head: Laisse 261
lg.l: Up the middle of the street to the vast castle,
They led the noble knight.
The more he looked into the other roads,
The more ladies and young men he saw.
He saw one group playing ball,
And another [playing] dice, and [others playing] backgammon and chess,
And everywhere he saw [them] courting ladies.
But [he saw] most of them singing and caroling,
Not to mention eating and drinking
[He saw] only pleasure and vain pursuits.
The count himself could not resist
Looking and gazing at them.
He began to speak to himself:
"There is no equal to this castle anywhere in the world!
If I believed that it wouldn't be a betrayal of my wife
And of Duke Thomas and Baldwin her brother,
Samson [and] Morant, who are my soldiers,
I would never try to return to Auvergne.
My lord, Charles, who causes me torment,
Would have to think of another messenger."
Once he had said this he began staring;
In a spot where he had to dismount,
He saw a lady situated above the others.
Many people approached her for advising
Twenty or thirty at a time, each one wishing speak to her,
Such that he himself began to marvel.
When they saw everyone going right up to him,
A group ran to him, [right up] to [his] stirrup.
They began speaking quite openly to him:
"You must present yourself to our lady.
At this time, I believe, she is without peer
When it comes to helping a good man with great knowledge."
"[My] lords," said Huon, "I have great need of it;
A more distressed man has never been born of woman."

lg.head: Laisse 262
lg.l: One of the people there where the count dismounted
Took hold of the good horse by the bridle;
He whisked him quickly away from [Huon] to the stable.
He brought the count to the splendid great hall,
Before him he opened the door.
Two young ladies dressed in samite
Led him forward to where he caught sight of their lady.
In that place there was no din or noise,
Except for musical instruments and singing too.
The count said, "I have never seen such a marvel!
I see nothing here other than joy and delight;
What can this be, most holy Son of David,
Who cried out on the Cross, 'My God, my God'?
Oh, have mercy on me in these days
So that I may be neither disgraced nor dishonored."

lg.head: Laisse 263
lg.l: The count was brought into the lower hall,
Here they were singing better than sirens.
On a bench at the highest position
Sat the great lady who ruled over the others;
She was dressed in black just like a nun,
With her head covered, she kept her face unveiled;
Her body was very white and scarlet-colored,
Her eyes large and sparkling and secretly laughing,
Seeming more joyful than any other chatelaine.
Had she been a human creature,
Polyxena and Helen could not have been as beautiful;
On the contrary their beauty would have been much further apart
Than an old woman's from that of a water nymph;
Nevertheless her beauty was completely false and vain.

lg.head: Laisse 264
lg.l: When the count entered the paved hall,
Then the noise of the singing quieted.
When the count greeted the lady,
She lifted her head toward him
With a welcoming glance like a flaming arrow;
She advanced a little toward him,
Sat next to him and then spoke to him,
But in no way did she touch him.
The count was asked about his country,
What kind of man he was, and what purpose
Had led him through this foreign realm.
Huon the count told her the truth:
"[My] lady," he said, "to your question
I reply: I'm from near France, the broad [country].
I'm from Auvergne, its lady is my wife.
It's been six whole years since
That emperor of Rome the renowned,
Who is king and lord over all living people, separated her from me.
For he wrongly conceived of something quite foolish,
That he wants tribute from the people driven
Down from Heaven because of their plotting.
He made me swear when I was sent off
Never to return to my country
Until I had found the gate of Hell,
And had recounted to Lucifer what he wanted:
That [the Devil] swear fealty to him and send tribute.
And if [the Devil] doesn't do it, I am to challenge him on behalf [of the king]:
He won't leave him anything at all;
He will be completely dispossessed."
The lady heard this and laughed at it,
Saying to the vassal, "And you, what do you have in mind [to do]?"
And he replied, with a troubled look,
"To find this place of the damned."

lg.head: Laisse 265
lg.l: "Vassal," she said, "you are looking for Hell?"
"Indeed I am; I request your counsel about it."
She replied, "Gladly, with pleasure,
I'll give you such [advice] with the understanding
That Medea, who knew so much of the magic arts,
Never helped Jason more, by means of her spells,
To find the shiny Golden Fleece,
Compared to what I will show you now:
[Namely] the straight path to go to the bottom
Of great Hell, where the wretched are found,
To relate your message [and] return safely.
But if I do this so that you are pleased
With this thing that you so desire,
What reward will I have for it, or what present?"
"[My] lady," he said, "if I were powerful,
There is nothing in this earthly life,
[That,] if I could do it well and reasonably
For you, I would not do at your command.
You see me here [ready] to swear it,
If I can do it henceforth."

lg.head: Laisse 266
lg.l: "Vassal," she said, "your coming here
Delights me above all things and urges [me]
To serve you without any restraint.
The great beauty that I have seen in you
Turns what I have lost into joy;
I am revived by meeting you
Following the loss of my lord.
I hold you as lord and I [hold myself] as your beloved;
Accept me and right away I'll turn over to you
All the land that I have held for such a long time
If you will hold me naked in your arms tonight.
Before the light of day appears tomorrow,
By the strength of the skill in which I believe myself accomplished,
I'll send you down among the fallen people."
Then the count made an woeful face;
"[My] lady," he said, "I have understood you well;
Once I have fulfilled my promise
And returned from that defeated people,
Obeying you will be thought through.
One way or another, let the truth be known,
Never will chastity be violated by me."

lg.head: Laisse 267
lg.l: When the lady heard what he said,
That the vassal would not consent at all
To give his love, but rather resisted her,
She appealed to him again and entreated him gently:
"Friend," she said, "you have already pledged [your] faith to me,
That you'll do my every command.
There is no nobleman of ancient ancestry,
However handsome and brave and endowed with wealth,
Who should refuse me as a beloved.
But I believe you to be full of cowardice,
When you possess something good and [yet] go seeking foolishness.
And besides, I would consider myself completely mad
To love someone who doesn't welcome it.
You'll make me say a very foolish thing;
If I didn't have any company here
Other than the two of us, the desire with which I am aflame
Would have been fulfilled long ago.
Act, noble man, and through your courtesy,
So that your coming [here] doesn't kill or destroy me;
Never have I loved a man in my entire life
Aside from you, by whom I am betrayed!
I can boast and say without trickery,
There is no more beautiful lady from here to Hungary,
Nor richer with everything in great abundance.
Carry out my wish now and you'll be acting courteously."
Once he had heard the end of this speech,
The count kept his face very humble
In the manner of a servant who cries for mercy from his master.
Then, in tears, he bowed over down to the ground;
The more he looked at her, the more his heart softened,
So strongly that he didn't know how to express himself.

lg.head: Laisse 268
lg.l: The queen rose to a standing position,
The entire court rose with her,
And she commanded that the tables be prepared;
Those whom she charged with the task did it.
The queen entered a chamber;
She left the noble count in the hall.
Many young ladies gathered behind him,
Each one beginning to speak seductively to him.
One said to the other, "What a marvelous wife he'll have,
He who will have such a one in his arms!
He will surely have joy in this world."
With these words, which the count heard,
They were pushing him towards sin; Nature reinforced it
Beyond the desire that his eyes procured.
But Abstinence was there which freed him from it,
From the great stain that Nature gave him:
Beyond the need that visited our count,
A sweet love of Abstinence mounted in him
Which so thoroughly shielded his heart
That he exited and said he'd return quickly;
Down from the hall he entered a garden.
Hear, [my] lords, for the sake of God who formed everything,
About the noble count, who loved Jesus so much,
How fiercely he punished himself!

lg.head: Laisse 269
lg.l: The night had already chased away the day,
When the count was overwhelmed by this transgression;
He entered the orchard, completely full of great grief.
He took up a stone of which there were many,
He struck himself on the chest, proclaiming himself a sinner;
He cried out aloud, "O King of compassion,
Help me, I am full of dread!
I have failed, I fully believe, on this day;
God, have mercy on me, on this miserable sinner,
Who allows himself to be misled toward treacherous sin!
Oh, wretched flesh, full of wanton appearance,
How is it that you are thinking to drive yourself into everlasting fire?
At that time you'll have the reward of your deeds;
You have experienced a desire for adultery due to madness,
But you'll feel a different pleasure."
He gripped the stone and hit himself vigorously,
Striking his flesh all over and all around;
"Now, enjoy yourself, flesh, full of stench!"
He hit himself so much with the heavy rock,
That he lost earthly sensation;
He almost fainted from the pain.

lg.head: Laisse 270
lg.l: [Huon] had beaten and thrashed himself with great force,
There was blood spurting out of several places.
Then he returned [to the place] from which he had come.
As soon as he was in the hall,
He thought to find joy and entertainment [going on];
[But] the cheerful faces had become troubled
And the singing had turned into silence.
Never had the barons of Macedonia been so upset
Since the son of Philip had been taken from them
When he drank the poison
As [the courtiers were] when the count found them completely distraught.
Now they understood clearly, indeed they perceived,
That he had fought off the sin;
Through abstinence he had defeated the plot.
Then he cried out with as much strength as he could:
"Succor your servant, O God, Father of Jesus!
Help me, don't let me be deceived by this;
I see that I came to this place foolishly."
Once he had said this, he saw another miracle:
The [well-]dressed young women and young men
All turned into horned devils.
They seemed to be overcome by great rage;
No thunder in the air when winds came up
Ever made such a noise when it broke
As did those devils who were defeated.
The count remained alone in the hall;
On all four sides there were fires ignited.

lg.head: Laisse 271
lg.l: Before the doors that were in the room
The great hall was soon aflame;
The count remained inside woeful and wretched,
Full of fear; but but he wasn't so overwhelmed
That he forgot heavenly speech.
In the middle of the hall he got down on his knees;
He stretched out his hands toward God Almighty,
He recited a psalm, calling out loudly,
"Let your servant now depart, Almighty,
Today in complete peace."
Before he had recited it all to the end,
Three angels descended amidst the flames.
They were all white and their vestments were bright;
The fire was extinguished by their arrival,
Just as happens to the night from the burning sun.
The first one carried a book in a noble manner;
He opened it and held it out before the count
In order to comfort the count who was wretched,
And to show that God rewards merit
And never forgets any good servant of His.
All three of them sang with great devotion
So gloriously and repeatedly
--Which greatly pleased the count--
That he forgot something of his torment.
Yet he was nevertheless somewhat fearful,
Because he couldn't really see their shapes.
He certainly understood that they were messengers from God Almighty
To comfort him and give joy.
"Glory in the highest" was how they began,
Before they said firmly, "peace on earth."
The song they recited seemed so sweet to the count
That he fell asleep right on the paved floor,
Such that he felt no doubt or fear or dread.

lg.head: Laisse 272
lg.l: Here there is a beautiful example for worldly sinners
Who shouldn't be either arrogant or vain:
Out of arrogance--be certain of this--
No earthly man ever served God at all.
But he who wants to be helped by Sovereign God
Must not himself be base
But rather pious toward Him, humble and open,
Nor [must he] despair when he sees himself in distress.
As Odinel now recounts in the vernacular,
The count of Auvergne, sleeping that night,
Rested until the next day.
When he awoke he felt his gorget
And himself and his buckram garments all wet
From the dew that had fallen overnight.
He looked all around himself, he saw nothing of the great hall,
Nor house nor town, city or dwelling.
The captain found himself in the great forest,
On a branch that was of a very dark green
He saw his war horse tied up by the reins.
Then the faithful Christian knelt down;
Devoutly he stretched his hands toward Heaven:
"Holy Father, You who sent John [the Baptist]
As a witness into the sin of the world,
Then You followed after the first one
To extricate us from dangerous deceit
And in order to save us from original sin,
Save me, Almighty God,
From those who wish to make me sin through trickery."
Once he had said this, he crossed himself with his hand,
Then he remounted his mighty war horse.

lg.head: Laisse 273
lg.l: "Horse," said Huon, "who led me into these woods,
I don't know the way; show it to me now."
He placed the bridle low over [the horse's] neck,
Then he said to him, "Go where you please!"
The good war horse took off quickly;
He passed through the forest, which was very extensive;
He passed by cliffs and valleys and hills;
As far as the riverbank of the Euphrates' companion
He came, where the Tigris rushes.
He had carried a great burden and great weight;
When he arrived at the river, evening had already fallen.
The count dismounted from the proud Bucephalus;
When he saw the ship that he had never believed to find again,
He never would have had such joy for all the riches of Baghdad;
Then the nobleman gave thanks to Saint Nicholas.
"Horse," said Huon, "you have toiled for me;
The way I see it, you'll eat first."
He gave him to drink from the river, clear as ice,
And then filled up his shield with a measure of grain.

lg.head: Laisse 274
lg.l: Once the horse had drunk and eaten,
The count satisfied himself with a bit of bread.
He took hold of his war horse and led him on to the ship,
And he himself lay down next to him.
Daylight disappeared, night approached;
He slept little, but thought much,
The count feared that he might be tricked.
Then the next day once the sun had risen,
He brought the horse off his ship,
And attached the rope to the golden saddle-bow.
He cried out to the horse saying, "Forward, let's go!"
He made his way along the bank of the river;
He was hindered by absolutely nothing
From outside, not beast or vermin or demon
Until four days had passed,
When he found evil birds aplenty.
They were blacker than stirred ink,
With huge beaks like thick hammers;
The smallest one was immeasurably large.
Three of them would have loaded up a cart;
They lived on fish that they found in the river.
The first one that noticed the count
Because of the horse, at which it was astonished,
Abandoned the river and turned toward him;
It gave out such a cry from its throat,
That the war horse shied way back from it.

lg.head: Laisse 275
lg.l: The bird came flying toward the horse;
The count saw it, he was indeed deathly afraid.
Immediately he leaped on to the saddle without delay,
Drew his sword, quickly positioned to help.
The fierce bird swooped down from above,
Its feet reaching out and its beak likewise.
If it were to touch the nobly-born baron with its wings,
They would be in danger, he and the horse.
The fierce bird gave him such a blow
As no blacksmith ever struck on an anvil.
But with his sword [Huon] struck it down;
He sliced its neck at the level of the chest.
The trunk of the body fell to the ground;
It resembled a stone thrown by a catapult.
May God, the Heavenly Father, help the count,
For whom in a short time a great battle is destined!

lg.head: Laisse 276
lg.l: The huge bird that the count had killed
Was then vigorously assaualted by the others,
So he got himself ready like a well-trained man;
The marquis hastily boarded his ship.
First, as quickly as he could, he placed
The Arab war horse's coverlets,
Made of two silks and rich samite, up over him.
Then he arranged the rope around the golden saddle-bow.
With a spear in his hand, he set off;
He laced up his polished helmet.
He took hold of his curved shield by the leather straps;
He urged the horse forward to attack;
Suddenly the birds raised the cry.
More than fifty issued forth from the Tigris;
All of them seemed intent on doing evil.
They attacked both him and the horse.
There you might have seen such a great clash,
Such a dreadful fight with foot, with beak,
That the count never thought to escape alive.
He wasn't slow to defend himself well;
Before it shattered, he killed more than fifteen of them
In that wasteland with his sharp spear.
When his spear broke, he was very distressed;
The birds harassed him with wing and beak as well.
If he cried out to God, he shouldn't be blamed.

lg.head: Laisse 277
lg.l: The count put his hand on his dangerous sword;
The first blow he struck killed two of them.
He killed rather a lot of them like a brave man;
He prayed to God the Father, that He come to his aid.
The powerful fighter made such a effort
That he vigorously knocked them away from him
[And] the others into the river Tigris without [hope of] rescue.
Thenceforward, nothing would harm him anymore,
But soon after this [something] worse surrounded them:
A flock of small birds, not very big,
Similar to partridges, for they weren't any larger
--I don't know--in their beaks and wings they resembled them.
If they touched anything alive where it was uncovered below,
Know this, they would surely have such a bite,
That soon they would swell, they would never be healed from the effect [of the bite].
A flock of these evil birds rose up
Such that the air was obscured by them and all in shadow,
So that a man could hardly see in front of himself.
May God keep the count and the mettlesome war horse!
He would be in bad shape if he were bitten by them.

lg.head: Laisse 278
lg.l: The count of Auvergne clearly understood;
He knew about their nature because it had already been described to him
In the land of Prester John, and [now] he had seen many of them.
So he attached the ship to the bank where he was,
And mounted the horse; he wasn't going to remain any longer.
Crouching under his closely held shield,
He stopped in the middle of the clearing without saying a word.
He remained there waiting patiently; he was without fear;
He let the birds pass over in large swarms and small.
They passed over, stirring up a great commotion;
The wind that they brought stank rather more
Than any carcass of a dog that had rotted.
Up until nightfall these birds flew around;
Then they left, afterward not one of them was seen.
At this point it was going well for the count of Auvergne,
Who had not lost his way in that place,
Yet the stench came to him as a great torment;
His whole stomach turned over inside and the count vomited;
If he hadn't dismounted, he would have fallen.
He moved close to the riverbank,
Forcing himself like a man of great strength,
For he wanted to drive the stinking air away from himself.
The more he moved, the more of it he encountered,
He was so weak and wretched from the mire
That finally he fell to the ground; great suffering overpowered him.
Then he said to himself, "Now I am completely defeated."

lg.head: Laisse 279
lg.l: The count of Auvergne was lying on the ground;
Owing to the great stench that polluted the moor,
His stomach turned and great suffering overpowered him.
He rolled over, he was hardly conscious;
He had to vomit four times which was enough;
Then he remained still like a man stunned.
He felt very little, he was feeling so faint,
But as soon as he recovered himself, he wasn't slow
To pray to God, the King of Paradise,
For himself and for others who died in agony.
He beat his breast and struck himself on the chest,
He called himself a miserable sinner,
More than any other man ever born.
He recited many a psalm, then he confessed his guilt.
The suffering eased and he fell asleep;
Afterward as well he remained thus all night long
Until dawn when the daylight appeared.
The count woke up, he found himself recovered;
He blessed God and His Mother as well.

lg.head: Laisse 280
lg.l: The next day when it was dawn,
The count felt completely better.
He thanked God and His great power,
Which had granted him more than he had asked for.
He was overcome with great pity for his horse,
Who had not eaten the previous day or night.
He hastened onto the ship, brought him grain,
And he ate it in holy charity,
For there was nothing left of that foul wind
That had previously filled all the air with stench.
Once they had eaten and were satisfied,
They soon readied themselves for their journey.
He took to the road and they set off;
Subsequently he traveled a good five long days,
During which he was hindered by nothing at all.
He covered so much ground in a day's journey,
Day by day, that they arrived
At a mountain; there they stopped.
From there onward, the ship couldn't go.

lg.head: Laisse 281
lg.l: The count stopped when the ship could [go] no further,
Close to the mountain that stood before them.
There the noise of the water of the Tigris dissipated;
In a cave where there was an opening,
The water disappeared, it went underground;
In a short time [the land] swallowed the river,
The channel emptied; it didn't appear
That the fish had ever left that place where they were,
But the count didn't remain there very long.
On the other side he saw the water gushing up again;
It issued forth with such abundance [that] if the count hadn't moved,
He would already have perished and been completely undone.
He seized his horse first, he backed away [with him];
The river turned back where it came from;
The count remained bewildered and completely speechless.
He had no advice at a time when he was so lost;
He called out to God and to His great power,
That He help him in this situation so that he not be thwarted
That there be no case made for his having to turn back.
"Let's go forward in the name of Jesus;
Let this great, sharp-peaked mountain be conquered.
Let's see further on what is on that peak up there."

lg.head: Laisse 282
lg.l: Huon climbed a high hillock;
He led the good horse by the reins.
Once he was up there he found it fairly flat,
Then he looked all around him in front and behind;
Behind he saw the sea striking the coast.
He saw nothing other than water and great [stretches of] land.
In several places there were steep precipices;
He saw clearly that he could do nothing in that direction.
The count descended and came to his boat;
He remained there, I don't really know how many days.
Then the count decided he wanted
To abandon the ship down on the running river,
And to search the flatlands completely:
Either he would die there or he would accomplish his desire.
As soon as he thought this, he carried it out immediately;
First both of them ate to their fill.
He mounted the horse and commended himself to God;
He left the river; he rode along the mountain.

lg.head: Laisse 283
lg.l: The count set out riding through the valley,
Going along his way much refreshed;
In little time he had gone quite far
From the river that he had left behind.
Had he even wanted to turn back,
He wouldn't have found the correct path.
Indeed there were many evil lands to be passed through,
The days were made more difficult by many beasts.
Then the count looked, he gazed in front of him;
He saw a serpent with an open maw
That was coming toward him, and he was very tired.
The count wished he could have avoided it that day,
But the horse was quite frightened,
Such that he couldn't move his feet forward or backward.
The count dismounted to the ground, he gripped his shield;
He placed himself in front [of the horse] and brandished his sword.
The evil beast had advanced a lot:
It picked up the horse with with its curled tail,
It would have cruelly hurt him
[But] Huon advanced, he gave it such blows
That with great force he thoroughly stunned it.
Then many times he redoubled [the blows]
Until he struck it down to the ground.
He clearly realized that the horse wasn't injured
By the fear that had completely overwhelmed him.
For a long time he didn't stir from the spot
Until Huon had calmed him many times.
For a long time he stroked his flanks and his sides.
[Huon] reined him in gently like a well-trained nobleman.
The horse recovered, then looked at the serpent,
Then he backed away when he saw it there cast down dead.
Three times he trembled, then he thrashed his tail;
He began to neigh as he calmed down.
Huon understood him, he felt much relieved,
Therefore he thanked God many times.
After this, [Huon] led him to safety;
Then he mounted, he left the serpent behind;
Next he made haste to continue down his road.
He rode so much, covering a lot of ground,
That he had advanced for nine days already
Without finding any rest.
Before he entered a valley,
He couldn't seek out, because of the vermin that lived there,
Whether a few plants and trees grew [there].

lg.head: Laisse 284
lg.l: Once the count had left the riverbank,
Where he abandoned his ship to wander
On the waters of the Tigris without a helmsman to steer [it],
Afterward, for many days, he reaped great harm;
Many a very wild adventure befell him,
Which he had to complete whether he liked it or not.
He often missed the ship in his heart
As well as the kindness and hospitality of Prester John.
He committed great folly when he entered this forest!
Never had mortal man committed greater folly
Than Huon had done to carry out his journey.
In order to remain loyal to Charles his lord,
He had left behind many honors by going wandering,
Without either the desire or the heart to turn back.
He wanted to press forward every day, come honor or harm.
He came out of an evil valley [and] entered into a more savage place
Full of vermin; he smelled no good odors.
This went on for more than three days; he found no good passage there,
And the steep mountains there were vast and wide.
I want everyone to know this well: no beast would dare stay
Except for flying birds.

lg.head: Laisse 285
lg.l: The noble count did not resent
What came from the hand of the Sovereign King;
Rather he accepted peacefully everything that came his way.
Often he entreated the great Holy Glory
That He keep this sinner constantly in mind.
He lamented his sins and moaned a lot [over them] in this way;
He didn't cease to invoke [and] pray to the Heavenly Lord
That He watch over him and the war horse, that no evil overpower them;
He made the sign of the cross and crossed himself many times.
He drew near to the coast, and left the plain behind;
Many times dangerous adventures came upon him.
He left the strand behind, ascended toward the mountain
That always appeared to collapse toward the plain.
The great rocks that fell from the very lofty knoll
Thrashed and injured many of the vermin of the plain.

lg.head: Laisse 286
lg.l: The stones that fell down from the mountain
Crushed most of the vermin;
The others still alive retreated.
When the count saw this, he departed from there
And got away from the mountain as quickly as he could,
For he greatly feared getting hurt.
But God protected him for Jesus loved him very much!
The count rode his horse with the flowing mane
Until he had gotten out of that evil valley;
Then he found the slope of a tall, pointed hillock;
So the count climbed it, he came to the other side;
There was nothing at all to be seen but the sea and the mountain.
He made camp between the sea and the mountain;
In that place he had good shelter, for the field was grassy.
He settled there for several days for the sake of the horse with the flowing mane,
Until [the horse] was rested and he [himself] alongside him.
The count pulled out roots of plants;
Thus he satisfied himself, praising the name of Jesus.

lg.head: Laisse 287
lg.l: The count left that place when the desire to do so came to him,
Once he had been somewhat restored from his great fatigue.
He continued riding between the sea and the mountain,
Many an adventure occurred as the author has been recounting;
I won't tell a fair number of them, but I will tell a few.
He came upon a race of men [and] women together
Who had the shape of a human from the navel up
And from the hips on down, they looked like fish.
They couldn't speak at all and they went about completely naked;
The eyes that they had in their foreheads looked like burning brands,
As a result they were marked with a hostile look;
They call them the Ocifal, as many people say;
They are a good fifteen feet tall fully grown and large.
When they spread out on land,
They seem able to stay there for more than a day.
So many of them were together, one couldn't consider counting them.
But had they lingered a little on land,
As far as I know, it might have gone badly for the count,
But their natural instinct was to return to the great sea;
At their return, they let out such a noise
That the mountain and the water all resounded.
They stirred up the sea and the air by the wind they caused
Along with a really huge storm; it went one for more than five days
Such that no ship or boat could budge in that country;
The count saw this and was very troubled by it.
Never at all did he fail to pray to God;
He crossed himself constantly the further he went.
When he was climbing a hill, when he was descending,
Many times he stopped to rest in the best places,
But he got very little rest, know [that] for certain.
When thirst and hunger became really troublesome,
He satisfied himself a bit with the roots of plants,
And while he was sleeping, the horse would go grazing.
But he didn't feel very safe, know truthfully,
For disturbances appeared there day and night.
One who would recount the doings hour by hour
Would find it a great annoyance.
For this reason I'll say no more about that, but will speak about some important events.

lg.head: Laisse 288
lg.l: Never was the count cowardly about pressing forward;
He climbed up for an hour, he descended for an hour
Toward the sea that surrounded the mountain.
It took great effort to climb up and come back down;
They went on in this way for more than three days.
The heat of the sun bothered him ever more,
He didn't find fresh water either in a cave nor in a well;
Much did he desire it, he would have liked to have a drink.
He could do nothing else; he went off at an angle.
He made his way the best he could
To the shore. Next, he saw below
Men deformed and outside of human nature
Who were split down the middle of their bodies to the navel;
And each one had two heads, two chests and two torsos.
The count marveled at them when he saw them;
He saw a kind of people that he didn't recognize.
They were all barefoot and appeared completely naked;
More than a thousand traveled in a throng.
They would have soon caused the count much harm,
When a whirlwind came toward them across the open space
That disturbed and stirred up all the winds.
With brute force, it lifted them up
Quite high, where they were clearly seen.
Then it dropped them down into the sea.
They made such a fall that the noise and the clamor
Could be heard a good two leagues away.
Following this harmful thing, others appeared before him:
Just like snow, there was fire raining down from the sky,
Which burned the land in many places like a conflagration.
But things went well for the good count,
Who hardly felt any effects from this disturbance,
Except that he was indeed very disconcerted.
To himself he said: "I can well perceive
That I am sinful, as much as any man could be!
I should have been undone a long time ago;
I set off out of arrogance
When I went to seek that which no one can find.
I consider myself fallen into terrible sin.
God is demonstrating for me [His] might and miracles,
I didn't realize it; for this reason I am confounded."
He proclaimed himself a sinner, he struck his chest;
Tears fell from his eyes, he called himself wretched:
"Through my sins, I have angered the living God;
If I don't make better repentance, as I have seen,
I'll thus be placed in worse torment."

lg.head: Laisse 289
lg.l: Once the wind had died down as well as the great tumult
Above [and] below, the sky poured down abundant rain
That completely put out the fire, the flames and the burning wood.
Then the weather cleared; it wasn't very long
Before his good luck returned to the count;
He thanked God very much for what He had done for him.
He rested for a little while, then the baron set off again,
He and the horse got back on the road.
Huon never ever ceased praying;
Thenceforward, as the story recounts,
He rode his horse a good fortnight's distance.
He faced many adventures and overcame them all.
He rode until he came to the summit of a mountain
That seemed to be completely on fire a league away;
He saw firebrands rising and falling,
Lit up and burning like torches.
Then he heard sighing that sorrow causes.
When Huon heard it, he wondered at that moment:
"O God," said Huon, "Lord King, I give thanks
That I have come here to the place I was seeking,
For this is Hell, by means of which so many suffer.
I see there many souls that look like birds."
Then he said, "Alas, what will I do now?
Just looking at it is one of the most terrifying things in the world.
He who can accomplish all that is required
Would have more courage and goodness
Than any earthly man who exists in this world;
Nothing but divine power could accomplish it,
[That is,] He who established this place, as Scripture says,
In order to torment the souls of criminal sinners."
After saying this he got off his horse
[And] let him graze, for which it was certainly time.
Then he went along the hillock that was there
To see, if at all possible, the rest,
[That is,] whether he, the baron, could carry this through or would die.
He climbed the mountain on foot;
He saw no good country as he looked all around;
He didn't want to turn back for anything.
The more he looked in that direction, the more Huon wondered.

lg.head: Laisse 290
lg.l: "Oh, God," said Huon, "alas, how will I do it?
I have no intention of turning back;
Nor can I go forward, thus I'll just stay here.
I'll end my life in great wretchedness,
I do wrong against my Creator, I see it clearly and know it well,
When I go seeking that which has never been [sought].
He has demonstrated it to me through many good examples,
Through many great perils, and He has indeed rescued me,
[So] I don't want to anger him; my cruel heart makes me do it.
The pope and Prester John already told me, I know,
Not to go seeking this and it would turn out well for me
[And] they would absolve me, if I had any sins as a result.
And many other wise men told me often
That they believed that I would fail seeking this thing.
Even if no one had said it, I truly believe
That I have gone as far as I ever could.
For a long time I've had no protector;
If anything attacks me, I won't defend myself:
I'll behave now like a wretched and cowardly traitor."
Then he said next, "Alas, what have I said?
I shall not be a coward, as long as I can help it."
Having said this, he beat his chest,
He called himself miserable and quite a sinner.

lg.head: Laisse 291
lg.l: The count with the sincere heart wept tears;
The noble count palatine thought
That he might remain there forever.
He dreaded the fire, the cries and the howling,
He said to himself in his heart [that] if he weren't scraped [clean] of sin,
He would never thus [be able to] enter Hell;
"But this way I will serve Jesus and Saint Thomas."
At that moment his heart was full of contrition,
Thenceforth he thanked God as much as he could;
He said the office, as he had done at other times.
Once he had finished, he crossed himself.
He looked before him without any intention of harm or quarreling.
He saw a young man coming across the fallow land
Toward him without any obvious ill intent;
Where he was coming from, Huon had no idea,
But no one had ever seen a more handsome young man;
No young man was more splendidly attired.
The count stood up for him promptly;
He wanted to greet him, but [the young man] did it first.
First he greeted [Huon]; the count thanked him,
They took each other's hand, then seated themselves comfortably.
They spoke of many things, and of many fine subjects;
The one responded to the other, there was no arguing,
One respected the other; [when] one spoke, the other was quiet.

lg.head: Laisse 292
lg.l: "Oh, young man," said Huon, "you speak well;
I see you worthy and wise, and you are sensible.
You dwell in a good place; tell me, I beg you,
Please tell me the truth, whether anyone knows anything
About this evil place before us.
Is it called Hell or does it have another name?
It is evilly inhabited and we see nothing good there."
"You speak the truth," he said, "I'll explain it all to you;
The mountain that you see burning like an ember
Is a branch of Hell, not the deepest part;
There are many of such appearance on earth.
On [their] way to the cruelest abyss of great Hell,
The souls of scoundrels who have shown great disdain
Toward the Creator don't pass through here;
They go by another way, as it pleases God of the firmament,
If God doesn't perform a miracle by giving some sign;
This place that you see here [and] several others that exist
Are made to torment some of the spirits who fell:
Some [of them] went into the abyss, they have a great deal of torment there;
Others remained on earth; others dwell in the air.
Whoever might now want to explain it all, how they fled there,
Would have a lot to say. Therefore I'll say nothing
About seeking more than what is appropriate for you,
Except that you clearly see there in the mire the suffering they undergo.
Tell me about your situation, please, worthy man.
I'll willingly counsel you according to what I know."
"Many thanks," said the count, "indeed I will tell you about it."

lg.head: Laisse 293
lg.l: Once the count of Auvergne had heard this speech,
He was much comforted and forgot his sorrow;
By [these words] he was much reassured.
Thus he felt better; he didn't know who [the young man] was,
He thought he had come across a human being.
But in truth, know that [the young man] was no such thing;
Rather he was a messenger from God who had sent him like this
To comfort [the count], to guide [him] on the right path.
If he had recognized him, know for certain,
That he would have been kinder to him;
But [Huon] believed completely that he was an earthly man.
Nevertheless, he honored him rather a lot,
Never would he have been willingly separated from him.
It seemed to him that the whole time was tranquil.
The count didn't fear being harmed one bit;
And [Huon] spoke a lot; he satisfied him.
He spoke to him as a countryman, as if to a human being,
But as to other matters, [the young man] asked him insistently
That he recount truthfully to him his entire quest.
Huon told it, he didn't hide it from him;
He recounted the entire situation concerning his mission.
He thought it would be foolishness to tell more than that,
And he didn't want to wallow one bit in vainglory;
And if a few times someone else had questioned him,
[Huon] really regretted it, thinking he had sinned;
The most he would say was, "In truth, know this---
That this road has vexed me sorely.
But if I could carry out all that I have undertaken
And return to the place where I was born
So that I might recount my mission to my lord,
I wouldn't fear dying one bit then.
But it is going much worse for me, so I believe,
Thus I will die; I believe it's destined for me,
If I don't have other succour or help from God,
And He doesn't send it to me out of His goodness,
As I have placed all my hope in Him.
Even though I'm a sinner, I bow down before Him in all things;
Thus may He watch over me, as I go in good faith."

lg.head: Laisse 294
lg.l: The young man replied, "Now,
If you finish just as you have recounted here,
You will have good sense as befits human nature.
For one knows well that [humans] are fragile things,
That the most righteous who live in these times
Feel themselves in sin day after day.
They absolutely need to have good understanding
To keep themselves from sinning all the time.
Yet, according to the strength with which they try,
They must do as much good as they can:
In the end they gain salvation.
If you cherish God, God will be there with you;
If you behave otherwise, it will likewise be evident.
Nevertheless I tell you truly
That, in my way of thinking, it seems to me, you are taking the wrong path,
And your lord, whom you bear in mind,
Committed great folly with this mission.
According to proper reason, in my opinion,
He'll be thwarted by it if he doesn't repent.
The undertaking seems excessive, as I think about it;
Truthfully I don't know at all how to advise you.
Act so that you keep a positive attitude toward God Almighty;
God loves his servant more than you know.
He who has trust in God will indeed be properly led,
Nor should he really fear anything.
I say it for you whom I see doubtful:
Follow your road because a reward awaits you,
By remaining in this way you'll achieve nothing.
God will be with you if you love Him faithfully;
If I could serve you in any way,
I would do it willingly, I swear.
I am of little value, as you can clearly see;
I can no longer remain; I commend you to God."
After he spoke, the count became thoughtful;
He lowered his head, bowed down to the ground.
When he raised his head, he saw nothing.
"Holy Mary, what has happened to the young man?
I don't see him, I am quite astounded."
Then he looked before him, great light was shining;
Then he really understood quite clearly
That [the young man] had been a messenger from God Almighty.
Then he beat himself, striking himself in the chest;
He called himself miserable, a wretch, unlucky,
When he hadn't had enough good sense in him
To have recognized [the messenger] before his departure;
He would have honored him more than anything in the world
And he would have asked him many other things;
For this reason he believed that he had acted quite wrongly.
He called himself a sinner as much as he could;
He wept tears and was extremely sorrowful.

lg.head: Laisse 295
lg.l: Count Huon was greatly grief-stricken
Because of this transgression, [namely,] that he had not recognized [the messenger],
And then afterward, he had not honored him more.
He believed that he had sinned against [God's] majesty;
[But] he hadn't [done] that; everything he did pleased Him,
Just as when good gold is in the furnace:
The more it heats up and the hotter it gets,
The brighter it becomes and the higher its refined value.
Thus it was with Huon; the more hardship he experienced,
The less it mattered to him, and he had shown this many times,
For in many situations this is what had happened---
He had succeeded in them; he didn't preen because of it,
Nor take any pride [in it], but rather humbled himself the more;
He gave the honor to the One who had created him and others.
He often called upon Him, and loved Him with all his heart;
Now what more can I say? He had entered into such a matter
That, indeed, if he wants to carry out everything he began,
It will be quite remarkable if he isn't greatly afraid,
And if he comes through it, he will be more knowledgeable
Than any mortal man who has lived until now.
The count wept copiously over his trouble,
And then afterward he said his prayers;
He wept a lot, as was his custom,
And then afterward he hit and struck himself;
Calling himself a sinner, he commended himself to God;
He recalled to himself what the angel had said,
That staying here would achieve nothing.
He crossed himself as he set out,
Then he affirmed all that he had in his heart:
If he had to die, he would simply pass on,
He would see more openly what would be;
As for his mission, he would search for as long as he could.
By word or by deed, he would carry out his mission;
Then he would return, if the Creator saw fit.
He crossed himself, he commended himself to God;
He noticed there was a great noise in the valley,
He didn't know what it was. He remembered his horse,
Then he jumped up, he took hold of his arms,
As quickly as he could he went down the hill.
He saw his horse which was grazing in the meadow;
This was a very good thing for [the horse]. When [Huon] approached him,
He looked beyond to the other side:
He saw two griffons who were fighting with a serpent,
Each one crying out because of the great anguish it was undergoing;
One was scratching the other as much as it could.
The serpent had seized one of them with its tail,
Which as a result defended itself very little, you should know.
The other fought, but gained very little.

lg.head: Laisse 296
lg.l: When Huon saw such a great battle
Between the serpent and the birds who were pulling back,
He didn't see anyone having any advantage there,
At that instant he resolved on an act of courage.
He said [that] if he could, he would protect the birds;
He preferred to die than not to come to their aid.
He came toward the battle and struck at the serpent,
First at the side, then also at the head.
It spewed forth fire and then screamed out.
When he saw that he had achieved nothing,
The baron thrust his sword into its throat;
He pierced the heart and then it fell prostrate.
Next it let forth such a great roar,
The whole mountain reverberated with it.
Then the count pulled the sword back out;
He knew well that he had killed it; for this reason he was very joyful;
Over on the other side he saw the birds, completely wretched and exhausted,
That couldn't move the least little bit.
He moved aside, and then he began thinking of
How he would cross this branch of the water so wide.
He had no ship, nor any good vessel,
Nor wood for building any raft, as far as he knew.
Then the baron sweetly prayed to God
That He come to his aid if it pleased Him,
So that he might be able to accomplish what he was seeking;
Never because of a difficult situation would he remain
Without obtaining that for which he was striving.

lg.head: Laisse 297
lg.l: Before the count had finished his prayer,
God heard them; hear how [it happened]:
The two birds immediately got up;
Each one began to preen itself with its beak.
They returned to their natural instinct, as it pleases God the Father;
They saw the dead serpent before them [and] the handiwork;
At that moment they understood all His thought
Through divine power, that God wanted to help him.
He wished to compensate him for his great hardship,
He would not abandon him any day of his journey.
[Huon] had found a good companion, if he could manage to accompany him;
One of them took hold of the count, who couldn't prevent it,
The other [took hold of] his horse which it saw grazing.
It carried him so gently, as if he were in a litter,
Across the branch of the sea to the other side,
Because the riverbank was still blazing and burning.
Then it placed him down alongside an old path.
It didn't show him any evil intent, rather they [both] acted like mothers:
One of them placed itself in front and the other behind
To support [their] weight if it were necessary.
They got involved in this serious situation with good reason;
No sinful man ever escaped from such [a plight].
The good count knew it well, he gave thanks to God;
Three times he crossed himself, then he went to mount his horse;
One didn't see him frightened by this event.
But [the horse] neighed and brayed as if he were on the [burning] riverbank;
His master gave comfort as much as he could,
And he took courage from this, then he set off.
He didn't hesitate for fire nor for fear of what they might encounter.
The baron, remembering the little cross that the pope had given him,
Pulled it out with his hand;
Three times the noble count went to kiss it.
In his hand he carried it like an olive branch;
He felt as safe as if he were in a castle.
Then he rode between the mountain and the sea;
The birds escorted him in front and behind.
Now I'll recount to you the great fearsome adventure:
What happened to the count, who put himself in such a situation.

lg.head: Laisse 298
lg.l: Now the count rode with marvelous speed,
He feared no difficult situation, nor what could befall him,
But all the same he often called upon God,
The cross that he grasped in his hand--he had [it] always.
There he saw a ditch that roiled, everything was burning:
He saw great stones continually falling into [the torrent],
Here they rushed, going as far as the sea,
Everything that [the torrent] took was in tumult.
It's a wonder that a mortal man might see all this:
He saw that the air was completely dark, filled with wretched spirits,
And they were calling themselves sorrowful.
With a great sad voice everyone cried out loudly,
Such that it seemed the world must come to an end.
As one entered into the fire, another came out of it;
They never stopped crying and howling.
And there were many of them who threatened the count,
They continually tried to cause him then great torment,
But he didn't care at all about their great provocations.
He trusted in God, whom he loved with good faith,
And in the holy cross that the pope gave him:
They saw it, they swerved off in another direction.
The griffons launched themselves after them at once.
Without a doubt the fire pushed Huon beyond the sea;
He truly endured this suffering for more than a day.
He didn't rest, not for heat or for cold;
He rode night and day by the light of the fire.
It truly appeared that land collapsed wherever he advanced;
He saw many other distressing things that cannot be recounted:
You'll never believe a single one that I might tell you.
[But] I'm going to tell you just one; I must remain silent on the others.
When he got to the third day where the mountain descended,
A great company of spirits issued forth from the mountain.
I don't know why they left but they had joy of it.
They went on foot in front of the count; nevertheless
They demonstrated no ill intention toward the count.
They led many prisoners in torment toward captivity,
There were more than two thousand, as his heart believed;
They went along beating them, crying out and roaring;
They went along cursing to their utmost
Those who struck them [and] heaven and earth.
Listen to what the count did at this time:
No fear took hold of him, he was not dismayed by this.
He remained on the road as if he were to fight;
The birds did the same so that everyone saw them.

lg.head: Laisse 299
lg.l: Count Huon gripped his shield in front of him,
With his other hand, he clasped and held the cross.
He cried aloud to the spirits: "May God curse you!
By the command of God the Father, who chased you entirely away,
Stop a moment; in the name of the One who was never willing
To suffer falsehood, that is the Father, the Son [and] the [Holy] Spirit
Who are bound as one substance.
Just as I truly believe this with a sincere heart, I say without trickery,
Agree to do what I ask of you,
And let me not be hindered by you."

lg.head: Laisse 300
lg.l: The count appealed [to them] and said in good faith:
"I invoke you," he said, "also in the name of that King
Who was stretched on the Cross where He suffered so much pain
To cause me no harm whatsoever," he said.
Just as he said this, they became completely quiet:
They asked him what he was seeking, why he was disturbing them.
"Let us go on our way, in this way you'll act as a courteous man,
For we are in torment enough; it doubles it for us, you see clearly;
That thing you have in your hand, I can't look at it,
For it doubles our torment; for this reason, [it] will remain with you."
The count could not immediately say anything other than:
"This is how it should be; may I never fail to believe it."

lg.head: Laisse 301
lg.l: "Now listen to me," said the count, "Don't hide anything from me;
Who are those captives whom you are taking away in such a way?
They have the appearance of earthly men which you don't have."
"How does it concern you?" several said right away.
"I just want to know," said the count about it.
And one of them replied, nor did he seem crazy:
"Although you want to seek what you shouldn't,
Yet for the sake of that Name in three by which you have invoked us,
Because of the wood that you have in your hand on which He was crucified,
That One by whom we have all been defeated,
We'll tell you all the truth about it.
This one was Jamin who was once on earth,
Who did a great deal of evil during his life.
He would have done more of it, if God had allowed it;
He was completely filled with such knowledge,
Concerning him, we have told you about him.
You must hear about this one who is worse.
This one over here was Cain, who committed the most cruel act:
Know that he killed his brother out of jealousy.
It was the first murder that ever took place on earth.
The next one is Ham who was indeed the son of Noah,
Who spoke wickedly concerning his father, thus mocking him greatly.
Because he had been cruel, he was cursed by [his father];
The retribution he received for it, you can see there in part."

lg.head: Laisse 302
lg.l: "You will see greater torments, vassal;
I put it before you as an exemplum; now know this.
The One who does so much for you will never be named by us.
We cannot go further, as you wanted,
But this much we can tell you because you have compelled us:
Had you not asked, we wouldn't have spoken willingly.
The third one is Pharoah, who was so famous,
Who made such great war against Moses and Aaron
And against the people of Jerusalem as well as [against] the Jews.
And the fourth one was called Esau the bad,
He persecuted Jews a lot and many others;
This one picked a quarrel before he died.
That other one was Herod who decapitated children,
And who had the head of John the Baptist cut off
Out of love for his daughter, who had greatly implored him for it.
When he did this, he committed great cruelty!
Now you can see how it is paid for in the end:
This [group] is quiet, troubled that you can now see
What they have have endured there; let them have what was prepared for them.
That other one was Judas, who hanged himself,
Who sold his Lord and [did it] for thirty coins.
The other was Ganelon, an evil traitor,
Who sold his companions to Marsile the Saracen.
There are quite a few other people who are not named at present;
Now we beg you to let us go henceforth on our way,
Because we're late, we'll be much worse off.
We know quite well all that you are asking;
You cannot accomplish all that you are seeking—-
It is necessary for you to go by another route,
And you'll see many other still greater things.
When it will please your Lord, everything will be achieved;
If we had power over you, you would soon be dead!
Go on your way for you have delayed us too long.
You see the mountain there; soon we will have descended.
If you happen upon us here, I tell you truly,
That we and you will soon be killed."

lg.head: Laisse 303
lg.l: "Go," said the count, "with the curse of God!
Justice summons you for what you have merited,
And we here will go on without difficulty.
When it pleases God, we'll complete our quest."
The evil spirits [went away] hurriedly
And Huon followed them always at a good trot.
It seemed to him that the mountain was disintegrating,
And huge rocks were often falling
Which [fell] on those wretched ones on the head and rump;
They howled so much that the mountain resounded.
They traveled past the mountain, fleeing every which way;
Never did they frighten the good count,
For God defended him as well as the two birds with him.
They hurried along their way until they came
To the other peak of the mountain, where the sea washed up.
The sea was quite violent and very deadly;
The count thought about what he should do;
Before he realized it, the two griffons just took hold of him.
They carried him beyond the sea along with the horse,
As gently as if he were in a ship.
Then [the griffons] placed them right away on flat land,
Without it being at all a burden to them.
They traveled far from the evil land,
A good forty leagues, so we believe,
For they approached another mountain:
On the top it's called "Noah's Ark."
It had many marvels all around and about [it],
As I will now recount in part to you at present.

lg.head: Laisse 304
lg.l: The count dismounted near the mountain,
He decided to rest, for he was rather tired out.
He wished to eat, because he hadn't been able to at all;
The horse grazed freely on the grassy meadow
Where [grass] grew in abundance,
And [the count] ate and drank a bit
At a spring that was there nearby;
As soon as he lay down he quickly fell asleep:
The birds that were with him kept watch.
He slept a lot and rested to his satisfaction.
After this, the baron said he wanted to climb up there,
On top of the high mountain. The horse could remain below;
He remained with one of the birds on guard;
The other followed [the count]; and so it was done.
The baron set out on his journey, he didn't want to tarry any longer,
He climbed the mountain in the name of Jesus.
Once he had gone a little way, he saw off to one side
A humble stone dwelling; it was part of a cave.
Three men lived there who followed a [monastic] rule;
All three wore the habit of the Augustinian order.
When Huon saw them, it pleased him very much;
Then he came over in that direction, he didn't tarry any longer;
When he drew near there, he said in a loud cry:
"Is there anyone inside there? Now don't be silent!
"I ask it in the name of God, for I am a Christian."
When those inside heard him,
[And] heard him name God, never had they been so joyous,
For it had been a long time since a living man had been there.
They came to their door, they opened it a little to him.
In hand [one of them] held a cross burning like fire:
"I conjure you, for the sake of Jesus,
That you not be able to harm us; if you are a good creature,
Now come forward; you are welcome."
And the count replied, "May it be just as you say."

lg.head: Laisse 305
lg.l: The count of Auvergne said, "Be reassured,
For I tell you as a certainty that I believe in God.
You'll suffer no harm from me; rather I'll help you
As much as I'm able, if God allows me to.
As for my comings and goings, please be patient regarding this;
A literate clerk, know this truly,
Certainly could not describe it in a month's time,
[Saying] anything other than this, I would be telling you a lie:
I have more good fortune than I'm worthy of."
At these words, the three friars went to hug the count,
They gathered him to them, they took great delight in him;
He was quick then to tell them [his story] with good speech.
Afterward the count of Auvergne continued with questions,
What country this was and what it was called, how they came to be living there.
The most senior of them said, "Now listen carefully:
People call the mountain 'Noah's Ark' currently,
At the time of the flood, as it pleased God,
There truly were [some] from every species of animal here.
After the flood they spread over the entire earth,
Each one reproduced [and] filled the great world,
As you surely see day by day.
Then the first generation remained up on this mountain,
Then another generation issued forth from them,
Another from that one, then [each species] went on multiplying.
They can never produce more than one offspring;
They remain on the mountain, they don't leave.
People call all these animals holy;
Indeed, each year, on the day of Good Friday,
Adam and Noah with other holy men,
Who in ancient times were likewise under the Old Law,
Come to visit the Ark, which they love immeasurably.
For eight days they remain there in true tranquility.
As they leave, they bless all the animals,
And others present--believe this!
They then return to the realm of glory, as it pleases God.
One who would like to tell the story and what it concerns
Would have quite a lot to say on that subject; for that reason I'll stop talking about it.
But I would tell you this much about it, indeed I'm announcing it to you,
That now in fact the celebration of this day approaches
When [the holy men] must return to perfomr their task.
Those who come to this place will celebrate a feast day;
They'll be able to see some of God's great mysteries,
From which they become better if they have the discernment.
But he who remains in great sin must really beware
Before he can go up there safely:
He would have to pass through several great trials,
It would go well for him if he came back alive!
But every good man who believes in God
Will be little harmed by these, for God doesn't allow it.
He can surely go wherever he wants at that point;
I've told you a part of the story concerning this great mountain.
Now I'll tell you about my situation, how I am dwelling here,
And what my lineage is and how I am called."

lg.head: Laisse 306
lg.l: "My family descended, [my] friend, from the Narbonnais;
My father was the son of Gerart de Cormancis, [...]
Who, below Barbastre, won [my grandmother] in a tournament;
They called her Malatrie the Noble,
She was the daughter of the emir of Persia.
From them was born my father and one other as well,
Who served Lord William in the battlefield many times;
He died at Aliscans in the great combat.
My father was named the baron of Savary,
And as for my name, I'm called Henry.
During my youth before [I was] fifteen-and-a-half,
The desire came to me to go searching through the world
For the sake of remembrance of God and the Crucified One.
I was at Rome, I saw Saint Peter's tomb,
And I prayed at Saint Paul's.
I set out from there once I had gotten a pardon [for my sins],
I went to Saint James [of Compostella]; I honored him;
Thenceforward I was tormented for a long time,
So much so that one day I started out again [to go] to the [Holy] Sepulcher,
And I celebrated it; I remained there a long time.
I was much mistreated by those evil Arabs,
Both myself and these my companions whom you see here."

lg.head: Laisse 307
lg.l: "Worthy man," said the friar, "that cruel people,
Avenged their deadly wrath upon us,
Which is no lie; they did such things to us
[That] for the love of God, we served them peacefully;
For a long time we were captives in a fortress.
One day we were cast out, as it pleased the Holy Spirit.
Anyone who wished to recount all these misfortunes--
The telling would take a long time, and for that reason I don't care to,
Except that there was a galley, on which we ended up,
Of deceitful Turks who pillaged every day,
And when they took something that displeased them,
They turned their mockery and evil onto us.
However, one day right after Pentecost
They were forced to come here because of a strong and evil wind.
The galley shattered, not even one of them escaped;
We however survived, for which we were joyous,
Since we were delivered from those villainous sailors."

lg.head: Laisse 308
lg.l: "As I have explained to you, [my] friend, we escaped,
We were on the shore, frightened, for many days.
We didn't know what to do, but the Holy Spirit
Transmitted to us a message from Himself,
Saying that we should remain here forever,
And thus we would be more cherished by Him.
Neither phantom nor spirit could hurt [us],
Nor vermin, nor beast, however cruel it might be,
As long as we were in His keeping; you must truly believe this.
It's been a very long time since we were placed in this grotto;
We've been waiting for the coming of a renowned knight,
Who is thus supposed to do wonders in this land;
[At that time] he hadn't yet been born and wouldn't be born for a while."

lg.head: Laisse 309
lg.l: "Thus, fair brother, we await the coming
Of this good knight as I said just now;
We live every day according to God's commandments.
You still don't know the whole truth of my situation:
My father had a brother whose name was Boson.
He was a very worthy man for as long as he was alive in the world;
He held the city and castle keep of Auvergne,
And many great possessions besides that.
I saw a son when I left [there];
If he were alive, he would have the heart of a nobleman.
Every soldier and servant called him Huon;
We placed my two young brothers with him,
They are called Guiolin and the other Bovo.
Since I left my home,
I haven't heard any news whatsoever; I have mourned for them.
May God guide them to the good! He will do so, this I believe.
Now I have told you about my family, I don't tell it vainly;
These others, my brothers, are quite noble men,
They were born in Auvergne." Then he told their names.
When Huon heard this, at that moment, the count was moved;
He went to embrace his cousin without saying anything at all,
They wept copiously and then sighed.
The friars noticed it and marveled greatly at it:
"How can this thing be?" [the friars] said to them immediately,
"Are you related?" And Huon answered them:
"Yes, good friars, I am his first cousin.
I am that Huon whom we've been talking about."
They embraced one another and kissed each other several times.
Then afterward they told one another many other things;
Huon recounted to them part of what he had done in the world,
And what he seeking, and he told them the reason for it.

lg.head: Laisse 310
lg.l: "This is an incredible thing," his cousin answered him,
"Who could accomplish this without there being a miracle?
There is indeed a mountain over there; it is, appropriately, always burning;
It's a branch of Hell, where the damned go.
The great shouting and the cries are heard all the way here;
If all the carpenters in the world were there
And were hammering away as when they work the hardest,
They wouldn't make such a noise as those [creatures] always do.
Anyone who's been up on that mountain would certainly be able to see them;
Nearby it is surrounded by a very deep body of water,
We often see it boiling with fire that rises upward:
It is just for instilling great fear of the mountain.
Never will mortal men be able to enter there
Without having suffered death according to how their hearts prompt them.
But we will pray to the Lord of Heaven on your behalf
That He allow you to accomplish what you seek, lord count.
Yet I believe that no man in the world could leave that place."
Then Huon replied, "I've already been there
And indeed I really have experienced it and Jesus himself granted me [this],
Nor was a hair on my head harmed."
"Good God!" he said, "It's a divine miracle."
"I completely believe it," Count Huon replied.

lg.head: Laisse 311
lg.l: "By God," said the friar, "you make me really wonder
How you have survived in this way; in fact, you have more merit
Than any of our ancestors who have ever lived.
Enough of them have come straight to this land,
Each one was dismayed and silenced just at the sight of it;
I don't wish to tell you any more, but I believe with a true heart
That nothing in this earthly existence will hinder you from now on.
God will be with you, wherever you might go.
But this bird that is flying over the fallow land,
What does this mean, why does it have such an evil look?
Neither I nor these my brothers would dare to leave."
"By my faith," said Huon, "don't be afraid of them at all;
On the contrary, I truly thought that they would give you solace.
Another one of them is keeping watch over my horse;
See him there, grazing in the meadow?"
The [friar] looked at them, then he said, "O Crucified One!
Never has there been such a man in my lineage."

lg.head: Laisse 312
lg.l: Huon recounted to them how he came upon [the griffons],
And how they carried him over the body of water,
And how evil spirits tested him many times;
He told them the whole story, how he found himself there.
Nor did he conceal the prisoners whom he saw;
He told them everyone whom he had seen there by name.
When the friar heard this, he was much amazed,
Just hearing about it gave him the shivers!
Several times he shuddered violently,
But Count Huon comforted him a great deal.
"Let's consider going now," each one said,
"The road is a long one to climb, we know,
Before we make it up there where
Noah's Ark, which restored the world, is situated."

lg.head: Laisse 313
lg.l: The friar said, "The mountain will be very difficult going;
In two and a half days you couldn't climb up there
Without possible dangers [along the way] that now seem fearsome.
Since these birds are here for you to direct,
Just have them carry you up over there,
And we'll follow behind you at a slower step;
Thus they'll be able to spare you many difficult passages."
Then the count replied, "I'm not willing to agree to that;
Rather I'll share every hardship with you,
Since you can [only] go on horse or on foot;
He who wishes to serve God musn't fear any dangerous place
Or any bad thing that he might encounter.
Start on the road; we might tarry too long."
And so they did without delaying any longer.
The bird flew in front, thus it showed them the path.
If it came across any dangerous challenge or ferocious beast
That didn't clear off from the road they had to travel,
It quickly got into a fight with them; his fellow griffon had trouble enough.
When they entered into the fray;
Then you should have seen them, those evil beasts bellowing!
The whole mountain resounded as if it might collapse.
One trampled over the other, then started to roar;
They made many rocks fall when they were knocked down.
When the friars saw this, they began to marvel greatly;
And after that, they began to thank Jesus.
The journey caused them no harm; they hurried on;
They went quite far in one day and the next, they came to the top.
Next, there, at that moment, one of the griffons began to descend
To guard the countryside where the horse was grazing.

lg.head: Laisse 314
lg.l: When Huon was on the top of Noah's mountain,
He was quite joyous, for he had much wanted it.
He looked all about and around the fields;
He saw many animals that he had never seen before,
Which were different from those that he had seen.
He saw none of them cruel or ill-intentioned toward him;
Each one showed him signs of humility.
Many herds approached him one after another,
And he, [going] from one group to another, made the sign of the cross over them all.
Those [whom he had blessed] departed [and] sang in their [animal] language;
They went off to graze there where they found it best;
[Huon] had a lot of animals to bless there that day.
Then, as night approached, he drew near to the Ark;
He spent much time looking at it and contemplating it from all sides.
He saw it as whole as it had ever been;
He saw it very clearly; once he had thoroughly considered it,
He held it to be a holy thing, he kissed it a lot.
Afterward he and the other friars took shelter near it.
Huon got down on his knees and wept for his sins.
He prayed for himself and for humanity.
All night long he remained in the open air until daybreak;
He prostrated himself and sang his psalms,
And after that, he praised God very much.
He crossed himself and then he arose,
Huon the wise looked around the fields;
He saw the animals assembling according to their many groups.
Then he asked the friars, "You who know the custom,
What does all this mean? Now tell me,
Why does no [beast] make noise, nor does one hear any cries?"
The friar replied, "You will know it all;
They do this the day of Good Friday; know this for certain—
That our entire holy day must be observed by us
And continue the whole octave, I want you to know this for certain.
The holy forefathers, our advocates, are here
In remembrance of the Flood that came to an end in this place,
For Friday was when the Ark landed.
Know this, God [Jesus] was born and died on a Friday,
It is on this occasion that the Lord is remembered.
Every year they have observed the holy day for Him,
And for this reason these animals have assembled here.
According to the understanding that God has given them,
