They honor the Holy Father and He honored them very much.
In the rays of the sun once it has risen,
You will behold everything on this mountain
Accompanied by music; you mustn't get up at all,
You'll see Him clearly, but you won't be able to speak [to Him].
While his form stands and moves, you'll perceive Him
In three ways according to His pleasure.
And if you want to know about anything at all,
On some parchment sheets under His seal,
He will tell you the truth regarding your endeavor;
You won't learn it from Him in any other way."

lg.head: Laisse 315
lg.l: Huon the count said, "Brother, explain to me,
Will the holy forefathers come here to us,
In order to commemorate the Ark and the animals that are here?"
"Yes, indeed, you'll see them both here."
As they spoke, in fact, he suddenly heard a song;
No prince or king has heard such a melody,
He couldn't yet see those who made it.
Nothing in the world could compare to this.
They descended to the earth upon the land.
They blessed the animals and all those who came before them,
And then at once everyone bowed down in front of the Ark.
They conducted their service as they were accustomed to do,
And the song increased more and more in joy.

lg.head: Laisse 316
lg.l: Now the singing got louder and louder;
When Huon beheld them, he followed them,
He as well as the friars with him.
He was very well accustomed to pray to God;
He had never ever ceased to pray fervently;
He had never before been [so] moved; he didn't raise his eyes;
All the grass was bathed with tears from his eyes.
Huon saluted the holy fathers and grew faint.
When they saw him weeping so, they felt great compassion for him.
Willingly they would have spoken to him, if God had allowed it,
But it didn't please God the Father at this time or place;
They acted for the best, as they believed;
If they had spoken to him, such delight it would have been to him
That he wouldn't have been able to leave; because of this they refrained;
[Huon] would surely have forgotten about completing his quest.

lg.head: Laisse 317
lg.l: When [one of] the holy fathers saw Huon,
He then signaled to the friar, who was there alert,
That he immediately attend to the count who was much stricken:
He would be somewhat comforted by him and by them.
And so he did; many times they shook him;
So much had they turned him toward God
[That] he cared little about earthly existence.
The count greeted them and looked beyond them
And saw the holy fathers standing before him:
Then he was ashamed since he hadn't honored them;
His heart constricted, he didn't speak at all.
He approached the first one,
And got on his knees at [the holy father's] feet.
[Huon] thought then to seize and kiss them a great deal;
He found nothing [there], he was very ashamed.
Over and over again he did it, many times,
But in vain did he reach out; then he wept a lot.
So the friars raised [him] up; the holy father made the sign of the cross over him,
Between them they completely surrounded [Huon].
They showed them a friendly mien and signs of humility:
If he wanted to know about anything, let paper be given to [the holy father]
And ink as well, and [Huon] would know their information;
And Huon the valiant handed some over to him.
[The holy father] wrote in part about what [Huon] had been concerned about,
And he explained the truth about other things.
You will never know from me what the letter said
For these are secrets belonging to God, know this indeed for sure,
For He equips people to act rightly according to doctrine:
Anyone who carried [the letter] on him will not be unjustly condemned,
Nor will he sin mortally either by word or act.
It said other things further on that will be related to you--
That he should leave after his offering,
And then follow his path as he was accustomed [to do].
Other things would happen before this matter would be over;
If he trusted in God, He would bring him to salvation.
Thus the letter ended. Huon read it many times,
So much so that the count committed it to memory;
He put it in his alms purse, then he turned toward the fields.
The friars were speaking, expounding upon their entire journey,
So that he would remember [it] once he had left.
Afterward they showed him signs of humility;
Willingly he would have remained with them if it had been destined.

lg.head: Laisse 318
lg.l: Great was the celebration and the offering
Of the holy fathers and of the animals present!
There is no man alive who could describe it well:
The singing from Heaven that they heard from time to time—
It lasted the whole octave. Huon saw another things
That the book doesn't explain which is done for the best.
Above all the things that Count Huon did—
The baron displayed his cross out of great devotion.
On the holy day of Easter the baron took communion,
He and the three friars who were there before him,
With that very host that the pope had given him;
The holy forefathers attended that Eucharist.
They showed humility, but they said nothing;
What should I tell you, without making a long speech?
The count was highly honored, he saw quite a lot that we aren't recounting.
After eight days they then took [their] departure.
Once [the holy fathers] had blessed each one there,
They visibly ascended into Heaven, which everyone saw.
With great singing they went; the [other] four remained;
The three friars showed Huon the entire area.
The mountain was so high that from it they saw far away;
All other mountains were nothing compared to this one;
He saw the Burning Mountain, as they were closeby,
And many other mountains whose names I couldn't say.
He saw many plains that had no inhabitants
Other than beasts and vermin; there were many other passes,
On one side was the sea, on the other a river lapped.
At the foot of this mountain one heard a noise of water;
Huon looked and noticed a river that ran there,
That flowed along the mountain and disappeared there,
It went underground, he didn't know where it went next.
He asked the three friars if they knew what it was named,
And the friars answered, "We call it the Tigris.
We know for sure that it issues forth from the earthly Paradise;
It flows through the fourth part of the world, so we believe.
Just as the sea [tides] rise precisely,
So does this river, indeed we know it well,
But how it comes to be, we can't tell you."

lg.head: Laisse 319
lg.l: "Cousin," said the friar, "no one can know
God's secrets, for it doesn't please God."
"Cousin," said Huon, "so my heart also believes.
Thanks be to God! You'll remain [here] from now on;
I urge you now to continue your pious life.
You see clearly that it's now incumbent upon me to leave this high place;
I want to continue my quest so long as I'm able to do so."
He made the sign of the cross over himself and over the animals he saw before him,
Then he kissed the Ark and descended the mountain.
The griffon went in front, opening the way,
So that no dangerous beast approached him.
He traveled until he came to the plain;
He caught sight of his horse and the bird who guarded him.
The horse saw his lord, he whinnied in his direction;
He demonstrated great delight when he saw his lord.
Huon took hold of him and then he mounted;
He commended the friars to God, then took to his road.

lg.head: Laisse 320
lg.l: Now the count, who didn't delay, departed;
Never before had he been so lighthearted any day of his life,
He thanked God profusely, he recited many psalms:
He recited Beati imaculati to its conclusion.
He made his way along the river Tigris,
Once he had found it, he didn't leave it.
The birds went ahead, always flying.
They protected him for a long time on the road;
[Huon] was in many difficulties; I can tell [it] in part:
Dragons and flying birds, other frenzied beasts,
All decamped out of fear of the griffons,
Thus the count wasn't vexed by them at all.
Once he had left the Holy Ark,
He rode more than half a year, riding all day long;
The shortest [daily] stage he did was fifteen leagues' worth of steps.
He was not alarmed by anything he saw,
Never had there lived a man with his daring.
The more tight spots he found himself in, the more assured he was:
He came across a valley that he followed for a day,
No one lived there except wild lions;
He saw quite a few of them in many groups.
The baron walked right in front of them;
None of them ever gave him any evil looks,
Rather they demonstrated every sign of humility.
Huon passed on and blessed many of them.
Then afterward, he came across another valley
That was completely full of resting elephants.
He took him more than three days to pass through it
Without finding any harm from them,
For God, who was helping him, didn't allow it.

lg.head: Laisse 321
lg.l: The baron rode energetically
--I can't tell you about his travels--
Until one day he arrived at the foot of a mountain.
Between the river Tigris and the side of the summit,
There was a small haven in a lovely meadow.
There the baron dismounted, he rested a bit,
For the worthy man wanted to eat and sleep.
He ate some herbs that were found there,
Then Count Huon went to lie down close to a round tree
To sleep as much as he liked.
And then later on, when the baron awoke,
He saw the entire tree as well as the entire meadow on all sides
Filled with little birds,
In a multitude that no one could count;
They were completely black, just like crows.
Among themselves they sang and spoke beautifully;
One would start, the others would repeat.
As he listened to this, a beautiful song rang out,
"God, how good it is for brothers to live in unity."
They recited this psalm and Huon heard it well,
At what he saw and heard, the valiant man
Marvelled greatly; he crossed himself,
And prayed to God that He demonstrate
What the meaning was of these many little birds,
Who sang so well and gave such fine sermons.

lg.head: Laisse 322
lg.l: Once the baron had completed his prayer,
One of the birds that was with him
Explained to him in the Auvergnat language:
"You have prayed to God in Heaven
To know why we are here:
We'll explain it partially; now listen well:
It pleases Jesus that we know in part
Some of his secrets that otherwise [we would] not [know] at all.
Know then that we are from that realm
That fell into the deep abyss
That many men call Hell.
We were not at all part of that plot;
When the moment of the expulsion came
All around the heavens shook.
Angels and archangels and the entire kingdom,
Everyone trembled, full of fear.
At the voice alone of God the Father when He spoke,
All the evildoers appeared there.
They resisted as long as they had the strength;
When they couldn't anymore, they were cast down---
Some driven into the air, others came here to earth,
Others wear out their existence in the abyss."

lg.head: Laisse 323
lg.l: "Vassal," said the devil in the form of a little bird,
"We who are here did neither good nor evil,
But rather it was our intention
Always to stay on the side of those who would win.
Since God the Father knows our thoughts,
He transfigured [us] henceforth into the form of birds that we are;
We came to this mountain,
We undergo many torments, but there are worse ones.
I'll tell you about one of them, we won't mention the others,
For it would do nothing for you if I recounted them.
In the air and in the sea we do our fishing:
However the waves carry us, that is how we go along,
We know how to fish, yet we catch nothing at all;
Such is our agony.
One day of the week we have a respite;
That is Sunday when we remain in this place:
This is what we call our paradise.
Here we'll stay, we'll remain tonight,
Then, tomorrow at dawn, we'll leave right away,
And we will endure what we're destined for.
While we're here, we have rest;
We all raise our voices to exalt as we are able
In praise of God the Father, we know this well."

lg.head: Laisse 324
lg.l: "By my faith," said the count, "you've had good luck,
For you received some respite from God
Thus may God be praised above all.
I would like to hear from you concerning another matter,
Whether you [know] anything about my quest, for you [must] know something about it."
"I know a lot about it," he said, "as you'll be able to hear.
Your road from here is very long; I want you to know:
Without the Divine Power you'll never be able to get there.
But it pleases God well, and it actually has been revealed to me,
That this summer it could be completely fulfilled.
However, before that might occur, you'll see many marvels,
I can't say anymore about this; serve your Lord,
Indeed love Him with a good heart; He will be your advocate,
For in the end each one is rewarded for their deeds.
One gets what one deserves."
"Indeed I believe it thoroughly," answered the count right away.
Thereupon he began praying again,
As much as he desired. When the next day dawned,
[The little birds] left and the count remained.
He prostrated himeself in his usual way;
He crossed himself, then he mounted his horse.
He took to the road, the griffons going in front;
He rode for many days without rest,
And indeed he saw quite a few dangers,
Such that if God had not come to his aid,
He would hardly ever have gotten through them.
The baron advanced as far as he could,
He came upon an adventure, as you will hear.
The waters of the Tigris appeared to have darkened,
For many clouds shrouded it in three places
Because of the passages that were forbidden to him.
One hour of the day then it was bright enough to see,
Even through the entire country beyond.
The count gazed for a little while before him;
He saw one pillar that was bordered in marble.
There was another one carved since the time of Moses
That forbade passage, as you'll hear:
"Oh, you, man, beware hereafter what you do!
Don't go on any further unless you are filled with faith
And free of filth and cleansed of your sins!
And if you do it, you'll pay for it dearly;
Never has any wretch on earth suffered so much."

lg.head: Laisse 325
lg.l: When Huon understood this message,
He greatly feared his downfall.
He truly believed that his end had come;
He held himself a great sinner, he got upset.
He dismounted at once from his horse,
He knelt in the grass on the open ground.
He lamented his sins, many tears fell there;
For every sin he thoroughly beat his flesh.
He called himself a sinner, saying, "Oh, wretched one,
What if I weren't to complete what I have undertaken!"
No creature indeed could have seen
The anguished sorrow he expressed
Without being moved to pity for him.
For a long time he remained in this dejected state;
He lamented and sighed and asked God for help,
That his soul not be lost,
He didn't care one bit about his body.
After that, he recited his psalms:
De profundis clamavi, such was the beginning,
Ad te Domine Domine, so that he might be heard,
[And] Oracionem meam until its conclusion.
And when he had finished those, he recalled others,
And then he straightened up like an intelligent man.
He made a speech, he didn't say it silently:
Even if he should die, he wouldn't stop,
Rather he would continue on his way forward
For he wished to complete [his quest] the best a mortal man could.
He crossed himself, he set out on his journey.
He grasped in his hand the cross he possessed;
It showed him the way as it gave off great light,
The birds went in front, for they didn't linger.
The baron, whose courage impelled him, rode on.
Before he broke out of the shadows
He had ridden for three days, he had seen many marvels.
He passed beyond them all, he feared nothing at all.
Afterward he entered a great leafy plain,
There were plants and trees cultivated and flourishing:
All those plants that people seek for healing
And good fruit that is pleasing to the human body
Were found in that place; they were there in abundance.
No weeds flourished there;
Animals dwelled there whom God had first placed [there]
When Adam sinned and because they broke their pledge
To their Creator to whom they had sworn it.
Everyone in the wretched [human] race is born from them;
One calls it the Promised Land, so it is said.

lg.head: Laisse 326
lg.l: The baron Huon rode on, without ever stopping,
At full speed, praying to the High Majesty,
Along the waters of the Tigris, as the author has made known.
The virtuous count rode for a long time without anything troubling him
Until he came right next to a mountain,
There where the river lost its force;
The count was sheltered, without noises and without storms.
He let the horse graze over the wide valley;
In another direction the wild birds took their meal.
This count of noble lineage came to the spring;
He drank some water and ate some of that which pleased him best.
Afterward he lay down, as exhausted as he could be,
He fell asleep for a little while, then woke up feeling completely fit,
He felt himself to be as alert as a fighting lion.
Nevertheless he never stopped exalting [and] praising Celestial Glory,
So long as he had the ability to do it.

lg.head: Laisse 327
lg.l: Huon thought about all he was doing;
He stood upright, then afterward crossed himself.
He looked before him, he saw two men
From antiquity who came quickly toward him.
Once they were near him, they called Huon by name:
"In this kingdom, vassal, be welcome here.
We know well what you seek to know;
We have long awaited you.
But our Lord, whom man calls the Living God,
Makes known to you through us, and we will tell you
That getting what you have been recently seeking
Cannot be achieved by mortal man
Unless the Divine Power does it through you.
But because you are so determined--don't disbelieve this--
The Lord who restored the world sends word to you through us
That your quest will be accomplished with this year [and]
You yourself will return safely.
Before that, you'll see many miracles,
Hardly anyone has ever seen so many.

lg.head: Laisse 328
lg.l: When Huon heard this, he bowed,
He got down on his knees before them;
He thanked [both] God and them profusely.
Then he said to them humbly, "I entreat you
That nothing be kept secret from me
Concerning that which I am seeking; at present tell me the truth about it."
"Willingly," they said, "ask what you like.
I am Enoch, I'm still alive here;
This is Elijah, thus are we truly called.
Here we remain and [will do so] even into the future.
This place, truly, I want you to know, friend,
Our ancestors called it the Promised Land;
It extends two hundred leagues wide and long as well,
You don't see here anything at all that is not very good."
After [explaining] all this, he revealed the nature of it:
"That river that flows over there marks the boundary of this place here,
Of Earthly Paradise where Adam failed;
And no man living today may enter there
Except for us, to whom God has conceded everything;
We are guardians, informed of your coming."
Afterward they thoroughly explained to him a large part of the place;
They spoke a lot about it; he saw a lot of it,
Including the four rivers that flow forth from the spring
And divide the entire earth; one was named the Tigris,
The others, the Euphrates, the Jordan and the Pishon.

lg.head: Laisse 329
lg.l: "O God," said Huon, "It is good to dwell here;
I wouldn't depart from here if I weren't afraid of being disloyal!
But since I pledged my faith to my lord,
As long as I live, I won't act falsely toward him.
So I pray to my Creator that He allow me to carry out best
What I have undertaken to do, for the benefit of my soul,
So that I always proceed entirely in good faith."
After this, they began to speak about many things;
Each answered the other concerning what he was asking.
There he remained for several entire days;
Huon gave them the cross that the pope had given him,
They worshipped it devoutly and then they kissed it;
Tears fell from their eyes, then they took communion
With the very host that Huon gave them.
Each gave some of it to the other, with a good heart each asked for it.
After this, he recited his psalms, then began to cross himself.
"I commend you to God," said Huon the baron,
"I wish to pursue my quest in the name of God the Father,
What path shall I take now? I don't want to turn back."
And they replied, "It will be necessary to pass through on this side:
That will lead you toward the seashore."
Then they rushed all three to kiss [each other].
They made a great lamentation when it was time to separate,
And they gave him three fruits
From among the most precious ones that bloomed in the earthly Paradise.
"Here," they said, "these can never spoil.
They are worth a great treasure, should one want to assign a value."
The count took them and then he began to kiss them;
Then he placed them inside his alms purse.

lg.head: Laisse 330
lg.l: The count left them and mounted his horse;
The two griffons, whom the brave man did not forget, followed him.
He traveled past cliffs and through valleys
Until he came to the mist that created the darkness
That blocked the entrance in front and on the side.
The faithful man took hold of his cross and passed through;
He journeyed night and day for three days;
Once they were beyond [the mist] he saw the open sea.
The count rode on, making no stops in that place,
Day by day through pain and torment.
When sleep overtook him and he required something to eat
And he stopped, he and his horse,
The vassal never had the possibility of being really safe,
For many monsters came forth out of the sea
Often threatening them;
Many times the birds held [the monsters] back.

lg.head: Laisse 331
lg.l: The griffons frequently defended him from them.
Furthermore he caught sight of a swarm of birds:
There were so many [of them] together that no one had [ever] seen so many;
They were bigger than crows and had feathers like them.
They had long, hard beaks---longer than a foot and a half;
May God protect the count so that he not now perish!
The air was full of them in every direction,
And both he and his horse had to defend themselves.
He killed many of them when they got close to them;
I can rightly say--I don't believe I have lied--
That no man on earth ever suffered so much torment,
Because all day long swing his sword at the birds
Who planned to eat his horse and him likewise.
The daylight disappeared and the night darkened;
Those evil birds returned to their nests.
The count went away, he didn't lodge there;
The two griffons followed him, but they were greatly weakened,
For they had received more than a hundred wounds from those birds
By defending themselves and the lord count.

lg.head: Laisse 332
lg.l: For a great part of the night the messenger from France
Rode away from there with hope in God,
For he was very afraid of the evil birds.
Once he thought they were safe, he dismounted there.
He stayed in that place until daylight shone,
Then he examined his horse to see if he was at all harmed.
He found him in rather good health; he thanked God and His might for it.
Then he examined the griffons; he was very deeply distressed
When he saw them bleeding; he was heart-stricken.
He would have immediately treated them according to his knowledge,
[But] a misfortune rushed upon them which made things worse for them.
Wasps and hornets began to fill the air entirely:
They rose up from underground, which revealed their nature.
When Huon saw this, he ran to his horse from Konstanz
Speedily without making any delay.
He mounted him, then he fled at great speed;
The more he got ahead, the more he felt menaced.
The two griffons gave him little defense,
For they could not protect even themselves
Because of the previous attack they had endured.

lg.head: Laisse 333
lg.l: The two griffons endured the attack
From the wasps whose sting passed through their skin.
They cried out wildly; Huon heard them very well,
But he couldn't do anything at all to protect them—
He had so much himself to do [that] before too long
Both griffons were slain there.
Through the effort of the horse whom the wasps attacked
Huon had escaped; but he had a doleful countenance
Because of the two birds whom the hornets had killed.
When he found a meadow, there he dismounted,
He began to walk to refresh the war horse;
He led the prized war horse by the golden bridle.

lg.head: Laisse 334
lg.l: In this manner did Huon go on, leading his horse;
All day long he traveled, until full night fell.
The count ate a bit of wild plant roots
To keep up his strength.
He allowed the horse to graze for there were no oats;
Then the captain stretched out and slept a little.
It wasn't possible to safeguard themselves, he saw that for certain;
As soon as dawn brightened, he took hold of the Arab war horse.
He rode on, lamenting his sins, with a frank countenance;
The count went on foot and led his horse.
[The horse] was so exhausted that he could hardly walk;
The superior noble count wanted to spare him.

lg.head: Laisse 335
lg.l: The count, who didn't want to stop, continued on;
He feared for himself and for the spirited war horse,
That some cruel event might harm them.
He saw quite a few monsters coming out of the sea
That began to pursue each other.
They calmed themselves once they were in wild water;
They didn't take notice of Huon the knight,
For that would have given him quite a lot to do.
He baron continued on, he didn't want to tarry.
He rode along until he moved away from the sea;
There he found a very beautiful pasture,
And it was a remote place, as far away as one might think [to find].
He took a four-day rest there.
On the fifth he moved on and began to ride.
Once he had recited his psalms and the homily,
He raised his hand and began to cross himself.
He traveled until he came upon a mountain,
With the sea on one side, the forest on the other.
On the summit in front [of him] beyond the coast,
He came upon a huge mass of ants---
The smallest one was much bigger than a boar---
That were digging in the mountain where it was wildest.
They were excavating an abundance of gold out of it and then piling it up;
He saw many of them come out and quite a few go in;
He didn't covet one penny of what he saw;
He left that place, he didn't want to remain any longer.
He left the sea behind, he headed toward the forest,
Then he rode six whole days altogether
Without coming across anything greatly disturbing.
The seventh day the count began to ride
In the direction he thought it best to go.
He exited the forest and left the coast behind;
Nevertheless, he was able continually to watch it.
Traveling like this, the count[mulling] over a huge concern,
Presently had to ride through a difficult passage
Whether he wanted to or not; the way he had to go was narrow.
He came upon a great serpent, he couldn't avoid it
Because the passage was narrow and very difficult to follow.
When the count saw it, he dismounted right away,
For he thought to defend his horse.
But the count was unable to advance enough
To be able to protect his horse
From the evil serpent, for it darted behind [them].
It took hold of the horse across the flank,
It gave [the horse] such a squeeze that it made him fall,
Because the horse couldn't help himself.
With brute force it killed him.
When Huon saw this, he was filled with outrage;
He had never been so sorrowful since he had been born of woman,
He counted his life not worth a penny.
He rushed upon the serpent, he struck it many times;
He considered it of no worth, he didn't value it one bit.
When he saw that he couldn't kill it that way,
He moved to thrust the sword in its throat;
He split its heart, thus he struck it to the ground.

lg.head: Laisse 336
lg.l: Now the count was deprived of ;his horse.
He felt great sorrow when he saw him
Dead on the ground next to him; [the horse] had been completely defeated.
"Oh, good horse," he said, "you who have accompanied me
Up to this point like a faithful friend!
I never saw you exhausted because of hunger!
You have left and forsaken me in faraway peril;
There would be no way to return whence I came,
The routes are too horrible.
Oh, Promised Land, sacred and blessed,
When I left you behind, I committed a very great sin!
It would have been much better had I not left there
To go wandering through this strange land.
If I thought I could find a better road,
I would return there, rather than dying here.
I am in a kind of place from which I won't return alive;
Never will a family member or friend see me [again],
Not even my wife to whom I swore my faith.
Noble countess, now I can surely say to you,
However much I left you against my will,
The way [back] is forbidden to me and taken away!
I'll never have the consolation of going back.
It's been three days since I ate or drank;
I have traveled so much both by night and by day,
That I truly believe for certain, if the written texts are true,
That the quest that was sworn by me
Will never be accomplished; I am very downcast about that.
Alas, wretch, why did you leave
From Enoch and Elijah, who honored me very much?
May God guide me, I proclaim myself repentant."
At that moment he prostrated himself on the earth:
Tears fell from his eyes and he beat his breast;
He confessed his sins, he put himself in the hands of God the Father.

lg.head: Laisse 337
lg.l: He got down on his knees and looked up
As devoutly as ever he could.
He was accustomed to praying this way;
Day by day he never failed to do it.
"O Lord God, what advice do You offer me,
As You did for the lost prophets
In Limbo, where they were confined?
You were hung on the Cross for their sake and ours,
Your death redeemed us;
You carried clear light into darkness
To those who were suspended in Limbo.
By means of that holy piety and virtue
For which You were flogged and beaten
And placed and nailed onto the Cross,
At which time You were pierced with the lance
That passed through Your body right through the torso,
Every sin that anyone ever committed
As far back as when they were born
Was pardoned through You, Lord Jesus,
Provided that they repented.
When You were in anguish on the Cross,
Fair Nazarene Lord, out of pity
For Your mother whose heart was consumed
By great sorrow and overwhelmed and bewildered,
You said, when You showed her Your disciple,
And then you said to John as if to a beloved one,
'Here is your mother,' for You had chosen him
With such words as I have now recalled.
Have mercy on me, gentle and blessed fruit,
On this wretch who has been lost for a long time.
I am weary of wandering in this inhospitable place!
Everything I have set out [to do] has been impossible,
For the Scriptures speak of it and have said [so];
But if it please You, I will never be forsworn;
I declare myself overwhelmed by my sin before You."
Then he arose from his weeping completed overcome.

lg.head: Laisse 338
lg.l: Count Huon arose from his prayer,
He wept and wiped his eyes with his hand,
Then he looked around at the grassy valley.
Below a tree whose leaves had fallen
There appeared a shadow in the guise of a pilgrim:
He had a grayist-brown coat torn in several places,
The hat on his head wasn't worth a lettuce.
[With] small eyes of sinister appearance,
A broad mouth, jagged teeth,
He seemed a devil come out of Hell.
He propped his ugly face on one of his hands;
He signaled with the other and said nothing.
Huon saw him, [but] didn't move toward him.
Then he said aloud, "Saint Mary, help!
I have never seen anyone so misshapen in my misadventures."
He crossed himself and then he said, declaring [to himself],
"I see the shape of a man, I don't know if he is human."
Then he approached this sudden apparition
And said, "What are you doing in this lost wasteland?
Are you really a man or a visible phantom?
I invoke you, in the name of the three virtues,
That is the Father, the Son [and] the [Holy] Spirit, that are unchangeable in one sole God,
That you not be able to harm me; I have pledged my faith."
The pilgrim, who had heard these words, replied:
"I am not a man, nor made of flesh;
I first issued forth from the High Glory.
Owing to the evil intention [we] directed toward God,
We were cast out and fell from His kingdom."
The count heard him; it filled him with dread.

lg.head: Laisse 339
lg.l: The count was afraid, [but] the other told him not to worry:
"I'm not powerful [enough] to cause you any harm.
My companionship is indeed necessary to you:
I know well without difficulty everything that you are seeking;
Through long deprivation you have certainly won the struggle.
Now come with me and have no shame;
For the sake of our Creator to whom you have pledged your faith,
I have no power over you [for me] to imagine doing [you] harm.
It is fitting that I lead you into the presence of the great Demon
Where you'll be able to see the laypeople and the monks,
The various peoples of Auvergne and of Gascony
From whom Heaven has distanced itself because of their great sins,
And [where you'll be able to] tell what you will to the one who is informed
Through your coming, and don't think this is a lie,
On behalf of King Charles, who trades in justice."
Then the count replied, "May the Lord God not grant
That I have such company in this task."

lg.head: Laisse 340
lg.l: "Well!" said the false angel, "tell me then what you would do.
I know all the good and the bad about your situation.
If you die owing to your own failure you will suffer punishment.
It has already been several days that you've eaten nothing;
Make haste then on your road since you have a good guide,
And you'll deliver your message and then return from there
To the people of your land; you'll still have a difficult situation:
They'll suffer great deprivation, don't take it as a joke.
If you knew the truth of it, as things are going now,
You would die of sorrow, but it doesn't please Jesus Christ
That you should know, and for that reason, I will say no more.
Now come with me, good sir, if you please."
And the count said to him again, "You will never lead me,
For I would be very foolish if I relied on you.
Get away from me, oh, evil spirit,
For I wouldn't ever believe you about anything,
If it please God, concerning what you have said to me.
He'll send me a more trustworthy guide, I know,
To help me; you will never guide me.
You haven't been worthy of belief since the great transgression,
When you refused the high place for the low one.
In fact, when you were disloyal and a traitor to yourself,
That was a sign that you would never love anything
Owing to the covetous behavior by which you harmed yourself.
And you, as more of a liegeman [to Lucifer] than another devil,
Have come to the market where you will gain little."
And the [devil] answered him, "That day in your palace,
When you sent for all the poor people [and] you gave everyone dinner,
I was outside disguised as a hideous poor man.
You sent for me, you held up the dinner for a long time,
I was the one who took bread and a fat capon
From your table, as well as the wine and the dishes;
You'll need them again in order to eat
In the eternal dark of the sorrowful palace.
Since it was for the sake of God that you put me at such ease,
It's fitting that I guide to where the prime evil one lodges.
There you'll see my lord, the felonious Satan,
Who, because of great envy, was driven out from above to down below;
There you'll be able to see Cain and Judas,
And many wretched souls who are with the evil ones,
Who will never get out of the bad place, rather we will double their woe.
Now come with me, don't be afraid anymore."
"I will not," said Huon, "by Saint Nicholas;
Get out of here now, you wicked criminal!"
And [the other] replied, "Then you'll stay here;
Henceforth I leave you to your danger and to your peril."

lg.head: Laisse 341
lg.l: After this speech the baron replied:
"If it's true that it pleases Him who sits on the throne
That I come to the lost dwelling with a guide
He'll soon send me [one] more adequate than you.
Go on your way, and don't talk to me about it anymore.
If it pleases God, I will surely be provided for,
As the one who, with good intentions,
Goes to deliver Charles's message."
And [the devil] turned away, angry and crestfallen;
Thus did the spirit without favor
Take leave of the count with his head bowed.
He turned away back toward a grove,
Not going as far as a crossbow bolt shot.
Huon saw another shade armed from top to bottom
Come suddenly out of a stretch of wilderness,
As alone as when a bear emerges from the woods.
In his bearing he resembled a nobleman;
He was covered in iron from head to foot;
With a sword buckled on, he held a sprig in his hand,
All green, from a young olive plant;
His helmet laced up, neither eye nor forehead was visible;
He was fully ten feet tall.
He approached Huon slowly
And said, "What are you doing in this land?
You roam like a wild man, and who knows what else;
Aren't you willing to believe what we tell you about it?
From day to day you come across nothing but evil."
Then [the shade] said in a loud voice, "You won't believe anyone except yourself!
Safely, without any distrust,
Come with me; thus I will guide you
In security and as your protection
Before the master who is in the infernal prison.
Not a hair on your head will be harmed,
For that would never please God on high on His throne.
There you'll be able to see many souls in misery
Who are condemned to the infernal dwelling:
You'll be able to see Marsile and Danebron,
King Goliath, Agolant and Helmont,
Bishops, archbishops and popes, of which there are many,
And many knights, sergeants and foot soldiers;
One can see people of all sorts.
Each one has his just deserts from what he did in the world;
If there is greater torment for some than others, we know about it,
Their evil is written clearly, they have it on their forehead.
Ever to leave that place where they are
Is a lost cause and everyone knows it well,
Even Aristotle himself and his companions,
For so it is decreed by God on high on His throne."

lg.head: Laisse 342
lg.l: The count of Auvergne looked at the armed shade,
And listened to the words that were spoken to him,
Since they reassured him concerning the sorrowful road.
[Huon] answered him like a well-mannered person:
"Are you, who show yourself before me, a man or a shade?
You have spoken to me well;
Tell me who you are and where your country was.
Make surer you're not from the false multitude
Who were expelled from Heaven owing to arrogance;
[In that case] I wouldn't believe you no matter what was recounted."
"I am not [one of them]," he said, "but rather [one] of the damned,
[That is, those] people who were born before baptism;
Before pity was incarnated in the Virgin,
My flesh had been rotting for a very long time.
If I had just touched some of that water
By which the human race is saved,
I wouldn't fear waiting for the sound of the trumpet
That will call everyone to assemble in [the Valley of] Josaphat,
There where the Cross of God and the lance will be carried
And the great wound in the right side will be shown.
Then it will be obvious who has led a good life!
My ancestors about whom you have asked
Were Trojan, exiled from their land,
Which was set alight and burned by the Greeks
Simply because of the woman who was taken away from the temple--
That was Helen who had very great renown---
They[, my ancestors] thus died in that invasion.
After the destruction, I lived a good while
Because I escaped to a foreign land;
Then I caused harm to the Greek people;
I pursued them every day, as long as I was able.
The evil gods, out of their spite,
Made me go [still alive,] a soul within a body,
Into the land that you have sought for so long,
Where Sibyl, the evil one, led me
Using the great craft that spurred her on;
I searched Hell with my naked sword.
Now I want you to know my true name:
I was the son of Anchises; people call me Aeneas,
For whose love Dido, mad with grief, committed suicide."

lg.head: Laisse 343
lg.l: "[What a] marvel I have heard!" the count replied.
"Holy Mary," he said, "are you the one
Of whom I have heard so much,
Who was alive in the lost kingdom,
According to what the good Virgil tells?
Oh, Aeneas, if you had believed
In the Son of God who was [born] of the Virgin,
I would put myself in your hands for love of Him,
That you might take care of my well-being."
"I came here," [Aeneas] said, "in order to help you
Because of the desire of the One whom you mentioned;
Out of [that desire] good faith will be carried out through Him:
I must escort you to seek the tribute
For which Charles Martel sent you, you know it well.
Have no fear because of those wretched ones;
Neither Charon nor Cerberus can harm you;
Have trust in me, if that [devil] doesn't please you.
They won't have power over you, would that they no longer had it
Over me, a sinner, since I wasn't baptized."

lg.head: Laisse 344
lg.l: Like a young girl who is quite hesitant
To obey a man because of a promise of money
--Who worries that he will do no such thing, [that is, pay her,]
Because previously he had done exactly that--
The count also had just such a thought about
What Athenor did to the Trojan people.
[Huon] replied to him in a very friendly manner:
"Forgive me now, noble spirit,
For not being eager to come with you;
And if better assistance than you isn't forthcoming,
I wish to entreat you, by God Almighty,
Whom you never worshipped when you were alive,
That you show me the road to safety,
So that I may return to some [normal] dwelling;
Because I wouldn't dare because you're supernatural
To come with you among the lost people.
And if I have come here foolishly,
I confess my sins as a man who repents,
However late the thought might be.
I have realized that he offends God
Who asks for an impossible gift.
Flee from here; I won't believe you at all!
You were once a traitor, to yourself and to other people,
Part of the ruin of Troy occurred because of you,
Which meant its downfall.
Whoever might trust in you would act very badly."
And the other replied, "I'm sorry about this;
If you don't have guidance from me to your liking,
May God give you someone more adequate than I."

lg.head: Laisse 345
lg.l: Now the count was overcome by doubt;
He didn't know what to do or whom to trust.
He began to feel very sorry for himself.
Tears fell from his eyes to his chin;
They bathed his hauberk and gilded sleeve.
Even the spirit wept out of concern.
"Friend," he said, "this weeping is childish;
Anyone who begins his labor and doesn't finish it
Because of empty regret acts badly.
A lesser guide made me, with less hope,
Enter into the dark dwelling place.
And you, who appear to have more power,
Don't want to come; where does this ignorance come from?
I'm worried about you, for I see you in danger;
You sinned when you left France,
For you cause pain to others through your misfortune."

lg.head: Laisse 346
lg.l: For this speech, Count Huon thanked him,
The son of Anchises, who was moved on his account.
[Huon] looked in front of him toward the right;
Without a boat and without a galley, there seemed to issue forth
From a spring out of which water was flowing,
An old hermit with a white beard,
Low brows and a joyful countenance,
With long hair never combed at all,
Nine feet tall,
[Wearing] a coat as black as boiled pitch,
[With] outer flocking of a similar type,
The hood folded behind his shoulders.
When Aeneas saw him, he bowed down and cried out:
"Saintly spirit, have pity on this one,
Who has been lost in a strange country."
Then he said to Huon, "Your mission will be carried out.
You don't want to believe me no matter what I say,
Because I'm not in the high company
Of the prophets and of Saint Jeremiah.
Go with this one, in the name of Saint Mary;
Because he is in truth a saint, he will guide you well
Before the one who will never have remedy
Because he fell from Heaven out of envy."
The count of Auvergne listened to the speech,
He went toward [the figure]; he bowed down low,
Then he got on his knees right next to [the other's] feet,
For he seemed to him a man of holy life.
He wanted to embrace him, but he found nothing at all:
[The other] was a spirit, exactly like a shade,
For he consisted of neither flesh nor bone.
When Huon realized this, he was ashamed of himself;
He thought he might have been deceived when the holy man called to him,
"Have no fear; I cannot be a trick."

lg.head: Laisse 347
lg.l: The saintly spirit said, "Huon, arise now
And do come with me in God's name,
Because, for the sake of divine virtue, I must guide you,
To accomplish that which the grand Frenchman desires.
Don't be alarmed, for I am indeed of your faith.
I was a knight, and I fought battles
In order to observe the Christian faith.
I labored hard; I never had any rest;
For as long as I lived, I followed the right path.
Once I was old and miserable and troubled,
For I could do nothing with my sword from Vienne,
I did penance next to a large mountain.
I carried out a deed in honor of the Holy Cross
As penance---since it is always the route
Of those who go to Saint James to fulfill their vows---
I built a bridge [connecting] the tops of two hills:
Between, there was a very wide body of water.
All alone I would carry the large quarried blocks;
I cast one on top of the other in the water.
However much I worked, the next day it was undone.
Each night, an evil spirit who was unhappy about the work
Spied on me in secret;
He took it apart every time as I slept.
But one night I watched him secretly:
I deceived him by shutting my eyes,
Then I seized him when he wasn't on his guard
And I made him tell me the ways and the means,
In which manner he made such mischief.
And he told me, it was to create disorder
For the penitents, to make their way difficult.
Upon hearing what he did in bad faith,
I threw him down upon the bank,
And I exhorted him in the name of God and Saint Eligius,
That he might never depart from there, from that torment
Until the day when God, with His two fingers,
Would demonstrate His wound and His red blood.
And that devil will remain inside those stones;
He was the pillar that supported that King
Because Charlemagne charged me [to do it]."

lg.head: Laisse 348
lg.l: When the count heard such a speech,
He couldn't hold back without tears running down his face;
And when he spoke he said, "O Creator,
Full of pity for every sinner
Who returns nevertheless to your sweetness,
You show me more than I am aware of;
This one was the flower of my lineage.
Are you then William the fighter,
Who has come to me here as a guide?"
And [Huon] spoke again, "You wouldn't lie.
I have prayed to you and [beseeched] your intervention
[And prayed] that you might be moved to gentleness for this sinner."
Then he said to the spirit of his ancestor:
"Noble William, for the sake of God the Savior
Guide me--so that I not be afraid--
In the lost kingdom, if you have the ability to do it.
All your ancestors were of such vigor
That never in their life did they love a deceiver,
Nor any debauchee, nor ever a traitor.
For the sake of God you bore more pain and great unhappiness,
More than any man born, in your dealings with the pagan people;
You had neither rest nor reprieve nor respite
In Orange, nor did your noble wife.
Have you thus descended from the High Glory
To guide me into the great shadowland?
I render you thanks as a servant to a lord;
Watch over me if I have sufficient merit
So that I not die in the place of eternal weeping;
I will always believe what you say."
And [William] replied, "Have no fear.
You have me as your God-sent guide,
Today, from now on, you have a protector[, Roland,]
Who in earthly life was the nephew of the emperor,
Who was a Roman senator under God.
Virgins and martyrs came with him,
And the companies of martyred confessors,
Singing before Jesus, with great honor:
Roland beseeched the Powerful Prince
On your behalf, friend, I tell you this truly;
The Generous Giver granted his request.
He commanded me to come, without delay,
In order to help you, who wander in great uncertainty.
You must offer thanks to the great Redeemer,
And to the holy soul who took pity on you;
He wants to complete this matter of your mission now.

lg.head: Laisse 349
lg.l: Just like a little child,
Upon losing his mother and his father at the same time,
Who remains disconsolate [and] without help,
Then finds solace and becomes animated again
When he meets someone from his family,
In this way did the count, who had been sorrowful, react.
He took comfort because he saw the good saint
With good faith and no ill will;
Once more he knelt before [him].
He was forgetting [the nature of] the one before him;
He thought to kiss both his leg and foot;
He found nothing, nor did he touch anything at all.
Like a boy with little knowledge,
Tricked by a deceptive sight,
He felt ashamed and got hold of himself because of others's laughter;
Thus did the count react when he realized that he grasped nothing there;
He drew back, his hand trembling.
The saintly spirit said to him frankly:
"Neither you nor any living man will be able to touch me
Until the Day of Judgment comes
When bodies and souls will both return;
Then will both joy and torment be doubled.
Let's end this discussion for God's sake;
Let's go, we're tarrying too long.
Have no fear, for you are presently
Well absolved by the Almighty;
You have done penance for your sins,
So that you are the same as at baptism."
Then he straightened up [and] the saint made the sign of the cross over him,
Then they started off and the saint walked in front.

lg.head: Laisse 350
lg.l: Thus they went through the desert land,
Good William with noble Huon,
And Aeneas with the evil spirit
Came along behind walking slowly.
They traveled by night and by day
Until they arrived at the seashore.
There they found a fine boat
Chained to a massive block of stone.
First the messenger from God blessed it,
Then he said to Huon, "Now enter, dear friend,
And have no fear about anything that you see,
For the King of Paradise is helping you.
He who puts his faith in Him cannot be destroyed.
We must descend all the way into the abyss
If you want to accomplish what we're here for."
Huon crossed himself in the name of Jesus Christ;
He boarded the ship with a mild demeanor and a bright face;
Saintly William had him sit beside him,
And Aeneas placed himself before his feet,
And the one who looked like a pilgrim
Remained in back, silent and mute.
The ship set sail, without requiring a helmsman,
Like an bolt sent from a crossbow;
Thus they went to where there is no play or laughter.
Before the sun had descended in its course,
They went down without yelling or cries
All the way down into the deep abyss.
There is no peak or mountain in the world so high
That it wouldn't have lost its prestige to where they were descending now.
They lost the sun and the light of day;
They were put into complete darkness.
But the Creator didn't forget him;
As [the boat] moved forward, [He] lit [the way] as it pleased Him,
And behind it, the darkness returned.
When Huon saw this, he praised Jesus.
Along a narrow stretch of heath, as the story is written,
The water was deep and wide on either side,
Full of vermin and sea serpents
That spewed fire from their mouths, so it seemed to them;
Nevertheless it appeared that they gulped down the water.
Huon the bold was not without fear;
The saintly spirit had put himself in front,
And said to Huon, "Come forward, dear son,
Don't be afraid; you cannot be harmed,
For it doesn't please God, the King of Paradise;
We are close to the accursed kingdom,
Full of pain, torment and cries."

lg.head: Laisse 351
lg.l: With these words that you heard recounted,
They set off toward the [place of] eternal pain
Along a very harsh path, as you will hear me describe.
The further they walked, the further away they got
From the brightness and they saw the darkness.
Neither the light nor the path failed them.
The count of Auvergne began to look ahead of him
At a great marsh where they would have to pass,
Covered with reeds that a lively devil had summoned up
That hindered them a great deal,
Strong and sharp like steel-tipped bolts.
But Saint William, without a mowing sickle,
Caused the reeds to fall down immediately.
And as he began to exit the marsh,
He saw the side of an ancient wall
That had indeed the height of a bow shot,
Of mighty appearance to one who came to examine it.
"Do you see this wall?" said William the nobleman,
"This marks Hell where we must enter;
Those who let themselves be led here close to death
Must never think to leave.
It's the entrance to the eternal state
Of fire, flame, pain and weeping;
He who has the least of it [still] has more than he wants."

lg.head: Laisse 352
lg.l: The count stopped at this dark speech;
He said to Aeneas: "Is this then the wall
That encloses the people who endure pain forever?"
The Trojan said, "Look at that figure
On this gate of ancient construction.
Looking like a maiden in face and dress,
She holds a sword that seems of pure steel
Next to that open page of writing.
One can clearly understand what it is by reading:
'Noble justice against excess,'
And may humankind guard itself from this:
From entering into this burning right after their death,
For no one ever leaves who passes this painted image."

lg.head: Laisse 353
lg.l: And Huon said, "Is this meant for me?
I don't wish to enter if I must never leave again."
Aeneas said, "No one has power over you.
It would please God that you, without any trouble,
Return from here [and] that I leave with you.
That other gate, with that red dragon
Crowned in the manner of a king,
Through that gate enter those of the religion
That has no love for or faith in Jesus Christ,
[Those] who put Him on the Cross to be thirsty,
And who wait for the secret messenger,
That is, the messiah who will be born in opposition to the Faith,
The followers of Moses who follow that planet.
Indeed you will certainly see enter there a hundred and three of them
Who will never have the authority to harm anyone else."

lg.head: Laisse 354
lg.l: Count Huon said, "Instruct me further:
The third gate, on that high tower,
What does it signify, where that lion snarls and bares its teeth,
The one that, compared to others, seems to me [as big as] a mountain?"
"Through that gate where you see that sign,"
Said Aeneas, "enters that great people
That deem neither Jesus Christ nor Moses worthy;
They serve Muhammad who leads them to die."
"Oh, Aeneas," said Huon the great,
"This other gate here has a smaller entrance;
That image of a man has a ferocious countenance;
There is no door or obstacle that holds back passage there;
Those who languish inside can leave;
It looks like this structure collapsed a long time ago.
I don't know how it was; Aeneas, now instruct me."

lg.head: Laisse 355
lg.l: "Friend," he said, "the gate that you see there,
The One who can do the most toppled it with His feet,
When He deigned to die for the sake of our lives;
It was at that time that He harrowed Hell;
First He took the good prophets out of there
Along with other saints whom He next led out.
From that time forward the gate won't close
Until those days when, in [the Valley of] Josaphat, He will carry out
Great justice and will pass judgment,
When He will resuscitate all the dead,
And bodies and souls will all be together again.
He who is within will be fully enclosed;
The gate will stand straight, never will anyone issue forth.
It's Justice in the form of a man
Who guards the entrance, which has no other lock.
All the damned have great fear of him
Because when they pass by, [Justice] gives such a look there
That it is truly one of the greatest torments they have---
Look, that other gate that you see over there
Is Purgatory; it has a great bridge---
Yet one day they will enter the sovereign glory.
We'll speak of the three; beyond that, we'll let [it] drop."

lg.head: Laisse 356
lg.l: Of these three gates before which I have you,
Friend Huon, enter through the one that pleases you;
Either you want to see the torment of pagans,
Or of Christians, or of [those following] the Jewish law,
Or see that of those who aren't of minor importance:
The Christian faith calls it the Patarene heresy---
Those who strive only to accomplish their desires,
Not any good work, unless it be for themselves;
It is the worst of all those that you see.
Now the three roads appear before you."
Huon replied in complete good faith:
"My guide, my lord, my escort,
I wish to enter," said Huon, "on this occasion
Where I might be able to find some whom I know,
Who are within the infernal kingdom."
The spirit said, "There are quite a few Greeks
And Alemans, Teutons and French,
And Auvergnats, Gascons and Navarrese,
And there are quite a few from other foreign lands."
The saintly spirit said, "Now I'm going forward
In the name of God and of the Holy Cross:
As the sun makes the snow disappear,
Because it values neither its cold nor its blowing,
In the very same way I shall make silent
All those within in the accursed kingdom."
The count of Auvergne said, "All this pleases me,
Coming with you, noble courtly spirit,
For in life--which I'm still in for the moment--
You performed marvels with your good sword from Vienne,
And while still alive you threw down into a ravine
That devil that was damaging your construction.
At present you are here in the whirlwind
Of lost spirits; I don't have to be afraid anymore;
Lead me as you wish wherever you want."
Then he crossed himself devoutly;
Next William took hold of him by his garments;
They entered the doleful prison.

lg.head: Laisse 357
lg.l: Thereupon they entered into the wicked country;
Faster than an arrow flies from a war bow
They ran, the three of them, through a dark land.
[Huon] could hardly stand it;
The count of Auvergne, who had fear in his heart,
Held on to Saint William from behind by the shoulders.
Once he was in the doleful valley,
There were cries, pain and noise in that place.
Had there been ten thousand mangonels gathered
That [were] all prepared and all together,
And as many crossbows and war bows
And ten thousand blacksmiths hammering with their hammers,
Hearing that would be exactly the same.
Like the surging of a little water channel
Toward the sea when it swells the most, without a doubt,
In that place there were cries and mortal grieving,
Sharp sighs and the laments of affliction,
Wishes for death and harsh accusations
Because the Heavenly King caused them to be born.
Aeneas said, "Loyal man,
You are in an area of copper and metal;
These are the people who did neither good nor evil.
Their lives were like those of beasts;
Their conscience put them in this misfortune
As you have seen; it gets to such a din,
They never rest by night or by day.
Now may he who dies beware; he suffers without hope."

lg.head: Laisse 358
lg.l: Upon [hearing] the great wailing, Count Huon stopped,
He asked the Trojan about the many people:
"Noble spirit, what people do you say these are,
Who, with great wailing, make my head ring?"
"I say," he answered, "that they live like animals.
Now I've told you about the nature of their situation;
The force [of their punishment] must be equivalent."
"Don't they have any other pain," so said the honest count,
"Than the wailing, the weeping and the torment
That the mangonels and the crossbows cause them?"
"Because they are sure that for their entire existence
They will never leave here,
Except for that day when [His] Most High Majesty
Will conduct the painful inquiry about them,
When they will be placed at [His] left,
Then they will return with their mortal vestment,
And their sorrow and their torment will be doubled.
For this reason they'll wish that they were yet to be born!
Let's go forward and we'll see other situations."

lg.head: Laisse 359
lg.l: Count Huon started another inquiry;
William, who was in front, guided him.
"Say,"[Huon] said, "Aeneas, noble son of a baron,
Do you believe you will ever leave here or have pardon?"
[Aeneas] remained quiet, saying neither yes nor no,
But he wet his chin with his tears.
William said, "Into such questioning
You must not enter, neither you nor [any] earthly man.
If this one serves you because of divine intent,
You must say to him things that please him—
Comfort him; don't cause him anxiety.
You double his sorrow by discussing this subject;
It's not the practice of a noble or valiant man
To remind one's friend of his mistakes—
In this case there is no correct answer.
Let's go on further, for we will find a lot more
Pathetic people wailing and quarreling."

lg.head: Laisse 360
lg.l: Once they had passed the first level
Of those whom the harsh Last Judgment awaits,
They continued going on a great highway.
There they found many different kinds of people;
All the trades were there and they worked in their professions.
They showed their falseness in different ways;
Each one had his [just] desserts according to his own deeds.
Even those who had less [punishment] had more than they desired.
The guides continued, they didn't want to stop;
Huon spoke with an expression of compassion:
"Lord William, do not leave me behind.
I see people here of many different kinds;
Each one looks at me with a such a hideous expression,
They don't have their wish; I see them entirely.
I see the wretches two and three in a coffin,
Lying as if dead; wasps and worms
Eat their bodies, completely mutilating
Their feet, their hands and their eyes.
Nor do they have any power whatsoever to defend themselves
Against these wasps, so extensive is their wretchedness:
Each one of them has beneath his pallet
Thirty devils that stab his body.
Their aid is extremely cruel,
Oh! there isn't one not stabbing them with his claws!
Look how they wail. Each one calls out to their mother:
'Help me! May my father be cursed
Since he engendered me before dying.'
These are the ones who followed the banner
Of great debauchery in the manner of Sodom."

lg.head: Laisse 361
lg.l: Huon sighed and said, "Father on high,
How great is the justice that rules us!
Sorrowful is the one who winters in such a house,
There is here an evil host and treacherous inn!
Oh, Aeneas, noble superior soul,
Who are these others whose all gnash their teeth,
Who beat their palms together and weep eternally?
It seems to me that I recognize under their clothes
Blood bubbling through burning pustules
That burn their sides in eternal pain.
And these devils truly thrust there many a poker
With which, yelling, they stab each one and make them jump."
Aeneas said, "The sin that made each one
Enter into such profligacy constrains them,
The one that is called vainglory nowadays.

lg.head: Laisse 362
lg.l: Count Huon replied, "On account of vainglory
These people are therefore in these depths?
That is a great wonder if they have no other sins."
Aeneas said, "Those who are in such sin
Are hardly aware of their profligacy
And of the envy that doesn't please God at all.
He who won't proclaim his guilt to the world
Will never see the everlasting glory.
Their clothing has shamed them as well as the great reputation they made;
Unhappy [are] those who will enter here,
For some of the people are still alive
Who change their clothing for greater pleasure in the world
Which is hardly worth what they have left,
They abuse their bodies, and never do it for God.
Oh, those wretched onces, how they will pay for it!
For they will never leave such torment behind,
Except on the day when their pain will double!"

lg.head: Laisse 363
lg.l: "Again I say to you, dear friend, [let's go] forward,
For if these whom you see in distress
Had all of Charlemagne's treasure,
They would surely give it all hand over fist
To be able to pull those awful garments off their backs.
It seems to them that they would be completely well
If only they could pull them off right away.
This cannot be, for the Sovereign Judge
Doesn't want very much thus to endure their deceit;
They didn't do enough seeing as He died for the human race."
At these words the count came along, pale and weak,
And Saint William took [him] by the hand:
"Let's go on further away from this place."
He said to Aeneas, "Now you go first;
Be our leader through this place."
"Willingly, [my] lord," said the Trojan spirit.
They walked immediately through a land
By a path that was full of spirits.
"You who were a son of the Silvian line,
Who are those with the devilish faces?
They bring both their hands up before their eyes,
They are stuck in mire up to their backs,
They are hit here by catapults from afar."
He, who was not discourteous, replied:
"Those [people] were minstrels, sons of whores
Who served others as procurers
And to carry tales near and far:
Most of them were lies and tricks.
From their punishment, you can certainly see there
What good comes from all they did,
Whether they are repaid for what they wrought."

lg.head: Laisse 364
lg.l: "These minstrels, who weren't entertainers,
Turned their trade to spying,
And by speaking evil and committing treachery,
They forced many maidens into harlotry;
In such a manner did they earn clothing and money.
They are now fixed into this pitch,
But the devils hold them by their feet;
They cause them repeatedly a whole lot of harm;
They scratch their feet until they are badly hurt,
And [the minstrels] fear the scratching so much
That no one can stand firm.
Those great stones that descend on them
From the mangonels that launch them often---
They cast some down and miss others---
Those represent the tales that they brought
From one lord to another in order to sow discord,
And indeed a greater torment soon awaits [them]:
Those that scratch them are truly plotting treachery among themselves.
And say to them, 'What have you been doing for so long?
I have scratched you and you're not thankful to me for it?
Do you really think to do to me exactly
As you did to people on earth?
So take a deep breath now and say--I repent of it.'
Now watch, brother, how [a devil] gives him a great blow,
For with his claw he splits [the sinner's] spine.
The sinners who consider only the body
And don't remember the soul at all
And, however they can, pillage and seize,
Will bear the same conditions, brother.
Those who betrayed their soul for riches
Will forever be sorrowful."

lg.head: Laisse 365
lg.l: "There is great suffering here," said the noble messenger.
"Glorious Father," said the true-hearted Huon,
"Protect me when I come to the passage
So that I not be in the same anguish."
One of those who were in the mire
Heard the count [speaking] in the Auvergnat language;
He cried out to him in a loud voice:
"You who walk through this sorrowful dwelling place,
Who called upon the Sovereign Image,
Speak to me," he said, "on this path!
You spoke in the language of Auvergne;
You resemble a man who went out of loyalty,
Sent by Charles Martel of the proud visage,
To seek Hell in order to ask for tribute--
[His real purpose was] to split up a faithful marriage.
And I, a sinner, who didn't act wisely at all,
Gave counsel to the king regarding your voyage,
So that you would come to sorrow and harm
And that your wife might be turned to harlotry;
For this sin I am here in this savage place."
Huon replied, "You committed great madness."

lg.head: Laisse 366
lg.l: The count said, "For what reason, tell me, Saudin,
Did Charles send me on this evil road?
I am the one who has endured so many miserable mornings
Trying to complete this embassy;
But I have not gotten closer.
Did my lord therefore send me here as a ruse?"
And [Saudin] replied, with a shameful bow:
"Are you here alive, noble count palatine?
I am indeed that cur
Through whom the king wanted to cause your death,
Just in order to have your wife in his power.
There were twelve nobles, and I was the thirteenth,
Who advised Charles on how to carry out the treason,
Only out of zeal, not out of evil intention,
To shame and kill you, too.
Nine of them have died---all by the sword---
Of the ones who fashioned your death because of their evil hatred.
They thus acted just as Cain did;
Here they are hunted down just like dogs.
For this reason Charles sent you to the infernal kingdom.
Since God, the Lord of the cherubim, is helping you,
So that you can descend into the circle of Cain
To seek what the wretched king wants,
I wish to beg you, for the sake of the honor of your lineage,
That you lay aside your anger and your hatred for me,
--All of which henceforth isn't worth an Angevin coin--
For before the end I ought to request it."

lg.head: Laisse 367
lg.l: The count of Auvergne spoke to him and said:
"I forgive you if my pardon is worth anything."
The spirit said: "Leave, for if the mangonel
That causes everyone fear shot you,
I would be distressed if it hurt you at all."
The count looked at him as he was and as he was situated;
He spoke the words of a gospel to him
That the deeds of each one followed him after death.
As he left, a stone descended,
Because of which all the miserable damned ones trembled.
Just as anyone terrified by lightning
Crosses himself and called on Jesus Christ,
In the same way those of the savage troop
Cursed God their Father and their ministers,
And they cursed death, which had taken them unawares;
They would have been happy had they never been born.

lg.head: Laisse 368
lg.l: The count addressed the good spirit,
Who was the son of Aymeri, and Aeneas.
The baron recounted to them all that he had learned [from Saudin],
How the king of Saint Denis had entrapped him
[And] sent him here simply out of lust.
"And can this be, noble blessed saint?"
"Yes, indeed, you can be completely sure of it.
He was smitten by love for your wife;
For this reason the king had you sent to your death.
But the great torments [of Hell] will be [heaped] upon him, I tell you;
He'll come here and you'll return alive.
The Lord of Paradise is your help:
You are without guilt and he will be reduced to a sorry state.
Since you hate the sin of disloyalty,
God wants you to accomplish what you have so long sought [to do]."
The count of Auvergne rendered thanks to God,
Then they started moving slowly forward.
They traveled over hills and moors
Until they arrived--so explain the writings--
Before a river whose water was teeming,
Full of monsters and serpents too;
I believe the body of water was called Acheron.
More than ten thousand naked spirits
Were on the shore by a dark banner.
They were very desirous to cross over;
They almost got into a situation
Dangerous for them, I tell you rightly.
For toward them came, rushing to combat,
A large boat with a white-bearded old man,
He was called Charon in the sorrowful country;
Sorrowful are those who need his services.
He yelled to them, "Here, you evil rabble,
I'll conduct you to the [place of] infernal cinder."
And then Aeneas said, "Look, friend,
Now you can see the souls of the wretched
Who have always lived in great sin,
Who had fallen into despair before God:
They couldn't bear their poverty-stricken existence.
If they had been content with their humiliation
They would be seated with the martyrs in Heaven."

lg.head: Laisse 369
lg.l: Huon asked Aeneas, "And these,
Why do they have such great desire
To cross the green-colored water?
Most of them nearly make it in."
"If you want to know, right away
I'll explain it to you," [Aeneas] then replied.
"Look on this side and don't be afraid;
Nothing you see will have any power over you."
And the one who was observing did look all around,
And he saw coming in a rush with great fury
A hideous shade from ancient times.
From the chest on down he was a horse at a run,
While the upper part was of human form.
He came bellowing right up close with such great ferocity
That he made the whole earth around and about
Tremble; it sounded moreover like thunderbolts.
He held an arrow on a hazelwood bow
Fully six feet long; he seemed all fired up.
He came shouting, "You shall not go, you lechers,
You'll feel the the displeasure of my arrow."
Here you see Charon, like a sailor,
Saying, "Get in quickly! You're taking too long;
The centaur comes to harm you."
They saw him; never did a goshawk
Speed so quickly beyond his falconer
As did the sinners in the boat.
Like sheep that flee in fear
This way and that way before the angry shepherd,
Taking a foolish path and abandoning the best one,
Likewise these souls had no rest;
They hurled themselves into the water when they saw their hunter[, the centaur].
The one from the boat threw them overboard right away;
The monsters swallowed them up, then they entered into burning fire.
They were the people who were very sinful;
They are now blackened and reproached for great sins.

lg.head: Laisse 370
lg.l: Once they had thus been cast from the boat,
They were engulfed by fire and dragons.
Charon the demon cried out to them, "Come here!"
They turned their faces toward his bark;
[Charon] seized his oar, once they had boarded.
He gave them great blows on their flanks and sides.
"Take some of this charity," he said.
There where the four remained on the bank,
Charon cried to them: "What are you doing? Enter,
You'll soon be rewarded for your labor!
I'm obliged to transport the three of you;
But this stranger who has arrived without death
I'm not willing to carry; I would be blamed."
Aeneas said, "Get out of here, wretch!
We aren't supposed to leave this place.
This one is here solely by the will
Of that One whose light you lost."
Just as a woman who has sold herself
Finds herself rebuked by the truth alone
To which she has neither the courage nor the desire to reply,
So did Charon when he was taunted
About the reproach concerning his being chased from Heaven;
He just went away like a defeated man
And then arrived at the bank.
The centaur with his bow fully drawn
Cried out aloud, "You think you'll get away so easily?"
Then he let loose the feathered arrow
Over the bow of the docked boat,
And all was set alight with flame and fire.
The spirits in flames were toppled;
There were serpents [and] monsters aplenty;
They devoured all [the sinners], they carried them away,
And the swift boat thus happily sailed on
With the one who has enough [passengers].
The one who had the bow looked at William:
"And you, who are you, who give off such brightness?
I believe you are seeking better bread than that made of wheat.
And you over there, who were born in Troy,
You are one of those who betrayed the city,
Where so many worthy men were disinherited;
I wish to avenge them, since I have found you.
Why have you brought this living man?"
Aeneas, who was angry, said,
"Be quiet, scoundrel, insolent, stinking bastard,
Cursed by God, begat by a beast,
Go threaten in front of Diomedes,
For your nature is divided into two halves."
Then the two of them would have tusseled there,
When Saint William looked up;
He said to [the centaur], "Now get out of here, evil one;
I'm watching over him; he cannot be touched."
With his right foot he kicked the centaur
Who left that place and really went away.
He looked behind him, so alarmed was he,
And cursed all the monks of God,
He went hurling flames out of his mouth and nose.

lg.head: Laisse 371
lg.l: The count of Auvergne looked at the centaur,
Ugly and hideous; he never stopped bellowing;
The vassal of noble spirit was afraid of him.
But Saint William showed him great comfort,
And Aeneas countered his fear.
"Friend," he said, "this son of the Devil
Died in Troy, as Dares Phrygius recounts to you.
In this Hell he has nothing else to do,
Nor other punishment than running and shooting [his arrows].
He often strikes the souls who are in this dark place."
He told him quite a few other things, which are not explained;
Charon, who didn't take long, returned.
"If you wish," he said, "to complete
What you're seeking [to do], it is fitting for you to deal with me.
I will take you to the other side of the river that smells bad;
Your road is there, I know well what your business is."

lg.head: Laisse 372
lg.l: The heavenly saint and Aeneas the brave
Both affirmed that it was best
To cross the great, perilous river.
First William boarded, with a gentle, glorious face
Once he had crossed himself,
Then he comforted the fearful man,
[And] he boarded next completely willingly:
Thus they traveled over the shadowy lake.
God's saint said in a low voice
To Huon, "Friend, what is the matter,
Why are you so pallid when you were rosy?
Don't doubt God, the highest power!
Owing to his frail body, lacking courage,
Any fainthearted man lives wretchedly."
He replied with a piteous countenance:
"I'm not afraid, but I am very ashamed
To ask [for something] to drink, which I desperately need.
I'm almost dying of thirst,
But this is not a place to be too thirsty;
No goodness is found in here and no rest.
On the other hand I am very eager
To see the state of the woeful wretches."

lg.head: Laisse 373
lg.l: Good William, once he heard and saw
That the good messenger was complaining of thirst,
Like one who quickly serves
His good friend when he sees his need,
So William did for Huon on this occasion.
He called the spirit who wore the hooded cape:
"Bring the wine," he said, "since he must drink,
And make sure that there is absolutely no trickery in this."
And the other replied, "I will do it, since it pleases you."
No emperor or king has ever had
A servant so prompt to bring the thing that is his [lord's] highest pleasure,
When he sees him quite angry,
As this one was for the blessed saint.
An arrow from a bow never was released so quickly,
Nor any swallow [flown off] when desire captures it,
As [the devil] went through the woeful strait.
Before Charon arrived where he was supposed to,
[The devil] brought them the wine that was in the container.

lg.head: Laisse 374
lg.l: "Drink some wine," said the one who carried it;
Huon took it, looked at Saint William,
"[Do so] in safety," he said, then he made the sign of the cross over it.
[Huon] drank some for he needed it greatly;
The baron remembered that very wine
That he had left behind in his palace in Auvergne.
He said to William, "Here's a great marvel:
This wine was brought here a long time ago;
Its taste hasn't changed from either heat or cold."
The saint replied, "The other wonders
That the Lord will demonstrate will be much greater:
When earthly glory will pass away,
And mountains and fields will all turn to ash,
The bodies of the dead from three thousand years ago until now
Will be resurrected as they were before.
Fearful souls will fill their vessels,
Then they will go where they will be judged
By the One who asked to drink on the Cross,
The glorious Lord who endured so much pain,
Who will then receive the good ones there;
They will go with the angels with very great joy.
Then they will remain forever in the company of God.
And in the opposite group, since they will be damned
And will remain forever in great pain,
They will be very jealous of the good souls
And the absolved ones whom God will bless.
He will drive the other cruel ones toward punishment,
He will replace their lamentations with everlasting pain;
The great marvels, dear friend, will be there.
Now let's leave the boat, we have already arrived."
The saint disembarked and Huon followed
And Aeneas set off after him.
Since William as guide had put himself
In front of them, he said, "Come here."
He explained many kinds of sins to him
And the great sufferings "that they won't ever escape, count;
You would hardly believe them, even if I told you now,
For they are innumerable; for this reason I'll stop speaking."
But to elaborate what he had begun,
The count spoke of everywhere he had searched,
Just as the story has told us.

lg.head: Laisse 375
lg.l: William walked and Huon followed him,
Along with Aeneas through the sorrowful world.
The good Trojan joined them at their side.
He was showing him the great sins that abounded,
And he recounted the entire situation; he didn't hide the truth.
He pointed them out to Lord Huon the blond:
"Those in such torment who were once in the world
Want this place to hide them on account of their evil acts."
At that point they entered a deep valley,
Dark and gloomy, pure and cleansed of light;
It was entirely full; sorrowful souls spoke up,
They didn't stop crying out. They echoed back and forth:
"If only I'd never been born since such pain overwhelms me!"
Then said William, brother of Hernaut de Gironde:
"Tell me, Aeneas, who are they who dwell in such numbers
