And lament so much in this deep valley?"
And he replied, "The great clergy of the world,
Bishops and archbishops, prelates and priors,
Popes and cardinals, patriarchs abound here.
It's fitting that they cleanse themselves here [of] the sins they committed;
To others they taught virtue; for themselves they kept to no limits,
Rather they acted utterly evilly; they undermine their good work with [evil].
Now they are in a lost place; from now on it seems that they hide."
"Friend," he said, "you are upon the shore
Of the great abyss where all pain abounds."
He brought them down to where the damned sink.

lg.head: Laisse 376
lg.l: Now they entered into the first level
Of the great abyss entirely filled with darkness.
There was no illumination or brightness there
Except for the light that God had summoned for them.
They advanced to the right by a degree;
The more they advanced the more they lost the light.
The swollen sea when it is angriest,
Full of tempest from wind and storm,
Doesn't make such a noise there where it strikes on all sides
Of an island or promontory, where it strikes and turns back,
As those people cried out when they found such a place!
They made anguished and miserable sighs
That filled the dark air in spite of themselves.
There were quite a few men, and women as well;
They called themselves woeful, unlucky wretches.
Great pity for them overwhelmed the count of Auvergne;
He said to Aeneas, "Friend, please explain to me
Who these people are who are gathered here,
Who grieve, weep and cast great sighs.
Neither fire nor flame nor serpent nor demon
Troubles them, yet they seek pity.
And I myself feel grief and sorrow for them."
And [Aeneas] replied, "I'll certainly tell you."

lg.head: Laisse 377
lg.l: "This assembly that you see now
In this Limbo—they were those people
Who were alive before [there was] baptism,
And among them are [those] who committed no sin.
And they are those whom you see so sorrowful
Who lament so much, on whom you take pity;
Just as they were born, so did they die
Because not one of them had baptism.
And know for sure, in fact, for certain:
Everyone who is born alive on this earth,
Who hasn't been baptized properly and immutably
In holy water as the Scriptures say--
No other good act would avail them--
It will be obligatory for them to come into this darkness."
Then Huon decided to ask a question:
"Tell me, noble lord, do they have the understanding
That they will leave here on the Day of Judgment?"
"And I," he said, "can't answer except [to reply]
Only if it pleased God Almighty.
If these people issue forth from this sorrowful place,
I wouldn't think to be with those who remain;
Nevertheless, I, a sinner, expect exactly the opposite about it.
What is the point of these people taking comfort?
For I believe that their hope must be just
Like that of the one who hunts and captures nothing."
Huon wept compassionately about this.
The saint said, "Let's end this discussion.
Let it remain to the One who works in hidden ways,
Whose word never fails at all."

lg.head: Laisse 378
lg.l: Thus they walked through the darkness;
Huon asked Aeneas, who guided him:
"So is it really true—if you are up to it—
That Adam was indeed from this company,
Brought out along with others of holy life?"
Aeneas said, "Since you want it told to you:
The One who was incarnated in that holy life,
Whose Substance has the entire world in His power,
Once He had left this life--
Still appearing in the full blush of life
Despite having had a grievous wound--
He entered into this place carrying a banner. With His gracious hand,
He took hold of the first of our ancestors
And Seth, his son, [then] the other troop:
Abraham, Isaac, with Jeremiah,
And all the good prophets who were alive before.
Not one good person remained behind there,
All of them left with their company
For that glorious place where no one shrieks or cries.
Now that you have heard their entire life-story,
Let's go forward; my explanation is finished."

lg.head: Laisse 379
lg.l: Through the barren land of the spirits they went,
Aeneas and the count, speaking in this way.
They traveled until they arrived
At a castle that was not on high.
Seven great gates were in the first wall;
They belonged to the castle, as the story explains;
As for the great moats and walls that are there,
There in that place, many souls will perish.
Aeneas said, "There are seven walls here
Where you must enter; now you mustn't be afraid.
Absolutely nothing that you see will harm you.
If you look carefully and see beyond that bridge,
On the seat of the round capital,
You see there the fair-headed master Ptolemy,
Who in astrology was the best in the world.
The magicians are with him.
See how they set about studying!
More than all the others who are still studying,
He wants to know if they will [ever] leave that place.
They turn over the cards, but they don't find the point [they seek].
They will keep up this practice, dear friend,
Until the day when the angels will come
To sound the trumpets by which the dead will be revived."

lg.head: Laisse 380
lg.l: They passed through the first gate of the scholars;
The messenger [Huon] entered alongside Aeneas.
They heard great cries and much great commotion;
They recognized nothing, it took much effort to move,
The crying disturbed them so greatly,
It made their heads ring thoroughly with it;
The more they moved forward, the more the cries intensified.
The count of Auvergne began to be amazed,
He couldn't see nor ask from whom [the cries came],
He began to reproach Nicomacus:
"Be quiet for a while, [you] demon enemies!"
Aeneas said, "One can't do anything to stop this.
These [people] applied their effort and their thought
To learn and teach that body of knowledge;
They didn't want to remember God.
This is their torment—cries and quarrels,
And getting worked up by their excessive shouting."
The good saint said, "Let's leave these [people] to quarrel,
And let's go by another path."

lg.head: Laisse 381
lg.l: They passed through the opening of the second gate
While someone was calling Nicomacus by name.
A man was writing up above the gate,
The least letter was as large as a shield.
The saint said to the bewildered one:
"The text says that his name was Farabus."
[Huon said,] "Since you have begun and set out
To clarify what was confusing to us
[Concerning] those here who are so distinguished--that hideous spirit
With that sharp look, is he enclosed?
Who holds his finger on the spread-out document,
Doesn't he have the ability to advance any further
Beyond all the others? Like an eagle compared to little birds,
He surpasses the others in greater knowledge."
Aeneas said, "This one discovered the uses
Of dialectic and of other arts."

lg.head: Laisse 382
lg.l: Now they went away, they didn't tarry at all;
The count of Auvergne asked his question,
"You who explained about Farabus who studied
Dialectic as well as other arts,
[Tell me,] for such practices, doesn't he get [treated] differently?"
He said, "Indeed not until the Judgment [Day]."
The count replied, "By God Almighty!
Thus they will have to study such a long time,
They will know well how to pronounce a judgement properly."
Aeneas said, "Just the opposite,
He has indeed no desire at all for their disputation;
For sure, everyone awaits a different judgement.
Do you think they read the texts that they see,
And the stars and [their] movements,
And that they have no pain? Far from it!
Each letter before them that they look at
Is indeed all burning fire to them,
And explains and speaks forcefully of the future
Where everyone will have the punishment [befitting] their conduct.
They are very afraid of the great assembly
That will double their torment on Judgment Day;
He bows his head because of his misfortune."
William took hold of the count by the hand,
They closed the narrow gate behind them
And continued forward; they passed through the third [gate].
They will find a fair amount of sorrow and torment,
Damned souls and devils likewise,
Who doubled their sorrow more and more.
They went until they passed beyond,
And then they arrived at the fourth [gate];
They continued on, they didn't stop.

lg.head: Laisse 383
lg.l: They arrived at the fourth gate;
Before it there was a huge deep pit.
The gate was strong and the highest wall was tall,
A great obstacle. Without intense effort and without pain,
No human creature could enter there.
The beauty of the gate distinguished it from all the others.
They found beautiful young people, fresh and healthy;
Their clothing appeared white and scarlet-colored,
[Made] long like [the clothing of] people from far away
Who went to gain knowledge on the Seine.
The master above, with a high voice,
Read a document with full of writing
[Held] in his two hands. [Huon asked] Aeneas, who was leading him,
"Who are these [people], my noble captain,
Who remind me of earthly life?
With their beautiful appearance and worldly clothing,
They certainly don't seem parted from their human flesh."
Aeneas, the great Trojan soul, said,
"Here is the flower of the most ancient people,
Of the Trojans and the Greeks who hated each other."
With his finger he pointed out many eminent noblemen:
"This was so-and-so fighting that one," he said, giving the correct names,
He explained the matter to him; most of them were locked in combat,
Fighting each other; in this they had the hearts of Romans;
They would get little rest. "You can see well their fatigue.
Friend," said Aeneas, "such is their destiny.
When you get to the sovereign land,
You'll tell people in the world with informed speech
That you've seen first of all the fate of Hector,
Achilles, Agamemnon and other captains,
Without degrading punishment, dear friend.
Let's go forward, as far as the other leads;
That way you'll see how Aristotle of Athens is."

lg.head: Laisse 384
lg.l: The count of Auvergne moved on
And led the others, so they moved forward.
They had watched the armed people a good while.
[Huon] said something that came to him:
"If my soul must actually be damned to the lost place,
I would like to be with them, be that wisdom or folly!"
At these words that he had now spoken,
A spirit rose to his feet;
He wanted to call to the count in order to hear his story.
Another one hit him on the head with such a blow
That he toppled him all the way over; he threw him to the ground.
The [first one] sat up, feeling very much ashamed because of it.
"Think," [the second one] said, "it's not your destiny
To speak there; you have not been called."
The others mocked him and made fun;
The holy spirit [William] laughed about it,
Then he blessed Jesus of majesty.
He took hold of Huon, then he told him:
"Let it be; you have seen enough."

lg.head: Laisse 385
lg.l: The count went through the dark wasteland,
Where there is never any rest, only great and severe pain.
William guided him, and [did so] through such hazards,
That he lost nothing of value.
He didn't take fright at all from anything that he saw;
Likewise because of [his guides] he felt just as safe
As if he were staying in a castle.
Among the additional torments that the count indeed also saw,
He came across a lady who was going at great speed.
She looked like a queen; she had a very dark countenance;
Great torment seemed to have certainly taken hold of her bearing.
"Aeneas," said the count, "who is that figure?
Do tell it to me now, if you know anything of her concern.
She appears to be in more torment than her nature can bear."
Aeneas said, "Indeed she rightly must be so,
Since she thought [to do] great harm to her husband,
From which he was to die, through his bad luck,
Without confession; for this she is in this suffering.
Her name was Aiglentine, if the text has no error;
She was the lady of Gascony, indeed she held a just claim to it;
Guy de Nanteuil was the name of [her] strong and tough lord.
Do you see him there, coming on a galloping horse?
All the pain that he has he holds as nothing
Until he take revenge on that thieving whore,
Who put him out of earthly life through her deceit,
He who didn't receive the church sacrament [of extreme unction] at that moment,
For which reason henceforth he must remain in punishment.
Every day he goes pursuing her over hill and through valley;
In no way can he catch up with her; other hazards appear to him
That are great marvels both harsh and difficult.
Thus the baron loses his prey, he laments and weeps a lot."
"O God," said the count, "Justice, how pure you are!
He was truly a man of valor, he never committed savagery!
He had great tribulation in this life because of the Saracens,
In order to maintain justice and to serve righteousness.
I would willingly help him if it were within my power."

lg.head: Laisse 386
lg.l: The count departed, his heart was very sorrowful
Because of the one he saw bearing such great pain.
Something occurred in front of him;
He saw spirits who were once alive,
A great throng—no one had never seen so many—
There appeared to be many crowned ones, so it seemed,
The devils were indeed chasing them very violently.
The ones [being chased] defended themselves as best they could.
They fought savagely and harshly,
Such that a man might hear it from two full leagues away.
When Huon saw this, this violent behavior,
He asked Aeneas, "What people are these then?"
And [Aeneas] replied, "They are King Agollant,
Uliens the brave and Helmont the valiant,
That combative group who were on the field of Aspremont,
Because during their lives they loved neither God nor saints
And thought to destroy Christianity,
Whence what they have is still greater torment.
It seems to them that they are still fighting
The Christian people; they strike so hard for that reason.
Then each time they are in the greatest torment,
And when then they lay down their weapons,
And when they remember something about it,
They say to many [people] that it was Roland's doing.
When [Helmont] died, [Roland] killed him treacherously,
For he was exhausted, and [Roland] killed him while he was sleeping."
And the count said, "I agree somewhat with that;
But the matter is not at all obvious.
A man who was fighting for two days
Without resting or eating anything at all,
He must indeed have had little breath left.
But [Roland] attacked when [Helmont] was very slow,
His defense was worth less than that of a child;
For this reason, one can say that the deed occurred when he was sleeping.
It was surely not at all great valor,
But it was much better for the Christian people.
Now let us pass on; they'll continue their boasting."

lg.head: Laisse 387
lg.l: Huon followed his ancestor
Through a wasteland; it was rough going.
He very much thought to find great torment there;
He heard them howling and crying fiercely,
The noise was tremendous; one couldn't have heard God thundering.
A knight passed in front of them,
Who back in his lifetime was very brave and proud,
But young to wear a king's crown.
Huon asked Aeneas, [his] interpreter,
"Who was that? Now, do tell me, dear brother."
The latter replied, "Lord William should explain it to you,
Who, in his time, gave him quite a lot of trouble;
He should recognize and know him well:
This one before [us] is Thibaut the Saracen,
For there was no man of his faith more fierce
Nor who knew better how to pay [one] back
Eagerly when it was necessary to do so.
He knew well how to escape and also how to pursue well;
He was rather courtly in the giving of his wealth.
He gave it to those where he thought to employ it well;
There was nothing to teach him [in that arena]."
William replied, "You speak absolutely truly, dear brother;
We waged war for forty whole years,
But my heart was quite tough and proud;
That's why it was hard to bear the burden
When peace was made; it was necessary for me to promise
What our commander wanted.
But I couldn't dwell with them,
Since I would be afraid that he might betray me,
As he was the one who first broke faith,
Whwn he killed his brother-in-law, Folchon the baron,
In Babylonia, while playing chess.
Then, after much great hardship, he ordered
The destruction of Christendom; he wasn't a coward.
It's never possible to excuse this deed;
Let's go forward, I don't want to look at him anymore."
Just as he thought to pass on,
[A woman] with the appearance of a lady with a fair face
Seemed to come to meet them.
Thibaut was pursuing her, thinking already to catch up to her;
He wanted to take revenge on her, but he couldn't accomplish anything
So his venture thus failed.
He encountered William, who was her lord;
The lady said, "Now I have everything I could want:
This one will help me with my great trouble."
Then she came toward him, she approached out of love:
"Welcome, my beloved, my friend, my hope."

lg.head: Laisse 388
lg.l: Huon inquired and said, "My guide,
This looks like Guiborc, your wife;
But why does she suffer thus?
For I believed her abiding in Heaven above,
Since she endured such evil and such tribulation for your sake."
"So it is, brother," said the ancestral spirit;
"This one you see is not at all Guiborc,
Rather, [it is] a devil who has taken on her appearance
In order to cause Thibaut more sweat and anguish.
Guiborc was sanctified in the higher kingdom;
Within Gloriete, in my great palace
Guiborc died, and I was left then
Forlorn, and I thought in my heart
That I had become a sinner toward God.
I entered Guyenne to do penance with them;
I died a hermit when it pleased the Creator.
Now let's go on; let's not remain here any longer."
Huon replied, "Willingly, my lord."

lg.head: Laisse 389
lg.l: William departed, he didn't want to tarry any longer;
He led Huon, who was not a coward.
He wanted to inquire and ask about many things;
In fact they traveled along the easiest path.
He found rather a lot of very disturbing things;
Every place he went it seemed to him there was great suffering:
Each one lamented, repented of his deeds,
They wished they had never been born!
He saw many a torment that I can't recount,
That appeared harsh even just watching [them].
But among other things Huon saw a castle;
To anyone who wanted to look closely, it appeared quite well-furnished
With defenders and their weapons.
He saw a man with a ringing voice on a balcony who
Made himself much feared; simply because of fire being hurled
He ran back and forth to mount a defense
Anywhere he could offer the least resistance at all.
Huon asked Aeneas, saying, "Brother,
Who is this castellan who is so brave and noble?
[He] with the ringing voice believes he defends himself well!
He thinks little of those who come to assault him."
Aeneas replied, "He's beset with difficulties!
Devils are attacking him from every side.
They want to burn this man in a great fire:
He is Girart of Fraite, the warrior;
Every day he thinks he's fighting Saracens,
Every day he thinks he's winning.
Many times he did evil toward Charles, the emperor:
He was never willing to humble himself to [Charles];
He had more pride than any man on earth.
Now perceive here something of his behavior,
He remains in torment, his shouting doesn't help him."
"O God," said Huon, "I can give thanks to you!
Your justice is fearful merely to recount!
[Girart] was a man for himself wanting to oppose everything;
He loved no one superior to him, not even for a whole day;
Now he has his recompense for all his deeds;
He'll remain and we wish to move on."

lg.head: Laisse 390
lg.l: Huon left there without tarrying;
He and his companions departed at full speed.
They passed many hills and valleys in abundance;
In all of them they found evil lodging:
They found no place where there weren't great cries.
They found a lake where many serpents lay,
All of them of different kinds;
Each one was worse than the other, as they are in this earthly life.
Now the spirits were disputing among themselves,
And they were completely alight in fire and flame.
Girart of Fraite was thereupon put in prison,
Right into an oven burning up with live coal.
But once he had seen the two noblemen,
He cried out loud, "You escaped from this,
Because you became a hermit, as holy men do,
You don't want to see me; you turn your face aside,
Never would I value you the worth of a button for this.
If you are now a great lord in the kingdom of Heaven,
I have more power within this deep place
Than you could ever have in the heavenly house.
Although you have descended from my nation,
I wouldn't give a single button for your glory."
"O God," said Count Huon, "how afraid I am now,
When I remember the noble Burgundian,
Who did so much good as long as he was in the world!
Now I am completely willing to believe the saying of Solomon:
'Beginning well is only worth a little,
If the end is not good.' Here we can see it.

lg.head: Laisse 391
lg.l: Huon replied, "Now let's continue on."
They set off on their path that they hurried along the whole day;
The baron went on without any fear.
William, who was at his service, guided him;
Huon often asked him questions
About many things that came before them,
And [William] told him the entire truth about many of them.
This is why the count desired to know about it then:
So that when he returned to noble France,
If he were asked, he could tell everything truthfully,
What he had found out through what he did and what he saw.
For this reason the count was very talkative.
William knew it, thus he was willing to bear with him,
Nevertheless, as much as they could, he urged him forward
To complete his journey and not be afraid.
So [William] began to think about the one he guided,
How he was supposed to make it through such terrible suffering:
"There is no man on earth who wouldn't go out of his senses;
Let the count not be one of these, nor go recalling it."
He passed on, looking at a great deal;
He saw a lot of torment meted out, harsh and heavy,
About which, however, I won't tell.
It wouldn't be worth it to go telling everything;
I wish to talk about those who came before him,
And who thought to thwart him somewhat.
Many of them believed to take him prisoner;
When they realized their efforts were in vain,
They then returned to greater torment.

lg.head: Laisse 392
lg.l: The count departed, he and his company,
He seemed not to be harmed by anything that he saw;
God, in whom he trusted completely, wouldn't consent to it.
He came across a troop of souls badly mistreated,
They were in great distress, they often requested help.
Everyone hurt them; no one helped them at all,
They were reduced to a sorry state by great torment.
"Oh, Aeneas, do you know anything about this situation?"
"Yes, I will indeed tell you part of it.
These [souls] were already lost in the world;
They appeared humble in the trappings of poverty
In order to deceive others, who still trusted them.
The Gospels say it as we have seen;
Ah, [my] lord, watch out for those hypocrites
And those who artfully always dress shabbily;
They do it all the time to deceive others.
He who holds the world in His control calls them the 'rag-pickers.'"
"Indeed," said Huon, "do these people belong to such madness?"
I believe there is rather a large contingent of them in Christendom.
Now they all go together on this path,
Now they all have indeed reaped their recompense for that [sin];
In no way do I value them, I don't want to talk [about them] anymore."
Huon made his way forward, for he was not stopped;
He didn't look dismayed whatever he saw.

lg.head: Laisse 393
lg.l: The Count of Auvergne passed on from there
And he led the others, he went ahead.
He looked intently at those who yelled and cried;
They approached him very closely to hurt him,
They really thought they had trapped him among them
In order to do him some harm had they the strength.
But even though they thought so, they failed completely;
They never would have been able to harm him in any way,
Even if they really striven, indeed, for many days;
The count was aware of it, he watched out for them.
Then he cried out, "With me you will never win!
Go on your way, evil, cursed people;
For what you have done, you'll have payment;
You'll be in great suffering for all your days forever."
[The spirits] passed on by, for they were very ashamed;
There were several of them very eager to talk,
Who told the count something of their deeds;
Others didn't agree to it, they gave them a hard time,
Striking them a great deal on their flanks and on their sides.
"Go back to your pathway; this is not your destiny."
And the others mocked and scorned them.
The holy saint laughed about it,
Then he blessed Jesus of majesty;
They passed through the fifth gate.

lg.head: Laisse 394
lg.l: The fifth gate appeared massive;
It was of stone painted black and white,
And [covered] with many other things without any restraint.
On high ground, through the art of magic,
All knowledge of the seven arts resided in that place,
[Knowledge] that began with Tisias in his youth.
Just as the priest speaks low when he begins mass,
And then he raises his voice,
So [these spirits] still had the habit of singing:
Just as [the priest] lowers his voice, the [assisting] clergy begins.
Tisias acted likewise when he came foward to sing:
He sang the low line while the others continued [the top line] above.
The display pleased the baron Huon;
[His] question pleased the son of Anchises.
"For what reason are these spirits condemned?
Are they damned to punishment in Hell?
They bear the love of knowledge;
Do their customs therefore cause them suffering,
And does good learning weigh them down?
What should I say when I return to France,
That great wisdom is folly
Because these [spirits] are in the dark dwelling?"

lg.head: Laisse 395
lg.l: "Huon, friend," said Aeneas,
"They are not damned except the evil ones
Who knew about the true good way;
They didn't acknowledge the true God.
They trusted their own reasoning so much that they turned to falseness.
They dwell in this darkness here; in this valley
Live the devils whose names are Flagiras,
Ajax, Brugier, along with other devils
Who fell from Heaven above to down below.
Their punishment would be a comfort to you.
They take pleasure in mortal blasphemy:
Oh, they'll never pass beyond the city of Hell!"
Saint William said, "These [fiends] have nothing at all to jest about.
Let's go on; we'll seek other paths;
Let these exist in pain, as it pleases Jesus."
At this word they then departed;
They passed the sixth gate near a palace.
They saw a kind of people who were all shaven
Singing around Pythagoras.

lg.head: Laisse 396
lg.l: Those who sing in the infernal place
Don't do it at all for joy or dancing,
But in memory of former times.
They have no laughter or song that is equal;
They must be at the Day of Judgment
When there the True Master will have to deliver
Judgment—He who suffered anguish
In order to save everyone from the everlasting shadow.
He who receives a good [judgment] will have a good final hour;
I believe it will go very badly for the one who deserves it.
His singing means the same as
That of the oriole that laments its little chicks.
But their pain is acute and mortal;
Everything burns both in hill and in dale
Where they pass, thus they don't stop.

lg.head: Laisse 397
lg.l: After this matter that you heard recounted,
Huon, the noble knight, saw there
A place horrible in very many ways,
No language exists that might tell it—
[Neither] the great pain nor the great sorrow.
There was a lake there of fire and sulphur,
Full of serpents and fierce basilisks,
That gave off a stench; it fouled all the air.
He saw a huge mass of souls lodged there;
The fire burned them, then the worms swallowed them;
It made them remember their great sin—
This was pain upon pure pain,
And he saw men gather together there repeatedly
Whom devils pursued en masse and by the thousands,
They dove into the lake like falcons into a river.
Every language was spoken there,
One heard much in the Auvergnat language.
[Huon] recognized one of them whom he saw leap past
In front of him because he was so distressed.
"Say, there," said Huon, "aren't you Count Roger
Whom I see suffering to such exhaustion?
In earthly life you were considered worthy and valiant;
Now tell me what your sin was,
For which reason you are brought to such severe justice."
And [Roger] stopped [and] turned to him angrily.
"Who are you," he said, "who seeks me out asking questions,
Who wants to redouble my pain on me now?
Let me go on [my way]! It's none of your concern to inquire about
My difficulty which you see is continually worsening."
Huon replied, "Forget about all that;
It's best for you simply to reveal everything."
"God!" he said. "Since you really want to hear it—
It's for a great sin that I truly committed recently
Of treachery and evil method
Against the best [man] that one could find!
Simply because of lust and through evil dealings
He was made to pledge and swear in front of Charles Martel
That he would go to Hell to demand tribute
From that great prince of all the devils,
And if [the Devil] didn't consent to it completely,
That he challenge him in the name of the emperor,
Afterward he would how properly to tell and explain about it to [the king]
Whether the land [of Hell] was such that one could beseige it,
What men he had and what the men could do.
All this was done to drive [Huon] away
In fact because of his wife whom the king wished to shame:
Charles wanted to have her at his side.
Alas, that for this reason I am in this situation!
Since I never ever wanted to confess it,
I am damned for it [to be] in the harshest punishment."

lg.head: Laisse 398
lg.l: "Listen some more," said Roger the felon,
"We were twelve nobles who committed the treachery,
As well as a minstrel with evil intent.
We did everything according to Charles's desire and pleasure,
So that Huon d'Auvergne might be placed here in captivity.
He will be absolved here, we know it for certain,
And we are here in great wretchedness.
Out of the twelve that we were, nine are in here,
I know nothing further to say of this agony.
Who are you who have interrogated me so, baron?
You're so bright and good looking;
You have no pain whatsoever, I see you still alive.
How have you come to this cruel place?
I don't recognize you, but it seems according to your speech
That you're Auvergnat, from that region."
The count replied, "They call me Huon;
I'm the one people speak so much about.
I've come to complete my mission to the great Demon;
I won't leave until I know his intention,
Whether he's willing to obey King Charles in all things;
If not, I'll surely challenge him.
You'll remain here and we'll leave
Safely, so it seems to me;
We'll know well how to recount to [Charles] his entire situation.
You acted wickedly when, without any reason,
You sent me to seek this evil place;
Now go on your way to your damnation!
You'll receive the reward for your evildoing."
After these words he spoke no more to him;
[Roger] threw himself into the fire where the dragon was;
There was a great throng near to others who were coming;
The dragon swallowed them and the coal burned them.
Huon continued on, both he and his companions;
They came upon quite a few other great punishments there.

lg.head: Laisse 399
lg.l: Huon looked across the lost valley;
He saw many different other punishments there:
Where one after another they were eaten,
They flayed the bones and pulled off the flesh,
Nevertheless they never saw them satisfied.
"O God," said Huon, "your justice is sharp!
I see there souls who kill one another,
Such that it seems to me that suffering is being increased.
Oh, Aeneas," said Count Huon,
"Those two who are unknown to me--
Tell me about them right now."
And [Aeneas] replied, "Let the truth be known.
Those are souls--who were born in an evil hour--
Of the two traitors who set in motion the betrayal
Of Alexander who drank the poison.
If you'll wait here for just a little,
King Alexander will strive to pursue them.
Do you see him coming from over there, without stopping,
The one who's carrying that sharp lance?
He wants to kill them; his intention will fail.
He suffers because of it, his pain is increasing
Because he will never fulfill his desire [to kill them]."

lg.head: Laisse 400
lg.l: "Now look, brother, at the son of King Phillip,
On that Gascon horse, fully armed,
He was a madman who burned like a firebrand:
Look how he cries out and says in a loud voice
'Where are the traitors who poisoned me?
If I find them I'll render such justice to them
That everyone will henceforth talk about it!'
He chases them closely but doesn't quite reach them,
For he finds other skirmishes aplenty
And in great pain every day he stops and gives up,
Then he goes to lodgings with all his companions.
He asks for Aristotle; see how he takes him by the hand;
They speak to each other confidentially without stopping.
From day to day they reap such punishment."
At these words, Huon continued on.

lg.head: Laisse 401
lg.l: Huon traveled on across the dark wasteland
Of marvels, of punishments; he couldn't resist
Asking and posing questions to Aeneas:
"Who are these people who have such great suffering?
I don't know how to distinguish the least of these torments.
They all howl and cry as tribulation overcomes them;
It appears to be fitting [for them] to remain in great pain."
Aeneas said, "Now, you must listen to me:
This location is the dwelling place of the painful unending sojourn.
Just look, brother, how much they writhe in their struggling!
This one is Judas, who proceeded to sell his Lord,
This other one is Ganelon, whose flesh you see splitting,
Whom you see there tied to the tail of a horse and dragged."

lg.head: Laisse 402
lg.l: "Friend Huon, you are now without fail
In the depths of Hell where there is the most woe.
The greatest sinners indeed have this dwelling place;
They do such penance for our Lord.
This one is Cain who committed that wickedness,
Who killed his brother through cruel affection;
This criminal committed the first homicide;
The other is Ham who committed that wrongdoing;
The other is Pharoah, who had so much power in the world.
All of these, I tell you with certainty,
Demonstrate the decisions of our Lord."

lg.head: Laisse 403
lg.l: Aeneas said to Charles's messenger,how they engage in great quarrels
"See there Lucifer, with that strange form,
Who is filthy and dark and has a loud voice;
The entire world is terrified of his stench.
Go to him confidently, deliver your message to him;
He can't harm you at all, I want you to know it well."
The count heard his words, he raised his face;
He came before [Lucifer] and said in his [own] language:
"Oh, sinful spirit, listen to what I have to say:
Allow me to address you in the name of that Authority
Who chased you out of Heaven because of your great transgression;
I wish to deliver my message on behalf of the emperor
Who sent me to demand tribute."

lg.head: Laisse 404
lg.l: "Oh, Lucifer," said Count Huon,
"Listen to me, to what I'll say
On behalf of Charles Martel, for I am his messenger.
I don't greet you, now, mad, cruel demon,
Because you are in this [place of] perdition.
My lord commands through me, and I say it to you,
That you will retain your land from him as a grant.
He wants homage from you and you'll become his liegeman:
Send him tribute, for I urge you to do so now;
Let the tribute be such as is fitting for [the emperor].
If not, never expect any clemency;
Here, right now, I challenge you at once.
He says he'll look for you until he finds you;
Charles won't leave you [even] a full foot of land.
I have related my message; now, how do you answer him?"
Lucifer replied, "We'll indeed take counsel about it;
We'll pay it all to him quite thoroughly.
You'll have the payment just as it will suit you;
I'll hold you hostage here for now,
Indeed I'll put you in the deepest place,
In the most beautiful place where the devils are."
William replied, "That cannot be at all,
That he be harmed, and we won't allow it from you.
Through me God on high in His Heaven orders you
To take care that he not be harmed.
Do everything that he says in his speech:
Hand over the tribute, then give him leave [to depart].
This one who must carry it in safety
Can't perish in such a terrible house."

lg.head: Laisse 405
lg.l: When the Devil heard this speech
In which Saint William was giving him orders,
He then said to the count, "Sir, now pay attention.
I am changed in heart and intent;
Now I'll speak to you very forcefully
About this matter; I repent here [and] now.
I don't want to go against your lord for anything at all,
If I offended you, you would react quite badly.
I am his liegeman, and, if he consents,
I and my people will make a gift to him:
That I cede to him all my land as well as my people!
I have never seen him, but I await him eagerly,
If it might please him to [come] see this domain:
He'll be the most powerful one of us all.
See this tribute that I send him, that is to say:
A litter like a bed worth more
Than Germany and all its dependencies!
There are a thousand little birds on it of refined gold,
Who continually sing more sweetly
Compared to which any other melody isn't worth a bezant.
Moreover, [there is] a crown worth a great treasure;
See here this ring with which it is truly fitting to marry;
I send him greetings; tell him in public
That he should come to us very soon.
We have a great desire to serve him.
Henceforth, I don't intend to say more to you about it;
You are wise and you are well-experienced.
Whether you wish to remain or to go at present,
Do as you wish from now on;
Take this ring; put [it] on your finger now!"
The count said, "You won't do such a thing to me!
Put it there in the bag that you are sending on to [the emperor]."
And they did it, then they ended the conversation.

lg.head: Laisse 406
lg.l: Once Count Huon had received the gifts
From the Prince of Hell--who was confined [in Hell]--
And was able henceforth to leave as soon as he wanted,
He faced William directly.
Then he said, "How will I do it, worthy one?
If I wish to go, and I would indeed like to leave,
The road is long, the heights around it are forbidding.
There is no way I'll be able to keep up with you;
I'm weakened and I feel ill all over;
I've eaten nothing for nine days.
I would willingly rest, if I found a good possibility."
When William heard what Huon said,
He spoke to the devil who was dressed as a pilgrim:
"Go quickly, bring the round table
With the food that you carried away from his house:
Bread, wine and some game meat,
As well as the chair that you took from the baron;
He won't lose a button's worth of anything."
[The devil] replied, "As you command;
See there what I've brought him."
When the nobleman saw the food,
He wanted it more than anything in the world,
But he was reasonably afraid
That the food might not be safe.
Moreover, he thought he might commit a wrong against God;
He hadn't had or wanted such food for a long time.
The saint replied, "Thanks be to God!
You have now completed your penitence;
You can eat everything in safety
Like this [food], which was from your household.
The day that you left your country
Jesus preserved it for you in this state,
Thus never because of this meal will you sin at all.
Now eat some of it; don't be anxious."
William blessed [it], and then Huon sat down
On the chair that was his in the earthly world.
He recognized it well, as well as the entire table at that moment;
He was amazed; he made no sign [of it].

lg.head: Laisse 407
lg.l: The count sat down once he had washed his hands;
He took some food, as much as he wanted;
He found it tasted good, as if it had just been brought.
Once he was completely sated,
He said something that was overheard:
"I have done such a thing as no one has ever done;
I have received edible food in this place
From which I am as well satisfied as I could wish;
May the matter go as God wills it!
Now let's turn back; since our message
Has already been delivered, I won't tarry any longer.
Let those remain who must remain;
I'll depart soon once I have rested a little."
He supported himself on the table that was before him;
Because he had eaten and toiled a bit,
It wasn't long before he fell asleep.
When Saint William noticed him this way,
He then blessed him; he commended him to God.
He spoke to the devil who had brought the food:
"Go quickly," he said, "in the name of the sovereign God.
Carry him right away to safety,
With all the things that were presented to him.
Be in his land before midnight;
Place him safely without delay in his palace.
Do it so that he not sense anything, nor wake up."
[The devil] listened, he didn't argue with him;
He picked everything up in one go, then he carried it away from there.
He transported it gently so that nothing stirred.
How he traveled, I truly don't know,
But the next day, when the count woke up,
He found himself safe and sound in his city.
As for [William], the saint ascended
To Paradise from which he had come.

lg.head: Laisse 408
lg.l: Before the appearance of dawn, Huon awoke;
He felt alert, he didn't appreciate his danger.
He said that indeed henceforth he would be able to go,
Nor would the road trouble him from now on.
"Where are you, Lord William, come here!
I don't see you at all, don't forget me here!
This place is very evil, I have known it well for a long while,
The one who's going to carry back that tribute will be ready.
I don't want to tarry anymore, for the way is long."
He asked for [William] several times but he uttered not a word;
When the saint didn't reply and [Huon] became distraught,
Fear took hold of him a bit. He was waiting eagerly
For [William] and for the light that was indeed lacking to him.
While he was waiting, the bell actually rang out loudly
Down through the city and echoed all around.
"O God," said Huon, "what a great marvel there is here!
Is there a bell in Hell? Who then carried it here?
For the one in my country definitely has just such a sound;
This one is like that." And [Huon] then listened to it a little;
He heard the sentinel, who was waking up the guards;
He recognized several according to their speaking voices.
"Holy Mary," he said, "I don't know how this is happening;
These are my men! How have they come here?
Surely I'm in Hell, I just delivered my message;
I haven't left yet! They've delayed me for a very long time."
Just as the count said those words
And listened, well, he heard his wife, whom the guard had awakened,
Speaking, and [the man] was very troubled.
And she comforted him in a very friendly way:
"Be reassured, don't worry at all,
For Charles Martel won't have power over us."

lg.head: Laisse 409
lg.l: When Count Huon heard these words,
That his wife was comforting the warrior,
He recognized her well by her words and her language.
He said, "This is no time to delay."
As he was getting up, he also crossed himself;
He looked ahead, he wanted to step boldly
Out of Hell, once he had heard such a speech
From his wife whom the baron [now] truly believed,
For God made a sign to him in this matter.
After all, in that other place, in the eternal depths,
Many had told him about how the emperor Charles:
He wanted to seize her, whereas [Huon] refused to believe it.
Once the nobleman had returned to his senses,
He recognized his palace and all the other buildings.
"Holy Mary," he said, "this is a great miracle!
I'm supposed to be in Hell, yet I'm at home.
Here are the gifts that Charles is supposed to have;
Who has done this? I don't know the circumstances.
I give praise to God for it and thank Him for it,
And also to His Mother and William, the saintly man."
Then he headed boldly toward the palace,
Count Huon went toward his wife
To meet her. When he drew near,
He didn't say a word to her, for he couldn't speak;
Entirely armed as he was, the man took her in his arms;
She saw herself overpowered, she cried out loudly.
Right away she was helped by the best ones there were;
If he hadn't let go quickly, he might indeed have been harmed.
He got down on his knees and asked for pardon;
He didn't say anything, rather he gestured.
The lady then cried out, "Let go of this churl!
Take him right up to the great hall,
For I would like to find out his purpose,
Whether he is a spy or not of the powerful King Charles,
What he asks, what he seeks, why he committed such a misdeed;
It will go well for him if we don't pay him [for it] this very day."
They led him [there] without delay.

lg.head: Laisse 410
lg.l: They led him up to the great hall;
The lady came after, for she had a great desire
To know for certain who this knight was.
He didn't speak, he was watching her closely;
He broke into a heavy sweat and wept bitterly.
He couldn't stay on his feet, he fell to the ground;
The lady perceived that he couldn't express himself.
She didn't know who it could be, she thought he was afraid.
Then she thought in her heart that she would let [him] go.
Next she looked at his size and the shape of his body;
She saw him completely weakened, he had lost his color,
He was altered; he had a long beard,
And owing to the great harm of never having rested,
He had a completely white beard; he had never shaved
From the time when he departed and left his land behind.
"Holy Mary," Lady Ynide said,
"This one resembles my lord in his appearance.
He is completely altered, I can't yet be sure,
Nor by speech will he demonstrate it:
It doesn't appear he's able to talk, he hasn't spoken a word yet."

lg.head: Laisse 411
lg.l: The lady spoke to him with kind words;
His chest felt so tight that he didn't utter a word;
He refused to do anything but look [and] weep.
When the lady saw him completely nonthreatening,
She recognized through this [that] great love urged him on.
Then she rememberd a wound that [Huon] had on his person,
On his right shoulder, one that he got in Carcassonne.
Now she said, "Quick, quick, disarm him completely!
If this man is the one about whom I'm now thinking,
I'll soon recognize him; may God now grant it to me
That this be my lord, whom I love without impediment;
Little would I prize Charles or the men that he assembled."
She had him disarmed right then and there; he made no resistance.
When she caught sight of the wound, she cried out aloud:
"Now I don't care one bit about my war [with Charles];
This man is our lord, I say it to you now by right!
This man is my lord Huon whom God has returned to us."
Then she turned back to him to kiss his face and body.

lg.head: Laisse 412
lg.l: When Lady Ynide recognized her lord,
She kissed him lovingly more than a hundred times;
Because of great tenderness her eyes filled with tears.
A great mass of people gathered all around;
There was no one so very hard-hearted
That he wasn't overcome by tender-heartedness from seeing this.
Speech was now restored to the count;
Once he was dressed again, he spoke to those all around:
"By God," he said, "do not doubt, [my] lords,
I am your lord, Sir Huon the count.
I have overcome great distress, pain and suffering
In order to find honor.
I did much and endured great tribulation
Until I fulfilled my mission.
Whoever wanted to put it all in song,
[Like] a wise cleric who might be a good writer,
Still wouldn't be able to write it all out in three months time
With all the things I did every day.
I render thanks to God and always to His Mother,
Since She guided me honorably to safety,
That is, out of that Hell that I had sought, lords.
I know about your affliction and languishing,
That you are suffering great hardship and great sadness.
Henceforth you must advise what is best
So that the esituation will really end now,
And you'll dwell in peace and happiness,
And, should it please God, it will be this very day.
Have no doubt and have no fear,
And concerning this I won't lie to you:
You'll be free of the emperor.
Come with me without any further delay;
I'll show you another marvel."
Then they went to the place where his table sat;
There was the litter that gave off great light.
The little birds began their singing,
Expressing such a melody and such sweetness
That great numbers of people rushed up all around
Until Huon cried out, "Don't get close to them!
It's a supernatural thing that doesn't reveal its nature."

lg.head: Laisse 413
lg.l: Count Huon spoke to his people:
"Don't touch this litter in any way,
It's something supernatural, other than what it appears [to be];
You'll surely see its magical qualities today
For this object belongs to the king alone;
This is the tribute that [the Devil] hands over and delivers;
Eyes will never see anything more beautiful.
Look, my lady," he said, "now then
Do you recognize this table, the chair with it,
And this golden tablecloth that is spread on it?"
The lady looked and then she crossed herself:
"Holy Mary, here is a great marvel,
These are our things and belong to us.
The day you left this domain
These things were lost, I'm remembering it [now].
I don't really understand the one who took them,
But truthfully I saw him fly through the air."
Huon didn't pay attention to this; he said to them all:
"Don't go doubting me, I'm just telling you,
The One who has protected me up to the present moment
Saved the table and the various foods.
He didn't want us to lose anything of ours.
This will be the mark of a great lesson
For the one who wants to learn and recognizes [its moral]."
Now let it be done, what I'm about to say:
Let the army know about my arrival,
That I've come back safe and sound and alive.
I have accomplished my quest for which they sent me away.
I really want to speak to my lord
And relate my mission which put me through torment.
So let the gates be opened, don't fear anything;
Soon you'll see how the matter will go differently [from what is expected].
All of [the king's] machinations have troubled God;
He has already been damned to Hell indeed.
I really believe you'll see a part of his punishment today;
Don't worry about what I'm saying now."
And it was done quickly and rapidly;
The guards announced it loudly from their positions.

lg.head: Laisse 414
lg.l: The news was spread among the troops
That the good vassal Count Huon had come back.
Most everyone was moved by great joy.
But whoever might have been happy, it troubled Charles immensely;
He said to his men, "You are deceived.
The count is dead, it has been known for a long time;
But these foolish people who have spread the news
Are all upset because their land will be lost;
I don't rate their situation worth one little bit.
Quick now," he said, "let the city be attacked!
May they pay dearly for what they said!
If we can't seize anything, my whole army will feel cheated."
As he was having this discussion
The gates of the city were lowered
And many people streamed out.
They didn't appear to be men who were distraught,
But rather bold and courageous and quite confident.
They were all armed, but they came on foot,
Each holding an olive branch in his hand,
For it signified peace, that is a known truth.

lg.head: Laisse 415
lg.l: Lord Huon, the count, made his way toward the army,
He brought with him the best of his men:
Berart the valiant and Count Thomas as well,
Guy and Bovo, the warrior's nephews.
When those in the [king's] army recognized him there,
All the greatest [among them] came to him meet him.
They certainly didn't fail--out of fear of their lord--
To welcome him with tears and weeping
[And] do him honor as best they could;
And he humbled himself much toward them;
In a similar manner did he come to the emperor,
Then he knelt, like a servant to his lord.
He kissed [Charles's] feet, then said to him, "Please,
Listen to me, I won't lie to you.
In order to complete my quest, I have endured great tribulation;
I won't speak about this, I can hardly believe it,
Yet I remained many days in Hell;
I know the entrance and the exit and which people the great Demon hashave [there].
I spoke to him as an ambassador;
I told him the whole business, then I showed him the letter;
He took counsel with his advisors.
He said that he wished to hold fiefs and offices from you;
From here on out, he holds you as his lord.
If he has failed [you], he is very sorrowful about it;
Indeed he thinks to make amends appropriately at once.
He sends you gifts that represent him;
Never has any king or emperor received finer gifts.
But these are all nothing, compared to what he is thinking of now;
Do you want to see him? You would honor him by so doing,
You can also see the land and domain.
I'll never at any time fight against you, sire;
I am [your] vassal and you are [my] lord.
Command me and I obey immediately,
If ever it is within my power."

lg.head: Laisse 416
lg.l: When the emperor heard his speech,
And saw Huon, who stretched out at his feet,
With his mission reported and next awaiting mercy,
Offering himself and his land publicly to him.
It seemed then that [Huon] wasn't humbling himself to him;
[Charles] said that [Huon] would never in his life act this way;
As to what [Huon] said, [Charles] didn't believe it at all;
He addressed him and spoke quite harshly,
Telling the count, "Get up right away,
Get out of here, traitor and also perjurer!
Your words are lies, I hold them as nothing,
You have been hidden for a very long time, I know it.
Now that you see that you are vanquished, you come
With humility and acting friendly;
You think to get back everything that you are are losing
And return to my favor; but that will never happen.
Were it not, however, a question of my honor,
Because you came here to seek death and mercy at the same time,
I would have you hanged from a leafy tree!
Now get away from here, disloyal, stinking traitor,
I wish for no truce with you; I challenge you right now."
"My lord," said Huon, "you can do whatever you want,
With me and mine.
As for what you say about not believing me,
I'm telling it truthfully and not lying to you about anything.
I've never been a traitor a day of my life,
Indeed I'll demonstrate it to you, right now at present;
Then you'll know if I am telling the truth or lying."
Huon called the spirit who was on hand;
He spoke to him and told him quietly:
"Go," he said, "and bring the gifts,
And make sure the birds are singing."
[The spirit] heard him, he brought them at once;
He displayed the litter before King Charles.
No living man had ever seen anything so beautiful,
Nor anything more sumptuous with beautiful workmanship.
No one could know how it had been enchanted:
It was cast from gold together with precious stones;
So it appeared to everyone who was looking at it,
But so far no one knew what it really was.
The birds took great delight in singing.

lg.head: Laisse 417
lg.l: Count Huon spoke thus to the king:
"My lord," he said, "now listen to me:
This is the tribute that [the Devil] sends you through me.
Now you can see whether this purse
Befits a king, as I believe."
In it were [the Devil's] letters and he eyed it directly.
Then he said to the spirit whom he saw before him:
"Now open the bag, that I see right over there;
Present the letter from your lord to mine."
And so he did; the king didn't expect this,
[The spirit] took out the letter and said, "Take the document."
The king replied, "I wish to postpone that a bit;
Then I'll reply everything I would like [to say]."
He looked at the litter and all the other trappings,
He couldn't get enough of admiring this.
Huon made signaled to the barons
That [the king] be placed on the high litter.
At once he was placed there, and, without delay,
The crown [was placed] on his head and the ring on his finger.
As soon as he had the ring, the litter took off:
It was carried into the air, where everyone saw
The servants of Hell who did him great harm,
For in a moment [the Devil's] trappings were burning.
[The king] called himself wretched, "What evil ideas I had!"
He didn't cease crying and shrieking in a loud voice.
Up there in the air the litter stopped for a moment;
The king was crying and shrieking, he was entirely filled with pain:
"Oh, Huon d'Auvergne, in what an evil hour I [first] saw you!
Like an arrogant fool, I thought to lead you along
And shame your wife and have all your belongings;
But it didn't please God the Father, now I know it;
I'm going to cruel judgment in the infernal dwelling place!
You remain safe and sound, I truly see it clearly!
And I am damned for it, for the sins that I committed.
I have a great number of them in truth, a wise priest couldn't
Count them in two or three days.
But the greatest one was what I did to you;
I don't want to say anymore, now pray for me."
Then the litter took off with a falling thunderbolt;
The servants [from Hell] carried it with the bed upon it.
Some were sad and others were joyful,
But Huon comforted them, he explained the reason why
Everything had to be thus; this was right and just.

lg.head: Laisse 418
lg.l: Huon spoke before the assembly of barons,
And he explained to them with very good logic
How [Charles's] sins had condemned him:
"It will be a good example to those who remain alive;
If they wish to know themselves, this shows what to do;
Thus they can then amend and lead a good life.
It was a divine act, don't doubt that at all.
Now let's let it be, he has what he earned;
Let's consider another matter with which we are tasked.
This kingdom cannot exist without a ruler,
For the factions among many would go badly;
One pulls in this direction, another in that, however good or bad it might be,
But above us all there must be an authority.
In whatever manner we do it, let it be agreeable to us all,
So that we not be reprimanded by anybody else."
At these words, a great mass of the people then cried out:
"Oh, baron, accept the gift; there's no one at all better than you!"
And Huon answered them, "I don't want it for anything in the world!
I'm not that important, may God bless me.
Whoever the lord will be, my faith is pledged to him
To serve him loyally my entire life."
When his words had been heard,
There were many who, because of their empty vanity
Thought they should be lord, but it can never work that way;
They would already have come to blows quarreling among themselves
When Huon the vassal humbled them,
He expostulated to them all with good sense.

lg.head: Laisse 419
lg.l: "Listen, [my] lords," said Count Huon,
"By God, let there never be quarreling among you;
He who gets himself into a fury never hears reason.
Each one of us must have the right intention concerning this,
About accomplishing what pleases God and this secular world.
We'll organize this matter for everybody,
Because not everyone can be here then.
I'll speak for the group:
We know Charles left a daughter,
She is quite sensible and of beautiful appearance;
I'm not at all saying that she be in power,
Let's place her in the pope's custody
Until the court assembles in a year and a half,
Then there will be people from many regions.
We have to pursue this matter well for everyone's sake;
At Pentecost everyone will be in Paris;
Let no one quarrel there in selecting a lord.
Right away we'll select four such men
Who are clearly well-reputed and wise,
And so that we cause there to be no counterclaim by anyone,
We'll give them free choice
So that they put into writing now
All the great lineages that there are in Christendom from descendent to descendent
So that everyone read a clear case [for rights to the throne].
Let him who is the best---provided that we've eliminated the possibility
That he have a wife or be in holy orders---
Be our lord by right;
We'll then give him the daughter of the emperor Charles [in marriage].
When the court will be in plenary [session], someone will make the presentation,
And, using sharp logic, I will explain it--
Who is this one and that one and from which lineage.
I can't believe that this will not be good for everyone; no doubt at all.
I don't know what else to say; let everyone discuss it now,
Then we'll make the best choice."
Everyone cried out and at the top of their lungs:
"We won't take any other advice concerning this.
Let the names of those who will do this work
Be declared now quite quickly."

lg.head: Laisse 420
lg.l: Through joint deliberation, they selected four men:
One was the king of England, who had quite a lot of property;
Another, the king of Hungary, who was noble and valiant;
The third, the archbishop of Geneva, who had a large domain;
The fourth was the bishop of Brittany, I don't know anyone more worthy.
Each one had the approval of the religious and secular worlds;
Those who were in the crowd swore at once
Not to interfere as he would explain shortly.
And they sent quite quickly
For the others who were not there at this point.
They gave them the terms and the orders,
And they pledged to act loyally.
Next they appointed a place
Where they would have to be to carry out their tasks.
Now I'll stop talking about that, for now I'll say nothing
Until that moment when everyone knows it openly.
Then it will be known if they made a good decision,
Or one that might be greatly reprehensible.
As for the army, now we must make it clear
That [the troops] withdrew from the siege at once.

lg.head: Laisse 421
lg.l: After this, [my] lords, as you'll hear me recount,
The host was disbanded after having a meal.
Everyone was indeed able to go as he wished
To see again his wife and children whom he had left behind.
And everyone had great desire to see them,
And they departed as no one was hindered [from doing so].
A number of the highest ranked ones who were there
Tarried a little; they said among themselves
That the possessions of the king that the army had amassed
Should be given to Count Huon,
Along with the food that was found there,
To compensate for the hardship that had ravaged his land.
So many men said it [to him] and so many entreated him
That with much difficulty he consented to it and agreed.
After all that they had said and arranged,
Next, all together, they gathered for a meal
In the palace of great antiquity.
The food for this [meal] was prepared,
But before everyone could be properly seated,
He sent for the table so that it was brought,
The one that had been in Hell.
[Huon] pointed it out to everyone as a significant miracle;
"What I'm going to recount is complete truth:
Know that the day I departed from this house,
Before I had either eaten or drunk
And when my court was completely satiated,
I hosted a pilgrim next to me;
I thought to eat with him in holy charity.
I made the sign of the cross over the table in the name of the Trinity;
The companion that I had placed next to me—
It was the devil who wanted to trick me.
But he couldn't, because God helped me in this;
He couldn't look at the sign of the cross.
He departed at once with the entire table;
It was housed there in Hell.
Seven years have indeed come and gone,
I have traveled so much and suffered so much
That God the Father took great pity on me,
For which reason I was able to go on; He showed me the way
To relate my message in complete safety.
I'm not telling you about how the case went,
How I went and how I came back, for you would hardly believe me,
But I believe in His Holy Majesty,
Such that in a short time you will know well what happened,
Not through me but through divine goodness.
But I can surely tell you this much and this is not a secret,
That I was in Hell; I went through a large part of it.
I saw great cruelty [done] to many souls:
Their pains won't be described by me.
There I found the minstrel of our lord the emperor,
And Lord Roger the count, who was considered so wise.
Know absolutely for certain that they lie in great pain
He recounted to me the situation that has been going on until now.
I hurried past him, and I was so strengthened
That I spoke quite a lot to the great Demon.
I completed my mission, I took leave of him.
He handed over to me the tribute that I have brought here;
Next he told me to leave in safety.
Then this table was prepared for me;
As soon as I saw it, I clearly recognized it;
Then I blessed it in the name of the Trinity.
I ate some food, for it was revealed to me [that]
By means of the sign of the cross that I had made over it previously in good faith
It had all been preserved for me by God the Father.
I ate my fill until I was sated;
Human nature fought [me] such that I was exhausted.
I leaned on the table, I fell asleep very quickly.
How what happened [next], I cannot tell
For I wouldn't be able to explain all the facts.
The next day before dawn, I found myself in my city;
I marveled quite a lot at what I saw next.
I found with me all that you have seen;
Who did this, I have no idea.
It was a divine miracle, know that for certain.
What couldn't be completed in seven years and more,
Was all achieved in less than one night.
As for this food that I brought back here,
I pray you that it be eaten in holy charity.
Do not fear a holy thing,
Then you will be able to recognize what His goodness has been."

lg.head: Laisse 422
lg.l: The noble Count Huon spoke to them further:
"Now eat of it, and have no fear.
Then you'll tell me how it tasted."
With these words he appointed a servant
Who carried the food to be shared among them all.
Everything was distributed correctly throughout the court;
The higher-ranked people had as much of it as the lower-ranked.
Now he tasted the flavor of it with everyone,
Whoever ate was satisfied right away.
Whoever wanted most to satisfy himself
Indeed didn't care ever after to have other food.
The thing become known far and wide;
Many people considered it a great marvel.
Those who remembered God thanked Him right away;
The others didn't bother to do Him too much honor.
Let's speak now of the army; each one returned
And went back to his land with joy and happiness.
And Huon remained in his great hall;
With him [were] his people whom he loved truly.
Concerning the [good] fortune that had come to him that day,
He thanked God, he recognized it all from Him.

lg.head: Laisse 423
lg.l: Now the count remained among his people,
All of whom he loved with a good heart;
Everyone rushed to serve him,
Even as he rewarded everyone for their service.
The count led his life now in a holy way;
He rendered gratitude and thanks to God constantly
For all that He had allowed him to see before.
He prostrated himself in order to contemplate Jesus,
He often avoided his friends to be by himself,
And [avoided] his wife exactly the same way;
He spent very little time with her, for he awaited something else;
Indeed she understood this in part, for this reason she was patient.
Since he felt Him near, he feared nothing.
For this he thanked God who had given him such a gift,
For He had given him more than he was worthy of.
The situation remained just like that
Until the day fixed for the court to assemble.
A lot of men came there from many places;
I couldn't recount all the names correctly.
The pope was there, there were many clergymen:
Bishops and archbishops, priests, I believe,
And dukes and counts and other noblemen;
Princes and kings who support Christians.
Others came there for the news that they expected,
And others were inspired by God Almighty,
Just as you will hear the matter presently.
Some of them there were from faraway lands,
For this reason I don't relate their names at all.
The narrative source recounts it rather quickly and briefly:
Now let that drop, [my] lords, and listen well.

lg.head: Laisse 424
lg.l: My lords, be seated in peace, may God bless you!
Listen to a song of great renown:
This was not a fiction, but proven truth.
God performed a lot of miracles for Huon;
Even though he suffered great pain in his life,
The major part [of it] wasn't known through him,
He wasn't going around boasting about it, he had hardly disclosed it.
But God now wanted it to be revealed at this time:
It was for the best for Christendom,
Just as you will hear, just as it happened;
Afterward then I'll skip a portion.
When the time approached for which the court had been proclaimed,
Huon left his land in good company;
His brothers-in-law were there, and of course Berart;
Along with them [were] his nephews which pleased him a lot,
And other men—he chose two thousand of them.
They left for Paris without tarrying one bit;
I can't recount to you all of their journey.
When they arrived at the court, there was already a great assembly of barons;
Most of them were staying in tents and pavilions
Throughout the area that was densely populated.
Because of the many people who were amassed there,
Who were there outside in that field,
The baron said to them during their council
That the court would take place without any delay
There outside in that field.
Everyone thought it was a good idea;
Everyone went there, then it was decided:
The pope had the young woman brought there;
He placed her upon a raised dais.

lg.head: Laisse 425
lg.l: When the young lady was brought to the dais,
The four wise men got ready then
To recount everything that they had done.
But the pope spoke before the others;
He explained everything to them with clear reasoning,
And then afterward he blessed everyone.
At that moment he looked out across the field:
Two messengers were coming, quite quickly,
One from one direction and the other from the other side.
Neither one knew about the other, nor anything of the other's intentions;
They were on horseback, they had greatly exhausted [the horses].
They passed the crowd, they stopped at the dais,
They presented in writing what they had to tell,
For they knew little of the [local] spoken language.
The letters for the pope were quickly grasped;
The messengers departed, they were observed by many people.
They couldn't be properly greeted by anyone there
For no one was able to say where they had gone.
There were quite a few arguments concerning them;
Some people praised God, others said however:
"We're certain now that we're bewitched."
At that moment others then dropped that [particular] matter.

lg.head: Laisse 426
lg.l: The pope said, "[My] lords, listen to me!
This is a miracle from God, so I believe.
I'll read this letter; no one should think it presumptuous [on my part],
I don't know what it might say. Now stay perfectly quiet."
He took one of them in his hand, the other he gave to a king;
He broke the wax, then he looked inside.
He read it three times before he read [it] to the people;
Then he said aloud, "Now listen to me:
Great honor accrues to you and to the Christian faith,
But most of all to the people of France.
In Jerusalem they have chosen a new king;
By divine miracle our faith is maintained."
He explained the matter, just as it came about and how it was going.
He left nothing out, neither more nor less was there;
When the barons heard this news,
Since a large number [of them] gathered around Huon,
His deed was known in his great goodness
And to his honor; those [present] took great joy in it.
With good reason everyone pointed out [Huon] to each other.
The count didn't behave arrogantly because of this;
This time he immediately began to weep
As it reminded him of what more he could do.

lg.head: Laisse 427
lg.l: Now I'll tell you about the other letter,
Whence it came, and afterward who sent it:
It came in this way from the Land of Truth.
Prester John sent it to the worthy pope;
He sent him both greetings and love first of all.
[The letter said:] "Let what the letter says be made known to everyone,
Because it will indeed be found to be completely truthful:
"God revealed him to me one day while I was praying."
He narrated [in the letter] the entire situation concerning Huon the warrior
From the time he left the land of Jerusalem,
Everything that he did next until his coming [to Prester John's land],
Concerning the four kingdoms that he conquered in his time [on this quest],
And about all the hardship and the great pain,
For he suffered great distress in many places;
How he went safely into Hell,
Everything that he saw, who was helping [him] then;
Now he had returned, safe and sound and alive.
"We know well his career in its entirety;
Know well that he was considered saintly by us.
Do him honor above all other men!
If I had him in my own domain
I would love him more than any brother or relative
For previously I saw wisdom in him."
That was the end of the letter.

lg.head: Laisse 428
lg.l: When the tidings [in the letter] were known to everyone,
Everyone replied, "O God, O God, help [us],
Never has such a marvel been seen by anyone,
That one man alone vanquished four kingdoms,
Converted [them] to Christianity, then gave it all up;
In order to be faithful, he put himself in peril."
Then he bowed to him, "Welcome here indeed.
This one must be king, it's very clear,
The land would be well maintained by him.
Now let him be lord without holding an election."
"This cannot be," replied Huon,
"My mind is set on other matters:
Heed the ones who were elected by you."
And then he fell silent; everyone was silent and mute.

lg.head: Laisse 429
lg.l: The pope spoke, the people were silent.
"[My] lords," he said, "now listen a little.
We're meeting here at God's command
To choose a new lord who is noble and valiant,
And of lofty lineage and of a noble family,
So that there be no bastardization in the [line of the] emperor.
Four have been selected by the community;
Do you want them first to report on their work?
Before they make their report,
I would really like to have your approval concerning this;
Let each one state [it] again and make clear his inclination."
Everyone replied, both great and small:
"We all approve what will be said presently;
We hold them [to be] good men and [they] will choose well."
At that moment they opened the document,
The king of England read the writing,
That is, the summary: these were the highest candidates of noble lineage."
Gradually they read through them all;
When all of them had been fully scrutinized,
Who was this one and that one and others likewise—
All the great lineages had been debased.
Certain ones pretended to be from a lineage that they'd never belonged to
Because family lines had declined and no one was left anymore.
There were two of them that still existed now;
In these two families, [there were] only two men altogether.
One was Huon, who was from the Narbonnais family;
The empire truly didn't belong to him,
For he already had a wedded wife, as we've known for a long time.
He was quite worthy and wise [and] of excellent behavior.
From the other family, that of Ganelon, only one was currently found;
He was worthy and bold and truly loyal,
He was a man rich in land and with a great domain:
Everyone called him William Capet.
He was a short man, courageous and valiant,
And a generous donor, not loving cupidity,
He was much loved by those who knew him;
It seemed that destiny was falling on this choice.

lg.head: Laisse 430
lg.l: The pope said, "You have heard, [my] lords;
This one is destined to be emperor over you.
Come forward, William, receive these honors;
You will be crowned here this very day."
Six kings and six counts led him to the dais
Singing Te Deum laudamus with joy and jubilation.
They then presented him to the pope;
He knelt weeping and crying;
As many people watched, he was crowned
By the common consent of those surrounding him.
From all those people there was no opposition,
But there were quite a few who regretted that day.
From them nothing [of their dissatisfaction] appeared on that occasion,
But little time passed before they brought him woe,
Just as you'll hear before the end of the work.
William was crowned and married his wife,
Charles Martel's daughter whose name was Belisor.
All the barons swore to hold him as lord,
And he invested them with lands and domains.
The celebration was quite grand; the court lasted for eight days,
Then they took their leave and returned to their lands.

lg.head: Laisse 431
lg.l: The court was disbanded and the people left
For their countries from which they had come.
Most of them were at peace
For a good while, as the story explains.
A year later, just as the tale recounts,
A great challenge confronted the Romans
When a Saracen army crossed the sea,
All of whom set up camp below Rome.
There were actually four hundred thousand [of them] by estimate;
There were fifteen kings and a sultan.
All had sworn that they would destroy Rome;
And the pope, if they could find him,
Would be burned or skinned alive.
They besieged the city, from three sides they would take it;
They pillaged and laid waste to the surrounding land,
Everyone would be killed if they had not fled.
When the pope saw such a battle imminent,
Neither he nor the cardinals who were there knew of any solution
Except to barricade themselves within the city,
For they weren't at all accustomed to wage war.
They defended the city as best they could.
Later [the pope] sent some messengers [who] would speak extremely well
To William Capet, the king of the world,
That he should help him and not wait at all,
Knowing that they couldn't hold Rome.

lg.head: Laisse 432
lg.l: The messengers left and didn't tarry at all,
They rode a long way, covering a lot of ground,
Until they came to Paris early one morning.
They asked for the king, where he was to be found;
There were quite a few people who pointed him out:
"See there, the lord whom you seek and about whom you speak.
If, for any reason, you are applying to him for anything,
He will certainly act fairly toward you; you yourself will lose nothing.
He is indeed worthy and wise, he accepts good advice
And helps his people to lead a good life.
In him there has never been anything other than politeness and courtesy."
[The messenger] heard these words, right away he dismounted;
He came to the king before whom he bowed.
In a loud voice he recited his message,
He revealed what the pope asked of [William],
And the great need for which he sought aid.
He gave him the letter and [William] unfolded it quickly;
He read the letter, then he put it down quickly,
And this was a sign of good manners.
He replied to the messenger, properly and courteously:
"You will remain, you will be well-lodged,
And throughout my lands I'll send word
To kings, dukes, counts and commanders,
That they come to court with their men well-equipped,
That they not delay at all to wage war
In a month so as not to let me down;
Should anyone be arrogant so as not to come on this mission,
He would be banished from my entire realm."
The letter was written as soon as the messengers were selected;
They were sent out in all directions.
To all [William] proclaimed love and friendship,
[And] that this business be attended to for the sake of God.
The many barons who heard the missive
Swore and vowed in their hearts
That they would never ever budge for him,
And that they would never obey him in their life.
They sent him arrogance and insult,
Nor did they hold him as their lord at all.

lg.head: Laisse 433
lg.l: When King William got the reply,
That those very men were failing him who were supposed to serve him,
You must truly know that it vexed him very much.
And then afterward, he grieved greatly,
It couldn't be otherwise; thus it was to be.
He gave leave to the messenger, for which he was distressed:
"Go, tell your lord how things are;
May he forgive me, I can't do it,
For those who promised to serve [me] have failed me.
I want to send for Huon; this I believe, he wouldn't fail me;
If he doesn't help me, I am completely undone."
The messenger returned to Rome, to the lord who awaited him;
He gave him the message, which weighed on him heavily.
Then [the pope] promptly sent again to Germany,
Begging the king, the dukes, the counts who were there
To come rescue him as they should.
If they didn't do this, they would betray Holy Church,
But if they deigned to do this willingly,
If they came to the Holy See to drive out the enemy,
Then, let happen afterward whatever might happen,
He, [the pope], would place the crown of the empire on a German,
And he would always support it for them
Against all those who would wish to challenge [it].

lg.head: Laisse 434
lg.l: The messengers left, they sped on [their] way;
They traveled until they entered Germany,
They told the news to many barons.
When the Germans heard this, they rejoiced;
They sought each other out in ones and twos.
Then they consulted among themselves:
