If the pope was willing to do what he intended,
And he truly meant to keep his promise to them,
Then let him be rescuced without any delay.
"We have an awful lord, we don't esteem him at all;
Compared to anyone else he's a stinking dwarf!
We aren't willing to obey him steadfastly."
Even though they were servants, they desired power
Because of their arrogance, which they exhibited quite often.
With good reason it had to go badly;
A time would come when they would grievously repent.
They declared that they would obey [the call] right away;
They levied the troops in the name of God; by agreement
Each one certainly summoned his own;
Within fifteen days they would hold their muster.
A good hundred thousand men assembled;
They started out on the road without more delay.
As for their journey, I can't tell you anything about it;
They traveled until they came to Rome.
Then they entered [the city] all together:
They spread out over the land took lodging.
Two or three Germans took over two houses,
They didn't care at all about causing hardship for others;
Rather they became completely overbearing and swaggered more.
They remained in the city and did nothing else.
But now we must tell about the Frenchmen.

lg.head: Laisse 435
lg.l: Huon came to the court with all the men he had,
He brought four thousand knights with him.
William heard it spoken of, he came to meet him;
He received [Huon] cordially as one who him loved greatly.
To him he complained about what had occurred there:
"The majority of the barons foreswore;
They said they wouldn't come for any reason.
Little do they esteem me; on the contrary, they threatened me a lot,
And they said to the messengers that they wouldn't obey me;
I plead my case to God and to you for what they have done to me."
Just as they held this conversation and spoke,
A messenger arrived who brought news
That the Germans had set out with all the troops they had
To rescue the pope; they had indeed gone to Rome,
And [the pope] had promised them, if they concluded the war successfully,
[That] he would give the crown of the empire to the Germans;
He said that he would defend them against all other men.
[The messenger said,] "I heard the letter read [aloud], and [the German leader] actually swore
That he would never hold you as his lord anymore."
"By [my] faith," said Huon, "great harm will come from this.
Before this thing is carried out,
I will go seek those who have failed [you].
I intend to give them such a summons that they'll change their minds.
As for you, be prudent and let me do this for you;
Thus no one will behave badly toward you at all."
The king promised him that he would do everything [Huon suggested].

lg.head: Laisse 436
lg.l: Huon left, he didn't tarry;
He went with few companions; his men remained at court.
From land to land he sought out loyal friends;
He begged them greatly not to be false toward God.
He explained to them thoroughly every widely-held reason:
Otherwise, they would be held to be evil
If they thus let their lord down.
The count spoke so much truth to them
That everyone promised him to do what he wanted.

lg.head: Laisse 437
lg.l: The men were assembled by Huon the vassal;
When everyone had gathered together near a valley,
A hundred and fifty thousand were on good horses.
They rode to Paris with jubilation and joy;
Day by day they rode all together
Until they came to Paris and took lodging;
William welcomed them in a completely friendly manner.

lg.head: Laisse 438
lg.l: The army stayed two whole days;
They left on the third, and they traveled hard.
They made their way toward Rome, and quite rapidly;
They rode day by day until they arrived
In the city of Rome, without hindrance.
They entered into the city, they stopped in the main square,
They sent out inquiries for lodgings, but they found very few of them,
For the Germans held them for their own needs.
Nobody was willing to leave them; rather [the Germans] mocked [the French].
William sent word to the pope that they had come,
That he should clear [the Germans] out of lodgings, they should billet on one side:
For remaining like this would go badly for them.
There are enemies who oppose them;
It would be fitting for them to behave differently and better.
Concerning this news, when the pope got word,
He thanked both God and the barons.
Next he sent a message telling the Germans to limit sthemselves,
That some of them evacuate some housing,
There where the French might be able to lodge fittingly.
They promised them quite a lot but did nothing;
Many times they mocked him continually;
The king, with all his men, couldn't get lodging.

lg.head: Laisse 439
lg.l: When William saw that he would do nothing else,
You can understand, of course, how much this distressed him.
He consulted with Huon about this matter,
And [Huon] replied thus, "They are completely arrogant,
It doesn't appear that they do this to serve God,
For they value nothing, they love no one but themselves;
If it weren't for the fear and dread that one has
---For we have come here to serve God---
I would have done something else, you know well, a good while ago,
For God doesn't love arrogance; because of [their] pride he cast down
The evil angels who plummeted to Hell,
For which they were then damned and are in great pain.
These [Germans] have thus done exactly the same thing;
They don't want to recognize the great error they commit.
Let their folly be on their heads; now let things take their course.
Order your men not to wait there any longer;
Throw out the Germans who won't have strength [to resist],
And take the lodgings on this side here,
We'll soon see if they stand up to us.
They are striving for the kind of thing that will turn to their shame;
The servant wants to become master, this will never happen.
No one can grant [authority] to them, except he who has it;
Through common consent, it was given to you,
And the Germans want it but they don't ask for it.
[This] thing is dishonest; I don't believe it will please God."

lg.head: Laisse 440
lg.l: After this discussion the French charged forward;
They spread out throughout the streets in large groups.
There where they found Germans, they put them to the sword;
To the displeasure of them all, [the French] took lodgings by force.
They cast out their gear and horses likewise;
A great number of them complained to their lord.
He mounted his horse, completely stunned;
A large group of their men gathered together.
They ran rapidly toward the French
Who engaged with them, for they were not slow.
On the contrary, they struck [the Germans] wherever they were;
It was soon obvious who had the upper hand.
The French were always a noble people;
They have always dearly loved reason and the right
And brought down arrogance as much as they could.
In this affair, which was instigated deliberately,
It went badly for the Germans.
They lost a good ten thousand of their men.
When the pope heard the news,
He came to the [site of the] dispute with a large group of his men.
He passed through the throng where it was greatest,
He found the lord who commanded his men.
He spoke to him quite courteously,
He said so much to him about it, they immediately stopped
This quarrel, for it couldn't be otherwise:
"We will never be friends from now on."
The Germans were threatening the French violently,
But [the French] didn't respect them any more than a gust of wind.
They put aside the matter; each one went to his lodging;
The pope went about splitting the area in half;
The waters of the Tiber separated the two sides.

lg.head: Laisse 441
lg.l: The French were lodged on one side of the Tiber
And the Germans were on the other side.
The French king spoke to the pope,
He excused himself vigorously for this affair.
Then he told [the pope] that he would sally forth in the morning
Against the Saracens in order at that point to be tested;
He wasn't planning ever to return into [the city],
Until they were driven away from the Holy See.
"Let the Germans know tomorrow
That they should sally forth toward [the Saracens] from the other side;
Then you'll be able to know who fought the best."
The pope said to him, "It will certainly be announced to them,
But I really believe with certainty that they will do quite a lot
In order not to move, so much have they been angered."
Then he said in his heart, "I was badly advised
The day that I promised them that I would charge them
With such a high office as the position of the emperor.
I have behaved badly, for which I am troubled,
And great harm may yet occur from this.
It can't be otherwise; in truth, I promised it.
The very great need and anguish had overcome me
Made me do it---[at present] I wholeheartedly repent.
Now let the matter be as it may;
What I have promised will be observed by me."
At this moment, [the pope] left the king;
He went to the Germans, he saw them quite angry.
No matter what he said, they wouldn't yield;
The battle would now be completed without them;
Concerning their affair, they would never be pleased.
They would threaten the French a lot:
They considered doing something so that [the French] would never be happy again.
Oh, alas! Why did he say it? For it did indeed happen
That both sides suffered because of it,
And even the pope would be dismayed.
He never did anything that weighed on him more;
So this situation was left thus.
The pope departed, he sent word to the French king
To take care of this matter, for they would not be helped by [the Germans].
King William laughed and said, "Good heavens!"
He warned his men about what they had to do.

lg.head: Laisse 442
lg.l: That night the French lodged within Rome,
Then in the morning they sallied forth out of [the city],
Properly armed and equipped.
The king made five battalions in all by dividing them.
He instructed the commander quietly
How each battalion should aid the other:
Each battalion contained twenty-five thousand,
Not counting the foot-soldiers and the archers who were there.
And William kept fifty thousand of them,
Apart from the foot-soldiers who guarded the standard.
They rode fiercely toward the Saracens;
Huon the count was in front of the first rank;
He had with him quite a few very noble men:
There were twenty thousand five hundred.
Five counts were there as well as two kings,
One, the king of Navarre, which borders on Spain.
Each one was worthy, impassioned and valiant.
They were a battalion that stayed tightly together;
They rode beautifully, always boldly,
Until they and the Saracens closed together [in battle].
The [battle] cries went up from both sides, indeed.
In that place they conducted no pleas or parleys,
For right away they joined together in combat.
They attacked each other and hurled and thrust;
From both sides enormous blows were exchanged.
Indeed no one was feinting to strike hard;
In that place there were no friends or well-wishers:
As one did well, [so did] the other soon after.
Huon the valiant kept the whole thing going,
He and Berart and Thomas likewise,
For they had the best of the battle.
That whole battalion that set itself against them
Fled from the battlefield at full tilt.
But with little delay the pagans reinforced themselves;
They returned to the battlefield so increased [in number],
That they were, so I believe, more than a hundred thousand.
If God doesn't think [to help] through His good work,
Our men will rush too far forward.
The ones who had remained on guard
Told the French troops what was happening;
Right away another battalion rode out quickly.

lg.head: Laisse 443
lg.l: When the French [guard] saw our men overwhelmed,
And that they had great need of help,
The king of Ireland, who was called Thomer,
Along with [the king] of Scotland, who were [both] worthy and proud,
Came to help them without any fear,
[And] twenty-five thousand troops with them,
Not counting the foot-soldiers and the crossbowmen.
They thrust in among the Saracens when they got to the battle;
In this assault, they unhorsed many [of them];
Whether one watched it from one side or the other,
The battle was both very hard and fierce.
If one smote, the other struck back only too well;
There was no one who could really measure [who was] the best,
Except for the two cousins who had no peer in the world.
They gave courage to the timid
To strike down hard on the infidels;
It was evident there that they really helped each other.
Why should I draw out the story any more?
God loved our men, it was quite evident on that day
When He had them advance continually;
No matter what suffering they might have been enduring,
One never saw anyone leave the battlefield.
Our men accomplished so much that God wanted to help them,
Such that the Saracens weren't able to hold out.
They were put to flight toward the other battalion;
There they remained, they couldn't do anything else.
Then you saw Saracens full of derision,
Yelling at and threatening their own men whom they saw fleeing:
"Whoresons, how cowardly you are,
When you run away for such a little matter!"

lg.head: Laisse 444
lg.l: Gandres, the lord of the pagan people,
Who held Palermo, the city and the tower,
Realized that he had the very worst of the battle;
He kept shouting threats constantly at his men.
He gathered them and then he shouted at them:
"The French are dead men if you hold your ground a bit longer."
With one cry they charged [the French],
In one swarm, if I'm not a liar,
A good two hundred thousand of the Saracen troops
Encircled our men all around and about.
Now may the Lord in Heaven protect them!
They won't leave that place through death or through fear!
Our guard, which was waiting all day,
Soon provided something valuable in this situation.
They told the others about [what was happening to] our French troops.
The king of Brittany, with [the king] from Valcolor,
Attacked [the enemy] that day with twenty-five thousand men,
They helped our men with force and vigor
As they came all at once, joined in combat with them.
They didn't bother to choose an equal to fight;
On this battlefield, I tell you truly indeed,
So many were there both of our men and theirs,
That one couldn't easily choose the best.
Each one strove to win honor
And to satisfy his shame and his wrath.
Our troops performed extremely well that day
As they kept advancing upon the pagans.

lg.head: Laisse 445
lg.l: The third battalion of the pagan troops
Was defeated, so they turned to flee.
Our men chased closely behind them,
All the way to where the fourth squadron of troops stood.
In that place there was great violence
Between our men and theirs as well,
There they were demonstrating their utmost power.
At that [point], our troops were clever;
A single battalion was formed out of two,
Everyone abandoned the weapons and other armor [they were winning].
They all came rushing to the battle.
Our troops closed off the battlefield on all sides.
Now may God the Father, the powerful King, watch over them,
So that they never suffer for fear or anguish!
They wouldn't leave unless death overpowered them;
Each one stood fast, striking well with force.
Those of our guard who were waiting,
When they saw that the situation was serious,
That no one at all remained on the field,
They left, simply leaving behind tents and pavilions.
Our troops made this known right away.
And King William was wise and intelligent;
He made one squadron out of two put together.
He didn't care, no one remained [behind]; rather let them ride;
If anything destroyed this battalion,
The rest would subsequently matter little.

lg.head: Laisse 446
lg.l: King William entered the battle,
Three kings with him and he the fourth without a doubt,
[With] seventy thousand men of great valor,
Not counting the archers and all the foot-soldiers.
In the battle he struck like a sparrowhawk [descending] on a quail
When it chases it with blows and strikes it hard;
He gave many blows that day.
The French started out very well
As they sliced the bodies and bellies of the pagans.
They strewed feet [and] fists all over the meadow;
With that start, the king of France,
Even though he was a man of short stature,
Did so well there against that rabble of men,
That there wasn't even one of the other barons
Who could hold a candle to him,
Except for the two cousins, Berart and the captain count.
The Turks couldn't defend themselves anymore;
They were put to flight whether they liked it or not.

lg.head: Laisse 447
lg.l: The Saracens were defeated, they couldn't resist any longer
When they saw Count Huon cut off the head
Of their lord King Gandre, who was so worthy and brave.
Then it was fitting for the French to completely clear the battlefield [of Saracens];
The French chased them across the plain and along the riverbank;
They killed all those whom they were able to find
If they weren't willing to renounce their faith
And believe in Jesus and have themselves baptized.
By the time of this defeat, once they had succeeded in disengaging,
Five kings and a very proud sultan had been captured,
And other people among them who were the most valuable,
Besides them, there were probably about ten thousand;
Furthermore, Huon was the conqueror of most of them
[Because of] his great honor and his great power.
He was the best warrior of all, which at that moment couldn't be concealed:
Friends and enemies, each one began to speak of it,
That one couldn't find anyone better than he.
Even if he had to attack an army all alone,
No one would be able to stand firm to return his blows.
Now let's leave the subject of them going along the riverbank,
Killing and taking those whom they can find.
Now it behooves me to tell you a bit about the Germans.

lg.head: Laisse 448
lg.l: Now let's leave the French, who continued the chase,
Killing and taking everyone and everything they found.
When the Germans found out about the whole situation,
That the pagans had been defeated,
It distressed them that they didn't have any of the reward.
So they streamed out of Rome quite quickly.
They came to the field where the fighting had been;
They found no one there, except for those who were dead;
Then they agreed among themselves not to go any further.
[Since] they were there, they started to steal,
They despoiled the field of arms and war horses.
Those who were wounded and found alive,
They killed them all, such that they left no one.
They took the booty and then they left;
They entered Rome and then they stayed brazenly.
They thought to be avenged of their earlier shame.
Alas! Their despicable people had acted badly,
And then he who allowed such a deed---
It was the pope who in large part knew about it---
He said one thing, then did another;
If God doesn't take thought for His good work,
All of Christendom will remain in disorder;
The rest will soon matter little.
I'll stop speaking of this situation, but I will say briefly:
Once the pagans were dead and captured,
All the French began to return [to the city].
They had truly captured some handsome spoils:
A good ten thousand pagan infidels.
They had taken [as well] five kings and a commander.
They stopped in a field to inspect all their troops
And to take stock how many there might be left.
They had lost a third and more of them;
There were three kings and more than a hundred counts lost.
When the king realized this, he sighed very often;
He greatly bemoaned their deaths, then he resigned himself to God's will.
He took counsel with Lord Huon and the other good men
As to what they should do
With those who were dead and with the prisoners they had.
Huon spoke, "If you trust me,
Let the dead be buried very honorably.
Let those who wish to take some of the other arms do so,
But let the prisoners stay in your custody;
Once they'll be in your land, they'll certainly bring you great tribute.
From the great wealth you'll acquire and from the great presents,
You'll indeed be able to give to everyone great and small."
Each one of the others praised this counsel.

lg.head: Laisse 449
lg.l: The king and his men came back from the battle;
They had acquired great spoils that day.
For those who had died he had grief in his heart;
He sighed frequently, his eyes brimmed with tears.
Then he noticed something where the battle had been greatest;
He saw everything stolen both big and small.
"Oh, God," said the king, "who has done this deed?"
Many local inhabitants who were there then,
Who were plundering the remnants,
Said to the king, "Don't be angry;
The Germans did this and then they returned [to the city]."
The king and the other nobles were very angry about this;
They would have soon fought with them, without delaying for long,
When Huon admonished them, speaking with great mildness:
"Let go of this matter; don't demonstrate greater folly [than the Germans];
Let them have the goods, and we'll have the honor.
There will be time yet, so I believe;
Have your men removed [from the field] and buried with honor."
And thus they did without any other delay,
Then they buried them in several different churches.

lg.head: Laisse 450
lg.l: Then they all went together to their lodgings;
There they remained; they would rest for a little.
I won't explain anything else about what happened there,
Until after they had spent three days in complete repose.
On the fourth day they heard some news,
That some of the Germans were going
To the pope, who had in fact promised them
That he would give them the crown of the empire;
They wanted to leave, they didn't want to remain any longer.
And next they threatened the French,
So the pope made excuses and refused:
"That can't be, nor are there reasons for it;
Your deeds show that you were never
In the battle at all except to rob.
You are rich; others are suffering;
All the enemies have now been defeated
By the French, the most noble people in the world."
[The Germans] protested, they wanted the thing promised;
If not, before they left,
They would set in motion such a melee within Rome
That twenty thousand people would die in it before the day was out.
The pope was indeed very upset about this;
He had no idea what to do or not to do,
Nor did he want to renege on a promise under any circumstances.

lg.head: Laisse 451
lg.l: Because of this the pope was in great apprehension;
He didn't know what might be the best counsel to take.
He saw the Germans completely full of rage;
He wanted to uphold what he had promised them.
The French then showed up [to] where they were talking;
They knew well the news [of what] took place several days before.
From one side of the hall they came without clamor,
They stood nearby, in front of the pope.
William threw himself to the ground and said, "Great Pastor,
Let my appeal about this be made to God and to you,
That my honor be entirely maintained.
You know well [how] events have gone up till now;
If I acquired honor, it wasn't through my effort.
I never deserved it, but God the Creator
Granted it to me and the people as well.
With one voice everyone great and small said
That I should henceforth be their lord.
As for these Germans whom I see all around here,
There were many of them in the square that day [when I was chosen to be king].
If they don't want to have me as their lord,
Why didn't they demonstrate their force and their vigor at that moment?
For there were many good counsellors
Who were considered correct up to now;
But when they forsake their lord without warning,
They have neither faith nor proper love;
They are treacherous, deceitful and disloyal.
How can they acquire any lands or any honors,
When they are servants and have no nobility within themselves?"
At this point, a brawl might have broken out there among them,
When the pope cried out, "Beware, don't act foolishly!
Those who stir up quarrels or rush into a fury
Will immediately be out of my favor."

lg.head: Laisse 452
lg.l: After these goings-on, the pope spoke:
"Take care that fighting never break out among you,
Rather make peace; listen to me here.
Do not disparage what I will say.
When the pagans were coming here
And when they attacked my land all over,
No one will question me about whether I was afraid;
I don't know how to fight or how war is conducted.
I sent to France for you, king, who are here [now],
For you to help me, for I had great need.
You just excused yourself in this matter;
That response troubled me terribly.
I took an oath, which I have since repented of;
If it could be abandoned, I would do so quite willingly.
This can't be, for one would be forsworn."
He told everything, how he had sent for the Germans,
How he would give them the empire
If they came to his rescue
And chased the enemy from the field.
There, in that deed, they had failed;
Such was the situation, as we all know now.
No one will be praised or blamed by me
The actual deed will demonstrate [all of] that clearly."

lg.head: Laisse 453
lg.l: "Let's let this be," the pope explained,
"I ask for advice from you all:
What am I to do about what I promised?
I will then choose the best option;
Be mindful of my honor and the high office that I have,
For I would never want to be forsworn at all;
It cannot be otherwise, I've gone too far---
To the best that one can amend [the situation], I'll do it.
You're wise; I'll hear your will."
Once that was said, there were a lot of serious arguments,
One person said one thing, the other answered him back;
They expounded opinions that couldn't be carried out.
But I'll be silent a little concerning this deliberation,
I'll speak a bit further about Huon the count;
Huon clearly heard the entire quarrel.
He left the deliberations, he retired to an isolated spot,
To a remote place where no one would ever go.
He said his prayer with weeping and tears:
"O God the Father, counsel me on these points!
Don't pay attention to our wretchedness:
Of a hundred thousand [woes], I can't make ten known.
The one who should counsel others most is failing now;
Such a transgression is underway right here
That great harm is coming upon the people of the world;
We now see Christians in sorrow and lamentation."

lg.head: Laisse 454
lg.l: Huon the count was down on his knees;
With tears and weeping he was entreating God the Father
That He have mercy on the people whom He saw there.
They had now entered into such a situation
That Christendom would be in great uncertainty:
"O God the Father, may your goodness be
Shown to them so that they find justice there."
A voice from Heaven began speaking to Huon;
He couldn't see it, but he heard it well,
For the light greatly enlightened them.
"Huon," said the voice, "hear me now truly;
Jesus Christ, who served everyone quite well, sends word to you.
You are without sin up to the present moment;
You may continue to live, if it would please you.
But know that earthly life is getting ever worse.
That ruler has little faith;
He should correct others, yet he does wrong in this case—
He often stirs up quarrels about things which he shouldn't do.
Now go to your men, advise all of them thus:
If they want to continue to live, let this obligation be kept.
But know well, before anyone heads toward battle,
That the French will still remain in an honorable position,
Thus they will have a king as it was before;
They will never lose anything else other than the honor of the empire
Because of that pastor who doesn't judge rightly;
If your lord hadn't gone somewhat astray,
He would have nevertheless quickly expelled him.
Fight for the faith, uphold your lord rightfully,.
If you do this among you, good action will come of it;
You can do the kind of thing that will please God greatly,
And others can surely be confounded."

lg.head: Laisse 455
lg.l: Huon heard the angel's speech, he understood it well;
He rendered thanks to God the Father and then to [the angel].
Then he crossed himself and went to his men;
He found that among them many were dismayed
When, unable to agree among themselves,
They would indeed have fought each other.
Once Huon had broken through the throng, he stood before them all.
"Listen to what I'll say without resorting to fighting each other:
Both sides want to hold on to their claim as they see it;
For anyone who had self-control as well as some sense
It would be an easy thing to understand with certainty;
But the sins that you commit from day to day are so many
That they have taken your sense from you and you know nothing at all,
And the arrogance that you do have overpowers you.
Nevertheless that pastor has a large part in this conflict
Since the matter has gone so far forward
That our greatest pastor wishes to keep his oath,
And [the Germans] obviously want to have what was promised to them.
Those who carried the weight against the pagan people,
Who killed and captured all of them, there where they were---
For all that, I don't boast---were instead robbed:
That was a signal to set in motion a great quarrel.
Since it isn't possible to settle matters otherwise,
Between two great evils we'll then choose the lesser one."

lg.head: Laisse 456
lg.l: "Do therefore what I say, [my] lords;
Since it can't be otherwise, let's do the best we can now.
On both sides there are people of great valor;
Let's fight for the faith on this day.
Let each one be confessed of his greatest sins.
Let the pope, who is here, whose responsibility it is,
Absolve them of all their error.
Let no one be forced, rather everyone must be
In this affair willingly, for the sake of God our Lord.
Let him to whom God shows grace have the honor,
Understanding, nevertheless---I say to you with particular meaning---
That the kingdom of France will always be free,
So that it have nothing to do with the pope and emperor,
[And] never be coerced against its will;
Rather it is an independent realm, as it must always be.
Do you wish therefore to consent willingly?
This is the best [option] that I can say to you, [my] lords,
And if you must go through another major battle,
All of Christendom will dwell in suffering.
You can fulfill this mission with ten men or several,
Without having everyone great and small die.
Now carry out your will." Each one then replied:
"This is good advice; we'll take the best [option]."
The pope replied, "I consent to it immediately.
Let both sides come forward without making a long delay
To swear to uphold this [decision] faithfully and willingly.
Next then let the champions be found
Who will carry out the fight in honor of the Creator;
Let those to whom God shows favor have the honor of it."
The matter was sworn and agreed among them;
Very soon it was settled who would be the combattants.
On the French side there were four kings and fifteen counts,
As well as dukes and princes [and] other great nobles,
A hundred and fifty in number from only the best men.
I can't recount and tell all the names with certainty.
There was Huon, of course, then one of his brothers-in-law,
And his cousin Berart, the noble warrior.
I'll tell you the kings---I remain silent presently regarding the others---
[There were] the kings of England and also of Navarre,
And that of Brittany, [and] with them, that of Ireland.

lg.head: Laisse 457
lg.l: On the other side there were quite a few noble men,
The kings of Bohemia and also of Hungary,
The fierce duke of Bavaria from Ottenberg,
And other great barons and from other high-ranking households,
Until a hundred and fifty were indeed chosen
Who would do battle completely willingly.
Each one was confessed, the pope going around absolving [them];
Afterward he made the sign of the cross over them and put them in God's hands.
He prayed that among them they have good understanding,
And that they bear this truly for the faith.
If they were such as they must be,
God would have mercy on them entirely.
They replied [that] such would be their task.
Then you might have seen all the men weeping,
They would remember this with great sorrow.
Those who most aspired to act boldly
Wept the most and were very distressed.
Now we must tell the story of what happened:
Each one deliberately organized his affairs,
Then they came to the place to which they were assigned.
They entered the combat arena without noise or cries;
You might never have seen men of such courage.
They were all mortal enemies; they offered each other no peace.
They had to fight each other, undertaking it with good grace.
Everyone crossed himself, pardoning each other,
Kissing each other with weeping and tears.
After doing this, everyone confronted his opponent,
Each choosing his man as he was most worthy:
King against king, duke against duke, and likewise, counts,
And prince against prince, commander [against] commander.

lg.head: Laisse 458
lg.l: Each one approached his counterpart
In order never to have anything to be reproached for.
Once they had done this, they didn't wish to delay any longer;
They began to deal blows to each other;
They sought each other out a great deal with polished steel swords.
They sliced shields and hauberks that were good double-meshed ones;
As many as they took on of them, they had to fall to the ground.
They said not a word to each other, but soon each one was hitting his [opponent];
The most capable showed their worth that day.
There were many who slew their opponents,
And afterward, two or three [more], as they came to attack them.
But in the end no one could boast,
For everyone would die before sunset.
Three remained now behind as I can now recount to you,
One of these killed Thomas, the good warrior,
Brother-in-law to Count Huon, who was very noble and proud;
Another killed Berart, which grieved Huon greatly.
When Huon saw him dead, he began to praise God;
He cast down his own opponent, he made him fall back,
Next he attacked the one who had caused [Berart] trouble.
He rained blows down on him until he finished him off,
Then he came back to his counterpart to demand battle.
That one [whom he fought] was called Thomas of Luxembourg, the warrior,
He was count of his land and a very good knight.
These two fought, neither one was cowardly;
Hour after hour, they were stronger than any wild boar.
The dreadful clash of swords between them lasted a very long time,
As neither one could overcome the other in any way.
If one struck well, the other struck back better.
The one didn't see any way to surpass the other;
Huon said, "O Holy Mother Mary!
I see clearly that it is incumbent upon me to die here.
Have mercy today on this great sinner:
May my soul not be damned in the eternal fire.
This is the worst battle, I do believe,
Than when I was lost in the infernal dwelling place.
Now let the matter go as it is supposed to go,
For we'll really accomplish what we've set out to do,
Which is that at least one of us remain alive."
At that moment [Huon] attacked him fiercely.
Each one without threatening the other at all
Endured this great clash for a long time,
But in the end no one was able to boast about it;
They had no arms left that could protect them.
Their bodies were filling with wounds in many places;
The wounds [being] great, their blood started to flow,
The guts from both their bodies spilled out.
At that point they separated one from the other;
Both went to sit on the flat ground.
They confessed their sins, they began to call upon God
To have mercy on their souls, for they could hold on no longer.
At these words, there was a great amount of weeping;
Right away the pope came to them
And other wise men rushed to adjudicate
Between the two champions whom they saw on the ground,
Since he had to speak to them.
Listen, [my] lords, how the story turns out:
He saw them dead, passing away from this earthly life.

lg.head: Laisse 459
lg.l: Listen, [my] lords, how the story describes
The judgment at the death of both barons.
No one had the advantage at all in this undertaking;
Each one lay stretched out on the ground
And mortally wounded; let God judge their merit
So that the barons might have certainty
As to the verdict they pronounce: may they provide justice.
They looked at the wounded men who lay on the field;
They found everyone dead, their faces pallid and gray,
Except for Huon's counterpart who was not yet dead,
[Though] he had little life before death would overpower him.
With good knowledge they could make a decision,
Since one heard nothing from them---they didn't speak or say anything---
This was what was conclusive for the judgment
[And] how the legal decision truly went at that time:
They gave the victory to the Germans,
But nevertheless, for the French, there yet remained their liberty.

lg.head: Laisse 460
lg.l: As for those who died, may God grant them pardon;
As for the empire, since the gift of it was made to the Germans,
May they receive it with God's blessing.
Everyone afterward wondered at such a choice.
The court was then disbanded without delay;
Everyone turned toward his own house.
Certain people were happy and others were grieving;
Never had anyone ever seen such a loss;
The best men in all Christendom had died there.
They wouldn't be replaced for a hundred years.
Whoever might weep over it or be joyous about it
More than anyone else the French mourned.
They left Rome, they carried Huon's body,
Of course they had it buried with great procession
Within Auvergne at his principal residence.
Ynide died because of [his death] out of her grief for the baron;
The people of the realm placed her
In a coffin next to her companion.
They said that he was holy just as we have said;
He gave proof of many great miracles.
Here ends the poem of the faithful Count Huon;
You who have heard it, may God grant you pardon,
And I who have written it, may I not be forgotten by Him!

lg.head: Laisse 461
lg.l: By the grace of God and the noble Saint Martin,
I have brought writing this book to its conclusion.
It was in the year of our divine Lord 1340,
On a Tuesday at the hour of matins,
In the month of July, entirely without any delay,
That this work was begun in honor of Saint Augustine.
In 1341 my goal was achcieved
On a Saturday when the sweet daylight dawned,
And it was the month of April when the gardens were blooming.
Nicolas Trombeor, son of Master Lafranchin,
Did the writing and all the storytelling as well;
May God welcome him when he comes to his end
Into His holy kingdom where the cherubim sing.
Amen. Amen. Amen.
